Interesting place for an assortment of things. From Spa to Restaurants to Cheap things, you can find them all in this tourist place. An evening walk around this place can be very interesting!
Khatmandu in a nutshell. I love Thamel. It is bit touristy, but that is the charm of the place. Narrow roads, small shops, many nationals.

Chaotic Beauty. Thamel is such a crazy city with narrowing streets and endless shops. Next time I visit I will definitely stay in Thamel. The rich culture and vibrant colors are a site to see. The shop owners are so friendly and most speak some English and are great to barter with. The things you can buy at the Thamel markets seemed to be cheaper and more unique than anywhere else. There are great places to eat all over Thamel. It's easy to get lost here.

Interesting, sad and crazy. Interesting because it is the real Kathmandu! Sad because of the damages of the earthquake. Crazy because of the noise and chaos. FUN because that is the Kathmandu I expected to find!

Good shopping place. Nice shopping area. Picked up some yak shawls and thanka paintings. Local tea, paper lanterns and incense sticks may also be interesting to some. Also a good place to pick up souvenirs and gifts for folks back home.
The City is very clean. The whole thamel city is very neat and clean. Every things can be bought but i found the street shopkeeper annoying, asking their stuffs to buy forcefully!

A Colourful Paradise. Walking through the winding roads of Thamal taking in all the noise, the colour, the smells. Rows of shops selling bags, scarves, felt crafts, handmade paper gifts, jewellery. Good for presents. Many of shop sellers will speak some English, enough to barter with and haggle a good price.

Crazy Nepal - I loved it. This is a few crazy streets, where you can buy all that is Nepal. The atmosphere is fabulous, There are bargains to be had, and haggling is the game. Remember these people have way less money than you. The clothing I bought was all made by the trader, usually upstairs in their shop. The traders were polite and engaging. There are restaurants and coffee shops in the area, and money changers everywhere. Go and see what shopping can be had in Nepal
Stayed here for five days. Heart of KMD's tourist area. Narrow streets, lots of local culture shops. The locals are frightfully polite and unlike India don't pressure you.
Energetic and a great vibe!. Full of activity. Shops, restaurants and bars everywhere you look. Roads aren't the best so be prepared. Definitely should visit!

Unusual Copper Masks. These big ( 30 cm) heavy copper masks will decorate the outside of our house. We bought them together with some lovely silver bracelets encrusted with genuine turquoise stones from BABU HANDICRAFTS in Patan Kathmandu ( e-mail :<babus@mos.com.np> or <<babuhandicrafts@gmail.com>>). The friendly, honest owner of this shop Khun Juju Bhai Shakya knows Thailand well .His son is studying at Bangkok’s Assumption College.
Wonderful touristic market. It is wonderful touristic market and social, shopping and eating points. Good for leisure and relaxing as well.

If you are staying in Kathmandu pick a hotel in Thamel. Thamel is a vibrant area with lots of shops restaurants and cafes. It's the best area for a tourist to stay in Kathmandu. Everything you want is just outside your door. Lots of bargains to be had if you want to go shopping. Just be careful about the quality.
Crowdy Thamel!. Such a crowded place ,people from all over the world looking for souvenirs,tiny hotels,restaurants .You can find anything there!

Just a walk. Thamel is most popular tourist spot. It is mostly popular for 4 star level hotels, nice resturants with dance and live music, night life. There are lots of shops where national products are available.My suggestion for the CDO and government of Nepal to avoid entry of vehicles inside Thamel for convience visit. And there should be the show room for the brand outlets.

Good atmosphere, traditional, ready for tourists . Very nice, but when you are a guy from the Western world, it seems people look at you like you are a walking wallet. Good bargains are possible everywhere, they try to offer you the best price (my friend!), I sometimes managed to get it from 7000 to 2500 Rupee.
UNIQUE ATMOSPHERE. Mountaineers, trekkers and tourists for over the world come here for eating, shopping or dancing. Very lovely restaurants and shops. This neighbourhood doesn't sleep too much.

Such an amazing array of sights and smells. The first thing we noticed was the smell of incense. It's perplexing because the greeting of spices and fragrances were with us on our ENTIRE trip - we didn't much get a whiff of sewerage/trash! The vendors are mostly lovely and they welcome a good haggle (though the prices were always very inexpensive for us). When eating/purchasing services, we recommend you tip (around 10%), unless the bill already contains a "service charge" (not "VAT", that's not a tip).Rickshaws are great, especially at night visiting the markets till 10pm, though not for the faint-hearted because many roads are cobble-stoned. Agree on the price before the ride, else just say 'no thank you' and walk away; and check if it's per person or total. Add a NRP200 tip if it was a good ride.We walked most of the time to get around and it was a better way to experience the culture first-hand. Google Maps worked amazingly, and we downloaded the Google map so we can access it offline, but almost every eatery/restaurant had wifi anyway. To be respectful of Asian dress standards, we always wore t-shirts and I wore my newly purchased yoga pants, to cover up our shoulders and legs.When choosing the local cuisine, try 'Dal Bhat' - it's Nepal's staple meal of rice, lentil soup with coriander and spices, and a dry curry of potatoes, onions, tomatoes and legumes. Nepalis eat this sometimes twice per day. "Full battery", my local friends call it. So yummy :):):)We recommend staying at Tibet Peace Inn, getting your groceries at the Shop Right Supermarket, eating at the Electric Pagoda, refilling your bottles at KEEP (behind Kilroy's) and buying goods from co-op vendors. We loved the Local Women's Handicrafts on Paknajol Marg, which is what it's called in Google Maps but the shopfront says 'Handmade Products by Women's Group'. It's a social enterprise whereby they train the local women in handicraft skills, sell their works in-store (clothes, purses/bags, jewellery), and the money goes back to them, like a wage. Inspired! Thamel is the best for shopping, better value than Bhaktapur.Don't just stay in Thamel, however! Book a trek around Kathmandu, or if you're brave, to Basecamp!

Best for the weekend.. I am not the best at travelling but with my friend it often enjoy weekend so my weekend spot would be the thamel most of the time. Thamel is the tourist attraction of nepal but you too can see local tourist in the weekend mostly. The soul pourpose of local tourist is to make the perfect weekend . Althought it's in the heart of the capital but the resturant,bar,caffee,lounge etc have the different rates and different services. In my personal experience the the palce is awesome for the party and the dance lover and most of all for the die hard live music lover. My suggestion would be that get in the thamel at 7pm and have a full stomach meal a thakali meal its really cheap and head toward the bar which doesn't charge the entry fee and have a love music and order some snacks and a beer tower if you are with friends, by doing that you would have a budget and the awesome weekend at thamel.

Good days in the Thamel. I spent a month in Thamel, very enjoyable.You can find nice things to buy, just make sure they don't rip you off, usually you should be paying about half what they are asking for...

The Hub. Many lovely cafés, all too many shops and guesthouses... also, hub for buses and departures around Kathmandu or Nepal. A good home-base if you are here for a long period. Detailed resumé below:As far as bideshi/foreigners go, Thamel is a mass intersection of folk arriving or leaving for elsewhere, and all too often, looking for some pleasure in-between. Evidently, the swathes of foreigners, and restaurants catering to them, attracts many young Nepalis and vendors looking for business. There are, as anywhere in the world, some wonderful folk, alongside some of the sketchiest, desperate characters I've ever met. I had the strange pleasure of being here for a long time for a research project, meaning I saw the different waves of tourists and their diversity, as tourist-season ended in Nepal around late-May.If you are white and under 30, you will be approached for "Hash, weed, SHMOKE" (there seems a method using the lower jaw to push out the word) or for Tiger Balm, or to buy various trinkets.Often, vendors will not know what "No" means. One must, however, keep in mind that it is the previous types of tourists that have conditioned locals to ask other foreigners for these things (i.e. amongst the pot-smoking tourists, I also witnessed a young European couple shooting up heroine in public in the early evening... the effect a sight like this has on local Nepalis is unfortunate).

Great Area to Explore. Really enjoyed exploring the streets of Thamel, where my hotel was located. The area is very touristy and sells everything you could imagine. Its quite easy and safe to navigate during the day, with lots of shops and places to eat (yummy bakeries and coffee shops!). The only real danger is the cars, motorcycles and rickshaws swerving around you. If you plan on trekking and forgot something at home, you can find almost anything for colder weather in the shops here (as well as in the true North Face stores, not knockoffs) and rent some equipment too. Lots of places to do same-day or next-day laundry for a reasonable price. Finally, lots of places to take out or exchange money.

manic and mad but brilliant. This is the must place when you visit Kathmandu. It is the tourist hub so you will get a different cultural experience. The place is chaotic and totally crazy but absolutely brilliant. The streets are are small and lined with shop after shop so do your shopping here. The traders have suffered with the drop in tourist numbers due to the quake so they are keen to make the best deal for you. There are plenty of bars and places to eat (Thamel House Restaurant is my favorite!) If you are keen for a trek or experience and haven't organised anything go see Prem from "Ace the Himalaya"....his prices are extremely competitive and their guides are fantastic (felt very safe with them and they knew their stuff....told us where to go for best deals and what to watch out for).....We stayed in Thamel which was a great decision as I would have been disappointed if I stayed anywhere else as this was the place to be.

Thamel never disappoints. Whether you want to window-shop or actually buy, Thamel is a mecca. It's worth getting away from the two main shopping streets, and wandering through the local market. I sampled a delicious samosa.

Lively, bustling but not much variation. Staying in a hostel in Thamel, I spent a couple of hours walking around in the evenings. It's a lively place with shops and some nice places to eat or grab a coffee (Rosemary, Sum Cafe). Some of the streets are very narrow, and all are busy with both pedestrians and traffic. While there are a lot of shops many do seem to sell the same things, so eventually you end up just window shopping. I'd recommend something to cover your nose and mouth as the streets can get very dusty and clogged with vehicles. Would make a good walk between the Garden of Dreams and Kathmandu Durbar Square if you don't mind walking with taxis, mopeds, rickshaws and people coming at you from every angle.

Manic markets. These markets are manic. Consisting primarily of three interconnecting roads with tourist shops either side the shopping experience was spoilt for me by the constant traffic which meant that it was difficult to casually browse in the shops as you were always trying to avoid being knocked over.

Without Visting Thamel, nepal tour is incomplete. Whether you go for business or travel one should go to Thamel. It is a nice place to shop and to acquaint with local culture. The clothing made up of pashmina or Yak wool will definitely bring some smile if you are giving it to your friends and relatives.
Unbelievable chaos. Narrow streets have never been intended for cars - but there are cars, rickshaws, motorcycles, pedestrians, and dogs all sharing the road. And we never saw a traffic accident.

Fun couple of days in Thamel. Not as crazy and chaotic as many describe. Some good restaurants and bars, good prescription glasses copied, decent massage treatment, enjoyed the shopping and fun to walk around.

Tourism area in Nepal. Thamel is a tourism area in Nepal Kathmandu.when i was in Nepal that is nice place in Nepal whatever you want you can get from there hotel restaurant spa shopping bar tropical nepali food cloth and other many thing which in famous in Nepal so if you want to plan to visit Nepal must stay at Thamel there is a travel and treks office too i travel by RG Adventure treks in Nepal it was great trek company open by experience mountain guide that company trust in safety first in mountain and qualified guide who are experience in mountain so many years so you try and visit by RG Adventure and free tourist information from RG Adventure. thanks see you and visit again by RG Adventure treks in Nepal.

Colourful Charming!!!. This place is so vibrant and full of energy.Meet with lots of street vendor selling their goods.Really good local brand shop for trekking equipments.Sovenir and handicraft and pashmina.During night every club has live music and serve pretty good food and drinks in resonable price.

Maddness. This part of town is bustling with shop owner vying for your business. Cashmere, wood crafts jewelry all available and everything is negotiable. This is the place to get your friends a small gift too. Be careful if you are easily over stimulated. The sounds, smells and sites can be a bit overwhelming.

Nice place to spend half a day.. The area has nothing much to offer except some decent eatouts and trekking gears shops. Being from India couldn't find anything new but it's a good place for westerners to pick up souvenirs.

Oh boy. You have to visit here just to see it all. Heaps of trekking stores selling everything you need and don't need. Peddlers on the street, with all the traffic it is absolutely mayhem but that is what makes Thamel.

Amazing place to just stand still. Photgrapher's paradise, just stand there and take it all in. Many different ethnic groups busy shopping, walking, bargaining. We also went there early in the morning and it can be quiet and serene.

Bazar area.. Innumerable narrow lanes lined with curio shops and restaurants best describes this place. Shoppers throng the street for window shopping. One has to be careful about vehicles that move and negotiate the bends. Rather scary.
Tour . Thamel is a one of the most popular place for the tourist. It's popular location and easily find out every once.

Visit once and Visit First!. Slightly expensive, limited stock and variety than Asan. Good eateries around makes the difference. Shop keepers know they are serving rich tourists and hence pls bargain even if it says fixed price in bold letters!
Crowded narrow but a must visit. When in Kathmandu one must visit Thamel to explore the artifacts, souvenirs, shawls but a place of total bargaining narrow lanes but lots to explore

Still the place to be . Close to Durbar Square and in the old town Thamel offers it all, hotels and restaurants of cause but also trekking agencies, trekking supply stores, supermarkets, laundry and of hundreds of shops selling everything Nepali.The streets can be narrow and are in various states of repair add that to minimal road rules and the hectic pace and sometimes it may feel you have walked into mayhem. ATM's nicely scatted ensures you don't run out of money.Kathmandu in general is very dusty and Thamel is no exception the city also has a rotation power plan so be prepared to be with out mains power at some stage everyday.If this is a problem look for hotels with there own large generators.If you are staying in Kathmandu city then Thamel is the place.

Shopping. in Thamel's a must! I've never seen anything quite like these narrow little streets, be careful though as it's a real maze & easy to get lost. We enjoyed a rickshaw trip on our last night as it's well worth the money, these lads work so hard to pull the overfed & overweight tourist.

Crowded, noisy, and enjoyable. You may not like it if you are in Nepal to see the mountains. But even then, a couple of days in this crowded place are really worthwhile. Just wander around the shops, the small alleys, the Mandala street (the only pedestrian alley in Thamel, as it is advertised) with its collection of coffee shops and restaurants and chill-out places. Walk south to the main Bazaar and Durbar Square, but along the way stop briefly at the small square (on your right-hand side walking south) housing the Shree Gha stupa and the Drubgon Jangchup Choeling Buddhist Monastery; enjoy there the quiet atmosphere (only slightly altered by the students evidently taking a break from school), so different from the bustling activities on the adjacent main street. Before entering Durbar Square just walk around the main Bazaar and the delightful small shops. Touts advertising a bit of everything are active in Thamel as in any other place of this kind, but I found them quite less annoying than in similar places of Delhi or Agra, for instance.

"Heart of Kathmandu". Great place to discover the arts, culture, people lifestyle in Nepal . The Thamel is always crowded because it is the only first place which accommodate all the travellers from different country in Nepal. The pub, restaurant, hotels, Atm, Banks ,MOney changer, thousand of treks and tour company.. Owl it's really amazing place to visit in Kathmandu. The luxurious or budget traveller it is suitable for everyone. "Recommended"
Great to walk around.. Anything and everything on sale here and the hassle factor is fairly low, especially if you've previously been to Egypt.

Crowded and vibrant. Nepalese walk on the left. Narrow streets with stores competing to sell the same goods. The bicycle rickshaws are a great way to become familiarized with area and saves getting lost.The pedestrian only street/mall is popular with western tourists for its coffee shops and quieter surroundings

A definite treasure throve for trekking fans. Busy, dusty and loads and loads of shops! Good bargains for those looking to get trekking gears. Just look out for traffic along the roads and bargain, bargain, bargain!
Top tourist market. I love Thamel because 90% tourist shops, bar, cafe and hotels are in Thamel. It is the hub for every type of travellers and it is quite safe place before and after earthquake.

Full of life!. I could walk through Thamel everyday and discover new places. Be on the lookout for the man who makes drums inside a tiny hole in the wall on a dirt floor, and, the same for the man who makes jewelry. Pashmina scarves are easily had at 400 Rupees. There is a school where the students learn the art of Thanka.. see if you can find it if you are interested in a Thanka because the prices are good and they will negotiate (know what you are doing before you go in). Also, there is a tiny spice shop right by the square that has wonderful spices and teas at great prices. It is a place with alleys and hidden spots, so be on the lookout and watch out for the traffic.

HELLO KITTY Restaurant in Thamel road, Bagmati region. This fair price good foods restaurant is indeed a hidden gem in Thamel road. it is situated in a small quite lane on the left side opposite Kathmandu city hotel. The deep fried momos, Chinese fried rice, nepali set dinner, Indian curry chicken, vegetable noodles are really yummy and very generous helpings. very attentive staffs clean kitchen orderly cosy sitting areas and a very friendly manager adds to the cosy dining atmosphere. What's more to expect when there is no extra service charge and taxes.
Staying in Thamel. Our hotel (Kathmandu Guest House) is in the centre of Thamel. A perfect location for exploring and experiencing the hustle and bustle of Thamel.
Great place to hang out. Cool shops, nice people, cozy cafés and an unforgetable ambiance in this wonderful part of town. Don't hesitate, getting lost in this neighborhood is a great experience !!!

Hot and happening. What a place. One of the liveliest place to chill out in the evening. Nice restaurants, bars and music coming out of every corner. However this ambience is only in one street near la bella cafe. There is a new hypermarket where you can find almost everything you get in Developed countries. You neednto be there between 7PM and 10 PM to feel the rythm. Loved it..

Kumar. Excellent place. Centrally located. All type of accommodation and food available. Nice arrangement of music and dance. Bustling market with a lot to bargain. A ladies paradise as far as casual dress merchandise is concerned.

Thamel. Town centre of Kathmandu, easy to get to full of shops for all requirements. Even mountaineering equipment is available. Many good restaurants too. You should take out a local simcard NCell networks seems to work the best.

Shopping, Yoga & meals to your hearts content. Had a blast exploring all the streets & alleys shopping & meeting the most fantastic yogi and then gathering at Places to eat and getting the most beautiful henna on our hands, not to mention an entire wardrobe that I LOVE for cheap!!
Crowded market. Thamel is considered to be one of the most crowded and posh areas of the capital city. There are a lot of shops on the streets of thamel along with the luxury hotels.

City stay. Stayed in Thamel during my visit to Kathmandu. Perfect location to base myself for my first solo trip to Kathmandu. Enjoy the small winding streets with many shops, restaurants serving local and western foods and cafes. Easy to walk to Durbar square and Swayambhunath. Traffic is busy in the small lanes, pedestrians be prepared to squeeze past taxis and bikes and listen for the horns of oncoming vehicles but Thamel is a lively area with all the hustle and bustle you'd expect from an Asian City so just as to be expected.

Its like a mini version of Bangkok. Everything is there. I can call it mini Bangkok. Everything you need as a tourist is available there. Do not forget to try Chicken n Chips restaurant in Thamel. It all about bargaining.

tourist enclave. every year Thamel gets more noisy, gaudy, crowded. if you like hundreds of shops and tens of restaurants squeezed into a small area, and if you want to experience commerce rather than Nepal, the place is fine (as long as you have money). It's safe, definitely colourful and convenient for buying clothes, books, souvenirs, crafts and much more. also good to explore and book trips of any kind. The choice of restaurants is amazing and value for money reasonable. But all of that is shared with thousands of tourists.

Hmm- thamel costly. Happening place in KTM- everything under one roof+ from hotels to street vendors- all costly compared to Indian standards- nothing to busy- everything available here- I don't see anyone doing big business- thousands of shop but empty customers- if we ask for price, definitely dent ur packet - best is lot of resto bars- filled up thousands of foreigners- I never saw anywhere in india- stay here by booking any of the hotel here at thamel- enjoy evening walk but don't buy

Touristy yes but fun place to be centered. Yes this is def the tourist capital. But it's a great neighborhood to be lodged in at night to go explore the true cultural areas during the day and come back for a glass of wine & nice meal in the evenings Though I dislike souvenir shopping I also found a few gifts for friends home & everything is at your fingertips here. They also don't harass in Nepal like they do other countries so buying is more laid back I'd recommend getting a hotel here & then exploring authentic Kathmandu as well

The place to be pre-trekking. Packed with hotels, hostels, cafés and restaurants, there is no shortage of options. An endless number of trekking shops, bookshops, money exchange kiosks, you can get everything you need to prepare yourself for an upcoming trek.
Lots of stores very touristy. Knock offs abound here. Lots of people and traffic. Some decent places for food. Doesn't offer a local Nepali experience. Lots of westerners.

Dangerous for Pedestrians. Thamel is the main Kathmandu visitor area with a ton of shops and restaurants. The roads are very narrow and are shared by pedestrians, cars, and motorbikes. It's dangerous for pedestrians and found it both annoying and stressful to walk and dodge cars and motorbikes whizzing by.

Getting Lost in everything. From the time we got back from the mountains going water rafting and reppeling which I have to say was awesome in itself Thamel gave us a chance to get lost within a dozen things from pottery shopping to winter head coverings along with finding beautiful material for a holiday tablecloth back home, Great way to just enjoy our time in Katmandu. It's a must!!!

Shopping & restaurants. Great area for purchasing gifts.Pashminas are great, make sure you haggle over price.Creative jewelry & tons of knock off trekking gear (really who knows the difference)Also some lovely art galleries to buy a special moment I of your visit.

Good Chaos. Thamel is chaotic for the first-time visitor, but great for bargain shopping (especially trekking gear), restaurants and cafes. Once you adjust to the traffic, noise and dust you can really enjoy the experience.

most colourfull part of life in Kathmandu. Since reaching first Thamel in Kathmandu, the most striking thought was - this city has no pavement side! Motorbikes, fruit selling vehicles, bicycles and passers-by melt together along the narrow streets dressed up in the most colorful design of small shops invading the street with their merchandise. Enjoy the ride through Thamel at any pace, lose yourself peacefully through all narrow streets, see the temples, the open markets, the fresh fruit and vegetables as well as the antiques, shop for some mountaineering equipment if you need it or just spend good minutes in a bookshop to go through all sorts of titles, languages and topics. Tips: do not hurry to buy, the merchandise you find in the shops situated in "the center" of Thamel, even when offered with a good discount, may be found cheaper if you advance on to the corners. Get accustomed with the strident horns of the different vehicles and become immune - they will manage to pass by you even if you don't jump immediately aside.

Good for shoppers. When i'm doing city tour in Kathmandu, Thamel is the first place that i'm going to explore, because it's not so far from the airport. There are many outdoor shop here (if you're going to trekking) and also gift shop.

only place to stay for shopping and night life. Thamel is where all the nightlife and action is in this city. If you want everything in walking distance, food, bars, and night life...this is the place

get everything here!. my hotel were situated at thamel road, and we basically get everthing here easily such as restaurant with good food,money changer,bank, clothings, gems, sourviniers, and even temples and all could easily be reach by foot, This place is clean, and the people are helpful and friendly too. from breanded stores to markets, standard restorans and hotel to stalls.. all are found here.a good choice for tourist to stay around this place.

The hub for tourists. All tourists that visit Nepal will either stay in or around Thamel if they fly in to Kathmandu. It is a hub for tourists and you will be able to get whatever you need to your next stop from here. Highly recommended to stay in this area as they are used to tourists and our needs :-) If want to do shopping make sure to walk around and compare prices...

Happening place !. It is the most happening place in Kathmandu. Mainly a market area with lots of shopping and restaurants and bars and branded stores. You can see many foreigners in this area. but the shopping is quite costly and you have to negotiate for every thing.
Ok. Not to bad it's ok little croudly but nlce too many different activities like restaurants toga message shaping

Busy tourist destination . Thamel is a bust tourist location with non stop noise... It has everything you'd need to go hiking and it's really not reflective of the real Nepal. Saying it- it's a must visit location with nice cafes and plenty of western faces...
Entertainment and food. It's a great area to visit and stay in, as it offer some of the best restaurants and pubs and hotels. Stay away from some shady places, such as dance bars.

Touristic Place. Thamel is main touristic hob. Many hotels, restaurant, club, pub, night life are in Thamel. Having lot's of travel company, trekking company are in Thamel so people can have lot's of chance to compare the offer for nepal tours.

Tourist Central - And That's a Good Thing. Thamel is the main tourist center of Kathmandu. There's great food options, souvenir shopping, and hotels. The narrow, brick streets may be filled with modern faces, but it very much retains its old-world charm and mystique.

great if youre a fake hippy or prepping a trek. Thamel is an interesting neighborhood where you can find high priced handicrafts (ok, not that high), and people constantly asking you if you want "something more." even the "dirtiest hippy" who has dreads and doesn't wear shoes and is "connecting to the universe....via facebook" is asked if they want hash.I can't find the culture in thamel, unless you want dance clubs masquerading as no, no, were not really brothels, or good chinese food. wear your hippy hemp pands and be totally connected, bro....and look like a chump to your hearts content!in Ashok Galli, there are two really good szechuan restaurants hidden away. one indoor, one outdoor.

Busy and dusty place. Stayed 5 nights before and after EBC trekYou only need couple of days hereToo busy and dusty...but lovely people trying to make a living. People in Nepal need lots of help from tourist to survive.  We liked endless interesting eateries available in Thamel
Tourist palace0. When yuo welll be nepal kathmandu must visit thamel thamel is one of main tourist destination place to meny deferend saping item menu kind of restaurent also to meny more thing

Busy, full of hustle and bustle. This place is fun, but also a little nuts! The fact that none of the streets around here are pedestrian makes it all a little crazy with taxis and motorbikes zipping down narrow alleys, often at some speed. It doesn't make for the most relaxing place, but it does seem full of local flavour. I would not feel relaxed wandering around here with my kids.

Shopping in Thamel. Thamel is the heart of shopping and dining. It's just 1/2 hrs car ride both to the domestic and International airport with slight traffic jam. You may find a good mixed of good local, middle eastern, Chinese, Korean and western food Many shops sell camping gears etc so if you need anything for trekking, you can get everything here for a fraction of the price. Sounding of the horn is common In Nepal so don't get offended if someone horns at you. Have this is useful for you. AT
Thamel. Very vibrant market place with hotels, restaurants and plenty of shopping opportunities. This is where we bought socks, gloves, etc. to face the chilled weather.
Try Friday Night. I walked through Thamel area on Friday night. There were many local people and tourists from all over the world. They like drinking and dancing.
River expedition. Good teamwork and river knowledge with devoted guides to look into our needs and safety. Being highly skillful on the river helps:)
Thamel. A very vibrant place and where most tourist stay when visiting Kathmandu. Busy, colourful, friendly and a abundance of restaurants very popular with many a must visit.
i love thamel. a cheap place to fine trekking equipment, hotel, food.if you visit nepal, dont miss this place. its amazing and fun
Buzzing, vibrant, noisy. A great place to come and explore. Plenty tourist shops of varying quality. Cafes, bars, restaurants and shrines. Too many motor bikes!

Need gear. Head to the Thamel. Lots of good deals on fake stuff that looks real and performs almost as well.
Some good bars with live music at night. The locals are pretty cool.
A busy place never miss it. Thamel i like to say busy on ownself, the tourist who come to nepal once visited second time never missed and this is place we can found almost all handicap material.

Thamel is definite worth a visit once.. Thamel is the tourist area for retail goods, restaurants and tour agencies. Its definitely worth going once, and if your going to go treking, there are plenty of treking operators to choose from (actually too many - a bit like choosing a needle in a Haystack). Great place to check out scarves and anything manufactured from cashmere wool. there are also plenty of more westernised restaurants there as well. I probably would not seek accommodation there though, as its just too touristy.

Touristy But Fun. This is the tourist area and you will get you share of people trying to sell you cheap items, drugs, and other things. However, it has built up like this because of the number of tourist. The ease of booking trips from this location can not be topped. The streets are lined with great food, good atmosphere, trekking agencies, and much more!

Too good. I used to work for Vaishali Thamel long back that time we used to explore thamel we all friends used to stay Thamel itself. Nice time we had spent there at around 10pm there was 50% discount in hot bread we all used to go for dinner there.
Sick City. Almost known as a city of foreigner And area of tourist but its also good for Nepali teenager who wants to chill out with friends in some club live music bar **** queen of night thamel ***

All the things you need is here!. Thamel is the famous touristic area. In here, you can shop anything you want, starting from food to souvenirs. Thamel is also the heaven for backpackers' style accommodation. Cheap price for everything sold here is the comparative advantage compared to other places in Kathmandu.
Thamel. Just visiting through the Thamel, looking around and absorbing the special and unique experience of the Thamel, after returning from a long trek at the Himalayans.
Safe tourist area. It was nice to stay in Thamel. There were lots of restaurants, shops and hotels. It's a safe tourist areas
Center of Tourist attraction. Thamel is central attraction of Tourism. Hotels., Restaurants, Bar. clubs and other transactions are the major. factor to make trip ready.

Did not expected to be that happening. I was surprised to have restaurants and places catering quality in a earthquake struck place. May be owing to the inflow of foreign tourist they have been able to keep going.

Very active . Thamel is a very touristy and the locals know that as well. A lot or souvenir shops and restaurants/bars. Good place to go for budget backpackers but also luxury travelers. If you stay in Thamel it might be a bit difficult to find a quiet hotel/hostel
Big. If you want to have a great time go thamel. Here you will find the best restaurants , clubs and bars. And you will make friends.

Main tourist area. Almost as many tourists as locals here, but the local flavour is still very much present. You'll probably be staying here as most of the hotels are located in the area. LOTS of restaurants, great food, shopping... everything you could possibly want or need is in Thamel.
Crazy street life. In Thamel, the cows, motor bikes, cars, pedestrians, carriers of all sorts all share the same narrow roads. Very unique experience.
Cheap tourist attraction!. Little boutiques with cheap tourist junk, not a must in kathmandu! much better and more authentic other neighborhoods. Dont waste time to go to Thamel.
Thamel the crowed area... its a best place for crowd lovers...Everyone can enjoy here with crowd...there are lots of club, pubs, restaurant, cafe and so on...lovely area for live music restaurants...
Busy Tourist Area. Thamel main tourist area in Kathmandu. Huge crowd of the tourist. You can go there for shopping, buying foods and explore nightlife as well!!

Great for shopping!. Spent a morning with friends shopping followed by lunch in the 'Garden of Dreams' which was fab. There are plenty of shops selling art, jewellery, pashmina's and lots of brass & copper ornaments. I would definitely go again.

Bustle and hustle. The place to be for tourists, it has a feel like many other places yet in some ways is unique. Busy, narrow streets are home to a myriad of stores, bars, hotels, restaurants etc. Cars and bikes whip past, backpackers and locals fill the street and there is a definite sense of adventure in the air. A labyrinth to explore, just remember to haggle if you plan to buy.

Quaint, but overcrowded and noisy. Thamel is THE location to stay if you have never been to Kathmandu (rich tourists usually stay elsewhere, such as nearby Durbar Marg, but miss a lot). It replaced Freak Street many years ago as the backpackers' Kathmandu destination. Narrow busy streets crammed with backpackers, old buildings, guesthouses, trekking agencies, minimarts, restaurants for every taste, trekking gear shops, 'pashmina' clothing and jewelry shops, Tibetan trinkets and Nepali kukuris, etc. Over the past 25 years, I have continued to come back. However, traffic has increased three-fold in Kathmandu since 2000, and air pollution has become intolerable, so I usually leave after a couple of days for a trek or to Pokhara. Thamel has only one main vehicle entrance from Kantipath Rd, which is inconvenient and adds to the urban density; however, making Thamel more vehicle-accessible would probably destroy a lot of its old-world character and not solve the other problems.From Thamel, all of the main Kathmandu Valley tourist attactions are accessible - the three Durbar Squares (Kathmandu, Bhaktapur and Patan), Pashupathinath, Boudhanath, Swayambhunath, Nagarkhot, and others.
Great shopping. The area had great shopping, but was stressful with the traffic, and dodgy after dark. Our guide recommended going to dinner in groups
Food and shop. Endless rows of shops for tourists and lots of nice restaurants and boutique hotels. Convenient but can be crowded.

Alright . Yeah you can get a feel for the culture, but it's very tourist focused which I don't like. You can definitely buy cheap stuff and knockoffs there, and you gotta go- at least for a bit- if you are in Nepal, but I got the entire picture in half an hour. Monkey temple (a temple with monkeys hangin around) and the palace tour are good ideas to check out too.

Heaven for hikers. We stayed near Thamel street back when I was in Nepal and this place is full of tourist from around the world AND outdoor shops. A heaven for those who are looking for knocked off hiking gears.

Centre of the tourist activities in Kathmandu . The one taxi driver remarked that this is the section for the VIP's in Kathmandu and they surely treat tourists like VIP's. Just be aware of the fact that if you want to buy anything, you will have to sharpen your haggling skills and shop around, don't buy at the first shop you walk into. Great atmosphere and a lot to see, do, experience.

Pre and Post Trek. There are tons of placesto buy gear for hiking if you forgot something or badly need an item. The prices seemed to be comprable to what you would pay at retail price but I personally did not buy any gear so you'll have to check other reviews on the prices of items. I also was ablr to buy plenty of trail food such as gorp and trail mix for good prices.The local restaurants have awesome chicken curry :)
Family Visit. Nice n Excellent Family visit especially Thamel n in Thamel , The Hotel D VadeThe Way They treat was excellent , All required things was around the hotel.

A good stroll.... A typical busy market... narrow lanes...crowded...old buildings...you have bargain on prices... every thing available right from Pashmina... Yak Wool winter wears... Mountain Trekking Gears...

Tourist area (shopping). Narrow streets and lots of places to buy gifts. A lot of them sell the same sort of thing. Bargaining is a must. You WILL get lots of people saying there are artists/students/porters and they will offer to show you around, be aware they will try to take you to the 'school' to show you some art, this is to try get you to buy from there instead of shops (the bonus with this is more chance of original art than mass produced prints). You will also get a lot of people trying to sell you 'smoke' / 'hash'. Have a good walk round as its a big area and lots of narrow streets. If you are looking for incense there look for the small shop just off one of the 'main' streets, that has a sign higher up saying Tibetan Incense, they will have a few bits outside but up a couple steps is main shop (down sells colourful boxes). It has biggest selection of incense in Thamel, and they hand make a good portion of it.

lived up to the hype. I was initially a bit reticent about staying here but in the end everything turned out fine. I stayed for 8 days in Thamel and loved every minute. There are tons of things to see and it is the perfect base for day trips to Bhaktapur, Patan, etc. It is a shopping mecca and you can find anthing you want. I travelled by richshaw or taxi or walked; if you want to go on a day trip, you can ask the hotel staff what a reasonable price is to pay or even ask them to flag down a cab for you. For sure can get all the North Face kit you've ever wanted lol.
good seeping . we been in thamel far sapping there is to meny deferent tourist shap to meny tourist nice culture restaurants nice peoples so must visit one time

Bit of Fun. Thamel is a confusing maze of small, narrow streets with loads of little shops selling the same stuff. There's plenty of good little restaurants to scope out and plenty of bargains to be had if you haggle enough at the shops. The streets are a bit dangerous with the poor condition of the road, the amount of people and the amount of traffic in the area. Overall, a fun experience but not a lot to do apart from eat and drink there as every second shop sells the same cheap rubbish.
Historical international backpacker's town. This town is a huge mixture of international travelers, furthermore consolidation of Nepalese traditional culture and contemporary going.

Noisy with lots of shopping opportunities. Thamel is known as the tourist quarter with lots of shops with pashmina's, scarves, cashmere jumpers/cardigans, jewellery, healing bowls, masks and teas plus lots of trekking and climbing gear and places to book your adventures. Beware the fakes. The good news is the vendors are not pushy and you can just look.There are also a number of fast food restaurants and other restaurants catering for a wide range of tastes and relatively cheap and cheerful. There are also a number of backpacker hostels and small hotels in the area, but beware if visiting here there are no pavements, no road names and the traffic takes no prisoners - there are motorbikes, rickshaws and cars all sharing the space in the narrow lanes.it would actually help the area if it became a pedestrian zone. Also, a happening place for Westerners in the evening.

Nice tourist place. Thamel is the place to visit when u r in kathmandu. its quite touristy yes but its worth a visit. there are lots to see in the area, and a great place to hang out w other travellers, and the durbar square is also within walking distance. thamel offers a variety of choices of local food, yummy indeed, and traditional clothes and such tourist stuffs can be found easily.

Iconic Tourist Trap, a Must Tromp While in KTM. Evolving slowly over the years, Thamel is iconic; both stuck in time and being slowly renovated - reminiscent of Khaosan Road in Bangkok, but without the ping-pong shows and fried-bug vendors found there. Now supposedly open 24 hours, this maze-like neighborhood features great food and souvenirs galore. See the restaurant reviews for the best eats, but my favorite is Fire & Ice, for good pizza and lasagna. I also suggest that you park outside (several public lots near Garden of Dreams) and walk in, as the gullies are narrow and full of potholes and few establishments offer any sort of parking, motorbike or otherwise. While a centre for trekking supplies, I recommend you go to the new Sherpa outlet for that, as the quality of goods there is triple A and no knock-offs sold. For those still owning a CD or DVD player, this is the place to stock up on cheap media; but the quality is the same you would find on any internet torrent site. Thamel is a must see, but may be too chaotic for some travellers.

Place to be in Kathmandu. Thamel is the place you find most night time activities in Kathmandu. It's full of restaurants, bars, clubs and lots and lots of shops. Cool place to spend some time and money. Not to be missed.

A must for all visitors to Nepal. The most vibrant part of Kathmandu by far is Thamel. There are shops of all descriptions that cater to the tourist market. Note well that much of the trekking gear on offer is fake, but at a bargain price will most likely outlast many of the treks tourists engage in. There are many coffee shops and restaurants to choose from but be careful of what you choose as a high percentage of tourists end up with tummy bug issues.

Great Touristy District In Kathmandu. District has tons of great food and pubs around as well as hotels.
It's a popular place for tourists coming and going and if trekking there are tons of shops to pick up necessities of hitting the mountains.
As a Westerner it was easy place to hole up

Thamel Night life in Kathmandu. Want to spend best night life come to Thamel
Grt crowd local & foreigner
Come to Friday night weekend masti
Bargain shopping. Very dusty, so wear a buff or mask. Sellers not pushy and hawkers are tame compared to other places.
Chillout . Nice place , best location for tourist . Chillout . Nice staff and good service. i like this hotel. Again soon ☺☺☺

Liked the market . Very nice market but you should always bargain, nice handmade crafts , it's all about the crafts there is people who is selling different hand made like instrument ( music) it's the only good market in Kathmandu where u can find everything

Like a video game -Amazing. This part of town is like walking around a Tomb raider game. It's an amazing experience to wonder the streets and soak up the atmosphere and people watch. The people are friendly and there are some cool bars and restaurants. It's very cold so wrap up warm.

Fun frenetic little streets. Nice bustling walking neighborhood. Watch for traffic. Lots of good little restaurants and shops. Lots of travel outfitter offices here. Find a shop where the selling is low key - it is a breath of fresh air.

Shoppers' heaven. Amazing part of Kathmandu where you encounter prices ranging from extremely low to funnily high but also authentic goods of good quality. You can bargain but in the end it is your decision if you want to do so. People are obviously rather poor due to the 2015 earthquake so sometimes even if you know the thing is not worth that money, you may decide just to pay at that price. People are incredibly kind and smiling although thick dust still wafts the streets and ruins are visible at every corner. Despite all that this place fills you with joy and peace.
Great area for shopping and food. This area of Kathmandu is very touristy but all the people are friendly and there are great shops and restaurants.

A colourful local market with nightlife in kathmandu. Thamel is a home to pashmina shawls/dresses/jackets and some good trendy stuff. I bought some jewellery of stones along with a Pashmina full sleeves jacket. The jacket has got beautiful hand-embroidery done all over it. I also visited a shop where they do embroidery with sewing machine on your t-shirt of whatever design you give to them. Thamel also has some good night clubs and bar/lounge to which i couldnt go, but they are nice. Interestingly its home to some good dance bars too ( a place where girls dance for money, i guess). There are some good restaurants and cafes, overall worth visiting.

A happening place. For any tourist, this is the area to stay in Kathmandu. It is full of activities and excitement. There are plenty of hotels to choose from and so many eateries are here that it would be difficult to take a pick.

Thamel bee hive. If u like market shopping it's your thing If u don't like crowds, better off going at night time, seemed less packed with locals and was a westerners hide out.Plenty of cool places to eat tucked away around a corner or in an alley. Hipsterish bars popping up like phat Kat and hole in the wall. Ben and jerrys was good to go to for a game of stick and mixing with the locals, cheap drinks and free pool.

quite crowded but okay to visit as a tourist. it is one of those places where they sell you touristy souvenirs. can find valuable stuff sometimes in shops. lots of nightlife, club fire is good. nice pubs.

Thamel is Fanthamelastic. I must admit , that my expectation from this place were slightly elitist , before I hit this suburb of Kathmandu . It is slightly more grainy that what I expected it to be , but not to any shred of disappointment . This place has a life and I am glad to experience that during the Holi celebrations.We came from Pokhara to Kathmandu on the morning of Holi ( Hindu festival of colors ) , the entire city ( on the way from Airport to Thamel) had this quaintness and self imposed civility, on the occasion of one of the most celebrated and crazy Hindu festival .All that what I saw in city was about to change in the interiors of Thamel , and the perception got changed to such an extent that it has been by far , the most grisly and celebrated Holi festival I have seen in my 32 years .The indulgence of foreign tourists in this festival of locals , perhaps brings out the comfort and the resonance found by tourist in this place .Other thing , which came to my observation was that this place (Thamel) is self regulated , similar to the way almost all the good tourist spot in the world are .Thumbs up to Thamel . If in Kathmandu , then stay here

Busy Thamel. Stayed in Thamel for 6 days. Busy, friendly, with plenty to see . A haven for those wanting to shop for trekking gear at very reasonable prices. Great places to eat, plenty to choose from.
Souvenirs!!. Fun. A must see. Buyer beware. Great for last minute shopping on your way out but many of the goods can be found elsewhere for cheaper.

Westerners town. Thames has what most Westerners want: all kinds of soda, pizza, coffee shops, music bar, baguette, Western food etc. The only thing I will advise NOT to do is message. The so call "oil message " or "trekker message" is having someone applying some smelly grease all over your body, including your hair. I took four showers to get rid off all that grease off my skin. The room usually smell, I don't know when was the last time they changed the sheet/towels. The roads in Thames are full of potholes, very narrow, lots of car, bike, rickshaw, and they do not stop for people! So watch out.There are also lots of shops, make sure you compare the prices. Lots of bargains.

Can get crazy, but great fun exploring . Thamel is the tourist hub. Plenty of hussle and bustle with so many shops selling fake/real hiking and trekking gear. There are heaps of great places to eat, with some in plain sightand others that you have to try a bit harder to find as they are down alleys you wouldn't necessarily think anything would be down and alot are through a door and upstairs..I spent 4 days in thamel before my EBC trek and I never ate at the same place twice. Some people hate how crazy the streets are but I loved it. Part of travelling and experiencing other cultures
nice and crowed. Its a good place to visit and you can find most of the things you want. Lots of discos and bars around and little bit crowded at night.

Good shopping for cheap Nepalese things. Its a good place to haggle and get some gifts and souvenirs! Any amount the shop keepers tell you will be atleast twice the amount! They are looking to get every penny they can out of every customer!
An interesting neighborhood. Thamel is full of all the usual shops. It is quite easy for walking around. The paving or dirt roads are very uneven, so be watchful.

Great relaxed bohemian traveler vibe neighborhood to stay before trekking or just to relax, eat and shop. Love the quiet and bohemian corners of Thamel. It has a really great travelers scene vibe and the little side streets have a wealth of food, shops and cafes that are inexpensive. A great stop before you head to the Himalyayas..

Nice memorable shopping experience. Thamel is the heart of Kathmandu... busy streets... lot of restaurants... great shopping... food...drinks... night life... nice people and helpful people... fun and enjoyment...
City stay. Busy place for a short temporary stay before our main trip starts:). But a good shopping hub for you to gather things you had not gotten ready before your trek.

Tourist Shopping Heaven . In Thamel you'll be able to buy anything your heart desires : cashmere, yak wool, wood carvings, metal statues, instruments, singing bowls, prayer flags, lanterns, artworks... Literally every Nepali thing is sold here. Don't forget to haggle, or else you'll be paying double or triple what the item is worth. My rule of thumb is to start at half or 2/3 the initial price when bargaining. Don't be afraid to walk away, there are hundreds of stores that sell the same things... The vendors know this and will do anything to keep you from walking out of their shop if they sense you are serious about buying. Be prepared for lots of honking on the streets... Pedestrians, rickshaws, motorbikes, and cows all share the small winding roads in this part of the city to be vigilant about what's around you. When crossing the street, maintain a consistent pace and don't try to slow down if you see a vehicle... This will only get you hit. Motorists are used to weaving their way around pedestrians. Pollution is heavy in the air here and I recommend coming with or buying a mask upon your arrival. The only country with worse air quality in the world is Bangladesh... The pollution can make you very sick so be careful. You'll often get young men coming up to you asking if you want weed/cannabis. Although it may be cheap to buy, nothing is worth sitting inside a Nepali jail for, and the police will crack down on tourists they find smoking. This is a very active and overwhelming part of town and I found myself tiring of it after a few days. One day at the beginning of your trip and one at the end should suffice for this area.

Too busy and noisy. I stayed in Kathmadu for seven days last week, in the town center. is Tamel a sopping, market and restaurant area.The small streets are full to the brim of large motorbikes, taxis and the locals.Believe me it is hard to relax here, the noise is wild .Ok there are some good restaurants here but it is not an area to spend much time in, if you need to relax !I reccomend you stay a few nights a get out to the mountains, thats the real Nepal.

The wild memories. I love to visit this place at evenings and night. It is so mesmerizing. You can see a lot to types of people hanging around the street. Thamel is a great place for music, food and drinks. I've made lots of memories here, it is one of my favorite one.

Overrated. Thamel appears to be a popular tourist site for the very simple reason that it caters to the tourist - whatever your nationality. In a word, "overrated". The shops are nice, relative to simple, local shops, but they more expensive. The streets are more like alleys, too narrow for the cars, bicycle-tuk-tuks, scooters, motorcycles, and people. There are no sidewalks, so you have to dodge the vehicles that seems not to care. The whole place is really quite dirty. I preferred to spend time around the stupas, drinking local (excellent) hot ginger tea, smelling the incense, and watching the worshipers.

Loved it. You arrive in Thamel and say, what a chaos. After you start to walk on the streets and realize how amazing is the place. Crowded streets with a lot of shopping opportunities and the thing I liked the most was you enter in passages and find out oasises in shape of restaurants with gardens etc. Go there and enjoy.

Only for who love night clubs and bars. Good palace for night life and shopping like trekking equipment shops is in also available large amounts of clubs, bars, spa body massage, and live singing restaurant is in there.most of the country's food restaurant available in this area this is the tourist hub off Kathmandu

Good. I visited Thamel in This April few days. I like this place you can find many different type of restaurant shop and many more this is best market if you visited kathmandu once you must visited here.

Intimidating at first but grows on you quick. This is a bit of a culture shock at first but grows on you quick! You have to be careful as there are no pedestrian right of way laws here and no traffic rules as well. Brush up on your bartering skills and hit the markets! Lots of places to see, things to do and places to eat! So glad I came. Would come back again if I get the chance.
We stayed right in the heart of Thamel. We stayed in three different areas of Thamel. All special in different ways. We would recommend Epic Adventures to guide your stay in Nepal.

Could be cleaner.... After two days, when you have seen everything, Thamel becomes boring. One day is enough to visit it, shop if you want, and that is it. Othervise too noisy, too crowded, too dirty, too much traffic, too many tourist, too many sugestions involving drugs... There is absolutely no reason to favour this part of the city - no tourist products specific to it, no more favourable prices, just a long string of look- alike shops and reasturants.
Good for Shopping. Good place to shop...Check prices in two or three shops before buying...In most shops one needs to bargain

Organised chaos. Can't help feeling a bit lost in this urban jungle of narrow streets shared by everything on 2 or 4 feet/wheels. One would expect some part to be traffic free zone, but this is not to happen soon i guess...
Shopping. Great place for shopping. You can easily buy all souvenirs in one place. Remember to bargain! Lots of restaurants as well.
Good area to stay. this district is very vibrant with human activities. Many good cafe, restaurant, shops and hotels are located here.

Crazy place. Thamel is a hub of activity. There are lots of bars and restaurants. There are also lots of shops where you can buy or rent walking/camping gear and buy any gifts for back home. The streets can be busy with a mix of people, cars and scooters so you need eyes in the back of your head but worth a wonder round.

Must experience this place. It is the active part of the city. Night life ends early except for Nepali New Years which I happened to have stumbled on. There were lots of kids shouting and having fun, but at no time did I ever feel threatened.During the day the show are full of mostly similar items and some real characters that operate them. Tourism is way down so I went a little light on my negotiations this year.

Must experience this place. It is the active part of the city. Night life ends early except for Nepali New Years which I happened to have stumbled on. There were lots of kids shouting and having fun, but at no time did I ever feel threatened.During the day the show are full of mostly similar items and some real characters that operate them. Tourism is way down so I went a little light on my negotiations this year.

A lot of restaurants and shops. You have to spend at least a couple of hours here if going to Kathmandu. A lot of shops here and restaurants to choose from. But in my opionion traffic should be forbidden in here.
Busy place. Most of the tourist stay in thamel, it's hub but so busy and commercial. Lots of atm,shop, restaurant are there. It's completely tourism area.
Good for shopping. Tourist hub with plenty of budget hotels and restaurants. Absolutely dull and initeresting place, full of traffic and hawkers. Good for shopping tough

Buy all your knock off mountain gear here. Thamel is a very busy area where you can get all your knock off mountain gear for half nothing. You will find yourself arguing over cents. There are so many shops to choose from. You can also pick up all your gifts for home here. The exhaust fumes in Thamel make staying too long difficult. There are plenty of coffee shops to stop and take a break. My favourite would be Himalayan Java or Roadhouse Cafe

Fabulous streets, shopping and atmosphere. Thamel is great to walk around and look at the local shops, pashmina and singing bowls and crafts of Nepal. We went late afternoon and then had an early dinner. We were two women travelling and felt safer than Durbar Square during the day.

Great place to shop for gifts. Lots of colourful shops with good prices. Some cool restaurants too. A fun place. You will find a lot of counterfeit gear here too at very cheap prices. You just need to watch the sizing. Better try it on to check how it fits and looks first.

Chaos but can be fun . Important you be in the right mind set before tackling a day in Thamel. It's a rabbit Warren of shops, many selling the same thing. There is no quick sale and be prepared to spend time haggling and talking and even drinking tea before concluding a Sale. However it's fun and there are Great bargains to be found.

Still for tourists although those are mostly absent. Thamel is a warren of small streets lined with tourist shops, supermarkets and restaurants ... Once you have found an honest shopkeeper stick to him! I go there every time I am in Kathmandu just for the atmosphere!

good night life, day life is chaos !!!. Thamel being most popular tourist destination in Kathmandu, we expected much more, but to say we were surprise to see day life very disturbing especially the hookers, traffic jam and crowd.I do not recommend to visit here at day.But night life is very nice, the restaurants, bar, cafes and loud music are really nice. We had dinner at evening in a restaurant then went to the rock bar.The night life is very very recommendable to everyone.looking forward to visit here again.

Mad. Thames is one of those places you will love or hate. 2 long streets with hundreds of shops - mainly trekking gear- spoilt by a constant stream if cars and scooters doing their best to knock you over. Very dusty and fumes from the vehicles means you can't stay long without eyes streaming . Would be much better if pedestrianised.

Hustle and Bustle. Typical City Bazaar. Old, local streets filled with beautiful stores. Go here if you want to get locally made beautiful jewelries, clothes, north face knockoffs and beautiful, authentic Nepali craft goods !!Just be a little more careful during nights, you might be approached by dudes trying to sell you drugs. Say no to drugs ...unless you're into that stuff. In that case I can't really help you.

Busy, annoying, dirty & yet most enjoyable place in KTM. . Thamel is the tourist area and it projects itself so. All the super overpriced tourist shops and locals trying to rip you off. The streets are busy as cars, scooters and bikes are constantly passing through. Not a great area, no good deal to be made, no good food neither. Yet best area of KTM which is a super super polluted and dirty city.

Bustling Streets and at Times a Little Crazy. Lose yourself in the tight busy streets of Thamel, which do seem to be disorderly but they work somehow. Great to wander around and end up in a courtyard like Gaia for coffee or food, maybe you will end up buying spices or fruit, get the things you need for your trek, talk to the lovely smiling locals, one thing is for sure you will get "beeped at" more than once. Enjoy, I did.

Busy, dusty and so interesting!. Everywhere you look, there are people. Busy people. Cars and especially scooters are honking to let you know they are coming. Can be stressful (if you need to be somewhere at a specific time), but funny if you have time to stand still for a while and just watch the organised chaos.

Lots of great shopping!. We stayed for several nights in this area. There were plenty of "tourist" restaurants that were safe to eat in as well. Lot of great shopping. We stumbled up on a shop called Local Women's Handicrafts that supported Fair Trade and Fair Price. lwhnepal.com The prices were so unbelievably low you felt like you were stealing. The sister's that are in the shop are so engaging and we brought a lot of others to the shop. It's fun to just get lost and meander the streets.

A fascinating place to visit. If you are staying in Kathmandu you will be used to the noise, horn honking and dust that comes with it. Thamel has narrow roads which can make it 'scary' at first- however the sights, sounds and colours all make it worthwhile- don't be afraid to 'barter' for your shopping- its what they expect.

The once great Thamel has lost its charm.. Been coming to Thamel since 1981. A lot has changed over time and rightly so. However the congestion in Thamel is now too much. We have reapeatdly asked locals to consider making Thamel a pedestrian mall, like in Shimla, Bundi and other places in India. They just get stuck in the mindset thinking it will mean a loss of business.Thamel is exciting, but for some of the wrong reasons now. It is increasingly dangerous to walk the streets there with crazy motor cyclists weaving through pedestrians at great speeds. Install pedestrian gates like on lakeside in Pokhara and make it people friendly.Still has the best eateries in KTM.Hotels there are getting dated and run down.Shopping is good for trekkers, but other areas are opening up.

Vibrant neighborhood. The narrow and bustling streets of Thamel offer a lot of selection for shoppers and diners. It is a great place to people watch over a decent coffee and become immersed in the culture of Kathmandu. It is a good location to book your hotel because after a day of sightseeing, dinner in Thamel and a bit of shopping is a nice way to spend the evening.

Shopping Paradise!. The street of Thamel truly offers the most fantastic view on what Nepal is. With a mix of locals and tourists alike, there's no better place for one to go to, when in search of food - and bargains - to enjoy!
cultural area. the building are made with different brick. and there are many handicraft shop.. and good restaurant..

Thamel touring. A interesting place with faces from all over the world and all ages.
Treasure hunters paradise.
Yoga lovers will encounter singing bowls, mandalas and plenty of: Om night pad me uom.
great tourist vibe. if you like to just roam around the street with lots of crafts and want to know the culture.this should be your choice
Fun and Exciting. This is a GREAT spot if you're looking for some hustle and bustle in the city. Plenty of shopping, food, and people watching!

An assault on the senses. Thamel is an area of Kathmandu that most visitors head for. It is a riot of colours, smells, tiny shops, market stalls, beggars, self-employed 'guides' and rickshaws. It is easy to get disoriented among the narrow streets but at no time did I feel uneasy or threatened. Life is bustling and noisy with bikes, cars and scooters constantly peeping their way through.There are shops that sell everything but most common are the ones selling trekking and mountain gear. Much of it is fake North Face or similar brands, but all seemed to be good quality and well made. Pashminas are sold everywhere but whatever you buy, be prepared to negotiated hard. The shopkeepers will quote dollars to westerners; I focussed on rupees.As well as the shops, there are bars, hotels and hostels a plenty.

Great vibe. Love the vibe in Thamel, it's a mix of different kinds of tourists. I travelled alone there and always felt safe. Some great cafes and restaurants, plus of course loads of good shopping. Head out of the main areas for a proper look around.

Buzzing and lively. I really like the feel of Thamel, loads to see and lots of places to eat. It would be much better if the closed the road to cars though as the roads are so narrow cars just make the place feel dangerous and add to the pollution.
Best place to stay while in Kathmandu.. The hub for tourists. Shopping Mecca. Eateries. My first time in Kathmandu - will definitely recommend staying here. Close to all that you need.
Best place for travelers. This is where everything is happening. Tourists flock to this region for its shops, restaurants, bars & entertainment, and the widest variety of mid-priced hotels.

Spent lots of time here. Thamel was alot of fun. Ended up shopping in other areas alot after finding wholesalers for most items. The Gorkha Zone Kukri House is pretty cool, love the owner (great guy). Happy Restaurant was the best bang for your buck and Hotel Premium was better then any hotel twice it's price. Be sure to barter on everything that's for sale here because lots of places will cut prices in half. Great spot, enjoy!

Great place to go. Lots to see and do, with some great places to eat and drink.
Wandered the streets around here for half a day, so many shops with the same things but if you look hard enough you will get a great deal and something unique.

Tourist ghetto, but still not a bad place. Having stayed in many different areas of Kathmandu, whilst this is the most touristy, it offers a lot in a very small, compact area. Hotels to suit all budgets, restaurants, trekking equipment shops, souvenir shops and most. There are lots of places to hang out, have a coffee and gossip with other travellers. You are likely to be solicited a bit, whether for a trek or 'smoke' but it is fairly relaxed and most locals readily take no for an answer, making even this tourist 'ghetto' not a bad place to stay.

Amazing Town. Stayed in Hotel Thamel in Thamel before and after trekking..it is a shoppers paradise with dirt cheap trekking gear.....amazing restaurants and fab souvenir shops......the nightlife is also incredible!

Shopp paradice. A lot of shops outside Kathmandu Guesthouse,by walking you can enjoy the shopping fun..variety choice from clothing , Buddha statues,Thangka , jewellery ...you can definitely find the stuffs that you like.

A Shopper and Foodie's Paradise!. Thamel is the City Centre in Kathmandu, located at a distance of about 15 mins drive from the airport.It offers plentiful choices of hotels/ lodging/ boarding, restaurants, cafes, pubs/ clubs and shops for clothes, articles and souvenir shopping. It offers ample options to cater every person's interest. It is a Shopper's and a Foodie's paradise for sure!Well-connected to rest of the city by means of public buses and taxis, make sure you bargain well with the taxis for a fair rate.The place begins to shut down by 9 pm; however, some of the restaurants and cafes serve until 11 pm, while most of the bars and pubs/ cafes are open until after midnight. If you are a solo girl, it might be helpful to not stay out alone or without reliable company past 10-11 pm max, to avoid any trouble!

Good for shopping only. Alot of things to see and buying here..however, u need to be smart & survey price because some of the shops were selling fake items and expensive..also u can lost in the area too, so better use google map..also, this will be too crowded & try not to be too friendly with people here especially for female solo traveller..alot of guest house here in thamel..but for those who need a cheap budget like below 1000 rupees, it will be dificult to find unless u booked through website..
Mini ktm. Yeh right this is mini kathmandu Inside the ktm Everything's perfect else small road and crowded place, eveything find here almost every things..

Loud, horns and salesmen!. This place is crawling with people trying to sell you something. You also have to fight your way past motorcycles, cars and huge groups of tourists in unbelievably small alleyways. The shops all sell the same things; fake northface, Jack Wolfskin or patagonia clothing and accesories and an enormous amount of mass produced touristy handicrafts. If you need to buy some souvenirs it may be worth visiting but be ready to be overwhelmed!
A market place for all the things of Nepal. We visited once and then again and again. Its for all the things of Nepal. A colorful market place but for navigation with high negotiation skills.

Nice place to walk around. Lots of shopping. This place is chaos and is full of traffic, but it is amazing and full of life! Beautiful temples every where, as well as blends of architecture. There are many timy coffee shops and restaurants to visit all around.

Nepal's Bunghole. Thamel is a place where tourists flow in and out and Nepal's best and worst come to feed and pillage. For the most part Thamel is just OK but the gangs, drug sellers, dance bars and scams get old fast. Keep your money close, watch your back and don't trust friendly strangers. Tip...the begging children work for the gangs and anyone that ask you to buy milk for their hungry sister is trying to scam you.

Lots of fun, especially for boomers who remember the 60's & 70's.. Restaurants and lots and lots of souvenir shops make up Thamel, a spot everyone knows about especially if you're of a certain age. Won't disappoint, although there are some more authentic markets in Kathmandu.

Fool of crazy croud. Not a soothing place to spend your holiday. Full of frauds, drug dealer, Insane expensive of souvenirs. Only some good restaurants and bar..... that's all. You cannot walk due to narrow roads and thousands of people. Not a place go on a couple trip.

Thamel is an interesting district of Kathmandu, as there is much to discover. However, it is disturbing when driving mot. Thamel is an interesting district of Kathmandu, as there is much to discover. However, it is disturbing when driving motorcycles and cars in the narrow streets, making shopping and browsing is difficult or a bit stressful.

Trekkers stopover. Great place, heaps of stuff to see. Don't feel too pressured by local sellers. Look around and take it all in.Has pretty much everything you need or if you've forgotten to buy something at home this place will have 10 of everything to sell you.

Explore more and you find more. Thamel is crowded and lively area in Kathmandu. You cand find anything there if you like to explore the area, from historic durbar to traditional market, from good cafe to local snack stall. The market was amazing. With noisy horn from motorbikes and cars as sound background, you can find varieties products there: groceries, spices, clothes, shoes, fruits, souveniers and many more. You also find a branded items with a fixed price if bargain is not your good at. Yes! bargain skill is needed when you shop there. Thamel area is also a good place to stay in Nepal where you find any hotels that fit with your budget with many options of places to eat nearby. When you feel tired in the afternoon after exploring Thamel during the day, just sit in one cafe and try a himalayan coffe or tea. You will feel relax and boast your mood to explore more like i did.

Place to be for tourists. Thamel is the place to be and stay for all tourists. The place has everything for tourists, from all category of hotels and guest houses to the best of bars, pubs and restaurants to local shopping. The place is buzzing with people all the time and music during the evenings. It is also Good place to meet other travelers and find tourists to venture out together. Most must visit sites are a walking distance. I would recommend staying in Thamel for convenience and its liveliness. Couple of places I would suggest is the Sam's bar right next to Dalai-La, the OR2K restaurant and New Orleans restaurant.
Nepal's Modern day Freak Street. Busy buzzing Thamel, tourist local friendly. Great restaurants and low fare hotels. From pizza to Local food stalls, you won't stay hungry in Thamel.
Favourite place in Kathmandu. This is my favourite place in Nepal. Highly recommend to all. Nice resturants and interesting shops. The place is an exoerience on its own!

Entertainment District. Thamel is the area that most visitors to Kathmandu end up staying in and where most of the tourist shopping, bars and restaurants are found. Like most parts of this city it's crowded, dusty and filled with life. The shops are packed in and sell everything you can imagine you'll want to buy as a visitor. There are countless bars with relatively cheap drinks. There are dance bars here but they look a little seedy.The bars tend to close before midnight but before that you might find live music (usually bands doing western covers), and fellow travellers about to embark on an adventure (or about to tell you about the one they've just been on). There don;t seem to be any pavements in central Thamel so prepare to dodge the traffic and listen for the hooting. Considering the tourist hotspot that this is, the vendors don't hassle the visitors too much and I didn't spot any scams. You'll need to barter in the shops although probably not too viciously. Remember that prices in menus don't include the 23% tax and service charge.Remember all that and you'll love Thamel.For a couple of days - then it might start to get a bit much.

Exotic. Dont walk in the thamel area if you just finding a not tourist area, just walk little bit out from the thamel street you'll find a local street that is more crowd, more noise and annoying you, but everywhere at the corner is just looks exotic, and i like the local athmosphere there,.
Good. Bit crowdy, there are lots of cheaters so be smart and try to do your things by your self so tht u can save money
Chaos and dust but main area :) . The place were to stay in Kathmandu as close to all restaurants and shops. Here u can find all your needs and very touristic while kept alot it's original flair.
Cosy corner to snuggle in.... Loved it absolutely. I might get bored eventually, but then I will not hesitate to live for a few weeks and explore the little shops and quaint restaurants.

Great place to be. While in Kathmandu I will never miss the opportunity to come to Thamel. It has just about everything a tourist would like to see. From great restaurants to bars to dance clubs to spas, everything is here. And it is not that expensive.Beware of touts who will offer you the dubious things including girls which can easily be avoided by telling them you are not interested or a yes if you are interested!The people are generally warm and finding yourself around is easy. Do try visiting the karaoke bars as they are fun!

Manic but brilliant!. Like so many Asian towns/cities, Thamel offers the visitor a type of manic confusion that seems to work! Bustling crowds with superb priced gifts, and great food, all joins with people that are so warm and polite! Yes it can seem dusty and dirty!..... But this just adds to the experience. Go and visit and be mesmerised and you'll never complain about a London traffic jam again!
