Buzzy busy and shopping. Thamel is the heart of Kathmandu. A great place to stay with access to all the shopping you could want as well as loads of bars and restaurants. Close proximity to Durbar Square and with hotels to suit every budget. Almost impossible to tell there was an earthquake just a year ago.

See the Asan Market first.. I am so glad we stumbled on the Asan Market before visiting Thamel.The Asan market is like 'reading the book' and Thamel is like 'seeing the movie.' Everything in Thamel is geared towards taking your money as a tourist. You know a neighbourhood has completely sold out when you see bong shops, reggae cafes and Che Guevara knittings.The nuances are small as both Asan and Thamel share similar traffic, pollution, and confusing layout. However, the Asan Market sells goods to locals and shop owners won't try to sell you a brand new flat screen TV.And that is indeed the appeal!!! As a tourist, you may think you want 'genuine' singing bowls and thankgas but I assure you there is more authenticity in seeing a fridge carried on someone's back through a centuries old, twisting alley. That is day to day life of Kathmandu.

Loving Thamel. One of my memorable trips ever! Thamel being the center of Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal, everything is within reach - varieties of restaurants, hotels, bars, bed & breakfast hotels, apartments, supermarkets, money exchange centers, souvenir shops, etc. Plus, the hospitable locals that would make you feel home. One of the best places in Nepal that I miss & I'm still hoping to go back!
thamel in nepal close to kathmandu. many shops and outside stalls selling fresh vegetables to pots and pans to clothing to electronics ,very low prices,freshness at its best

Good center for traveller. I just spent 2 days in Thamel, before and after my trek. This a good shopping place, very interested in bargaining with the shop. I specially like a dream catcher shop. We went there 4 times for buying dream catchers as gifts to home.

Spectacular shopping and culture. A wonderful assortment of shopping and eating places. Secure with tourist police that can be found wandering amongst the crowds. A word of advice, when traveling this area. Get a local sim card for your phone. Turn on and use your phones GPS and then simply wander this area. You will find yourself immersed into the culture.

Shopping in Thamel. Thamel is renowned shopping area in Kathmandu for tourists.
You can find bargains but you must barter with the sellers.
Keep in mind everything you purchase will have to be washed as everything is covered in dust.

Launch pad for trekking nepal.. Thamel is the start point for organising treks and adventures in nepal. The place is busy there are many street sellers and people pushing trekks/adventures and some unsavoury things also. The seller's are not agresive but rather amusing trying to sell their things/ chess sets or flutes ect " just look, looking is not buying" it was fun bartering in the shops there's a lot of knock off trekking gear I bought a nock off sleeping bag which worked ok at abc and duearali at -6. The highlights were for me to eat big daddy burger near the garden of dreams best food in I ate in Nepal. Shops were good lots of solo travelers milling around.

Sensory overload. I don't really want to say anything negative because they really need the tourist trade at the moment. In writing a review, you can't really compare it to western shopping environments as this would be unfair and if you're in Nepal, then surely it's not what you're here for. There are some amazing stalls and shops and goods of all kinds. Take your time to look around - don't jump at the first bargain or pay the price they first suggest to you. There are also some wonderful cafes and dining experiences. An easy walk to so many other places as well including accommodation.

Not Exactly what I thought. I would not recommend you going for here if you came to Nepal to relax. This place is full with people who try to sell you stuff for a exaggerated amount. There are also a couple beggars which won't leave you until you give them money or state that you won't give them money clearly. This place is also dirty and filthy. I would not recommend going here.

Close to the city's other, better shopping areas - good for food variety. I've lived in Kathmandu for over 2 months now and I still come to Thamel to get food when I'm tired of Nepali or Indian spice flavors. It's a lot more expensive than local places, but worth it. This tourist area usually has safer food practices so you most likely won't get sick. It has a Chinese food street (on the south side, parallel to Kanti Pur) that has real Chinese food, not the weird Nepali-fied Chinese food. The Chinese restaurants aren't that expensive, around 200 - 500 rupees per plate. The best part about Thamel is that it's close to the other shopping areas. If you don't want to deal with haggling from such a high tourist price, walk south about 10 minutes to Indra Chowk and many of the same pashminas and yak wool items are sold there. If you want the finer cashmere items, they are not sold there though. Also, if you want to buy some real Nepali gold or silver jewelry, not the common looking silver jewelry that's sold at every other store in Thamel, walk to New Road. It looks very Nepali, both silver and gold jewelry, and not like ordinary silver pendants and earrings you can find anywhere else in the world. New Road has the gold hoops with handmade beads and molded design bangles. If you walk towards King's Road, there are some decent shops, although KTM in general is awful for shopping and not cheap like Bangkok or Kuala Lumpur. But they have coffee shops, restaurants, and stores that are nicer and cleaner than other places around town.Tip on walking through Durbar Square - if you look like a tourist, you will be constantly hassled by the security asking if you bought a ticket. If you're not taking photos and visiting the sites, let them know you're just walking through. Let them know you were walking from Indra Chowk to New Road, or vice versa. They sometimes say okay, and wave you through. But most of the time, they are total jerks and yell at you and say you have to buy a ticket. It's a very annoying thing in all tourist areas in the valley. To avoid the headache, you can cut down off Indra Chowk early to avoid going through Durbar Square, or go in the back alley behind the square.
Okay. Be careful while shopping try to be more protective better have one Nepalese Friend with you as a guide as you cannot trust few of them
Good marketplace. Good marketplace.You can go around for two to three days easily.Don't pay what they ask you and bargain for good price.

Bustling and busy.. So many things to buy. Bargains to be had but dont do them in, as these people have suffered enough and their hand crafts are beautifully done. Pay them what its worth.I bought a Yak leather handbag and 2 pancho's from cashmere.

Place to explore . If you don't visit Thamel while you are in Kathmandu then you have to think twice.
Because all fun begin from here and ends right here.
Place for Shopping, great Restaurants, travel agencies you get each and everything here.
I would say that thermal is the place to explore.

Where are the tourists stay. This is a part of Kathmandu that is known as the tourists district. Lots of shops, restaurants,hotels and so much stuff to buy. It's loud,lots of traffic and this time of year lots of westerners walking the streets.

Souvenir Central. The perfect place to pick up affordable souvenirs. Anything you could possibly want: kukuri knives, brass, masks, puppets, prayer flags, jewelry, tea, trekking gear, cashmere, singing bowls, you name it! It's busy and can become quite crowded but my husband and I enjoyed strolling through the streets to find a good deal on souvenirs we were looking to bring home. Lots of cafes and restaurants tucked away. Be mindful that bathrooms are hard to come by and are often pretty dirty (i.e. bring hand sanitizer and a pack of your own tissues).

Just enjoy your time. Our guesthouse is just a few blocks away from Thamel. Our day in Kathmandu will never be complete without going around this area. On our first day we learned that restaurants and shops don't usually open before 10AM, others, even at a later time (not sure if it's just because it was winter season). If you have a sensitive stomach you have to be very careful of where you choose to eat. I had days in Kathmandu where I dealt with bad diarrhea; almost missed my EBC plan. Once the shops and restaurants are open, the place could easily get crowded and dusty (though it's really dusty no matter of the date and time). I suggest that those people who are sensitive to dust bring something to cover their noses while roaming around the area or whole Kathmandu.Shopping can be fun here. Souvenir prices are cheap and authentic to Nepal.

Open your eyes. All the shops, all the people, ... It is just incredible. The bad thing is having to ignore the hectic people trying to sell stuff but it is ideal for an afternoon walk.Beware that streets become dark in the evening as there are no lights.If you love to negotiate, try and get some souvenirs or hiking clothes here!
Not a very good place!. This place is just for tourists market. Not very clean and quite congested. Nothing to do here. The only benefit is that it is centre to move anywhere in Kathmandu.

Worth visiting. This is a quaint, very touristy part of town, with lots of shops selling art, trinket souvenirs, painting, massage parlors, and restaurants, and trekking gear. Many foreigners stay here, and we had a good time..
Happening Area of Kathmandu. area is good and happening as me with my wife went before earthquake.But I think it was , is and still will be happening area of Kathmandu

Busy tourist streets. Thames has lots of shops and restaurants in narrow crowded streets teaming with people, taxis and motorbikes. Old carved wood window and door frames remain on tall houses but close together (not great for an earthquake zone) but any remnants of traditional term are lost among the shop signs and importunate vendors. There are still signs of the 1970s 'freak street' atmosphere with some weirdly dressed foreigners hanging around bong shops. Most shops selling the same old pashminas and knitted hats, all a bit tacky. Buy your cashmere from aa reputable shop.Some cafes have rooftop seats which are good for people watching.

Oasis in a culture shock. Loved my time in thamel, loads of bargains to have, if you haggle. It was my first time here, I was I bit nervous but it's safe and friendly even though you get pestered but it's all part and parcel of Kathmandu

Thee incredibly busy and fun part of the city. Tiny streets overflowing with eye candy things to buy.. I stayed right in the middle of Thamel at Hotel Access, great central location to walk to and from. Evenings. Can be quiet at the hotel and jumping at local bars

love crowded street. I heard a lot about Thamel but I had never been there, so once I decided to hang around with friends in Thamel to spend my free time during my stay in Kathmandu. It was really crowded with lots of shop selling so many traditional Nepalese goods. So many things to see there despite being pushed by the crowd. I recommend people to go there if you're interested visiting shops full of typical Nepalese stuff.
Good for souvenir shopping. If you need a little something to remember Nepal - this is where you will find it! More accessible ATM's (they close early). Lots of restaurants.

At home in a week!. The bright signs and lights and busy streets that were overwhelming on our first day became a sign of home after a long day out. Perfect area to practice your bartering skills, make friends with other travellers and eat delicious & cheap food of countless cuisines. -The only thing difficult to get used to is the common habit of loudly spitting onto the streets!
Classic Nepali Experience. We stayed in Thamel for 4 to 5 days before going to another part of the city. It is where all the fun shopping is located and has some of the best restaurants in the city.

LOVED Thamel. I absolutely loved staying in Thamel. It is very tourist friendly and the shops and restaurants are fantastic! Every night we found something new and fun to do, and felt very safe walking in the streets. Also, as a trekker, you can find everything you could possibly need or want for your trek.We also ventured out into some of the more local markets in KTM, which were so interesting and cheap, but I was glad we were sleeping in Thamel.

Narrow streets full of souvenir shops, restaraunts and bars, I loved it lol!. I actually quite liked Thamel, so many little shops selling mostly souvenirs and Hiking equipment. big choice of places to eat, and quite a few bars too. There is however nothing picturesque about thamel (and not much really about KTM in general lol). and other than loads of shops, bars ect theres not a great deal to see. its pretty tricky to navigate too!Mind you I spent ages just exploring the endless little streets just looking at stuff and it does seem to go on for ever almost! so I quite enjoyed it for those reasons :)

you can buy it all. this bustling area has generally everything for sale. if you are a small person you can have your choice of any 'down' jacket you want. great spot of outdoor gear, backpacks,etc. remember to always bargain so that the future tourists get a good price too!

Shopaholic's paradise. This is the upmarket shopping district of Kathandu where you can find EVERYTHING Nepalese you could possibly desire. We bought scarves, knitted socks, knitted caps, thick woollen jumper, tee-shirts, some cheap knick-knacks. The tigers & goats game and the singing bowl we bought elsewhere. There are also lots of jewellery, electrical, and of course hiking stores. Food is available from street vendors or proper shops. You can take a rickshaw through the area although more fun to walk, if you have the time. Enjoy absorbing the atmosphere of vehicle fumes, being offered goods to buy, the noise of constant beeping of vehicle horns and avoiding the motorbikes, not to mention seeing all the stupas.

The heart of Kathmandu.. This is one of the most recommended and busy places in Kathmandu. More like a travellers centre bustling with shops, restaurants, clubs and bars. A very global area which has tourists from every country.There is something for everyone. A fun place especially in the night to enjoy the night life of Kathmandu as it has some great bars.

Bargain shopping. You really have to bargain there. They try to strike you with double or sometimes triple price and hoping you pay. Many different shops with all kind of stuff. Many cafe/clubs/bars. Too many dealers offering hash/weed almost in front of police. Good place for souvenirs. Recommend to stay around that area as it very touristic place.

Shopping and food. Not much to do here except eat and shop. A busy enough market without the level of hassle and harassment that is everywhere in India. Plenty of scarves, trinkets and winterwear to look at, you can almost always bargain a third off the price.
incredible town tourist paradise. best restaurants & shopping galore. Tourists paradise. nicely hidden shops down narrow streets, colorful and aromatic smells.
Busy central market . Very crowded but the best place to hang out in Kathmandu , some average and some good places to dine out. All in all an interesting place to be .
I enjoy walking in Thamel and taking photos. You'd get here very inexpensive climbing and hiking equipment and clothes. I also bought here nice sculptures.
Interesting. Better than expected. . There are a lot of shops on Thamel and nearby interesting temples and durbar square. It's quite enjoyable and not overly busy like India.

Amazing place. Wondering through the streets of Thamel you get to experience old Kathmandu and see the culture from a different point. You may even get lost because of hundreds of little exits and and shops. People are nice and welcoming.

Old town kathmandu . Head for the verve and pulse of Katmandu
There is a lot of buzz and a lot of tourists flocking the place.

Love it or hate it, you have to visit it. Thamel is like the hotpot of everything that you would expect of Kathmandu. It is alive with colour, noise, food, shops, spas and just about anything you can think of (except quiet).So many places to eat. Shopping is overwhelming as you just do not know where to purchase from. One thing is certain, you have to haggle! And for those inclined, there is a never ending offering of illicit substances, usually as night comes in. Then you get to see a darker type of person entering the Thamel area. I never felt uncomfortable though, you just see friendly faces being replaced with a more harsher type of face. Best of all, haggle a good price for massages. Not a lot of tourists at the moment, so we got an hour for both my husband and I for 2000 rupees for the both of us. A bargain in anyone's language.
Must for Hindus. Others not allowed entry.. Lovely temple of Shiva. Has great religious significance for Hindus.Should be opened for entry to all

A must visit if you are in Kathmandu. A hive of activity, brilliant for shopping. Make sure that you barter!
I left at night time after visiting a restaurant with a group so I didn't find walking back in the dark too daunting. However, I may have found this unpleasant if alone.
Shops Galore. Thamel is a rabbit warren of streets packed with shops and eating houses and hotels set up for tourists . Great atmosphere and vendors do not over hassle you.

Street Vendors. Thamel is so interesting. One can spend hours browsing and seeing many Nepalese stuff plus many restaurants. Even if you do not want to buy anything, this place wakes your senses with the vibrancy of its people.

Visit. Crowded place full of Nepali traditional things, u can find anything starting from the traditional tea until traditional handicraft of Nepal. This place also offers a lot restaurant, cafe as well as night club. The only things which disturbing me here, this place Is far away from peace too much car and bikes which passing around.
Shopping . Shopping heaven. You can get lovely locally produced clothing, jewellery and crafts. It's cheap and stuff you wouldn't find elsewhere. Shop around for good deals.

Hustle & Bustle & Life Goes On.... You can find just about anything here.And if you can't...all you need to do is ask & someone will find it for you. Thamel is a great big mixture of many: locals selling their wares, tourists, pick pockets, drug dealers, monks, shopkeepers, etc.... A very very very crowded colorful bustling mixture of souvenirs and singing bowls and mountaineering shops and restaurants and clubs and travel agencies and banks and shops and supermarkets and over priced hotels and much more. Great place to shop but be sure to bargain. There are cheaper hotels to be found in other parts of KTM.

Awesome place to party in kathmandu. If you are party freak and love nightlife never miss Thamel. I spend weekend in thamel and go for party in club like fire, faces , purple haze and factory. fire is reasonable factory is lil expensive but good ambience and drinks

Great for dining and shopping. I loved walking through the streets of Thamel, where you can find some form of devotion, either as a Temple or statue of a deity, every few hundred yards. The shopkeepers are all friendly and not pushy- they don't try to force you to buy anything. There is also a good supply of restaurants and bars.
Shopping lovers. Souvenirs and gifts are affordable here compare to other places. It took only 20 minutes from the Kathmandu International Airport.
Pleasant . Nice place to walk around and they have lots of gifts to take back home.i liked the colourful shawls and the painting are really breathtaking .
great spot to shop!. On our last evening in Kathmandu, we spent it wondering around Thamel. A great place to shop….make sure you bargain though!

Excellent Place to Bargain and Shop. Thamel is rich with stores that sell about the same stuff about every other store. They usually sell scarfs, kukri daggers, little trinkets, and there's a night club/lounge at every block. There are many restaurants and massage parlors too. It's a very busy area, and with the right bargain, the products are worth buying.

Main tourist hub in ktm. Lot of markets, restaurants, hotels and travel agent in Thamel. Durbar square is just 15 mins walk from Thamel . This is the main tourist hub of Kathmandu.Rickshaw and taxis are easily accessible. Just 5 km away from airport.

Touristi place. Thamel is one of the major touristic place of Nepal. And also shopping place with touristic price. All the foods and what you need you get. Here all the people are doing business small or big. There is many street guy are asking you for any things for business. Most of guys are works for commison. From hotel or travel booking you made through them.
Lots of cool shops. Very friendly shop owners, narrow streets and lots of color. This is the center of Old Kathmandu. Lots of little restaurants as well.
A nice Touristic place. I like thamel very much.lots of restaurants,bars,pub,shovinear shops around here.lots of tourists use yo stay here.

Loosing it's charm.. Day by day Thamel is loosing its charms. Very narrow and conjusted roads. Also roads are not clean. And too many touts harassment. They force you for this service and that services. Most of the shops are cheating to customers by one or other way. Even the smallest things are not available at MRP. I mean printed price on product. I recommend to stay in other area then Thamel.

Always good to stay in Thamel . Still a great area to stay in? Everything you need here. Restaurant's, hotel's, cafés, trekking shops and tours, it was a small bit quite compared to the last time I was there, and due to blockade on the border a few restaurant's were closed. But there are plenty.
Day for shopping . Great place to look for local crafts and Nepali souvenirs. Little bit dusty but friendly people, ready to give you advice and helpful.

Shopping heaven for tourist. This is the 'It' place in Kathmandu. A lot of shops selling local souvenirs. You may find many local restaurants and cafe which served delicious food and organic cafe. Many guest houses can choose from budget to mid range. Everything is walking distance.
Crowdedd... Its a city center for the city of Kathmandu, we were there for one day and wanted to buy cashews before we leave for Pokhara. Its all crowded and sink in the old buildings.

YOU EXPERIENCE KATHMANDU HERE. This is the place that people converge, either for shopping, meals or simply to chill out. Rows of shops and friendly Nepalese will always willing to assist provided that you ask and make friends with them. Shopping heaven for tourist who look for souvenirs, Showcase of colorful Nepalese life.

Market Everything Here. Visited Kathmandu after about 2 years. Usual marketing place Thamel was very lively even though most part of the country is still recovering from Terror shock.
You get good variety of items - local, handmade and antique items are good to choose from.
Go around in the market and check rates before you start shopping. Do negotiate for better rates.

Tourist attraction. Thamel is one of the famous attraction for tourist. It consists of hotels and restaurants and is a big market place to shop for various Nepalese handicrafts & souvenir.You can take walk going around the market. Though it is a crowded place it is worth visiting.

Market for antique lovers . I stayed in a hotel of this area... Old down town... Having lot many streets, you can walk only... Lots of shops of every kind but best is local handicrafts, antique piece shops... You can a good momento at good price if you are a good negotiator

One-stop Shop. You haven't been to Nepal if you haven't been to Thamel. The place is littered with tourists and foreigners, as well as the Nepali hawkers trying to make a killing out of them. Everything is negotiable. The rule of thump (if you have to buy anything here) is: the item costs half the price you are told!You have all kinds of restaurants, gift shops, banks, massage places, temples and shrines...you name it.

Difficult to reach because of Traffic Jam. Thamel is one of the famous destination of Kathmandu for tourists. Specially, all category hotels, restaurants, shops, tourists information center but narrow roads & traffic jams will upset before reach here in Thamel. Thamel is hardly 4 KM. far from airport but we spent more than 1 hour to reach in Thamel now a days there are so many good hotels nearby airport so if you're going somewhere early in the morning from airport you have to think to stay in Thamel ....

Fascinating bustle. A must for anyone visiting Kathmandu. Thamel is filled with interesting shops, restaurants and cafes (with good espresso coffee!) making it easy to wile away a few relaxed days wandering around.Note, there is a general rule that you will need to barter when purchasing items as shopkeepers will automatically give you a higher price (being a tourist). That being said, the prices you are given are never completely out of the ballpark so aggressive bartering is not required not recommended - if the shopkeeper is unwilling to go lower and you think the price is too high, just smile, thank the shopkeeper and walk away. There will almost always be another store selling the product.

Crowdy tourist place . Everyone visiting nepal will at at least one time be in Thamel. It's a fun place to be, but it's really crowded, expensive and noisy. They have good restaurants and a typical tourist area.

Lively Kathmandu. Thamel is the place to go if you want to party - both with locals and other travelers. Most of the clubs have live music bands who sing covers of European and American music - but be aware, Nepali people don't usually dance in this kind of places, so if you don't want everyone inside to stare at you, you should stay nicely and drink your beer. I recommend Shisha - that was my favourite place! IF you want to shop, either go with a local or negotiate at least half the price - because like in any other Asian country there are prices for tourists - and very big prices. You might get stalked to buy stuff, but if you don't even open the conversation or don't look to close to the things they sell they would leave you alone. Everything closes really early, so make sure you know how to get home on foot, or catch a taxi around midnight. I recommend buying Mandala drawings, they are really beautiful and I think deserve the money.

City of diverse tourism . There's the very busy street with all the money changers, shops of souvenier, clothing , spa and hotel, all cramp together in the tight street. Then there's the slightly quiet back lanes. You definitely need to bargain when you shop here. I was charged 4X for buying fruits! I only found out after comparing the price in supermarket. A diverse atmosphere, there's the housewives shopping for grocerries in the market, there's the tourists bargain hunting, there's the mountain trekkers, and later in the afternoon children all over the street finishing their day at school. It's a busy alive city. People are mostly friendly and I certainly enjoy the variety of experience here.
Touristic place . Well it's the most renowned place. Thamel offers you good restaurant, bar, mart, coffee place, hotels and many more. Tourist most visited place in Kathmandu.

Great place for hang out n shopping. If you are looking for a quick shopping wt a quick friendly environment for dinner or clubbing thamel is the right place in Nepal. Local are tourist friendly, food are cheap, even its not expensive for heavy shopping.

Always busy, always something to do!. In Kathmandu I prefer to stay in Thamel because it is always bustling with activity, there are more restaurants and bars open till late than in other neighborhoods.

Busy and lively. Most happening place in Kathmandu. Pristine shopping destination where one can get everything related to trekking and winter clothing. It also hosts array of multi cuisine restaurants people can feast on.

Activities are getting back to normal, taxi running, restaurant opens, shops in operation, normal banking in place. Since the earthquake rocks Nepal, with the post earthquake nightmare of petrol and gas issues, clearly the used to be the hot spot for tourists, lesser tourists can be sighted, clearly affected by the rumors of Kathmandu city halted by gas and petrol issues! Do come back, Kathmandu is up and running slowly and surely! Taxi is ready to serve, restaurant is ready to serve, bank is ready to serve and hotel is ready to serve too! Help Nepal to back its footing with tourists influx to explore the ever charming Nepal. Tours and hotels would be at good bargain to attract the tourists to come back!
"Shoppers Delight". This place is always a buzz with foreign tourists, as it provides wide range of shopping articles, right from cloths to memorabilia.

Crowded, Over populated, Hippie-styled. Wander in the crowded street, sift through loads of trinkets and masks, discover quaint pubs and bars and be ready to take in a lot of noise and pollution. Not ideal for walking with kids. Go solo and hope you are a Hippie in your next life - I do :)
Great. Thesis a great area to start the Nepal trip. Lots to do lovely food/ shops and very friendly helpfull people.

Great shopping. Great variety of shops, beautiful pashminas,felt novelties, even dresses for back home. So reasonably priced and cheap. Be prepared to bargain with stall holders especially for multiple buys. There is also a lovely coffee shop and bakery for a break. Also on one corner was a very large convenience store for supplies. Bargain for taxi though as with fuel crisis fares really vary and make sure they know way back as we were staying in Boudha about 15 minutes away.

Great place to wander the streets. Can spend lots of time wandering the streets in this area. There is so much to see and experience - small shops, market stalls along the street, food to try, temples, and generally watching Kathmandu lifestyle.

Beautiful. My wife and I visited Thamel during a tour of India and Nepal in October 2015. Despite the recent earthquakes in the region which devastated many historical sites as well as family homes and businesses the locals continued to do what they could to welcome tourists and make their stays as comfortable as possible. We had a great time area enjoying the calm and peacefulness during the day and vibrancy each night. Would totally recommend a visit , your visit will be really appreciated by the Nepalise who's national economy is so dependant on tourism.

Great selection of Nepali goods.. On a day when we did not have a tour, we shopped in the Thamel district close to our hotel. This is a huge shopping area and not too hard to get lost in. A rickshaw driver dropped us off and followed us the entire time we were there. We did not ask him to stay with us and he did not speak English like others do; so we let him wait for us while we walked. Shopping was fun. Lots of interesting things to look at. The cashmere prices were not a bargain. They will bargain. There are many fine restaurants in the area to chose from. I do not think it was tourist season; which was drastically reduced after last years earthquake. Thamel was not reduced to rubble like some other parts of the city. When it gets dark, the shops close. I was glad our driver had stayed with us. I also made sure he had food and something to drink while he waited. I gathered he was one of hundreds of refugees who came to the city looking for work. Many of them live in tents if they are lucky to find one. After dark, the streets light up with colorful lights and fires to keep warm by. The streets are very uneven and full of crazy motorbike drivers. Then the electricity goes out making the walk even more challenging. We were never aware of any problems the dark could cause, but never wondered after the shops closed. I never look for trouble that far from home and not speaking the language. All in all, the best exotic market I have visited.

Mayhem. The Thamel is every kind of crazy jammed into a few blocks. It is the market place of Kathmandu and it never really sleeps. Dusty, busy, crazy and bursting with every kind of life. I loved it. Watch out for scammers with babies.

Great shopping!. Great area to go shopping and find some bargains. Lots of variety and plenty of opportunity to bargain for discounts! The hustle and bustle can be draining but lots of great coffee shops to recover in!

Nepal's own Amsterdam. I cannot describe how much i love thamel.i had been visting many places but there hasn't been a place which i like as much as thamel.the crowd,bars,pubs,restaurants,all are just exceptional as it is thamel we are talking about.there would be very less individuals who dont like thamel.As i am a party freak and wants to have a good times in my life its just a Amsterdam for me which i can afford living in my own country..

Stayed here in 2014. Very touristy place. Great for shopping and eating. Be prepared to bargain though. Visit the Rumdoodle pub if you have read "the ascent of Mount rumdoodle". We stayed at Hotel Micasa...A wonderful place. You can't but help falling in love with thamel. Simply loved the atmosphere. Do stay in Thamel while visiting Kathmandu.
Good shopping and food. close to accomodation but very busy with motorbikes cars and people Good cold weather gear at very reasonable prices
You got to be here. Eateries, hotels, pubs N bars, the tourist crowd - all of them at one place sums up Thamel.If in KTM, stay here

Thamel is neighborhood with many inexpensive hotels. Thamel depends on trekkers and tourists for its survival, not so much authentic Kathmandu neighborhood. It does have a number of decent restaurants.

Touristy vibes!. Thamel is for tourists like what Church is to Christians!
A must visit place in Kathmandu to experience a fusion of the culture here and of the West. People from all walks of life can be found-meaning, diversity is a synonym for Thamel!
A place to hangout for good times!

The section of Kathmandu NOT to miss!. Thamel is the teeming, mass of humanity, part of Kathmandu which is the heart and soul of this fabled city. We began our not-first-class trekking tour with an add-on of several days in a Thamel Hotel. We walked a maze of narrow streets filled with pedestrians, cars, trucks, taxis, bicycles, motor bikes, rickshaws, the occasional cow and hundreds and hundreds of small to tiny shops. The people are among the most friendly and welcoming anywhere. The prices are a fraction of those in the 'uptown' shops.Time and space do not allow for the stories and experiences we would have missed if we had stayed in the more expensive hotels, some which will discourage exploring Thamel. Don't miss Thamel!

still the place to stroll around if you are in Kathmandu. In October 2015 it was still deserted by travellers - a big pity for the local people. The earthquake is hiting twice: demolishing physically and demolishing businesses due to lack of travellers.I hope that will change very soon.In the shopping streets are all fully functional.

Shopping. The best Shopping in Nepal,fantastic carvings,handicrafts,the worlds finest cast bronze,Buddhist and Hindu art,clothing of a high standard ,a diverse and massive selection of jewels beads and gemstones,finest silver and gold,traditional paintings thanka's,wonderful street food and a wonderland of curiosities,restaurants on every corner,everything can readily be found. Note of caution all prices are by negotiation and very often 2/3rds of the first price can easily be knocked off spend the first day checking out the prices as there is a lot of repetition. Nepalis are very pleasant traders so treat all negotiation with light hearted ness,enjoy.

Tourist section of Kathmandu. A lot of hotels are located here so of course, they cater to tourists. You can get knock-off Northface and other brands but definitely look and feel the quality as not all under the same label are created equal. I was happy that I brought my trekking gear from home. There are tons of souvenirs. I didn't buy a lot, but did get some really cute felted items for kids back home. I wished I would have bought some of the knitted slippers. Its a fun place to browse and shop, if you enjoy shopping. I found that I had to be very direct and walk away quickly from some street vendors. If they catch you looking or if you engage at all, they will follow you. Its a very hard time there now with the fuel crisis so I don't begrudge people from trying to get money. It felt safe and I did not, nor did the people I traveled with, have any problem with pickpockets - not to say you shouldn't be careful. The fruit and vegetable sellers on the street are so colorful and provide good food to the locals. All-in-all it is a good place to visit and spend some time. I was there during the Diwali Festival time so there were many interesting things happening in conjunction with that.
So good. Can spend hours wandering around thamel. Pilgrims is a definite highlight, and or2k. Make sure you barter with souvenirs etc
Shopping and eating . Thamel is a very friendly busy place.. Full of shops everything from hiking gear to souvenirs everything you need aswell as good restaurants.. It's the tourist part of Kathmandu

Shops all around!. Thamel is one of the most popular tourist traps in Kathmandu in my opinion. Almost all shops there cater for tourists, thus, you should really haggle to get a bargain. There are shops for almost anything: trekking gear, souvenir shirts, shawls, scarves and jackets, souvenir trinkets and handicrafts... you name it, Thamel has it. There are also restaurants and coffee shops in every nook and cranny, you just have to look for them inside the area's maze of alleyways. One thing we noticed is the lack of popular coffee chains in the area... or maybe we just did not try hard enough.
lovely. I had a great time shopping here, you need to bargain prices, at least 20 or 30% off. Beatiful cashmere goods
life of ktm. no matter wat time what day, thamel has been always my favourite hangout spot.. must visit for tourist since it covers a wide range of soveniour store to many bars and restaurants..

Nice place to Shop Around!!. Its hub of Shopping and For Eating as Many Restaurants and You can enjoy Dances in Dance bar and have Great time with Your Friends..Many Things to shop here for as Have all Kinds of Handicrafts Items..I Bought Few Thankas from Kaulica Arts ,Jyatha Street Which Were Really Best Arts,,You Should come Here for Shopping and Eating Purpose once!!
excellent place. heart of ktm is said to be kathmandu .every travel and visiting propose is started over here.we can say this place as the place where you u get each and every thing

Crazy place to visit. We really enjoyed wandering through the streets of Thamel. It was a little sad though to see all the shopkeepers and so few tourists. Made me wish we could stop in and buy something from everyone.

Interesting vibe but wouldn't go back unless neccessary. Place to go to if you want to purchase hiking goods, souvenirs and scarves, and a place to have a good dinner. Remember, you need to haggle quite aggressively before you purchase! Foreigner vs Nepali (local) prices are quite stark... There are a whole lot of shops that sell the same goods, so walk away if you're quoted an exorbitant amount. we bought a wind breaker from one of the stores and realized the jacket was not in the best condition. check your goods before you leave. if you want to purchase a ghurka knife as a souvenir, go to a 'speciality' shop, you can get a pretty neat one for a good price. the ones that are sold along the roadside are usually of poor quality.taxis tend to over-quote by 40% - 50%, you can definitely bargain for a cheaper ride.

Nepal's Town. The one place to be when you're in Kathmandu.Great for shopping local clothing that are made in Nepal, souvenirs and, in general, everything tourist's would look into. Everything is here. Food too, you cannot go wrong along the streets.

Chaos, Pollution, Touts, Dangerous. Having travelled to many poor countries, I have to say, I've never experienced anything like this. Firstly the choke of fumes, dust and pollution causes this cough which just develops into an almighty chest dry cough, so recommend a buff or scarf.There are barely any footpaths and whiilst this may make it look more ancient or mystical, it just makes it a never ending dash to not be hit by a car or bike. Like most poor countries there are beggars, young children used as bait, and men trying to befriend you or taxi or touts trying to get money. If you are looking for trekking gear there is no shortage here. The restaurants are few, ended up at Yak Restaurant because it had the most westerners the others I avoided for fear of poisoning.Honestly I don't get why people find this place mystical or religious or devine, having travelled to many Asian countries, I find this place so far removed from spiritualism or mystic, yet rather a polluted, poverty stricken country hanging on by a thread as India or China knock on their door. Apologies if I offended anyone who thinks differently.
Nice shopping. You can buy everything here, and be careful not to be lost in the small lanes, which are so beautiful and you can forget where you are.

Good place for buying canvas paintings. As my hotel was just nearby this famous market, I have spent half a day doing shopping here, after my trekking in Everest region. One would be able to purchase canvas paintings in various sizes, in reasonable prices. For example I bought 3 small sized ones (30cm x 50cm) and a big one (50cm x 100cm), with scenes in Mt Everest and Ama Dablem, at only USD85, which was out of my expectation. Also one can buy some good quality tea leaves in cheap price also, which costs only a few USD per 100g.

Good place for Tourist !!. Nice area for Shopping and I love this area you can find many nice restaurant if you visited kathmandu you must visited Thamel once .very things you can find here what you want.
Very busy . It's worth spending time walking around this area. Or staying nearby as its very central.Have a look round, some eye openers.
Eateries and Crowded. More than the shopping here, I loved the eateries around this place. Must try out the Japanese and Tibetian food when here

Shop till you drop!. Unbelievable quantity of shops and street vendors. Wonderful felt items, figurines, handmade jewelry, pashminas, clothing, textiles, singing bowls, food, teas, spices... the list goes on and on.
Busy place in kathamndu. It is a touristic place . Lots of restaurants and shopping centers. You can find nepali handicrafts products in street. You can bargain for better price.
Shopping. You can buy shawals at good price and local made dresses. Prices needed to be done on bargaining basis.

shopping district. a very crowded, congested area with lots of shops; clothing an local souvenirs are popular...
keep a day or two to roam around in the area and do some shopping

Shopping, eating, live music.... Perfect for everything. No hassle or bother from the shop keepers and there are plenty of places to go to. Great eateries, check out momotaro for excellent Japanese. Kathmandu guest house for a variety of foods. Good bars all around with live music.

Mr. Excellent place for everytype of people vegetarian non vegetarian hotels pubs disco clubs bar moghlai foods turkey foods are available, it is a tourist place, you will fined different countries of people enjoying in the street, and a good street market
tourist capital. Thamel is the tourist hangout in Kathmandu. Lots of restaurants and bars as well as shops and trekking outlets. Has a great atmosphere with lots of bargains to be found

Simply Fascinating....... the tourist hub of Kathmandu, a must visit place! Great selection of souvenirs, music, clubs and a variety of restaurants offering magnitude of cuisines - fine dinning, medium-standard restaurant, street food etc. This is alike a melting pot where Nepalese and foreigners alike get together for a fun filled time.

Tourist Central. Thamel is always busy with honking drivers, crazed motorbikes, and rickshaw drivers constantly asking if you need a ride. There are folks selling everything from musical instruments to drugs, and plenty of roads to explore. Lots of great places to eat, lots of shopping, but definitely not a great place to relax. If you want all of the amenities of Thamel but without the crowds or frenzy, try Patan instead.

Too hectic and crowded. Thamel is the center of tourist place in Kathmandu city. It is very crowded, narrow road and a lot of motorbikes and cars moving around the alley.. I don't like it too stay for long time inside thamel.

tourist place. thamel is a place for foreigner tourist and the please where people do chill out.lots of bars, pubs, hotels, restaurants, shops, etc.i like to stay in thamel coz its so energetic and you can find all the thinks in walking distance.

The tourist place . Thamel is the place for all tourists no matter what your budget. One could find everything they need within a walking distance. Restaurants serving all kinds of cuisine, bars, clubs, lights, shops and travel needs. You will meet all kinds of tourists here. The place so very vibrant and probably the only place in Kathmandu where u will see lights all night. It's also entertaining and safe for solo travelers.

The crazy place they call Thamel. first time in Nepal,or if you have visited many times, most people go to Thamel. Part of the city of Kathmandu, Thamel is a very full of life place. The streets ( most have no sidewalks ) are full of cars motorbikes and people. This sometimes can be a bad thing. Thamel has so many shops and food places, that you can spend a day walking around. Thamel is fun because of the energy there, but it is only a small part of Nepal.

Crazy drivers and hectic markets streets. Quite an experience. I love Thamel even though it is 'touristy' and 'pricey' compared to the rest of Kathmandu - it's still really authentic and inexpensive for most types of travelers. Stalls to buy all the gifts you need and good eats around every corner. Bustling and hectic but I enjoy the vibe.

Okay for tourists. Thamel is the place to stay in Kathmandu if you are there for the tourism . Mainly small shops selling fake cashmere and other trinkets . Plenty of money exchange and massage places . The exchange rates are good and the massage is reasonably priced . Myself , I go for the massage and it seems like most of the places on the main streets are legit . Some good restaurants in the area , you just have to hunt them out . Always count your change in front of the person you are paying and make sure of the price up front .
best place to chill. I prefer thamel the best place to chill ..Hippies usually go there .... Just ignore the people in the streets..
Best place . Good plase for touris. It is smal but jice place . You can get wvery thing in this place. We loke this place and colture also . Hhhhhhhhhjjjdxgggsfgfdsaak
Enchanting. So so so busy! Full of life. Lots of shops selling scarves and tourist bits and bobs. They will all tell you it's 100% cashmere!! It's not! A super walk around with lots of colour to see.
All in one. It near place from hotel Nepalaya visited for eat'shopping and music nice to walk around for chill out

You can't visit Kathmandu without visiting Thamel. Kathmandu is a crazy, busy city but Thamel is the centre of that universe! Narrow streets, dodging cars, people and overhanging electric cables you can see a great cross section of life, shop to your hearts content, eat some great food, find books and music you never thought you would find and even find little peaceful havens to enjoy a quiet drink before venturing back out into the mad world that is Thamel. If culture is your bag then there is also plenty of history to see and we hope people stay safe and the area returns to some normality after the dreadful events there earlier in 2015!
Amazing. I loved Thamel. Tiny bustling and winding streets - I loved getting lost here! Definitely recommend spending some time here if you visit Kathmandu.

You can get all your take home gifts here. This is what we were told is the "Tourist" area of Kathmandu and is so worth a visit. It is colourful, busy, noisy and the shops are full of lovely things. Visit the felt shops for slippers, bags and scarves, Pilgrims book shop which sells vast quantities of gifts as well as an amazing stock of books and pashmina and t-shirt shops by the bucketload. Also a good of number trekking shops for your last minute walking poles or warm hats for Poon Hill. A host of restaurants and cafes to stop and have lunch in and lots of ATM's
quite good. thamel ..its place which one is very famous for tourist but its very crowded not too clean everywhere but some place inside thamel (sagarmatha sub way ) its wow.. amazing.

Crazy whacky area, full of life and funky people.... Just spend an evening here, get a taxi and just walk around. Loads of bars, hotels, restaurants and backpackers. We got short changed by a shopkeeper so be sure to strongly state the value of the note you are paying with.

Is a "movie place" where you are the real artist.. Thamel is the most "cosmopolitan" place in all Kathmandu, pehaps in all Nepal. Their streets are full with hotels, restaurant, bookshops, and handcraft stores, where you will be involved. Streets are safe till "the dark" get them "suspicious".Take as reference streets, around "Kathmandu Guest House" (which is a very good hotel).

Really an "ideal" area for tourists :). There's really no better place I can think of for tourists in Kathmandu than this vibrant area in a labyrinth of narrow streets (I noticed they're narrower on the east side than on the west side) lined with four-or-five-story buildings on both sides of the streets where you'll find shops mostly geared toward tourists such as those selling clothing & fabrics, travel necessities and decorative items like masks & statuettes (if you're after key chains & postcards for souvenir like me, there's a very nice shop for that near the small Chhetrapati Chowk roundabout at right about the center of this area); and especially for budget travellers like me, this area "abounds" with guesthouses & small hotels in the range of like US$ 10 to 15 a night or maybe even cheaper for a dorm room (I stayed at Rosebud Hotel near Chhetrapati Chowk as mentioned above for about US$45 total for three nights in my "own room" and that price even included the bus tickets to & from the Sonauli border! A travel agency on the Nepal side of the border arranged everything for me after crossing from India).And as for the convenience of getting to major "must see" tourist sights from this area: the main Durbar Square (also called the Basantapur Durbar Square after the Basantapur Tower at Hanuman Dhoka Palace located on the square) is only about a ten-minute walk south from the Chhetrapati Chowk at the center of the area (as mentioned above); Garden of Dreams is just like a five-minute walk east from the eastern edge of the area (which itself is about ten minutes from Chhetrapati Chowk); and Swayambhunath Stupa hill is about a half-hour walk west from the area.

Shop till you drop. If you like shopping this is the place. With hundreds of shops with too many varieties from bags, scarfs, trekking stuffs, indian clothings and many more. Its very very cheap as soecially if you like swals..pure wool swals are cheap here. There are statues in many form and qualities. You just walk and shop and there are lots of taxi around. They do have foods but i advice you not to eat at the road side stalls..

Vibrant and full of life. Thamel is a great place to spend a little time. Drink in the atmosphere, pop in to a café or bar, don't just go for the well known or written up ones. Take time to explore. It is a vibrant place. Once tourists start to return it will be a whole other world of crazy traffic, beeping horns and excitement. Loved the time I spent here.

shopping . cashmere the natural plain colour ones large size is around 750-800 rps do not pay more than that amount. tourist bus to pokhara cost Ard 750 (baba travel) buy the tickets in the morning at 6.30am at the tourist bus park. food to eat here: sandwich (must add yak cheese), there is sajan restaurant which sells fried momo for 90rps, there is a nice naan shop by the name of something tandoori. For those printed cotton t-shirts, u can bargain till Ard 300 rps. for northface gore-text jacket with removable fleece lining is Ard 3400rps, thick down jacket Ard 5300rps.

Not worth your time. If you are looking for cheap clothing and counterfeit goods then this is the place to go to. Streets are narrow with bikes and cars fighting for space and trying to push you out of the road. Would not go there again.

Very lively place for night life. Very lively place, multi cuisines restaurants, number of eateries,right destination if you want to hangout
Car and motorcycle horn can be irritating.

A great place to get lost!. Thamel is definitely touristy with lots of small shops selling trinkets and gifts. However there's not a lot of tourists around at the moment (possibly scared off by the earthquake and fuel crisis) but this doesn't make is a quiet place to visit, as there's still busy traffic and lots of locals. Despite the lack of tourists traders aren't pushy and don't mind bartering. If you venture into Thamel make sure you keep your bearings as its easy to get lost.

An exciting place, friendly people. I frequently visit this place when I visit Kathmandu. It has many thing to offer. The shopping areas arranged in narrow gullies, bargain shopping, and getting antiques are interesting. There are some historic places and temples nearby. A short walk to southward of Thamel will take you to very different scenery with old buildings lined-up so tightly and narrow road. You may also experience fresh vegetables market in the streets. People are very friendly and helpful when you lost navigation. Once is not enough as I had multiple trip to this area and had different experiences.

Loads of interesting shops. This is the area of Kathmandu to wander around. There are 1000s of shops with crafts, fake North Face gear, books, paintings...it is endless fun to just poke around, get lost, then hire a cycle rickshaw to take you back home.

Touristy but fun. Yes, Thamel caters to tourists, especially the backpack and older-tourist crowd, but you definitely get a feel for urban Nepali life here, regardless. *Very* easy to get lost amid the narrow, wandering, and crowded streets, so a city map is helpful. Lots of reasonably priced places to eat and rest and escape the noise, most with wifi.....

Bustling Activity of Every Sort. Narrow streets and alleys filled with street vendors, shops and an international crowd. Great food all over. A feast for the senses. Helpful Hint - take a map or be very attentive to landmarks, because you *will* get lost otherwise.

Shop, shop, shop. If you need to pick up some gifts or just want to walk around and experience the sounds and business of haggling and selling, this is the place. It does have a charm if this is what you are looking for. Several good restaurants and the palace is nearby. It is work a day of fun, if you have extra time on your hands. If you have limited time, spend it in the mountains!

Kathmandu Chaos and Colour. Thamel is a network of narrow streets of shops, restaurants, cafe's, trekking agencies and much more. You will see some amazing old temples amongst the squares and alleyways, very interesting place, so much colour, vibrancy and life. there are many cheap hotels and hostels together with a couple of up market places which can be quite pricey, there are great bars and and a thriving live music scene. Places not to miss include Zibro live music bar and The Garden of Dreams which is a little bit of green heaven in amongst the busy street life. Watch out for the scooters, taxis and rickshaw drivers who are constantly running through the streets. It's a noisy place but offers great opportunities to buy excellent knock off trekking gear and souvenirs. There is little evidence of the earthquake in April until you get to the Durbar tower which is so sad and you will see gaps in the street line where older buildings used to stand. All in all Thamel is recovering, at least on the outside, it now needs people to visit and help the economy to recover.

GREAT ENERGY AND AMBIANCE . Normally I hate crowded narrow places and markets but I found Thamel to be full of genuine Namaste's and smiles. I didn't find the vendors pushy or creepy...they were the exact opposite. If you're trying to find a specific restaurant I suggest asking for directions or taking a rickshaw. People are very friendly and if they can help you they will. The street decorations, signs, smells, lights, music, horns, and bells were rather delightful. Indulge.

The life of KTM. Thamel is where the action is. If you are a short time visitor to the city then do not even think about staying anywhere else. The place has lots of music, dancing and life on the street
Thamel is business!. In Thamel you find Shops for all you Need and for Souvenirs as well. It is the City and Center of Kathmandu!
Fantastic shopping and great value. Amazing deals to be had for all budgets, outdoor gear, shawls, in fact anything you might need for your trip of a lifetime

Good fun !. Vibrant place !
Really nice to walk around Thamel, get lost among the hundreds little streets, stop here to drink a lassi, there to eat some mo:mo or samosa, smell all the spices at the colorful market... awesome !

Was Wonderful. The last time I came here the square was beautiful, now its all gone. Gone in sixty seconds more like it when the earthquake struck. It is very sad to see these once beautiful building turned to rubble. sad,

Narrow cozy streets. . If your in Kathmandu, you're most likely to stay in Thamel. Although cars and scooters are allowed to drive through this neighbourhood, the streets are somewhat calm and cozy. I really like this area of Katmandu.
A shoppers paradise. You can spend a whole day browsing the delights of Thamel and take regular stops to have refreshments.
Lovely place. Lovely place to stay a couple of nights. You can get lost in all the little streets, but you can always ask the way and they help you in no time.

A GREAT place to go Christmas shoppimg.. There isnt much that you CANT buy, or eat in this district. Everyone in the world comes to Kathmandu to see Everest, and they bring their food with them. Nepal was my 51st country, and I have NEVER seen such a variety of food. You name it, its here. Schedule a few days just to wander through this medieval rabbit warren of shops, bars and charming restaurants. You'll be glad you did.

Thamel district. Bustling and fascinating, this is a wonderful part of Kathmandu to visit. In fact, I chose to stay in a hotel in this district and really enjoyed the immediate access to great restaurants, wonderful shopping and amazing sites. A rickshaw ride, which you can't walk 5 feet without finding, can take you anywhere you like for every cheap. When I get back to Nepal I plan to stay here again.
I love the crazy busy Thamel. Its hectic and crazy (less so at the moment with the fuel crisis on) but its alive, so much to do, and great people to meet. And amazing restaurants - 5 stars!

Greta place to be before trekking! . We arrived at Thamel the day before our trekking and we bought all our gears and equipment here in two hours. If you think it's funny with a little bargaining and like trekking equipment this is the place for you!
Interesting colourful place. Colourful places and very interesting. I found some bargained goods that I looked for, at good prices.

Great place to shop!. Thamel is a tourist district in Kathmandu. It is full of shops: souvenirs as well as gear for those going on to treks in the Himalayas. Any kind of food (pizza, New Orleans, etc.) can be found there as well as many places to exchange money or get cash from ATMs. It may not be the most charming spot in the city though!

One of the more popular tourist/traveler stops in Kathmandu --. Great food choices, wonderful shopping and a myriad of cultural opportunities, Thamel is one of the favorite parts of Kathmandu. We thoroughly enjoyed it for our meals and for souvenirs to take home. And if you're climbing or trekking and need anything, there is a shop that has it in this area.
Shopping. Thamel houses many good restaurants including local delicacies, shops selling unique and local stuffs. Good for bargaining.

Thamel is charming and fun. We visited Kathmandu as tourists, and we felt Thamel was an untidy showcase made for us. It had the feel of a crowded, low-cost neighborhood providing services to budget travelers. Most shops and even hotels are comparatively small but clean, and the narrow streets are rough with potholes, obviously not designed for such heavy taxi-rickshaw-truck-motorcycle traffic. We had to bring back small and inexpensive souvenirs for about 20 people, and the task was easy. Nepalese have created shops or restaurants that are suited to Western languages, likes or needs, yet they remain entirely Nepalese. Some shops are giving way to more formal, modern multi-storied arcades with higher prices reflecting the higher rent. Prices for items such as T-shirts are actually higher than in areas just outside of Thamel. The shopping and tourist area has spread out of Thamel into adjacent areas, particularly to the south. It is easy to walk from Thamel to the Durbar Square area. The availability of many shops selling similar items makes it easy for comparative shopping. We usually discovered the lowest price for items only when we held firm on our price and walked away without the merchant calling us back. We feel there is something for almost every tourist in Thamel. We felt sad when we realized that we had explored every one of the twisting and winding streets in Thamel and there were no more new shops to be found.

Bets Place ever to Hangout. It was my first trip last month to Nepal and had booked my hotel in Thamel. I have no idea about this place but just heard of it like the best place for the travelers and can get almost everything nearby. It was more than i thought about this place.. It was very cool and had lot of places to stay, to eat and to enjoy in the bars and the clubs around. And most of all Tourist Attraction were just in walking distance you can reach. Had great time there. Wish i can get back there and have some Sandwiches. ;)

Bustling Thamel. This is the hearth of Kathmandu and is just so busy with shops, cafes, bars d restaurants. It’s a great place for souvenirs and for meeting up with people from all parts of the world. Just be careful where you eat and drink is safe. It has lots of decent massage parlors as well as some iffy ones. It is a must visit when in Nepal.
busy but awesome . just an other word . impossible to follow your map anyway it was so funny to hang out across the short street. price and people perfect .

A sSopper's Smorgasbord. Streets are crowded with people and lots of shops. If you like to shop for cashmere, and other local crafts this is the place, there are also many good and cheap Indian, Chinese, Nepali, Thai Italian and Continental restaurants, you can go every where in Thamel by foot.

Exciting, exotic and just plain fun.. Thames is not "real" Kathmandu as it is absolutely oriented towards tourists, BUT it is fantastically fun. I enjoy the chaos, the eclectic stores and restaurants, the fact that you can buy virtually anything here and of course the delightful Nepali people who live and work there. I fail to understand how people can go to Kathmandu and not spend time in Thamel.

Tourist Trap. Originally was the hippie area of Kathmandu... now is a place for tourist or for post-hippie. good to do shopping (you must negotiate the price.. always) or to go to drink in the evening.
Shop till you drop. Great values in pashminas, carpets and other textiles. Very good for earrings and necklaces. Buy you t-shirts here, most can offer custom embroidery.

Busy, Loud and fun. This is the main tourist area of Kathmandu and is a fun vibrant area. The narrow streets are full of little shops with such a wide variety of goods. You can buy almost anything you need / want and will find plenty you didn't even know you wanted. You have to keep a constant watch and take care for it is packed with bikes and trishaws and pedestrians. The hawkers add to the vibrancy but some can be a bit too pushy and annoying.
Nepal experience . Even though Kathmandu is hectic and dusty, it is an exciting city to visit! Each day brings something new even when you think you have had enougj

Awesome . Great little hub for travellers have everything you need. Super markets m, restaurants and markets. All closed pretty early just watch out while walking the motorbikes intentionally try and hit you at night

Tourist ghetto in Kathmandu. Noisy and congested. This is the place to be when visiting Kathmandu. The narrow streets throng with tourists and it is possible to buy anything you want - at a price.Post earthquake the place was sadly very quiet
very central market. Thamel is area you can get everything. all hotels, market, pub, paper market are nearby. if you want to enjoy shopping you should stay in thamel area. plenty of hotels available.

Hustle and Bustle Thamel. Its great for tourist, can find local product with good quality of sleeping bag or dawn jacket here, outdoor shops and decide buy fake or ori clothing/trekking gears. Many variety of restaurants, cafes, some bakeries, mini markets, bookshops etc. Just take your time, no need to rush to buy your needs.

Shop, watch, take pics, get lost.... If you're into shopping, you'll find it hard to stop. If you're into photography, same thing. If you just want to watch colors and chaos around you, you're in the right place. But if you have a tight schedule or plan, forget it. This place has its own rhythm.

Busy shopping area. Busy busy area of small streets full of shops all touting for your business. Be prepared to haggle to get a better deal. Good shopping but in a chaotic area.
Surrounded by taxis, mopeds and rickshaws.

Some hidden gems among tons of shops. There are a lot of shops of all kinds in Thamel, but if you dig through, there are some real gems where you can buy local stuff at very low prices, some of them are hidden behind narrow dark passageways.BTW, I was constantly approached by people on the street who wanted to hook me up for some weed/hachis and so on, so be prepared for that...

horrible traffic, good dvd prices, lots of shops, travel agents, restaurants available. The fuel crisis has jumped up transport prices, so that makes staying in one place an option, and Thamel has lots of shops, restaurants, hotels, travel agents, mail services, all in walking distance. Streets are narrow and often crowded, so keep eyes open.

Very touristy and over-priced. Didn't enjoy Thamel very much. Full of tourists and everything is super overpriced. Walk a little further toward Kathmandu Durbar Square and you can find everything in Asan Market for at least 1/5 the price. It's also nice to interact with more Nepalese people there.

Noice, colorful, people, shopping... What you would expect from Thamel!. It is busy, colorful, lots of people, shopping, tourists... But these are what made Thamel so electric and energetic...! Don't let those sour reviews spoil your experience or discourage you to visit Thamel. Your trip will not be completed without Thamel.There are many shops, restaurants, bars... You can find pretty much everything here. You do need to bargain... 1/2 of asking price is a good start... Pashmina, scarfs, clothings, luggages, etc. When you get tired of shoppings and and hustle of thamel, check out the garden of dreams which is a few blocks from Thamel.

Backpacker central.. The backpacker region of Kathandu. A lot of over priced tourist shops, backpacker hostels and some good restaurants. Stay here if you're on a budget, try to avoid the shop owners who beg you into their stores.
a labyrinth of shops. Very crowdy place with thousand of shops to visit. A lot of restaurants with wifi, and reasonable prices.

Most happening place in Nepal. Thamel is main attraction for the tourists who visit Nepal. Here u can enjoy the Nepalese style food and many other varieties. You can doShopping, massage and many more !!
Wasn't a fan of the market.... Found this a bit too touristy and crowded... I would not avoid it unless you're interested in checking out local shopping.
Great shopping but great ready for lots of tourists. This is THE backpacker ground of Kathmandu. Good for cheap hotel rates and shopping but beware of non-stop noise and tourists everywhere.

Center if everything for tourists. Thamel is the Center of the universe. Everything is here. Supermarket, souvenir shops, restaurants, bars, massage, etc. Everything is here. The only catch is we need to be a good negotiator to avoid rip off!

not a big fan of Thamel. Perhaps it is because I live in Kathmandu, but I find Thamel one of the least interesting and most annoying parts of town, especially when compared to the Valley's many treasures, like Patan for example. While, on the good side, Thamel does have excellent restaurants, it is too clearly a tourist haven for my, perhaps jaded, taste. The tourist items and souvenirs you can find there you can also find in more interesting places, such as Boudhanath, and Patan. In Boudha they may be more expensive, but in Patan they are probably cheaper since many of the craftsmen, particular for silver jewelry and Buddhist statues, live there.
Get Lost in Here!. Shops galore. Merchants beckoning you in. Lots of "North Fake" clothing. A bit overwhelming, but a great taste of the city. For a little more local reality head over to Asom.

Staying in Thamel. Found staying in Thamel was the best choice made. Having read lots of bad reviews about overpriced restaurants - (not true unless you go the the best, i paid average about 1000 rupees for 2 people for lunches and dinners), dusty and heaps of cars and motorcycles - (but what place doesn't). Kids selling stuff to smoke - (simple say no thanks and move along I say) i would highly recommend staying here due to people being so friendly and location is perfect for where ever you want to go in Kathmandu, plus night time I felt safe in this area.

amazing place. in this area you find all shops for tourist, from pashmina to handicraft you can find all in this area that after the end of "freak street " as attraction all was carry in this area from about30 years

Colour, noise, bargains, and more. The Tamel area of Kathmandu is the most visited part of the city for visitors. There are literally dozens of trekking outfitters, jewelry stores, restaurants and cafés, touristy shops, etc. Every shop lets you barter for better prices. Best coffee in the area was the Himalayan Java, which is located in Mandala Alley. Great coffee, strong Wi-Fi signal, and there's even a guitar sitting at the entrance for anyone who wants to play it. The best restaurant we found was the Gaia restaurant which is on the south edge of the Thamel area. Varied menu, great food, good service. Lots of noise, honking of horns, and crowds in the Thamel area which just adds to this colorful, frenetic, chaotic part of the city.

Touristic but a must see. Thamel is very touristic but its a place you shouldn't miss in Kathmandu . Its a great place to meet other travelers and there are plenty of hotels for all budgets. Great place for shopping before going to the mountains :)

Lively district!. Chose to stay in this area as there are many eateries and shopping to be done. However, things sold are similar. Shops are being repeated. They are mainly selling tees, shawls, jewelries, masks, traditional knives. You can try bargaining to get the best price. Very lively place to be in with both locals and foreigners!

Throbbing area of activity. Thamel is a place that defines KTM for the tourist. Some of the finest restaurants and bars reside cheek by jowl with the seedy and dark ones - all at once. Thamel is a throbbing centre of activity in KTM. Close to the old palace grounds, and loaded with shops and stores, one cannot visit KTM without taking in Thamel.

A contagious bazaar. Thamel is abuzz with alleyways and market shopping opportunities that had me fixated from the day I arrived. The banter and chatter of the shopkeepers is constant without any indication of offence taken upon refusal. Prices are expected to be negotiated with the entertainment increasing with the pleas for tourists to accept their price [but of course you halve their initial asking price - never pay first price mentioned]
I absolutely love Thamel. Would come back again & again!. We absolutely loved our time in Thamel. We would come back tomorrow if we could! Would thoroughly recommend visiting here!

Tourist hub. Main tourist market with many hotel's, restaurant and shops nearby. I stayed at avataar hotel which is very nice with helpful staff and best location. You can find lots of restaurant and pub in thamel.
Best tourist city. A.small.but quite interesting tourist city where you find good restaurant clubs and shoppingPoints.No need car and small roads have shops both sides.
Tourist ghetto.. A place to shop for trekking gear, eat in overpriced restaurants and be attacked by cycle riksha men who try to sell hash.Zero authenticity.
Great locatiin for shopping and dining. Have stayed in Thamel twice. Walking distance to everything. Felt safe walking around shopping. Great area to stay in whIle visiting Kathmandu area.
Loved Thamel !!. Thamel is definitely the hub of Kathmandu !! It is so alive and full of character , not to mention the amazing restaurants and shopping available. Glad to have stayed in Thamel !!

Crazy and bustling market centre of Kathmandu. Wow!! Have just spent a couple of weeks in Nepal and quite a few days in the Thamel area of Kathmandu. It is abuzz with many different types of stores selling varying wares and the shopkeepers of which are very keen to entice you in to buy from them. All this coupled with thronging crowds and the ever present motorbikes, cars and rickshaws down narrow laneways makes for an exciting and fun experience.

The life of Kathmandu. Thamel is a hive of activity, noise, bars, resturants, shops, trekking companies, tourists, cars, and everything else you can imagine! A true whole body experience! If you are heading to Kathmandu then stay at least some of the time in Thamel (I would recommend Hotel Access Nepal) as this is something not to be missed; and you are within walking distance to a lot of the other attractions.

If you can live with the noice and the busy streets, then this is a cultural high.. There is a lot of noise, people, cars, and motorbikes. All sharing the same streets. But there are so many things available that can saturate any need for souvenirs and interesting things to bring home. And the life is an experience in itself. This is a must for Kathmandu, and if you do not like the noise, crowdedness, or the dust, then you should probably not go to Nepal.

A Whirlwind of Sounds, Aroma and Colours. .Background: Thamel is a commercial neighbourhood in Kathmandu. Sprawled over a large area, it is distinguished by its narrow alleyways, overflowing with assorted goods and busy hawkers. Various shops, businesses and eateries line the streets. Pilgrims and visitors also crowd its lanes. In modern times, it has turned into a hotspot centre for tourism, especially as a base for trekkers and mountaineers.PROS: It is in the middle of the city so quite accessible to pedestrians, although it can be challenging to negotiate with cars, trucks, motorcycles or rickshaws. It is also quite extensive so one day is not enough to explore this place. It is comparable to a Middle Eastern souk or an Asian marketplace. Whatever you call it, it cannot be called boring. Everything is here.CONS: For all its extensive sprawl, it would take you some time to orient yourself. I got lost my first few days. What helped me was to memorize the different kinds of streamers strung across each alleyway (silver, white, red, no streamers and so forth) along the way to and from my hotel to Durbar Square. Sometimes, the dusty roads turn muddy after a rainfall.Verdict: Worth a visit. To some, it is a ghetto; to others, a fascinating place. In some sense, if you want to go anywhere in Kathmandu, you really can't avoid Thamel. Let its whirlwind of sounds, aroma and colour beckon to you. Your choice. Grade A-minus..

Very busy. This is a very busy area. Lots of shops and people walking in the streets. Also you have to be careful to watch out for the people on motorized bikes because there are lots of them and they drive fast down the crowded streets. Otherwise, it's great for sights, and for buying stuff if you choose.

Wild and colourful. Tourist shops abound - but all of the streets are colourful and with so much going on. There are temples and rickshaws and all manner of strange things.... You will be harassed to buy stuff. Be firm & say "no". Haggle if you wish - the assumption is that you will then buy. Do not accept the first price!

Your home away from home. Less an attraction and more a home base while your in Nepal, Thamel is the hub of all things a traveler will want or need in Kathmandu. This is the best place to find a place to stay, anything from a few dollars (you can still find a bed for 500npr) up to hundreds of dollars (why bother!). The places is packed with restaurants of all types and budgets, there are trekking shops, gift shops and the best range of book shops in Asia. If you haven't planned your trek, then this is the place to find an agency (shop around, ask questions). It's all in this amazing place. Make friends, meet locals, have a beer, get lost in the maze of streets. My advise is to take your time with the place, get to know it. Find a local bar/cafe (New Orleans Cafe is my favorite) and become a regular. the fun thing is that when your done with your trek, and you come back to Thamel, you'll bump into just about every other trekker you met on your trek, because everyone ends up back here in the end!

Crowd and disappointed place. Thamel is toutist Place and good , many many tourist are enjoying at street, many shops targeted for tourist goods but very rough dealing, too much bargain, at evening very crowd and very disapointed for walking people normally it is difficult to go there with family, many street boy harresing to the tourist to asking about prostitution, the dance restaurant are cheated to the customer at night

Great night life. Whether you want to chill and have a drink while watching the game, have a date, amazing food, or dance the night away. This busy and lively street is the hub place for foreigners. Carefully designed to cater to all party goers, the place is safe and have well lit streets that makes everything feel like home. Come party there!

Even in December it was fascinating!. It was cold during Christmas time in December; however there were lots of shops in the night and many nightlife places playing very good live music and serving good western food.
