The Happening Spot. If you like a million small shops to visit and crowds stay away. If you enjoy the raw world of a fast paced tourist area there is much to like. I will stay there when I return.
Touristic Place. There are lots of gift shops around this place. I hope they don't have to much damage from the Earthquake

Zabojad Exploring Nepal. Thamel is the heart of Katmandu. Headquarters of Exploring Nepal pvt. Office of my friends Magda & Sujan. Here we go into the rental of bikes discoveries of Souvenirs Shops and small streets with Roof tops Cafés where to enjoy Nepali Delicatesse and share a beer after trekking in the Mountains. Let's stop at Bamboo Club in Thamel...Happy Sharing Happy Inside

Great shopping streets. You will find many different kind of art, jewerly made with real turquoise, silver and coral, to wool clothing, t-shirts, Buddhist art, stuff to go the mountains. And there are also cafes and small bars.

all around tourist place. the place is famous for tourist, all area is souvenir market, cafe bars restaurants hotels. the place is must visit in time of nepal new year. we visited in that day
there is a huge gathering and celebration of new year with loud live music and entertainment

Senses on Overload. Thamel is amazing. All 5 senses are operating on overload. Incense mixed with food, dust, the smell of endless stacks of curios, exhaust fumes, and general organised chaos is a must. Just laugh and go with the flow (which means any direction at any given time lol) - don't be in a rush - ever! Its magical!

A definite MUST visit in Kathmandu. This is one of those places on earth that everybody must visit. The sensory overload of sounds, sights and smells will stay with you for a very long time. A day is not enough! Only after my 4th visit did I begin to really appreciate it. Make time to "drink" everything in... stop and enjoy... take a lot of photos because in that way you can enjoy the whole experience even when you are not there anymore... don't buy anything at the first shop... you might find it much cheaper deeper in Thamel... Watch where you are walking, so many vehicles, people, things obstructing the road, unprotected holes in the road... Know where to get a taxi again... make sure you have your hotel or guest house address at hand... a telephone number will help... make sure you ask your hotel or guest house roughly what the rate of the taxi might be... eat, drink coffee and make sure you take bottled water with...find a place to sit and enjoy the sights as they pass you by!All that remains is to enjoy it to the full!!!And don't forget the souvenirs (I always buy a painting)

Touristy and similar shops. We went for a stroll. All the shops have similar items ie Tshirts, caps, carpets & shawls from Kashmir mainly and art pieces.Lovely art.But all art items can be bought at Boudanath Stupa - lots of variety.

Not sure what the fuss is about. It's the so called shopping and fun district of Kathmandu. But I wasn't impressed with it. The roads are narrow and dirty. The traffic is merciless and shopkeepers know that people want bargains and they always quote the price higher than what they would eventually sell at.

Watch where you walk!. Thamel is a very busy place! If you are in to that, or in to shopping, Thamel would be great. I'm into neither of those things (although my wife is).There are a ton of places to eat in Thamel, and they are all within walking distance.All in all, it wasn't a *bad* place, but it's busy (lots of traffic and people). If that's not your thing, I'd stay away.

Worth a visit. From all that i read of Thamel, i realised it's hyped. I was quite surprised by the pollution as well in KTM. Facemask needed! However, Thamel still has it's charm. Bargain and bargain hard! Do visit Sam's Bar next to Kathmandu Guest House.

Hustly and bustly. Loved everything about Thamel. Really chaotic and knock off trekking kit in every other shop, standard touristy souvenirs at hyped up prices and great fun haggling. real trekker/backpacker vibe and great fun exploring over a couple of days.

Best place to stay. This is the tourist part of town put also the nicest part of Kathmandu. A must see and in my opinion the only place to stay the night. It has everything there, lots of hotels around $25 a night, lots of shopping, lots of nightlife. I felt safe there traveling alone.

Tourist and trekking shopping. Although Thamel is a large tourist area with tons of shops and people trying to sell you the usual tourist goods, we had a great time bartering and shopping here. We did all our last minute trekking shopping here too, this is the only place in Kathmandu that we were able to find cheap trekking equipment. There are a few original trekking shops, between Thamel and the Garden of Dreams, like North Face. The knock off shops within Thamel have a big range of equipment and clothing at very good prices, we used a few items for our EBC climb and had no problems. The tourist shops sell the usual items, we found most of the items very comparably to buying in Patan or Bouda. Just a note, not one of the hotels we stayed in was immune to the noise pollution that is prevalent in this suburb. Thamal is also within walking distance to the Durbar Square via the Asan market, which I would highly recommend if you would like to browse through street filled with every day Nepali items. We stayed in the area for 2 days, we found this enough time to browse through the area, shop and visit the Asan market.

The nexus of everything touristic. Every tourist want and need can be met here but the getting out of the way of loudly honking motorcycles is nerve-wracking. The few riders benefit and everyone else suffers. Also, prices are good but the shopping is very repetitive and it's hard to find higher quality stuff. If they made it pedestrian-only or even permit-only (rumored) it would be a 3 but right now it's not a very nice place to be! At least the "sell" is softer than India, Morocco, etc.
shopping and tourist area. the place to be. lots of hotels and shops. some wonderful bars (Buddha Bar) and little shops for the souvenirs. I loved this place. it felt very safe and fun.

The area to start when you stay in Kathmandu. Find a guesthouse or hotel in this area and you'll glad you did. Everything you need is here. Yes, it's somewhat crowded and the passing motorbikes and cars on the narrow streets are annoying at times but this is where you want to start from, especially if this is your first visit as it was mine.

Happening place. Here they have Classy and modern shops and further down a place where locals do their grocery, eat and shop. Popular for backpackers. Local happening bars! Souvenirs to bargain, fresh meat to vegetables and temples. Love it madness.

Busy heart of tourist hippy Kathmandu. Thamel has to be a destination and we usually spend a few days there. It's streets are busy, polluted an full'of interest. But the shops mainly sell tat, gems have to be looked out. It's become much more polluted in recent years, and although most places go quiet by 12 midnight, the barking dogs make sleep difficult if you're over 50!

Beware vendors and traffic. They practically ran the place! You get bullied to the sidewalks but cars, motorbikes, and bikes, each trying to out horn so as to startle you. And if you don't jump,out of your skin, the vendors will hone in at you. Fakes trek gears at quarter of the price you pay back home but beware of the quality.
Bustling. All you need for your travelling needs.. money changers, various hotels, restaurants, camping/trekking equipment at excellent prices (need to bargain)
shopping haven. felt real and not too touristy, although a major draw for international visitors. traffic almost too close for comfort but part of the charm (keep tight leash on wayward kids)

Bad Impression. Never stay in Thamel. i am so much disappointed about this place. People are everywhere, so busy place. people who have vehicle the always blow their vehicle's horn. each 5 sec i heard people are honking. they come right in front of you and they come very close and ask in a very small voice "you want some stuff?" Bad Impression.
Tourist hub of Nepal. You can find all the necessary tourism related goods and services at Thamel. A wide range of market place for the tourists.

Mad, mad and crazy. I've been in Thamel for two days now - long enough to:- develop a cough from the endless dust and exhaust fumes -be offered drugs at least ten times by the world's politest dealers-buy a shameless knock off North Face puffer for $25 NZD -enjoy a different bunch of restaurants every day and pay between $3 and $7 per mealIt's insane, but has real charm. Practice your 'no thank you's', grab a day bag, and spend all day wandering around - you never know what you'll find!

Tourist Paradise. Well, if you are in kathmandu for visit purpose, you are probably staying in thamel. Its a town that never sleeps. There are hundreds of hotels to choose from. Wide variety of restaurant are available offering all sorts of cuisines. No worry for shopping as well. Every lane is filled up with a shop, where you could buy almost anything. Its a paradise for tourists.
Love the streets of Thamil!. Thamil is a must go for street shopping. It is simply amazing and there are just so many things to see and buy!

packed street. in this street u will find everything. i bought tea and shirts for my brother. u need to bargain a lot to get a good price since they dont put price tags and increase the prices for tourists. u will find everything and it is crowded area. a lot of pollution in the city
Shopping. This is good place for window shopping as for Indian most of the things sold are imported from, India and sold at higher price.
Great vibe all around. Very touristy neighborhood but full of nice guesthouses, great restaurants. Just have to be patient towards the hordes of hasslers!

Backpacker's Paradise. This is a super crowded place for the tourists, from the locals, and by the locals and of the tourists if you get the drift. Everything here is geared towards feeding, and quenching the hunger, thirst, curiosity for the backpacking traveller or for the curious foreigner. They have a few touristy souvenir shops and lots of choice places to eat , drink, listen to music, browse the net etc. It's tremendously noisy and crowded but it's the heart of Tourist Kathmandu. It's good for an after work dinner and drink....if you like a city kind of night life....but it's not for relaxation. Many cafes with Lavazza coffee ( you'll need this) specially if you're out and about, as the coffee served in offices and meetings are pretty terrible. Many nice italian restaurants and some expaty Nepali ones as well.

Magic in the street. A must go if you go to Kathmandu (anyways your hotel will be there). It's a pleasure to walk in the street and do a bit of shopping. I should stop myself because if not I will buy it all!Lot of different corners can surprise you.

Shops and restaurants as far as the eyes can see.... A dazzling array of shops and restaurants for every taste and budget. Camping and trekking gear, clothing, jewelry, music, books and souvenir, you name it and a shop around the corner will have it. The narrow streets are swarming with shoppers, motorcycles and cars, so keep your elbows in and watch your step. It is an intoxicating atmosphere if you are into shopping and/or people watching...

Vibrant centre of Kathmandu. Thamel is full of interesting shops, art studios and restaurants - and even cultural sites like stupas. You can easily spend a few hours to experience the inner city of Kathmandu.

lovably touristy. just a quick tip- we visited Thamel on our first day in Kathmandu, and were told not to buy anything as everything would be cheaper in Patan and Bhaktapur. as such, i deferred my trinket-acquisition until literally the last hours of our trip, when we eventually returned to thamel:I found Patan and Bhaktapur a lot less accessible than Thamel, with us wandering down side streets and getting impressively lost, to find the few souvenir/trinket-oriented stores charging more or less the same prices as in thamel; and you're afraid to walk away from these stores, in case you never find another, so your bargaining power is greatly reduced.The density of shops in Thamel makes it easy to find what you need, and [because there are so many shops and you can flit between them] at an ultimately cheaper price. while it might be true that the savvy traveler can pick up good deals in Patan and Bhaktapur, I found the attempt to be totally harrowing. Maybe next time!

Crazy. Crowded, hectic, dirty, bustling, and vibrant, Thamel is a great experience. The narrow streets are lined with shops selling all sorts of stuff, so it's nice for souvenir shopping. There are also lots of eateries around.

what happened?. So sorry to see that all the original wooden windows and doors and traditional architecture has been replaced with generic concrete and glass and one scarf/fake NorthFace/clothing score after another. I loved the old Kathmandu and mourn its passing....

Good bazar. Stayed in Hotel Taishan in Thamel. The entire road is full of shopping of all material from Rudraksha to clothes to travel accessories to travel agents and everything a traveller needs Could get excellent vegetarian Indian food at Satkar just behind the Hotel. Only we did not have enough time to browse around

a place to both stay and visit. It's everything everyone else has already told you - bustling, hectic, full of people and hidden temples and although much of it is focused on us - the tourists, it's so much fun to just walk around. And although parts are touristy, most of the place is just everyday life for locals - there are so many of them that walking around you don't feel like yet another tourist. Turn a corner into a small alley (of which there are lots and lots) and discover something new all day long. We had a guide for the first half day we arrived to help us get a feel of the place and some historical background and that was great. It's a place full of restaurants, hotels, travel/trekking agencies, but I wouldnt stay anywhere else. You could stay somewhere peaceful outside of town, but unless this just isnt your cup of tea, trying to commute into Thamel would be a nightmare in itself. Traffic can be very slow and air quality is often bad. Stay here to see Thamel, then go somewhere else for the peace and quiet. There is so much within walking distance and there are so many daytrips you can make out of town that make this such a great town to spend a few days in. As you can tell, we loved Kathmandu.

Chaotic bargaining streets. Through these chaotic streets of street vendors there are a variety of shops: a few fixed price shops full of bright and colourful goods. These are the people trying to make a living out of tourism. The shops are bright and colourful and is a great experience where you can make a good deal where both the seller and buyer are happy.

Busy, Noisy, Dusty and Great shopping area for trekking/climbing gears.. My first hour walked in the area nearly send me mad, as noise of Car Horn and all transport tried to squeeze through narrow roads. After that I think, I get used to it as nothing anybody can do about it, you just have to get on with it or stay in your hotel.!!Lots of Cafe and restaurant you can choose to eat or drink. Also plenty of trekking shops which are really good prices. A few items I bought from there, I paid less than half price in UK. Do not forget to bargain it.Nice and friendly people.

Interesting. Even though I was staying on Freak Street Basanthpur, Thamel was a must goe everyday. With its streets busting with life and souveniers, I made some interesting friends and got to take some amazing pics.The lil yak cheese sandiwich shop on the corner of Mandala street, and the friendly guys acorss the sandiwich shop telling me about their business tactics during a hailstorm, bargaining with the dream catcher shop guy infront of Phat Khat restaurant, running around at 5 and being totally lost on the day of rafting to watching the local people ustle around every morning at the vegetable market and temples, I fell in love with Nepal.Even though I liked Thamel, I would rather stay at a hotel in a much quieter place and walk around on foot here. This is the best way to see and experience the strange and fascinating colors and sounds of Thamel.

Love the atmosphere of people going about their daily lives. We love the atmosphere of the Nepali people going about their daily lives. It's also a great place to shop and eat local foods. Local womans handicrafts are very colorful and decorative and some Fair Trade shops promote hand made garments and jewlery. For us it's a great place to visit and stay.
One big shopping spree. One big shopping spree, shop after shop, trekking, clothing, restaurants, cafes etc. Streets crowded and not many touts , nice
Busy, hectic and noisy. This area caters to tourists and trekkers. Purchase a face mask for the incredible smog and dust. It is full of human and mechanical energy so that makes it special.

Tantalizing Thamel. The Thamel area is vibrant, safe and a complete feast for the eyes, the ears and one's nose! If you are into shopping, wether it be for clothes, hiking equipment or curios, then you need look no further. However, having said that, we did venture beyond and it was truly fascinating and it almost felt as if one was in a 2015 medieval city watching the locals going about their everyday activities and routines. When I return to Kathmandu I will definitely spend time exploring the old part of Kathmandu more thoroughly. Truly fascinating. And if you are wanting a break from the hurly burly of this bustling city, try the Himalayan Java restaurant just down the road from the Garden of Dreams - excellent coffee, especially the iced cuppaccino! Enjoy! We did.

Noisy and commercial. During my trip, I stayed in this area. Yes, there are pretty many interesting shops, bars, and restaurants. Since I'm not into shopping, this place seems too noisy and commercial to me. But you may find some cheap trekking stuffs easily. For those shoppers, this might be a perfect place for souvenir.

Ideal place for shopping and dinner. If your hotel is close to Thamel, visit the area everyday for dinner. The options are endless and the place is alive till late night. Safe to visit with young kids even through the traffic becomes heavy at time but narrow road allow only crawling speed. You can spend an entire day walking in the narrow lanes and exploring the entire area.

The heart of the city with many many shops and hotels but with some smelly areas . You need to visit it for sure. The heart of the city with many many shops and hotels but with some smelly areas . You need to visit it for sure

Practise your bargaining skills here. The area consists of a couple of narrow streets lined with shops flogging merchandise that include clothing, jewellery, travel gear and more. As many shops more or less sell the same things be prepared to do a lot of walking while you bargain hunt and to put into practice your innate bargaining skills. As the streets are very narrow keep an eye out for cars and motor bikes.

lifely place- not too big, not too small. Thamel is a great place to visit before and after you go to other cities in Nepal. especially if you go trekking, Thamel is like a "warm up" (to get your supplies) and "cool down" (to eat !!!).

A visitor cannot skip this. A buzzing shoppers paradise, one can say one could get anything here except Mum and Dad, all the replicas are here, plus good walking, trekking gear and many fake brands of clothing, foot wear. Jewellery, bags and some eatery as well.
Must visit place. main shopping area, must visit.lots of restaurants, shops. LOts of hotels alos located as this is a central area for visiting most tourist places. but crowded.

a trinket shopper paradise, Controlled chaos. Thamel is a 700 Rupee cab ride away from the airport. It is a tourist district. There is a vibe that is chaotic as with any part of Kathmandu. However, there are a ton small shops which cater to the tourist crowd and trekkers. Anything from inauthentic North Face, Marmot and other manufacturer's knock off sleeping bags, outdoor gear, boots, gloves, poles of various quality. There are a ton of shops peddling local trinkets, posters, oil and water color paintings, Yak wool scarfs, and other things. Make sure you bargains and be ready to leave the store since a similar item will be sold elsewhere. Start low. The streets are unpaved, the traffic is crazy, be mindful of mopeds. Some great eateries. Plenty of ATMs. Have fun

Too much!. Tamal needs a million words to describe it. It's just too much of a good thing. I wish the store keepers were not so overwhelming on a poor westerner who likes fixed prices and is often just looking and may buy later. There are people everywhere tourists, hagglers, prayers, the lot. Go there but expect to be harangued every few steps otherwise look like a local.

Great shopping and Lively streets. This place had great shopping and very lively streets full of people and action. If you like hustle and bustle and lots of interesting things to look at, you'll like this city. Much better than where we were staying at Hotel Shanker a bit away.

Place for shopping and hotels to stay.. This is like heart of kathmandu city. Too busy..too crowded. You will get lots of hotels to stay according to your budget. Lots of bars..night club. .restaurants. .shops around this place. This place is famous for night life. If you do shopping must do bargain.

The Garden Of The Peaches. IMAGING!!! Tradition Nepali shop and restaurant! Simple street but get a lot fantastic stuff! The stuff getting from east west south north! To eat, drink and be merry very good choice! Become to abandon oneself to a life of pleasure!

Stay here only if you must. We stayed at Thamel at the beginning of our tour (and never came back). We had decided to stay here because we had to catch the bus to Pokhara (bus starts from Kantipath). The streets are very narrow, there is hardly room to walk :-)Bikes and Cars brush past you. It isn't very safe.Added to this is the pollution (most locals wear face masks).Stay here only if you must. This is a place where tourists come for Shopping. The prices are not cheap. You have to bargain hard. :-)Tip: A better option would be to stay at Lalitpur (Patan) and make visits to Thamel!!!

There is something for Everyone. It's an experience. There is something for everyone! From knock off bard items to antics. Great shopping place and hotels. Lots of Tourist walking around. Interns of booking a hotel, depending on your budget, stay in a descent place. Look up the tripadvisor reviews and can't go wrong with Kathmandu Guest house. Mostly It's safe if you stay away from Dance Bar or GoGo bars during night time and massage place. Word of advice, don't matter how tempted you are, don't buy anything(drugs) from any street guy or Rickshaw puller as cops are involved in it too. Once you buy it, you could find your self in a situation where cops are asking to pay thousands to let you go.

Shopping and Tourist Hub of Kathmandu. Thamel is tourist destination. We stayed at Hotel Manang in Thamel. Here there are so many Hotels in Budget range also. Here there are very small and narrow street roads. You can get Padel Rickshaw in Narrow road and Van in some big roads. There are so many Restaurants,Shops of different articles,Exchange Shops of Foreign Currency and Bars too. Thamel is always crowded through out day. A nice area to stay & Shoping for tourist specialy for foreign tourist. Also known for its night life and activities.

Fun area to shop. Thamal is great place to do shopping on local handicrafts, of lokta handmade paper, which has great collections , Also local spice and tea, has very nice pushmina of many range. Himalayas Java is nice place to stop for coffee if you need to take break

just do it. you can pray and walk, and hope you don't get hit,or you canjust say screw it and take your chances, I opted for the latter,it's hectic, crowded, traffic everywhere, street people tryingto sell you everything you couldn't possibly use, shops guesthouses, resturants, crooked streets, total chaos, I lovedit for 2 days, then time to go to pokhara and chill out
Olde Worlde Experience. Like stepping back in time to the bazaars of old. Everything you could possibly want to buy, at great prices. You are spoilt for choice.

Its noisy its streets are crowded its great. The narrow streets of Thamel are packed with shops many selling North Fake Merchandise at very cheap prices . Many even have reduced price items in boxes outside so dive in and get a bargain Many places to eat and drink and at night the music goes until well into the early hours .A great base before you set of exploring the natural beauty of Nepal and to regroup and shop before flying home ,.Dont come here for peace and quiet and if you are lucky be here to Celebrate Holi and get covered in vivid colured powders and water . Its aso great to sit on a rooftop terrace like Bon Appetit and watch the world below . Always something to see

backbackers delight. lovely place to stroll around and buy nepalese handicrafts at a bargain. great pubs and eateries serving local as well as world cuisine, not expensive. superb for budget as well as other travellers.

Mad hustle and bustle. Thamel is the tourist hub of Kathmandu and as such its not really much of a place to dip into the real city, though it does have a fascination of its own. Most of the main hotels and hostels are based here and there are shops servicing the needs of both the hardy trekkers and the casual traveller. There's plenty of interesting souvenir material though haggling can be a waste of effort as most of the shops seem to operate an unspoken cartel, though when you come to think of prices are pretty inexpensive on the whole. A great selection of restaurants covering a range of tastes and cuisines, best to read the individual reviews on here or play for pot luck. Oh and you'll probably find yourself offered certain illegal substances, an offer I didn't take up and wouldn't encourage but if you choose to do so I'd say "caveat emptor"!
bring enough money. A proper commercial place where you can buy A LOT of stuff. Prices can vary depending on how they see you. Make sure to haggle and haggle hard.

Thamel is good for some shopping, but very noisy and busy. I stayed in Thamel off and on over a month in Nepal. It has a load of hotels, shops and restaurants. After seeing more of Kathmandu, on my next trip I think I would stay elsewhere. Perhaps around Patan where it is cleaner and the buildings are more interesting. My hotel in Thamel, Thorong Peak Guesthouse, was very nice but there was a noisy dance club near it at night. Very difficult to navigate around Thamel and the rest of the city as the roads wind like mad and there are almost no street signs. Be prepared for really bad air too, as some days the smog is very heavy. Overall, it was a fun and exotic experience. Be wary of the massage places. Stay away, far away, from Fishtail Spa in Thamel.

great bargain for scarfes and blankets. once you are in any of the numerous shops, you will most likely come out with at least three... whether ist is genuine cashmeere or yak wool.,.. I love all of them

A good place to start exploring Kathmandu. Thamel is a extensive market spread over the narrow streets of central Kathmandu. You may find all kinds of goods including a myriad of souvenirs to bring home, like brass/bronze ware, cashmere and pashmina scarfs, but beware: Pashmina is probably never 100 % or perhaps even normal cashmere wool.

Endless shopping. I visited the biggest street shopping area in Kathmandu. I must say it almost never ends. The place has clothes, antiques, guns, knives, woollen clothes and bars. Prices vary from customer to customer. You have to know the quality you need or could get duped easily. Knowledge is a key to street shopping. I have picked up some wonderful Nepali shaped knives. Woollen clothes are really exciting but be careful. The best in woollen that you should buy is pashmina which is made from mountain goat beard hair. This is one product that you can easily get duped as there are a million varieties. Women can spend a day at least for shopping clothes here. Lots of eateries around to help you manage the hunger bites.

Great place. This is the great place for dinning and shopping night and day both easy to get in and safe to walk at nite also . Most interesting inside the Thamel you can get Rickshaw ride it was awesome experience.

It's busy. My wife and I lived in nepal for a bit and out of all of then arrest we went to this area had the craziest. Way to much going on and theshops here will try to rip you off so you have to know your prices. Not my favorite area of all of them but the best if you want "Americanized." You have to be careful when your in this area because people will try to pick pocket you, sell you drugs and I'm pretty sure I got myself into a meeting with a drugs lord trying to use me as a smuggler. Sketchy!

As a budget traveller area to stay this is great. Not authentic Nepal but has everything you want. Nepali Khao Sanh Rd !. We spent 4 days using Thamel as a base to explore Kathmandu and the Valley and we came to love it. It is very much a Kathmandu version of Khaosan Rd in Bangkok - very little to do with the parent City but very attuned to the needs and likes of the budget travelling community.Packed with cheap accomodation, souvenir shops, Travel Ticket shops, supermarkets Trekking gear shops and money changers the area has a happy traveller vibe going on. Didn't feel pressured into buying stuff in the shops at all - the only slight annoyance was the occasional charachter asking if we wanted hassish.... which we took as a compliment that at 50 we can stil look part of the "in" crowd ! (And no - we didnt want any !).Ok it's dusty and there is a constant throughflow of many many mopeds and small taxis - but then the whole city is like that.In summary we loved the area. It is in no way representitive of Kathmandu or Nepal but its a great base to set off to explore what is.

The backpacker's Shangri-La in Kathmandu. Ive loved the mad, seething, hectic bustle of Thamel since I first visited in 1997 and discovered a world devoted to travellers. Restaurants of every description, cheap accommodation and loads of shopping, it also offers trekking companies, wifi and conveniences - it may have evolved in these past 18 years but it still retains its insane charm and character. Definitely somewhere to visit if you aren't actually staying here!

Shopping and Hotels Center. Thamel is district that where coffees,restaurant, shopping stores and hotels intensively present. It is a good idea that stay in a hotel which located in this area.Also thamel near to Kathmandu Dubar Square which is the one of the durbar squares located in kathmandu.

Dusty & crowded. I came for the hills. Not really happy with the dusty condition down here. Was always with a mask. Little shops everywhere be sure to bargain down their offering price by half. It gets cheaper the further away you are from the centre

No end to shopping options.....but be aware!. My wife and I recently visited Thamel beore doing our EBC trek. There are hundreds if not thousands of shops tucked away in a myriad of lanes that make up Thamel. You can purchase a host of imitation trekking gear (particularly NorthFace) that is of ok quality. But maybe not for the serious trekker. It is very very cheap if you are prepared to haggle. There are also some fantastic souvenirs, clothing and handcrafts at bargain prices. Beware! You can pay 4 to 5 times the price if you don't check prices with a range of shops. I recommend taking your time and not being over interested. Generally, Prices are cheaper in lanes out of the main shopping areas. Good luck!

A magical 7 days. Some of the best memories I will ever have are those spent in Nepal. I went with 2 other friends just before college for a 7-day hike around Kathmandu Pokhara. The scenery, i can never do it justice with words, but I could try! The mountains we could see in the distance were snowcapped, and we could see them from almost all our rest stops. For example, we would wake up to the sunrise, and it would be quite cloudy sometimes, but there would be at least 10 minutes where the clouds would just clear, and from our beds we would stare breathless at the mountains. It was simply surreal. Throughout the treks we also got to experience incredible views of the landscape. Of course the higher you went, the more rewarding it was, but no matter where we were, we got to see the day-to-day lives of the nepalese people in the region, and it was a real eye-opener. You would always see the kids being happy with what they had, and there was so much to be admired of the people. Oh and the food up there, they honestly had a shockingly wide variety which always tasted good. And the Milk Tea after a long hike, is just perfect :) In the city itself, we had a couple of days to look around. The food was good, everything was cheap, we were brought around by Mr. Bodhraj Koirala (he's in Glance Himalayas) who showed us a great time and even hosted us for dinner on the last night. The internal flights might be scary for some, but it was exciting for us, although navigating in the airport wasn't the easiest task.It was a fantastic trip, and well worth the money. Most, if not all, of the credit (as all my my friends agreed), was thanks to Mr. Bodhraj Koirala, and our guide Hridaya! (Hridaya was awesome, I've lost contact with him, but do request for him for a wonderful trip!) Definitely recommend anyone to go!

Busy, noisy and fun. Not traditional Kathmandu by any means but it is so typical of what this town has become. Busy, bustling and noisy it is an assault on all senses and as long as you don't want to relax you should enjoy it. You can buy anything, see everything and take your pick of restaurants and hotels.

Good base point. Thamel is the tourist city. That being said, all the shops here are catered to tourists. Accomodation options are plenty so no worries on getting a bed.The city itself is very dusty so get your face mask ready. Streets are constantly busy and noisy so advisable to get a hotel away from the main streets.The road signage here is very confusing for rather lack of it. Once you get into the inner streets, the place is very colourful and it was nice to see the locals carrying out their daily routine.Other than the various world heritage sites, there are not much things to be done here. Nonetheless, you can use Thamel as a strategic location to plan your stay in Nepal.

What's Thamel. What is Thamel ? 1. If you are in Kathmandu, then mostly either you are in as a tourist or for business. Either way, if you prefer a place which has lots of options right from supermarkets, eateries, thousands of hotels, easy cars, a happening enviornment, lights, security its Thamel for you. Note : "There is no other place which actually comes close to Thamel in entire Kathmandu" 2. Its equivalent - just to give you a feel : Khao san road in Bangkok, MG road in Bangalore, Bagha Beach in Goa..3. The area basically consists of three main parallel roads - a) Thamel Marg b)Chaksibari Marg c) Amrit marg - check google map for an idea. 4. You will be spoilt for choises while choosing between the following in Thamel a) Resturants b)Hotels c)shops to buy trekking gear, winter wear d)trinkets to carry back home e)supermarkets - mainly supplying the daily food requirements5. Thamel is a place to stay, from here you can go to the several of the destinations / site seeing places in Kathmandu. the first one is Kathmandu Darbar Square ( 1.5kms)

Dusty and dumpy. Back packer paradise with over priced souveniers and guest housea . Trash thrown all over the place .do not go there rif you are allergic to dust, the whole place is like living in a sand storm .

TOP PLACE TO BE IN KTM. THAMEL IS THE "kaosen road of bangkok" the spot for backpackers low budget night life shopping many many shop there bus station very near ambassy also me i like thamel a lot with his market life tahiti road jyatha road teuda road for whole sale little restaurants everywhere but careful of the dysenterie not very clean use the hydro alcoholic gel to clean yours hands every half day& before eating dont forget your mask for dust& pollution

Busy Busy. It's a busy place. If you don't mind the need to watch out for vehicles as you shop, it's an interesting place to visit. I would suggest Pokhara as a better place to shop for soveniers (proper path) and slightly cheaper prices.

Nice but expensive and repetitive. You will see the same type of stuff in all the shops. There is heavy bargaining but I was not sure if the stuff being sold was genuine or not. Good place to vist a few bars and eat.
Must visit. like walking streel and old market of kathmandu sleezy lanes and shope around low budget hotels with cafe and ancient stuff masage parlours music stores handicrafts

complete place!!!. I found thmel is a good place to stay for the first time in Nepal.the place is distinguished by its narrow streets crowded with various shops and vendors. You can find here every service you need like hotel, restaurants, Shopping, souvenires, trekking office. area is small but much like the place.Recomended to visit and stay there.
Good place to shop. best place to shop in Kathmandu very noisy and traffic but good thing is that you can get everything here, many shops, restaurants,hotels & clubs.

Good place but expensive. Night clubs, restaurants, shops, hotels....thts thamel.This area is made for tourist n foreigners.EXPENSIVE...But worth a visit for restaurants and night life.30 mins is enough to explore thamel area by walk.there are some place like durbar square n new market near thamel which you can also explore.

Great place to shop. This is the place to shop in KTM but be prepared to do a lot of bargaining. Lots of tourist shops as well as outfitting shops. Be prepared. It was extremely difficult to follow a map. Mostly I just walked in the general direction and looked for places listed on my map to see where I was.

Good place to shop. I visited Thamel as a part of my anniversary trip to Nepali. U can say its a good place to shop for bargainers like me.U get to see a lot of stuff like shawls from made from baby yak wool, or normal yak wool. I didn't try to purchase them because I might have been cheated.I instead chose items which were authentic like cotton kurtas and pyajamas which designs were rare in India. There are many shops for earrings and bracelets. Be careful and bargain to get the proper price. Thamel is a place , what I understood is Delhi hut of Delhi and Gariahat of Kolkata. Out there one would find restaurants playing live music.All restaurants and small grocery shops provide all sorts of drinks.. So a good place for alcoholics too.Here also one would find shops providing trekking utilities,from sleeping bags to sticks and what not.In short an good place for all tourists

authentic albeit noisy. As in many places of Kathmandu, Thamel may look noisy and chaotic. But this also gives a relaxed atmosphere. It is crowded with different types of restaurants, shops and hotels that makes your stay there more comfortable.

Awesome international vibe, great shopping. In Thamel, tourists from all over the world convene on a few city blocks. This is a great place to purchase cashmere garb, to outfit for your next epic adventure, or to learn how to haggle like a local. Make sure you try Fire and Ice pizza before you leave, and give Hotel Friends Home a shot if you're looking for a place to stay.

The Best Way To See Thamel, Kathmandu And Nepal. if you are looking for a great place to stay when visiting Thamel, Kathmandu then check out the Hotel Shanker.This hotel was previously the Palace so the quality of the surroundings are amazing!Not to mention the excellent services of the 5* staff that are always there for your needs.Also if you are going further afield then call on Naba at Himlayan Glacier Trekking.'Himalayan Glacier' is based in Thamel.This is the best tour guide company in Kathmandu for organising the most amazing trekking experiences or even the most excellent city tours of Nepal.
Home away from home. Everybody is friendly. Food is great. Atmosphere is perfect. Live music on the weekend. Something for every one.
Shop shop shop. Shopping at its best. I felt safe and comfortable walking around this area. We got great deals and there are lots of restaurants to go to as well.
Shop around before you spend on anything. If they know your new in town they will take you! 5`6x what the real value is. NO spending until you scope it out. Don't get trapped by anyone. Walk away.

Shades of Kathmandu. This is the main market for visitors and tourists. It has everything that you look for in Nepal. But be careful about the price. The shops charge exorbitantly and you have to be little careful about that. Big departmental stores are safer choice. Restaurants are really cool. Night life is really hot and happening.
What a westernized madhouse.. If you are looking for trinkets and would rather shop and hustle than experience Nepali culture then Thamel is waiting for you.

Place for tourists. This is a good place to stay for the first time in Nepal. You can find here every service you need and probably in english. Shopping, souvenires, trekking offices. But it is important to point out that this place is quite comercial, so it us easy to get tired if people calling tou on the street all the time. Recomended to see not to stay there.

best place to visit with loved ones or a beautiful reunion.... we go there with some some friends .and its amazing to stay there with your friends.this place is good for shopping,specially for girls.place is safe.also good to stay in Kathmandu.there are so many hotels and caffee in this area.the silver jewelery are also a attraction of thamel.

Colorful. We stayed in Thamel for 15 good days.Thamel is very different from other historic attractions and is a colorful place. Thamel has markets, crafts, restaurants, pubs, clubs everything for recreation. Thamel, actually Nepal is but over-priced.The best way to explore Thamel is to walk around different streets, shop(hipster clothes, accessories, mountaineering gadgets etc) and eat. Late night in Thamel can be little scary with some dance bar and clubs.It is great fun place and should be visited in the mornings, evenings and late nights too.

You have to come here. You really cannot visit Kathmandu without spending some time walking around Thamel. Yes, it is noisy, smelly at times, crowded and with a huge range of qualities and prices in its shops, bars and restaurants. But so is central London or New York's Times Square.Take care of your belongings, as it is a pickpocket's dream. And remember to try bargaining for discount in most shops.

local shopping area with lots of dance bars. If you are night person then this is the beat place for you to go , it is full with stone shops , bars and restaurant and other local hand made material of nepali like choths , handicraft you can cover full thamel area in 2-3 hrs my advice would be do hard negotiation and you can buy good stuff in good price
over priced. All types of Mountaineering stuff available, good quality jackets and bags but very highly pricedPlace surrounded by cafes, pubs. Can enjoy night life.

I liked it, but crowded lots of street level pollution. It's quite a neat place, with many shops selling everything you'll need. There is a famous intersection with three supermarkets, but the two level market is the best one for Diet Coke / Coke Zero bottled in Singapore. They also have Yak Cheese.There are lots of restaurants and hotels around here and many tourists, some whom have "gone local" in their dress. If there is a complaint it is that the vehicles kick up a lot pollution and mask is probably a good idea.When bargaining we always came back at 50% off and usually settled at 30-40% off. If you start to walk out they will usually agree to your price, but say something cutesy, "I would prefer more, but you did not want to pay it"

Heaven or Hell. Thamel is Thamel. You either love it or hate it but you cannot ignore it. It's noisy, dirty and smelly. If you're wanting peace and quiet go elsewhere. However, you'd be missing out because, despite the motor-bikes, the noise and the general shabbiness of the place, it is also wonderfully vibrant and friendly.Of course the shop-keepers, rickshaw drivers, street-sellers and taxis are all desperate to part you from your money, but they do it in a way that is hard to take offence at. You can buy anything and everything here although, it must be said that the actual range of goods, when you analyse it, is actually quite small: hand-embroidered t-shirts, other clothes, brass, stone and pottery, fabrics, carpets, trekking gear, jewellery, tea and coffee. Of course, this may sound like a lot but when you find that each shop sells the same things it does become a bit dull. However, if you can stand the constant badgering and you're feeling fit and well (and you are wearing an anti-pollution mask which is, sadly a necessity now) it's fun for a while. Exhausting, but fun.
Vibrant Thamel. Thamel is a busy vibrant place full of colour and bargains and it has some really good restaurants at very reasonable prices.If your coming to Nepal then a visit to Thamel is a must

It's okay if you like touristy. It's a bit tacky with lots of shops selling exactly the same thing and people selling ganja at every corner! Nice experience though and there are good restaurants and hotels

Kathmandu craziness!. Busy, noisy, packed with people, motorbikes, animals, rikshaws, cars, visitors and assorted cats and dogs! Whatever you want to buy, you'll find it here! Check quality of hiking gear very carefully before making any purchases.

Shoppers heaven. A tourist area with wall to wall shops and some great bargains, hotels, restaurants and yes, western style cafes. Some really enjoyed the cafes and bakeries, I didn't feel the need but writing is a bit on the wall I think with at least 6 of these in a few streets.Be sure to visit the Pilgrim's Bookstore which is fantastic.

Backpackers hub!!. if you love awesome food.....good shopping & maddness...then Thamel is the place to be.... for me it was crowded even though I live in India :).... but if you are a foodie & love to shop for local stuff then this place is just awesome...always buzzing and high on energy

A place that always lively.... Very crowded, noisy but always lively! Liked the old city view, night life. Specially good for shoppers those who like shopping :) NB: Be aware from any type of street boys and their offer and never go to any dance bar because that would be dangerous. I met 3 guys who had to pay 400 USD as they were trapped and suffered a lot after that. So be careful as its very common in Kathmandu.

Tourist haven. Thamel is where you find more tourists than Nepalis during peak trekking season. It's where you find all the clubs, bars, restaurants and cafes. It's also where you shop for crafts and hippie clothing, but as it is the tourist hub, you will be talked to by every local vendor. Make sure to haggle. It's a great place, so much fun, bound to run into any other foreigners you know there. Great place to buy trekking items that you didn't bring with you, if you are okay with knock offs, too.
one day is not enough. crowded, noisy but lovely, many many stuffs to be explored. one day is not enough & must stay no matter for eat, buy or do nothing

A Place where you get everything. Thamel area is at the heart of the city and is the place where a big number of staying options are available. Its got everything what a tourist needs. Hotels, Restaurant, clubs, convenience stores, laundry. Walk through the main street to enjoy the local cuisine in the Nepali restaurants. Shop for souvenirs and dont forget to bargain.

"Love it or hate it". It is a very attractive,energetic and a colourful place moulded in an semi western culture but still very over crowded. Overall obviously the shopping capital of kathmandu but excruciatingly overcrowded with lot of pollution. But Thamel has a perfect mix of hotels , hostels, bed & breakfast, boutique hotels and guest houses! Very vibrant with unlimited options of trekking gears, traditional khukri shops, pashmina shawls, music shops , cafes, handicraft options, tea wholesalers and garment stores.
Very interesting place. Interesting and safe place to be but mind out for the traffic. Good food and fair priced. Would come again

Tourist center. Most of tourist visit and stay in this are because they ll find everything here...from shops, liquor, night club, massage, food, garment, hotels, laundry, cafe, handcraft, trekking equipment etc. small road and crowded most of the time...if u need quite area just keep away from this place...

Must go place in Kathmandu. "Kau San Road" from Kathmandu where the world meet together to share their experiences ... You find the best eateries in Kathmandu here. I had the best Pizzas to the best momos and chilled Heineken Beer to localy brewed barley beer (Chang)This is also the best place for Buys like Nepal made Retro garments to souvenirs. I need to go Thamel every time I visit Kathmandu.

Good for shopping. This is THE place to get Kashmere shawls, shirts, artwork, souvenirs, also camping, hiking, trekking and outdoor counterfeit but still probably pretty good gear. There are many restaurants.

It was a zoo 18 years ago and now it is a worse zoo.. Go there once to see how mass tourism can destroy everything. It is horrible but one should go there once for an hour or so. All the junk stores, tee shirt stores, dal bhat restaurants, guest houses, hippie crowds all contribute to the mess.

To busy, to crowdy, to dirty.. We do not like the old "bacackers" streets and surrounding very much. They are overcrowded, not only with people, also with traffic. Therefore is a lot of pollution. It's difficult to walk, cars, motorbikes and riksjas everywhere. The shops are selling all the same. bargain a lot if you buy something. The charm from a few years ago is gone.

Nice market place. Thamel is the main market area. Its full of eating joints and full of shops with handicrafts, scarves, shawls, etc. Even the pavements have vendors selling all these wares. You need to bargain hard. Lots of nice restaurants for Momos, Tibetan Food and Nepali Food. The Taxis are old Maruti/Suzuki 800cc cars. They can be found near the entry close to Kaiser Cafe.Better to negotiate before sitting as they dont go by meter.A trip from Thamel to our hotel Soaltee Crowne Plaza (Tahachel) cost us Nepalese Rupees 250.00. He started off by demanding 500NPR.

too many shops. There are too many to choose from. Chaotic with so much traffic and no pavements, plenty of places to eat to stop and watch the scooters fighting with the cars. Nice to see the pilice stopping the traffic for a wedding procession. Good to visit for a day or so

Interesting place. I have a mixed feeling about Thamel. It's a heaven for people who want to buy presents and cheap hiking gears. There are many good restaurants too. But it can be tiring to walk around the narrow streets full of traffic noise, incense smell and colorful shops. Resting at a nice rooftop restaurant with free wifi is my advice if you feel exhausted. Using mobile map can also save your time to find your way back to hotel.

Tourism central. Thamel has everything you would expect: cafes, coffees, hotels, pashminas, tour guides, more scarves, trinkets, genuine amulets by the thousands, knitted hats and gloves, yak wool scarves, authentic Tibetan jewelry made while you wait. Fascinating winding streets with a hotel, guest house of cafe every few metres. Wander, meander, walk. There are a few supermarkets - I bought an electrical adapter for less than a dollar. Seemed safe to me in November 2014. No doubt you can find a quieter, cheaper hotel out a few kms. But Thamel is an OK place to start.

Interesting and eclectic!. The streets are messy and traffic is chaotic on the cramped streets of Thamel but that's precisely why it's such a charming place to visit! Shops are cramped with eclectic figurines, architecture is interesting, stalls selling local breads and pastries (super sweet!!) and there are all sorts of people going about on their daily lives... What a great way to see the city!

Do not pay a drink for lady in dance bar. I am in nepal since 6 days and I spend 140 dollars just with 5 red bull. girls working use to cheat tourist by asking drinks. So be careful also with advertisers on street or people offerring girls for sex.they all care just for your pocket

Interesting area to roam around. This was close to where I was staying and apparently a trousit melting point of Kathmandu. Nice place to walk around and see local art and crafts but only see, never buy. Everything is either 3-4 times than other places or fake/substandard. Has some nice eating joints in this area. Ask you hotel to suggest some to you.

Great place. Thamel district is a 100% touristic place but it has own atmosphere and walking around is free of charge. Lots of nice shops, restaurants, hotels, music and people from all over the world.

busy bazaar area. a great place to browse and shop for presents.you must bargain hard.start at 20% of their price and walk away. don't bother with the Durbar.waste of money.good view from 'du taleju' rooftop bar overlooking the Gurkha garrison and big temple

Great place. This is a very busy and bustling tourist area in Katmandu. It is full of tiny, narrow, twisting roads. It teems with, life, people, colour, noise. The area has everything, fantastic local shops, markets, selling everything you could think of. There are many restaurants, bars, cafes to suit all tastes and pockets. I would definitely recommend going there, or even better stay there which we did in Hotel Access a really good budget hotel.

A shopper's paradise and great places with live music. I was amazed at how much Thamel has to offer within such a tiny space. The colorful stalls to shop for cashmere goods, singing bowls, souvenirs along with supermarkets which offer chocolates and spirits of any brand on the planet. At night, the place is alive with pubs and eateries, numerous ones with live music. I stayed there for 4 nights and tried at least 5-6 different kinds of cuisine. Also, Nepali buff momos are out of this world. Except for a slight dust problem due to which most of the locals carry around a cloth mask easily available anywhere in Thamel, the place deserves all 5 stars. I would definitely visit it again.

Everything you'd like to buy in one place. Imagine somthing you'd like to buy in Nepal and it will be at Thamel. Remember that all prices are doubled or tripled so don't forget to bargain. In most cases I paid around half of the origin price. This area is full of life, energy, vibes. Also, it's quite easy to reach it from the centre of the city. I was staying next to Boudanath Stupa and it took aprox 15 minutes by taxi.

A madhouse with a purpose. Throngs of people wall to wall traffic, a madhouse, never the less we always return for our first few days in Nepal. A perfect place to pick up forgotten supply items or gear. The Northface or Patagonia may most certainly be fake but if need an item for a 20 day trek they most certainly will do, heavy bargaining is expected. A bunch of reasonable nice restaurants and bars, don't overlook the Kathmandu Guesthouse, a nice and quiet oasis. Has been hosting climbers and trekkers for the last 30 or 40 years.

Here was the Osho Home Hotel in the Tourist, you can find all kind of gifts you want to buy. Good restaurants , SPA. Beautiful T- Shirt, Pashmina...I dis like to walk in the narrow street, and the crowded.. Osho Home Hotel team helped me to rid a Riksha. It was a nice experience

A little chaotic. Supremely convenient. Surprisingly delightful.. At first glance, Thamel appears to be overwhelmingly chaotic. It is, no doubt. However, the fact is this compact heart of Kathmandu has all the amenities to ensure that visitors are never far from services they require, such as travel and trekking agencies; supermarkets, just in case you forgot to bring your toothbrush; pharmacies for your anti-allergy pills; and international or locally-made outdoor wear! It is easy to get your money out safely from several ATMs; hunt for souvenirs; and send them home via air cargo. Thamel is also conveniently located, allowing easy access - even on foot - to important historical, cultural and religious highlights that Kathmandu has to offer such as Kathmandu Durbar Square where the Royal Kumari, the Living Goddess, resides; Monkey Temple aka Swoyambhunath; Garden of Dreams; Royal Palace Museum, etc. All these places are walks of 10 to 30 minutes from us. And if you want to take it easy - after all you are on a holiday! - taxis and rickshaws are plentiful. Just get your bargaining chops fine-tuned to perfection!

Thamel, the recreation place for Tourists. as a Kathmandutian myself, i almost visit here more that 100 time in a year duration. its the best pplace for all as it expanded to large areas you can dine, wine or have some entwine herein. just near the main city area or walkable distance from many rated hotels of town or you can even get cheaper rates for stay to enjoy the life as of your nation.

NEPAL- FACTS:TIPS:SCAMS. FACT:Carry INR of Rs. 100 denomination only.Ensure you do not carry in notes of INR 500 and 1000 denominations into Nepal as it is illegal in that country.Ensure you got enough cash to shop dine & party.The exchange rate is 1.6 NPR for 1 INR(1:1.6)The official Taxi of Nepal is Maruti 800 which can accommodate 4 peopleTIPS:Carry your ID cards(passport not mandatory,voters Id pan card, Licence works).Take a share taxi from Sunauli to Bhairawa which is hardly 4 kms frm border and cost u around 200 INR for 6 peopleMake entry for your cameras especially DSLR's when u cross Indian border and get the slip of the camera ,otherwise while returning back the Indian customs will charge some extra bucks.Last bus from Bhairawa will be at 8 pm so arrive Early,If u missed catching the last bus you can start early morning by around 4.30 amA Nepali Tali meal cost around NPR 150-200 ie (95 INR),while travelling to Kathmandu if u having food on the way ask the price and then have a fine dineThe bus journey would be around 10-12 hours depending on the busSURYA is the official brand of Cigarettes available in Nepal which never matches the Indian Cigarettes. Carry.Carry enough Gold flake kings/Classic Milds if u are a smokerPlan your stay in and around Thamel in Kathmandu which is easily accessible to all places Once you get down in Kathmandu early morning ask a Localite about the distance to your destination hotel and then call for taxiThere are lots of hotels in and around Thamel one among the best is HOTEL Pushkar where we stayed.SCAMS:Never pay any extra bucks until and unless you get the bus tickets in hand (It cost around INR 450-600:convert using (1INR=1.6NPR)There will be many hawkers on the Nepal side shouting out destinations for buses. Sometimes they will inflate the rates.

Afterall It's Thamel. The first time i visited Nepal and off course in Thamel was in 2011, then 2012, 2013 and last time in 2014, and each time i went there i feel I am lost in Thamel. I always find this place very interesting and it's like a puzzle to me.I really enjoy when i am lost in those roads. It's also kind a hippy place. But the one thing that i observed through out the years that, Street children has dramatically increased day by day in Thamel.
Thamel is a very nice place for shopping local products. The place has a wide range of shops, Restaurants, Cafes and one can pick good local stuff. Do Bargain well

Shopping is great, traffic horrific. I found the constant traffic and all the motor cycles horrid plus none of the streets are signed, so when you first get there, its easy to get lost, even with a map. I do not know what to do to about that except be patient; eventually you will find your way around. It took me about 2 -2.5 days before I had my bearings.

The heart & soul of Khatmanu. After the madness of India Nepal was like a breath of fresh air. Thamel is a bustling, frenetic pocket of Kathmandu and not to be missed. I felt safe in the busy streets and there were so many stores with a variety of wares to sell. Once you are accustomed to the streets it is easy to find your way around and there are plenty of great restaurants, bars, bakeries and even supermarkets to choose from. When I return to Nepal I will definitely base myself in Thamel.

tourist hub. HOtel to shopping center still hustle and bustle. Asking for the trip by the street guide frequently , they are yet frank. street shop to decorate Jewell stuff and many more. it is better to visit at least one time if you are around kathmandu.

Always Interesting To Be Here. I never missed to visit this placed each time I flew to kathmandu. Some may love it,Some may just like it & Some may hate it. Anyway this is Nepal and don't expect it high. A lot of offering here from merchandizing to hotel and f&b outlet and up to you to choose. Overall on my several experienced on this placed I shall highly recommend it & remember one things everybody had their own ideas but put yours and experience it.

Happening place, shopper's satiate. A must visit if in Kathmandu. It reminds me of mall road of Mussorie, India. A very happening place. Full of restaurants, hotels, bars, shops etc. One can get stuff of daily needs, clothes, trekking clothes, electrical equipments and what not.

Hot and Happening. If you are in Kathmandu and you haven't visited Thamel then I must say you have missed something. This is the place where night life starts maximum nice and good pubs are there and you can get food here like donor kebabs and sandwiches till 12 in night.

Same, same and very unhealthy. It is undoubtedly the busiest part of town but quite frankly after a morning exploring we got tired of the same old shops, people trying to offer taxi rides and crappy souvenirs. It is also very stressful and unhealthy experience, dodging cars and motorcycles that belch out fumes. On the other side, Thamel is a bustling mass of people with a huge choice of restaurants and bars all within walking distance. For us it's interest faded quickly and we were grateful for Mandala Street, a traffic free arcade with nice restaurants, cafes and bakeries. If we came back, it would be for hiking again and we'd use Thamel as a start and end point.
Must visit place. Kathmandu's happening place , decent nightlife beware of touts they my try to fool you . Good restaurants around nice music . You can find lot of tourists and backpackers.

Purchasers Delight. Get Nepal T-Shirts from here with many designs and colours. T-Shirts are printed as well as embroidered. There are many designs to choose from. Its a good market for shopping where you can get clothing, maps, books, music CDs, etc. Take a hour time, walk and just see the market

The one-stop-shopping place with an unforgettable atmosphere.. If you are new to Nepal, or just want to experience an electric atmosphere with extremely friendly Nepali locals and mouth watering food, as well as gain help with organising adventures around Nepal, then Thamel is the place for you. The conversations are endless, the haggling is infectious, the atmosphere is (as previously mentioned) electric, the food and local tea is delicious, and I could walk down the street at night and feel completely safe. Thamel offers everything. It is a place for families looking to transition into the Nepali life and purchase beautiful handcrafted gifts, for solo people looking to meet locals and other travellers, for adventurous backpackers looking to organise their new challenge, and for part goers looking to find the best bars and clubs. The day life, the night life, you wont forget the Thamel life.

THE Place to Shop. What a paradise for shopping! Turn left or turn right, you will find thousands of things to buy, most of them with good quality and reasonable prices. If you are tired of shopping, stop at a momo place or have masala tea in a cafe. Money changers are there for you too but be careful about chipped or torn banknotes.What can you buy? From genuine North Face ski stuff to fake but excellent polars, from real cashmere shawls to ethnic blouses, skirts, pants, from silver to fake but beautiful jewellery, from bags to felt objects, you can find anything here. Not to be missed.

The place to go for Nepalese handicraft shopping. Shopping, food, chaos, and fun! A fascinating place to wander and great place for diversity of Nepali handicraft shopping. T-shirts, trinkets, beads, hand-made paper, and lots more. Also lots of restaurant choices.
Good Food. This is a local market which gives a brief idea about many things. The food at some of the small restaurants was very good specially the momos and the thukpa.

thank you thanel travel. this was one amazing experience we really enjoyed our afternoon with these precious coltures staffs at office very friendly we spand tow weeks in nepal amazing these time we enjoyed very much in chitwan while bathing by elephant pokhara is also beautiful city all the acomendtion were excellent with nonverbal price so thank you so much Balaram and thamel travel team for your wonder full help during our stay
Just another tourist place. Ok, Thamel is a busy place with shops, restaurants and travelagensts. But the shops are almost all the same. Nothing spectacular

Feels like Europe!. The quintessential touristy location! Something for everybody. Right from the good to the bad. Quaint cafes, all very well done, numerous bars, live music, dance bars, souvenir shops and drug peddlers.I went in early February, weather was cold and loads of tourists, felt like I was in Europe

Best location . I arrived to nepal and its first time in nepal and first time in hotel encounter nepal which was nearly located to the tourist place, thamel.due to my business I had a short holiday.the hotel was great with the good garden view and the staff were great in their services.The hotel is fulfilled with the good service and friendly staff.I was provided with a goog garden view room with a reasonable price and hope that I will get same room for my second visit and I will be coming for long holiday for my second visit but not for my business purpose but stay for longer time in hotel encounter nepal.
A great city. Thames is a beautiful central place , little tiny streets but within reach of everywhere . A lot of characters and the friendliest people ever

Busy and chaotic. Thamel is a very busy place with lot of restaurants, hotels and shopping for all kind of things. The place it a bit chaotic and dirty for my liking. We took a stroll around neverthless to get a feel of local life. It was on the tenth day of the Dasain festival and many of the shops were closed. We did buy a few souvenirs from here.

nice place but very noisy and crowd. a fantastic place for visitor for shopping and walk around but traffic is worst and very very noisy. but it is kathmandu , it is how is it. o love the place though.
Practical area. The Thamel area is noisy, chaotic at times, dirty in general, but it is the area to go in Kathmandu for touristic hotels and restaurants, as well as for shopping, especially clothing.

Shoppers Paradise. Its good to stay in or near Thamel as its not just Shoppers Paradise but a delight for Foodie's.Thamel area has tourist booking shops, simcard for phone shops, adventure booking centres, Bike hire places, shopping (with negotiation), whole bunch of variety in Food. Also Its easy to get tourist cars for sight seeing.Nevertheless, I enjoyed just roaming around the streets carefree, enjoying the place buzzing with local people, tourist, buyers, hippies or just sat near a road side café and read a book.

Shopping for Handicrafts : Priced high though. This is one place where all the handicrafts are available together. The pricing is on the higher side and bargaining rules the roost. Basic rule : Start with 1/5th the price quoted and usually the deal will be settled at 1/4th or 1/3rd the price. Many of the shops and artists make handicrafts that are so beautiful that one would not like to bargain at all. In case you are interested to visit the source of the place, go to patan or Basantpur. Here the artists live and make the crafts.
Touristy. Tourist shops that were ok. Not very interesting. Sidewalks on the main streets. Not worth the time. Side streets are more interesting
trip in kathmandu. nice people, nice views good prices. nice different villages, mountains, snow and hot weather the same time.
Lots of shops and restaurants. Easy to get in from the airport. Lots of nice shop and restaurants.Many of guesthouse,hotels and travel agencies.
safe. Well i went away with a group and i always felt safe in thamel unlike other places in Kathmandu. Good places for shopping also

The tourist area. We stayed in a hotel in Thamel and had all activities right outside the hotel. It is worth to book a fairly high level hotel. We had a small garden with a small pool, chairs for a rest, and very clean rooms. Thamel is hectic, and if you like shopping there are endless possibilities.

A nice place to walk and shop. Would be much better if the police would control the traffic better. Many shops most selling the same thing but fun to bargain. They really put up the prices when they see a gora so you have to be ready to knock them down to half that is asked or more. Fun restaurants with a plethora of fares.
shopping place for toursits. If you want to feel in Nepal, Thamel is not a good place to be. Thamel is a perfect place to fill your bag with souvenirs.

What a place, so full of life.. We stayed at the Kathmandu guest house right in the centre of busy Thamel. Thamel is a wonder to behold. So busy, full of taxi's rickshaws and people everywhere but such a must see place. The little felt shops are amazing and so many great places to eat. The best Italian I have ever had along with almost every cuisine you could think of. Don't miss it and stay right in the heart of it.

Similar to old Delhi market place. Thamel seemed like Old Delhi market place. Narrow streets, shops selling local stuff and food.Not much different to any small Indian city, it is good to roam around if you have nothing else to do.

What a change!. Thamal has been cleaned up since last year. It's clean and all the pot holes have been filled in! It seems as though the shop staff and locals have been told not to hassle the tourists too. Which makes very pleasant shopping and wandering through all the quaint roads and alleys. Love this place, There's no where like it

Center of tourist spots. A must to visit, to shop, to stay, to dine, to chill, money changer, tour company and so on. All amenities in a place. Good buy locally made winter clothing, hiking and tour gears. Interesting gift such as cheap yet elegant scarf, handy craft, thangka painting, prayer items such as mani wheel, incense, statues, hanging flags and so on. Many good bar and bistro of local and international cuisines is generously available here.

colour and life. thamel is the tourist heart of Kathmandu and so full of live - loud music blasting out of the many CDs and DVD shops - great little restaurants everywhere and tons of odds and ends to buy at every corner. the traffic gets a bit getting used to but once you master that - you'll love it!
Backpacker Central. Lots of shops, cheap good food, and ideal spot for backpackers and travelers alike to get situated in Nepal. Friendly people and easy to meet others for recommendations.

North Fake Heaven. Had a great time in the middle of Kathmandu and the main shopping district. They have everything here for you to buy and travel guides for all the fun activites. My best friend who loves North Face thought he died and went to heaven. He bought 12 pieces of knock off clothing that he bargained long and hard for. It is truly fun and enjoyable to shop in this area. Busy and fun vibe here.

It's not really Nepal. The place is full of characters but it's also full of fake designer goods & locals looking to get as much money out of tourists as possible. Our first night there we decided to buy some apples from a street seller there, and when he weighed the apples and said a price, we worked out he was trying to charge us £8 for 4 apples. He kept his apples at least until the next unsavvy passerby!It's certainly worth a look around and has some amazing restaurants and a few interesting bars, yet most of the stuff is not legit, and therefore I'd be a bit sceptical about going up a mountain wearing it. It's a cool place to meet tourists, and helpful for finding a knowledgeable local with a bit of English but please experience something else beyond the Thamel...

Something for everyone. Crammed with little shops,Thamel is a shoppers paradise for souveniers and jewellery.Silver jewellery is very reasonably priced and there are plenty of cafes and restaurants nearby. There was even a vendor selling typical street food. Plenty of touring companies based here if you wish to organise a trek. The area buzzes with activity and you will enjoy your visit here once you get used to the crowds and the honking of car horns.
Shopping!!!. Where you can buy cashmere. Nepalese are very nice enough to give you discounts whenever you ask them. The trick is, buy a lot in one store and they would give you a lot of discount!

Kathmandu's Walking Street. A bliss for backpackers. Ample restaurants, shops, convenience stores, hotels and awesome electrifying environment. Just taking a stroll and buying nick nacks is an absolute fun here. You can buy some genuine Pashmina stuff from here.

the heart of Kathmandu. the heart of Kathmandu , i was very lucky to stay in a hotel in thamel , i wasn't know any think about it before i came to Nepal , but if you didn't visit it , you didn't see half of Kathmandu
the only down side of it ,,, it's very crowd

shopping. The streets of Thamel was filled on new years eve and new years celebration. The area is a shoppers (tourist) paradise with lots and lots of little shops and food places. You can bargain with the shop owners. It is very busy with traffic and crossing the roads can be daunting with the constant hooter.

Loved Thamel. If you are looking for traditional nepali stuff or souvenir, thamel is a must . Almost all the people there knows english which is a great advantage. We went there during new year last year it was amazing it had open DJ all night . There are lots amazing restaurant in thamel i would like to recommend two restaurant first one is OR2K and Momo Star .Also if any of you loves confectionary item HOT BREAD is a must .Cheers !

Chaos of Life!!. The first time I entered thamel, I was struck by the sheer energy it oozes. Its si vibrant, chaotic and beautiful. You would stumble across people from every part of the world. The food, the music, clothes, handicrafts; everything is a treat for you.

Not to be missed.... Yes it is crowded, yes it is not so clean, yes it is a traffic madness, yes it is full of congested shops, yes it is noisy.....but it is also charming, it is authentic, it is nice, it is Nepalese, it is Katmandu with very friendly people, it is cheap, it is full of little bars and restau on the top of the roof, it is what you want to know about this city... and even if some objects are fake...you have no obligation of buying them at all... it is your choice...we loved Thamel in Katmandu...

Good experience. Thamel was very welcoming and embracing..I loved walking into the streets of thamel,a good experience indeed..the shops offer many shawls and stole,but one has to bargain pretty well. Thamel has every kind of cuisines to offer and the prices are pretty decent.anyone coming kathmundu for first time, I would recommend to stay at thamel.

Lots to buy here!. The Thamel area has loads of shops to help you spend your money ... some unique and some are knock-offs of other places. It's a fun place to walk around and "window" shop even though there are no windows!
A terrible neighborhood. Dirty, filthy, trashed and apocalyptic area of a poor city. Insane drivers, fake produce everywhere from clothing to "Tibetan" art.

Unfortunately you can not miss this chaotic place. Thamel is a chaotic place made of narrow lanes,maddening traffic,congested shops,shady hotels & dance bars.But you ought to experience it just for the same.For this is Kathmandu both at its best and worst.However you will probably get the best deals on souvenirs in whole of Kathmandu here provided you bargain well.You do not tire of watching the bewildering variety of stuff stocked by small outlets located next to each other.Some cafes like Himalayan Java,Fire & Ice are worth all the trouble of visiting Thamel(can not say the same about the famous Rum Doodle ,a cafe for mountaineers though).The best thing about the place is that the people are nice and the shopkeepers do not pester you like in similar places in Delhi(Pahar Gunj).The place holds a street festival.A place called Mandella street is being positioned as a destination shopping lane within Thamel,with its own street festival.

Crowded and noisy (but still charming). Thamel a super-touristy area filled with shops, restaurants and guesthouses. As a result, it's crowded and noisy and you'll be approached by dozens of "trekking guides", drug dealers and beggars. That said, there are also a number of excellent restaurant and cafes to be found here and the area is charming in its own way. If you're going trekking, you can get everything you need here. If you're looking to meet other travelers, this is the place.

thamel is the place. i have been staying in Thamel every year i come to Nepal, its been 4 years back to back and i have been staying here because it has everything a tourist needs. lots of supermarkets, restaurants, souvenir shops, pubs, restro bar, and night life too. all the places you need to visit are close enough. so to my conclusion it is the place to stay if you visit Nepal.

Bustling and overcrowded, but tolerable. The streets may be dangerously overcrowded with every manner of vehicle, two, three and four-wheeled, and the hotels may be noisy, but this tourist district harbors well-priced accommodation, interesting shops, high-quality restaurants (Kilroy's, La Dolce Vita) and opportunities to get last-minute gear.

I love those small crowded streets. Energetic place with lots small alley ways and streets filled from left to right, from bottom floor to top floor with shops, restaurants and anything else you can imagine.You basically know the lyrics to "Om Mani Padme Hum" Tibetan mantra song that is played on a 24/7 loop.Some of love it, other will hate it.

I love Thamel!. I know this is the tourist heart of Kathmandu but I love it. The narrow streets, people everywhere, crazy traffic, tiny shops - at times I had to go along narrow corridors and up narrow staircases to see the merchandise - great food, and all easy on the pocket.
