Although prices drop the further out you go. You do have to bargain and learn to clearly say no when you are not interested. The people are warm and friendly and chatting to the various shop keepers is just as much fun as the shopping. Do watch out for rip-offs though - but even if this happens it still is not a huge amount on money in western terms. You can walk to other parts of the old city, where the different areas have their own flavours. Definitely worth a few days or more.

Exactly what I expected, for better and for worse. Thamel is the tourist ghetto of Kathmandu and a great central area for getting oriented. You can find great budget housing and meals if you hunt for them, but there is no upper limit. Shop around, bargain, look at rooms before you say "yes," and get at least a few blocks away if you want a little more peace and quiet.

Backpackers heaven!. Thames is an ideal location for backpackers and other tourists offering great food, drinks, party places, shopping etc. Tourist can find food ranging from typical Nepalese, Indian, Continental, bakeries and all kinds of world cuisines. All in all you will mist likely miss home as you can get almost everything here.

A thrilling few days. The tourist trap everyone has so many feelings about treated me fairly well during my stay. After about 2 days, I got used to the spitting on the streets, the passing whispers offering weed and the vehicles honking in the narrow lanes.Prices are inflated here and you do meet some interesting characters who don't always want something from you. Helpful, curious people just living their lives are what I remember most after the rosey incense and mantras from the shops. Love it!

Great for Shopping. Four of us spent a week here, in Thamel, Kathmandu. Anything you need, you can get here. It's the best place to buy Pashmina,Yak wool and cashmere items such as shawls, sweaters, caps and winter wear. Lokta paper and paper products, such as stationery, lampshades, wrapping paper, carry bags and lovely Christmas cards are popular items. Tea comes wrapped in a small pouch and makes a lovely gift. Thamel has a great variety of Thanka paintings which are executed in cotton, canvas or silk using gold, silver and stone pigment. In other words, it's a great place to get your souvenir shopping done. A great variety of restaurants here also with lots of them recommended by 'Lonely Planet'. The place has a great buzz!

shopping and trekking!!. If you dont mind constantIy peopIe trying to seII you trips then you can reaIIy Iove thameI..its a bit fuII on, noisy...poIIuted, traffic is amazing....busy busy..many great eating pIaces but cheaper if you go further out of this area, IocaIIy I found. however, i met a few peopIe who ive here , ex pats irish, american and british, very few but they are around and been her 20yrs some of them. more expensive shops have shot up in the 18yrs i havent been here and theres defiantIy a `modernerty` creeping in...the hippy trend finaIIy is aImost extinct! good to get out after a whiIe as gets overwheIming
A labyrinth which deserves to be walked. Thamel is a labyrinth wich deserves to be walked. Lots of cheap shops to buy anything. Lots of rerstaurants to choose. Have fun and enjoy this place

Shopping haven. Happened to be here during the Christmas and New Year's eve celebrations on the streets. Hundreds of people crowding around the stage to usher in the festivities. But aside from that, this place is never short of crowds and traffic. As you walk the narrow streets, be prepared to be honked at at least once!Shopping paradise for those keen on outdoor gears, arts & crafts, beads and embroidery. Almost all outdoor gears are knock offs but quality not too bad for short term usage. If you like to eat Naan, give a restaurant called "Curry Kitchen" a go. We loved their Naan, just nice and soft. It's located above the Hot Breads bakery. Quite easy to find, you shouldn't miss it.
crowded and dusty. the uniqueness of Kathmandu is in here. Crafts, shopping, cheap accommodation, a variety of restaurants, all here...just crowded and dusty.

The heart of the tourist trade. It's more than likely that you'll end up staying either in or near Thamel when you are in Kathmandu. This is the place for genuine and not so real mountaineering equipment and clothing as well as just about everything else that you might need.The vendors that I met were all friendly and not pushy (a nice change to some places in Asia that I've been to).Just watch out for the crazy drivers, riders as the roads/ lane ways are narrow and they really don't give much way to anyone!

Colorful, bustling Thamel. Thamel is full of cozy little restaurants offering delicious food and great service, and little shops selling everything you may need - be it mountaineering supplies, clothes, jewelry, or masala spices.It was great that we left a day of our trip for just browsing around. I loved Nepal and it's great people, and Thamel was certainly no exception.

Exciting and very crowded. Take tricycle rickshaw ride through the traditional bazaars of Indrachowk and Assan and end up in Thamel.jammed full of people, stores, lodgings, restaurants in this touristy area. A ride and sight to remember.

Forgot your mountaineering gloves:no worries Thamel has some. Thamel is a happening place. It has shops with all sorts of mountaineering items to souvenirs. It makes you want to explore the colorful walls of merchandise. The vendors I came across were very unobtrusive. This made browsing alot more pleasant. Most vendors do not take credit cards or other foreign money. ATMS and money exchanger booths can be found to obtain money in Nepalese Rupees. There are some more structured stores that accept credit cards, for example, The North Face store selling genuine North Face products.Thamel offers many things throughout the city. I took a stroll along a busy street that led me to more local market where there are less tourists. I loved it. I saw sacks of different wheat, rice, and potatoes. An array of dried fish in satchels. Spicy chili peppers of all sorts. Teas galore and not to mention all sorts of fresh meats out on the counters. I enjoyed seeing some of the real shopping the locals do. It is a moving place and you have to pay mind to the cars and bikes on the streets. So overall, one can find mountaineering clothing/equipment, SIM cards, gloves, hats, food, soft drinks, water, arts, jewelry, yak wool gifts. batteries, bottled water, etc!

Still looks like what it did in the 80s. My first visit to Nepal was in the 1980s and this place still looks like it did when I first visited here. I can't say the same about Nepal and KTM but it appears Thamel was able to save its charm. This is a must visit location for anyone visiting KTM.

SHOPPING!!!! Great deal hunting!. What can I say about this gorgeous place. It is a lovely maze of wonders and bargains. Perfect for creatures that hunt for deals. There are books, spas, clothes, food, nightlife, tatto parlours - Mohan's Tattoo Inn and coffee packed into these very narrow streets. It kept us entertained for 5 days. Yes, you need a day to get through each intertwined streets. Oh....the regular weed peddlers are also present.

Fun shopping. Had a fun time walking around the market, going through the shops and negotiating best deals. The sellers were mostly polite and easy going, quickly to tell you the price in your currency. The stuff seemed quite good too. Although, not many street sellers accept cards.
Lively. Filled with tourists, tourist shops, cafes and reasturants. Very narrow streets, so beware of the crazy car drivers. Also might get a headache from all that honking

Crazy place !!. It really is crazy in Thamel, but I think you'll love it, we all did.
Not so good if you have a crowd phobia, esp,during market time.
Gets mad during that time. But the shopping, makes it all worth it! It's just one of those crazy places that keeps drawing you back...
Thamel. The area are very dusty but a lots things to see. Need to bargain all the way and there are plenty of shops to choose from.

Thamel hectic & crazy place. Make sure you stay here when in Kathmandu to absorb the atmosphere and to take in the vast array of market shops selling the tourist merchandise. Garden of Dreams is worth the entry fee into for the clean & historie setting plus their amazing coffee and fantastic lunches. Sam's Bar is a great trekkers meeting spot for a cold beer. Just watch out for the crazy traffic along the busy roadways - very noisy too.

Shopping Capital & Cozy Restaurants. Thamel is a one stop for all your needs, if you want to shop for yourself or planning to buy souvenirs for your friends and family you will find amazing collection of winter wear in cashmere, pashmina, yak wool etc, you also get lot of tibetan artifacts over here and if you are an adventure junkie. You will find the best trekking gear in this market. If you are tired from all the shopping you have done, just step into one of the restaurants/cafes next door to have a cup of coffee and plan your itinerary with free wifi available in all restaurants.There are many bars and pubs as well over here, so if you are looking for a little buzz and music head into one of these.If none of these excites you just walk the streets of Thamel where you will get to see the culture of the country, some funny display boards and some weird characters selling you weird stuff. LOLHave fun

Thamel! Great clubs!. Fun clubs, if you can find locals to direct you there! Noisy, crazy exotic. Great place for souvenir shopping, and some very good restaurants, including Rosemary's and RoadHouse! Stay at the Royal Penguin, or RP2~

Tourist's Haven !. Thamel is tourist's haven, very cosmopolitan, a full wi-fi zone, very bright restaurants/pubs/Tibetan joints, small lanes and bye-lanes jammed with two-wheelers and small cars, the street shops selling almost everything (from Thanka, junk jewellery to trekking gear).. a good place to pickup souvenirs .. just walk-walk-walk till you drop in one of the small Tibetan restaurants and watch the colourful world glide by ..

Great area for tourists. This area of Kathmandu if great for tourists with all the relatively nice hotels, street shopping and good cafes. It is a great location to walk the streets of Kathmandu and enjoy the city culture.
Buzzin. very nice area with alot of shopping & history. great places to eat at and nice places to visit. a bit busier compared to other areas
Night at Thamel. The place is good to walk around. Do not buy any stuff here as it is very costly. Just do window shopping

An Aladdin's cave.. From the moment you get there you will find something interesting around every corner. The old run down buildings with their small colourful doorways look like they can tell you a story and inside there are all sorts of treasures. If you don't mind crowds and traffic jams in little alleyways, then brave it. You won't be disappointed.

Crazy Fun!. The mecca for any climber and trekker and the area reflects it. Overwhelms the senses with stores, restos, face to face sellers, tourists, backpackers, no real one word describes this area.

Loved thamal...the heart of kathmandu. We loved Thamel. The hustle and bustle of Thamel was great. We were in Thamel for about 3 weeks and got to know the place quite well. There are a lot of great outdoor gear shops (Most selling knock off, but most still great quality), plenty of GREAT food (Try the Dahl Bhat and Momos) well priced accommodation and the people are amazing. For those looking for a more upmarket scene/some peace and quiet check out Mandala Street. But the best thing to do is just walk and get lost in the atmosphere.

Backpackers' den. Thamel is probably the place where everyone lands up after getting out of the plane. The place is great for nice slow evening walks although it's a touristy place. Thamel is where you get to meet new people from various countries in the cafes and bars strewn around the area. Try exploring the various alleys on foot. Also, some of the best restaurants in Kathmandu are located in or around Thamel.

A little of Potential but not being Utilised. Thamel could be so much more if it were to get its act together. Great assortment of shops selling just about anything, however these are replicated throughout the district, so one shop ends up just like it neighbours. This place should really take charge of its assets: temples and shrines are being left to deteriorate. Architecturally rich buildings from 200 years ago are being left to fall down and used as Pigeon Roosts. Dog mess issue needs to be addresses as does to motorcycles that use the lanes. This place could be so much nicer whilst maintaining its culture.

Backpacker's delight. Numerous gullies, economical guest-houses, riots of colours, artefacts and high-end eateries, Thamel seems to compress many worlds in one. Each day in Thamel is a new discovery. Visitors may however, need to be a little careful of the pimps who solicit customers even during daytime

The Brooklyn of Kathmandu. I'm staying in Kathmandu for three months, living just outside the center of the city. Every weekend I come into Thamel for food, drinks, and shopping. There are a lot of great restaurants, cafes, and bars to meet fellow travelers and expats. It's lively, artistic, and young. You'll meet incredible people from around the world as well as friendly locals.

It is touristy, but it's fun and the shopping is great. I know the shops mostly sell stuff straight out of China, but there is a lot of good stuff, negotiated at the right price, to bring home for presents - that's the main attraction of the Thamel area. There are lots of food options, the streets are pretty safe - at least that's what I found.

Shopping place in Nepal. Lonng way to go for shopping. All different variety of Nepal plus Chinese items. Take a taxi and asked them to drop you at the end or entrance and then walk around those shops. It will take more than 4 hours for you to spend/return back. This is again located in the mid of Kathmandu valley. And please be aware on the prices if its negotiable. Go for the fixed price shops if you are not good on bargaining.

Essential Kathmandu. Thamel may be "touristy" but it is a very essential part of visiting Kathmandu. The narrow streets are crowded with cars, SUV's. bicycle rickshaws, motorbikes, cows and people. Shops have most anything that anyone could ever want to purchase and provide a great bargaining experience which can result in some incredible bargains. The World Heritage listed Hanuman-dhoka Durbar Square is a must see. After you pay your admission fee you can take the ticket to the site office, supply a passport-sized photograph and they will issue you a visitor pass for the length of your stay in Kathmandu. Himalayan Coffee, at the Durbar Square end of Freak Street provides good drinks and a pleasant place to sit and watch the passing scene. Clean bathrooms are available in the palace/museum.

touristy market place... Nice place to visit when in Kathmandu..it is very touristy with all the small shops selling souveniers, khukris and trekking gear. the market also has some nice cafes selling local cuisine.
A must visit on your Kathmandu trip.

Great place to stay. Thamel is quite a fun place to stay in Kathmandu. There are tons of souvenir shops and shopping here is quiet fun - though it's a good idea to get to know what things are worth before jumping in and buying things. The restaurants in this area are great and you won't run out of new places to eat.
Asian overload. If you enjoy bright lights, bars up all night, shops and peddlers harassing you at every step, then Thamel is the place to be! The best part is the amazing bookstore!

Ideal for Shopping. This place starts with a Fire and Ice Pizza joint and a couple of nice eateries strewn around. Hustle bustle yes, but a few shops are available where you can get nice Typical Nepalese items . Do not miss if you are shopaholic.

Hectic, chaotic, noisy fun. Thamel is a wonderful place to spend time. The streets are packed with traders, tourists and traffic - the noise is unbelievable and incessant. A haggler's paradise and great fun to wander through, day or night.
really enjoyed. Really enjoyed the restaurants, shopping and people in this tourist area. Shopping and food great, lots of trekking gear, pashminas and interesting incence etc

Happening place in Kathmandu. Plenty of bars, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants and shopping. Most places shut by 10 pm or 11 pm but if you have the patience to walk around in the area you will find a few places that are open even till 5 am. Just keep a ear out for the music/noise.

Nothing quite like it...... The hustle and bustle of Thamel makes this a great starting point for any Nepalise adventure. Be prepared for lots of noise, dust and chaos......but great shops, restaurants and night spots.
Busy Shopping area !!!. This is one of the prime shopping areas of Kathmandu. Prices are reasonable, but you can get better price if you can bargain.

Superb street for restaurants. Super place for eating and also shopping. For shopping though most of the shop keepers were disinterested but few of the shops just blew our mind as the quality of stuff kept was just amazing. Though all the restaurants were just crazily awesome especially OR2KSuggest to go to every shop in all the lanes to finally find that 1-2 shops where you can do all kind of shopping you want. Worth giving full half day for this activity

Tourist District - but fun. There's a great energy here in Thamel. Hinking motorbikes, hashish and tiger balm hawkers, dogs,scarves, buddhas, and incense everywhere.You are surrounded by fellow travelers - some trekkers heading out, some looking for a hot shower and wi-fi after returning, as well as all the other ex-pats out there. This is the area to get all your gift shopping done, as well as some fun items for yourself, and cheap knock off trekking gear (north face jacket for a 2 year old - done!). There is plenty of yummy cheap food, but do me a favor don't just get a burger or a burrito - live a little!

A heart of KTM. Crazy, busy, vibrant, colourful; very easy to get lost in! Its a maze of narrow streets - a 'must' experience! Tiring too, would require a quiet time away after that:-) Full of shops and restaurants with a local cuisine; however the shopkeepers, and restaurant staff are not pushy or aggressively trying to sell stuff. Haggling required at all times, down to half price! plenty to see plenty to do! Anything goes, pretty much...

alive, busy and smoggy. You could walk around thamel 10 times or 100 times and always find something new. There's something for everyone, if you want to party, relax, go shopping or just explore. The air is a bit nasty though and after a few days you can feel the smog in your lungs.

Not for you if you cant haggle. Great place to shop really good winter wear and other souveniers. Make sure you negotiate well, even if you hear yourself sounding ridiculous. Be ready to leave what you see, and DO NOT showcase the affection. They will turn around, if they dont - you will find the same thing ahead.

Tourist shopping area. Thamel has lots of shops, selling everything from outdoor equipment to yak blankets and bells. Make sure you haggle on everything as you will be able to drop the price of items by quite a bit on certain items. During night-time hours expect to be offered drugs by local every couple of hundred meters. ATM's in the Thamel area have local security guards outside them to keep unwanted attention away from you.

Dusty Town. This was like a chinatown for the nepalese. Very busy streets with alot of shops selling cloth or outdoor gears (fake gears). It gets dusty too, so remember to bring a face mask or buffer.
chaotic, dusty mahem but do go!. the titles says it all! very touristy but heaving with young people before and after their adventurous trips. "Pashmina" heaven if you wabt cheap souveniers.

Avoid If You Dislike Crowds, Noise, Dirt and Touts. I first came to Nepal in 1992 and have only recently returned. I'm sad to say that in the intervening 22 years Thamel has been destroyed. It used to be low-rise (nothing bigger than two or three floors) with lots of green spaces and the only traffic was cycle rickshaws. Now there are buildings at least 7 floors tall, blotting out the sun like in New York, the streets are thronged with jeeps and motorbikes and you can barely walk ten metres without someone trying to sell you hashish. The dirt, noise and pollution is ridiculous. Buy a facemask or suffer the respiratory consequences. Thamel is just one giant hippie shopping mall, full of shops selling rainbow hats, brass buddhas and OM fridge magnets and a massive array of restaurants, which will surely be appreciated after the limited fare on offer whilst trekking. I am very sad that it has been so spoiled in 22 years, and I worry that when the next major earthquake happens there are going to be so many fatalities because of the terrible ways that buildings have been added onto. Some of the buildings look like you could push them over. I guess Thamel is a victim of its own success, sadly!

Buzzing with life. Thamel is a city in itself. Located at the centre of the heart, Thamel has something for everyone - Be you with your family or with friends, or even alone - Thamel has the ability to keep you engaged and interested in it. There are small shops selling everything under the sun - from very ordinary to unique. In between the jungle of shops, hidden are cosy and quaint cafes and bars, serving anything you desire for - coffee, beer or even milk!Some of the restaurants offer a variety of food - from Nepalese to Korean to Thai and Chinese - to suit your palate. In between narrow lanes - which are perfect for leisurely walks, there are miniature Stupas and strange temples which invariably attract the passers by. As the evening approaches, and it becomes a bit chilly, the nightlife of Thamel wakes up to keep you warm. Taxis (noiseless Maruti 800) start crawling on the streets, fairy lights adorn the streets, and music from dance bars starts filling every corner. Thamel is interesting if you are willing to have a leisure holiday and not in a hurry to achieve a lot in a short time.

A great Bazaar. Atmosphere! This place reeks of it. Narrow lanes, all manner of goods and travel services for locals, travellers and trekkers alike. The deeper you go into the endless network, the more genuine it seems to become with butcheries, ironmongers, tinsmiths, jewellers, mercers all plying their trades. Street level is where the buzz happens, but venture higher to the wholesalers at the next level for great bargains and quality merchandise

Shopper's paradise. If you lovie shopping eating and partying Nepali style, then Thamel is the place to be. Bargaining is essential, as is watching the quality of the merchandise, but if you're careful there are bargains a plenty and a lot of fun purchasing them. Pashminas, felted products, gems, books, CDs, teas, embroidery, clothing etc etc etc. Dining in any of the the plentiful upstairs cafes also gives you the opportunity to enjoy the atmosphere while being above the melee. Lots of great places to stay here too including the iconic Kathmandu Guest House. Since previous visits the streets have been cleaned up and there are hardly any beggars but the road surface still demands attention to avoid an injury. A wonderful buzzing part of the city.

Back in time. I was in and out of Thamel a few times during a recent trip to Nepal. I guess that describes every visitor to this tiny wonderful country. You start and end in Thamel. As soon as you leave it you realize this area is deliberately left in an antique state for the expats to immediately enjoy on arrival. When you get a half mile away you see their grasp on the 21st. Century. A very tenuous grasp it may be but Thamel is not a true reflection of greater Kathmandu. Who cares? When you leave Kathmandu you wil see much more rustic environs. I say stay in Thamel and kick up a fuss! Gear up for that Annapurna trek or whatever you came for. This is truly a one of a kind place! Enjoy it!
All your needs ends here!. A very busy place with narrow streets. You will find all your needs full filled in this place. Be it Restaurant,Duty free shops,Daily needs,Shopping, Bars etc...

Streets for tourists. You will find everything you need in this web of narrow busy streets. There is always a great atmosphere and a buzz of Trekkers going up the mountains and those who have come down. The negative is that there are only tourists about. If you want to get a real feel of Kathmandu for the locals make your way outside of Thamel.
crowded and small road. Been there to buy some gift for my mother, found very expensive .and its always rush over there, too many people walking around,,,

Shopping area. There is a lot of good restaurant, shops, bakeries, bars, cafes, pharmacy, supermarket around this area and the shops close very late. Youc an still shop after having dinner and they even have shop that will do embroidery on the t shirt according to your liking.

Shopping and more Shopping. You get the best imitation of brands at fraction of a price if you know how to bargain. Also, roam around a lot and you need to have the patience and werewithal to ask the prices at many shops before you arrive at a fair-value :) A few shops sell at extremely reasonable rates and I did not even feel like bargaining.

Touristy. If you are tourist in Kathmandu, there are very high chances for you to visit there. The area has narrow busy streets lined with shops and restaurants of all kinds,serving a gourmet of food and have quirky and unique settings. Shopping here needs your bargaining expertise.

Wasnt expecting such a labyrinth of a city - Thamel. Thamel is a real contradiction. An amazingly awesome contradiction. I had read about Nepal. Friendly people, a natural wonder and gateway to the Himalayas and was expecting to find small buildings, and lots of greenery, parks and open spaces. My first glimpse was from the plane. It is huge, it is high rise and it is most definitely a city. But Thamel is friendly, fun and full of culture. It is absolutely worth a visit and it is truly a heart-warming place. Today I sat for an hour watching men, small Nepalese men, cart baskets of heavy wet concrete up 5 storeys of stairs to flick the basket and empty the contents into a pile so the next level of a new hotel could be built. It was back breaking work and they did it with a smile, laughter and a lot of hard work. They are traditionalists and at sundown we watched as many people filed passed a bell to ring to signalling the end of the day. The day had been sunny and I watched as all the women climbed to their roof top terraces to hang their washing on a glorious day, they also took the opportunity to wash their hair and to see mothers, daughters and grand-mothers all sitting and brushing each other's hair and enjoying the sun and the great natural hairdryer was such a calming and simply enjoyable experience. We take a lot for granted in life, and Thamel makes you realise that these people are happy, truly happy and have not much more than the clothes on their backs. A life lesson learned in Thamel.

busy and dusty and it all happens here!. the city center of kathmandu, all the bars, lotsa hotels, good shopping. must visit for a couple of days but no need to stay too long, nepal is too big and beautiful to be in thamel!

Place to stay!. I like the location, to feel the touristy and the local life as well. Many restaurants, bars, travel agents, and shopping places. The great thing is many places has a free wifi-spot!
Traffic, traffic! Small streets like in Thamel should not allows cars to be entered.
Get lost in the streets. Ive been to Thamel several times, it is a beautiful and bustling place. Just remember never to travel alone and completely trust anyone in the streets.

Noise and pollution coupled with a great atmosphere !. I stayed in the centre of Thamel and got used to the narrow streets, heavy traffic congestion and the general chaotic nature of the place. I enjoyed the local restaurants and bars all with relatively cheap prices. It is a great place to do your holiday present shopping and hone your bartering skills. I got used to the taxi and rickshaw touts! ( never were they remotely aggressive but just doing their best to earn a living)

Loved Thamel! Charming!. Its the touristic area in KTM, its full of shoppes where you can find everything for your trekking plus souvenirs and handcrafts. The best hotels for tourists are here, that is why you will see tons of them! As it is full of foreigners, sellers raise the prices, tough it is easy to bargain and get the things you want at reasonable prices. Locals are friendly!
lively!. Thamel is the lively tourist centre of Kathmandu, bustling markets, cool shops. Very near all the main attractions, if you don't go to Thamel, you haven't been to Kathmandu!!
Thamel. Thamel Kathmandu is a Tourist Hub of Nepal. The beautiful market Thamel covers many hotels,.........

Tourist Trap. Thamel was listed as a great destination for tourists and we had a few hours to spend for touring around Kathmandu, so we decided to go there for some souvenirs. We soon grew very tired of fighting the street traffic because there are very few sidewalks. There are tons of stores there, but they all sell the same mix of jewelry, scarves, or trinkets. Also, bring your bargaining skills because they will quote you some outrageous opening prices and your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to get them down to about half of that price. It wasn't really our thing; we would have preferred a more open area with some haggle-free shopping.

Annapurna base camp and poonhill. Thamel tours guided us to Annapurna base camp through Poon hill. For this trip we had a very new car transfer from Kathmandu to Pokhara and back after the trek. The trek had wonderful views of the great Himalayas. Our guide was really friendly man in his mid twenties. He arranged our daily meals and tea houses excellently. It was very well arranged trek. We mostly ate nepali dal bhat during our trek.
Very crowded. A very crowded and busy shopping area. Good for shopping as almost anything and everything is sold there...but personally would not like to stay there.

Nightlife. Thamel is one of the most famous place amongst the foreigners from USA, Europe, Australia, etc...This place is full of nightlife...restaurants, hotels, discos, etc...Tourists can enjoy variety of foods, enjoy music, dance etc...Really a best place to enjoy...Also there are many tourist shops and also many shops selling trekking goods....

Super restaurant serving traditional food. We had a multi-course Nepali meal and it was superb. Excellent value and a choice of vegetarian or non-vegetarian menu. On leaving, they present you with a souvenir of Nepal.
Nice for shopping. The tourist enclave is dirty and loud, but good for shopping and convenient for the number of restaurants one can find there. I would prefer stay in Boudhanath though.
Charming part of town. The main tourist district & a haven for charming trinkets, trekking gear and just about anything else!
Roads?. The city should make this area a walking street only as it's hard to observe the stores when you are fearing for your life from the traffic on such narrow "paths"

Shops everywhere!. It's true that walking around Thamel can be chaotic and risky because its traffic. But it is the shopping centre in Kathmandu. You can find all types of shops there. Handicrafts, jewelry, tea shops, Tibetan paintings, book shops, and of course, mountain clothes and equipment shops. I specially recomend Himalayan Hardwear in a corner of Jyatha street, the have good prices and all type of materials. Don't forget to try Nepalese food in any of the restaurants you can find around these streets.
Fascinating Temple Complex. Fascinating Temple complex in small area, so easy to access and tour. Also restored so is in great condition.
Interesting. Nice place to shop. Good vibe in the evenings. Lot of hustle and bustle. Filled with a great variety of restaurants.
Interesting. It's hard to characterize Thamel - a lot of dust and pollution, but interesting in its variety in the same time. A lot of shops, a lot of cars and a lot of guesthouses.
Shopping. Cafes, restaurants and if you look hard, good quality outdoor clothing. Area was well lit and at no time did we feel hassled or threatened
Shopping in Thamel. Brilliant. So much choice of beautiful things and friendly shop keepers plus good prices. I am so thrilled with my purchases.

偶有驚喜的購物聖地. to bein Thamel,of cause you have to go shopping,shopping and shopping.even all they are quite cheap but you may also find some stroes that have marked price.and it's much cheaper than other stores.and don't forget to find singing bowl that sound will make you drunk.even if you didn't buy but also worth a try where people are friendly.by the way,some restaurant and teahouse in Thamel are also tasty with beautiful price. OK,excursus,air and traffic in Thamel is really bad,haha.

Good place to shop if you can bargain. I like to shop in Nepal, the shopkeeper wont follow you around all the time, they just comeover when you asked the price. I got irritated when the shop keeper following me. You should bargain, my local friend said that at least you should start your bargain 40% from the price the offered. Happy shoping :)

A Mixed Bag for Tourists . In a way, it's still the most happening place for tourists. Decent economy hotels, excellent eating joints, and quite in the centre of most sightseeing destinations in Katmandu. However some would prefer staying away from it all & choose to stay at much quieter places.... But then, for a first-timer, I would surely recommend a taste of the place. Thamel has a milieu of it's own, distinct & attractive.

Amazing shops !!!. Bargin hard as overpriced !!!! Shops along the streets squashed into every available space- cars and motorbikes share the road with pedestrians - noisy with hawkers selling their wares and horns beeping you to move out the way - crazy and fun, but remember bargin hard!!!!!!!

Shop until you drop. Shopping, clubs, restaurants, cafes, everything. If shopping ask around on prices. Most things can be found in many shops and it is enlightening to hear the "walkaway" prices to get a benchmark of what you can pay. Don't be upset about paying too little, the shop-keeps will not sell if they are not making a profit no mater how much the pretend.

Great place for tourists to stay!. This is a great area for tourists. I was staying with a host family, but if I ever was craving American food or pizza, I would find myself wandering back into Thamel. The shops are also a great place to get souvenirs (but be careful of being charged more by vendors). My favorite place to eat was OR2K, and I could get access to specialty coffees at Himalayan Java. With that said, I would still recommend exploring outside of Thamel to get a real feel for Nepali life.

Thamel area. Thamel is probably the shopping area and main tourist area in Katmandu. Not too far to walk to interesting sights. It is virtually all shops and small hotels. Plenty of restaurants and shops. (I had to leave my group in Lhasa and fly to Katmandu as I was sick in Lhasa and could not go to Everest Base Camp with my group. So had to wait for them in Katmandu for 5 days. During that time had a car and guide for 3 hours a day for 4 days, but they stayed in Katmandu. Got them to take me to the zoo and that was enjoyable. Also out to a small village was interesting.Spent most days walking around Thamel.)

Impossible not to go. visiting, or passing by, definitely the place to be. Shop for supplies for our trekking at anapurna in thamel. Impossible not finding what you want... The choices are endless. Crowded, dusty and crammed, it needs some getting used to. still an amazing spot.

Christmas Shopping. We took the time to look at what was in offer in the shops and got a list together as to what various people would get as presents. The problem is that very few shops mark prices on anything so you have to ask and formulate a probable price for a commodity. This all takes time and can be an interesting experience. Sometimes we would be up and down a street a few times to get the better deal or quality of item. Some shops can have fairly persuasive staff! In the end we got what we wanted and were satisfied.

Crazy place. THE tourist meca for Kathmandu. Crazy in many ways and always hectic. But, you have to go there. It's got everything you need and many things you never will need. If you can't find it in Thamel, it probably doesn't exist

Honk-Honk, get out the way!. This is a culture shock, coming from a typical European city but its a definite must-see for at least 2-3 days. Make sure to head out South of Thamel as well to visit more the more local markets etc.

Streets and streets lined with teensie shops. While there are hundreds of shops, you soon realize there is much repetition in merchandise making 'bargaining' fun as you choose handmade items made in Nepal or name brand ski wear. The "felted wool" items are beautiful and plentiful. Consider wearing a mask while traversing these busy streets. The air pollution is palpable and cumulative.
Excellent shoping view. For tourist it is very attractive view of the curves and nerves.Good shopping complex.Good place for shopping.
Fun part of town. Thamel was a fun shopping district. It also seemed to have the best hotels and restaurants. We didn't have any issues with the food here.
Shopping Paradise. A place not to be missed with lots of shopping. But you really need to bargain, probably slash the prices quoted to 50%-60%.
Kathmandu's Soho. This is where you'll find all the restaurants, bars, shops and guaranteed to find something to your liking.
busy streets of Thamel. Loved the festive feel of the Thamel markets, the amazing works of art in their souvenirs ad the friendly people. The traffic is an experience for the unseasoned.

Narrow, crowded, noisy, dusty. The place is sure of loads of hotels and travel agents. However, I found it crowded and very dusty. The street is very narrow too. I recommend anyone to stay outside Thamel and only come for a visit.

Tourist place for all. Thamel is where tourists stay when in Kathmandu. Thamel has rooms available from US$15 to US$200. Full of shops for all kind of things and to help you to take your Trek from 2 to 20 days.

nothing very impressive about thamel. not very impressed with the shops in thermal. most of the shops have cheap imitation and quality is a big question.. the only decent bargains are in the thanks paintings and some carpets

It is what it is.... Khatmandu and more specifically the Thamel are interesting places to see; they have unique characteristics that will either make you crazy or broaden your horizons. It is very dusty, dirty and smells of garbage/sewage that is masked by incense. It is not to be missed but I would recommend staying in Bhaktapur and only visiting the Thamel for as long as one can stomach it. More positively there are some wonderful restaurants and cultural sites to visit.

Touristy. It was nice to walk through however area around Ason (between Durbar square and Tamel) is much more interesting and less touristy. You can just stand and watch as people walk by in their hundreds. There are small little alleyways full of interesting buildings. Also prices are half of those in Tamel. I wouldn't do more than just walk through Tamel.
Fun!. Lots to do and see in Thamel - good restaurants, coffee shops, street vendors and shops. You can find anything for sale there. Be sure to bargain!

Chaos. This by far one the most chaotic shopping areas. Unfortunately like the rst of Kathmandu it has become vey busy with traffic and dust! Many places for bargain if you what you want and know the real stuff. Many good eating places!

This review is subjective to your expectations. We stayed in the heart of Thamel and everything you want you can find here. Seriously, literally, all of it, everything. Prices are also much cheaper than elsewhere because of competition. Caveat, this place is absolutely busy it will make you dizzy. From shopping, food, laundry service by the kilo, souvenirs, handicrafts, tailors, money transfer, and every imaginable need of the tourist.

Wander around the streets. Restaurants all round, shops all round, if you like to wander around and feel safe this is the place. Quaint shops mixed with modern hotels. Slightly crowded, like anywhere in Asia.

A chaotic must see shopping paradise of colours, noise, people, and cars.. The place to go to shop for all your Nepalese souvenirs , trekking apparel,gemstones, artwork and everyday goods.It is extremely busy, and unless you are careful you will get run over but then you can recover in one of the many quaint terrace cafés!!You cannkot go to Kathmandu and miss Thamel!!

Over-rated - with care. Thamel is full of shops and is like a maze. Easy to get lost and get cheated. Difficult to locate a place again - at least in my experience. As a tourist, you will be the target for exorbitant prices by most traders. Even for a magnetic sticker, prices can range from Rs. 40 to Rs. 150 plus. O ne can possibly bargain, but they may quote very high and bring it down a little. It is difficult to find a shop with marked or fixed prices for Tangkas or other items. One has to be careful of vehicles and motorbikes which do not care for pedestrians in narrow streets.. There are food stalls and restaurants of varying quality and cleanliness.Still it is a place worth a visit, but better to go in company and keep track of where you go.
Great experience in Thamel. Love that you can wander around, barter with the merchants without being hassled along the street, great restaurants, amazing place to be.

Stay away its the worst mixture of eastern and western culture. I really disliked this area of seedy shops and fake holy men AKA beggars. It was terrible dirty, and was full of drug dealers, seedy shops and one or two nice restaurants. I would avoid this place like the plague, unless you are looking to score drugs.

Busy and interesting.. The streets are full of beautiful and colorful Nepali things. A bit pricey esp for tourists. And a u have to be alert when walking around, narrow streets full of people and cars and bikes.
Manic but great. Twisting alleys ways packed with shops and restaurants. Not pestered or hassled to buy. Great atmosphere.

a must visit for all visitors to Kathmandu. Once upon a time - when the hippies all congregated near Durbar Square and hung out on Freak Street - Thamel was a sleepy residential backwater with a couple of hotels and some pioneer restaurants (including KC's - still there after many decades). Gradually over the years it became a centre for foreign tourists, with numerous places to stay from the cheapest lodges to the most expensive luxury hotels, restaurants ditto and shops selling all kinds of stuff from trekking equipment to curios and handmade art and artefacts and clothing. Now it buzzes with activity, offering tourists and others an amazing range of restaurants offering ethnic food from all over the world as well as some basic Nepal restaurants with dhal-bhat; and coffee houses and dance-bars and nightclubs for the wealthier youth of Kathmandu who flock in for an evening of mild naughtiness. In fact its getting overcrowded and the older buildings are being replaced with more modern structures - eventually it risks losing its appeal and becoming something garish and over-priced... I still keep coming back.. but for how much longer?

Best place to stay. Amazing area with great number of unusual people from all over the world! If you are going to Kathmandu it's the best place to stay! Amazing restaurants with all kinds of cuisine, great night clubs, thousands of shops!

Go and visit, but not in the late evening. Many shops, bars and restaurants in this area. For shopping it is a true walhalla, but in the evening there is a strange vibe on the streets, police everywhere. Due to local fighting and alcohol abuse.

Place of COLORS, PPL, SHOPS & MADNESS. Strictly visit on Friday & Saturday. This is a land of Colors where you may find each & every thing to shop. But be aware the rates are on higher side. You may find some good bakery shops & places to chill out. I would specially suggest FACES Lounge located on Nurshim Chowk. Remaining you go, WATCH OUT & NJOY !!

Noisy. We stayed in Thamel for nearly 4 weeks, found it noisy and polluted by the many cars and motorbikes on the streets. At first we also got hassled by taxi drivers and stallholders, though this got better as we started using a few Nepali phrases and became familiar to the locals, who realised we were no longer newly arrived tourists. Lots of bars and restaurants. I wouldn't reccomend staying in the heart of Thamel for more than a week or two.
Good for relaxation. Almost every bar. club, restaurants, hotel and shopping are in Thamel. It is heaven for nightlife. Go to faces bar for drink where you will encounter with Himalayan Beauties!!!

mad and chaotic. Just take it in, walk around, feel the vibes and the gaze around. Take a tea in the inner courtyard of one of the hotels (Like KGH), don't miss Pilgims book shop, and hundreds of other places. Night time is even more fun!

Experience an ambience of Thamel. Thamel is the tourist enclave. There are many shops where you can buy original souvenirs, trekking gears, small restaurants and reasonable guesthouses and a lively nightlife.You will meet all kinds of people here. Must visit, so much to do
great place for cafes. thamel is plenty of lanes of local knick knacks and cafes... we went there three evenings in a row for dinner to different places... you can walk around and browse..

Shoping Paradise!. You name it they have it kind of place.You can find all real and fake sport wear.They have great antique stores for local stuff.They do bargain but not push you to make a forced decission.They are open untill late(20.30)So you can shop after exploring temples.

Where else?!. Where else would you ever be if you are in Kathmandu! Thamel is the first place you would go. hotels to shopping to music, it is a one long stretch of colors that you will never forget in your life. Chill!~

STREETS OF THAMEL. A mind blowing experience of sensory overload, from wandering around the many contorted little streets & back ways to haggling with street traders, who know to the last rupee, just how low they are prepared to drop their price for a sale. It's all part of the fun & experience of shopping in Thamel & there's so much to buy. An Army Ghurka knife or Khookeri is a must, but be sure it has all its accessories. Yes, Australian customs will let you bring them in if you declare it, I have several various types.Also, Thamel has some terrific restaurants & eateries, from places like Kilroys, whose menu rarely changes but the food is great, to the amazing Garden of Dreams, a few metres down the road from the main Thamel crossroads to smaller joints in the back streets like New Orleans Jazz. Try them all & experience the fun of Kathmandu eating. Don't forget to try a long neck of icy cold Everest beer.......
market market market. sometimes I wonder if there is anything you cannot buy there... good bargains if you now how to play

A Wonderful market to pick up cheap trek / travel equipment & souvenirs back home. The Heart of Kathmandu , Thamel is the backpacker district of Nepal , almost everything can be bought , sold & organised here , be it buying / selling a motorbike to drive across nepal , arranging permits for a trek to hiring a local agency for arranging guides , to buying cheap knock off equipment of northface , marmot , etc , or shopping for souvenirs back home ..Plenty of cheap guesthouses , free wifi, loads of restaurants to try different cuisines from around the world to plenty of options for late night parties , this is where you will connect with travellers from across the globe , and make friends and find travel companionsA Word of Caution... Thamel has many scams to rip you off... yak wool products are a definite no - no , the prices must be haggled / bargained to atleast 2/3rd of he price quoted , it would be a good idea to get a fair price by asking in a couple of shops...never entertain any touts who may offer anything from drugs & prostitutes to free beer.

A Must Experience. Colorful Thamel probably has not changed substantially in a thousand years. Enjoy the hustle, bustle, noise and crush of the crowds. If you can't find whatever you want in Thamel, it probably doesn't exist! BTW, I strongly suggest you wear a dust mask wherever you go in Kathmandu.

Too many tourists and too many same same. We did only a quick tour through the crowded streets and found it not very interesting. Souvenirshops that sell the same stuff. We were not impressed. Had a nice beer though and Some fingerfood at the Thamel restaurant

Crazy Place. Its a nice place with a nice vibe. Parties happening everywhere all the time. The only place in Kathmandu where you can walk around anytime at night and have a good time. Will be staying there again..
Shopping. Shopping location for pashminas, other touristy trinkets. Need to bargain. Singing bowls, kukhri sword, and pashminas are the usual suspects to get.

Kathmandu's main tourist district. Lots of small shops with typical Nepali merchandise for tourists. You need good bargaining skills. If not, go to the adjacent neighborhood where the same products are sold at Nepali prices. It helps of course if you have a local with you. Walking in the small Thamel streets might be a little challenging when dealing with the many taxis, motorcycles and rikhsjas (?).

What a buzzing shopping area to see. This place is amazing - it just buzzes. The streets are narrow and dirt. It is full of cars bikes and walkers. There are shops selling tourist stuff, and cheap trekking gear everywhere. Lots of good eateries and little places to stay. Despite the place being so busy we felt safe and had no problems (although the haggling over price wears thin after a while). Wish we had waited to buy our treking gear there (esp trousers, shirts, coats, water bottles, etc) as they are as little as 15 to 20% of prices in western countries: whilst the quality varies a lot, they were more than good enough for the average trekker. Great range of tourist stuff to get to take home for friends, eg embroidered T-Shirts around Rs500 to 650 (US$5.50 to US$6). You shouldn't go through Kathmandu without at least a walk through this area.

goodwill spa & beauty parlour. I highly recommend this place to anyone out there looking to get a hair cut and not regretting it at the end.I got my hair cut by a sweet lady named indu, she is very patient and good at what she does.  i got a really bad hair cut the day before and she managed to fix it in no time.The salon is simple and clean. its located in the thamel opposite to A-one complex. (Bhagwatibahal thamel 29) tel: 00977-1-4432332

Tourist Zone. For any typical tourist I would say Thamel remains the central point with plenty of hotels with all categories, restaurants, shopping, Travel Agents. If you are staying in this location I guess you can cut town your transporation costs.

Centre to all Activities. Thamel is a centre of tourists attractions. All types of Hotels around. All type of shopping can be done here . Pl. note that this is the place where your bargain skills are tested . Lot of bargaining . Rs.5000 thing can be bought in 2000 . Night life is around this area. Night clubs too.

Shopping mecca. If you want to shop in Nepal, this is the place. It's crowded and congested at times, but again if shopping is your priority this is the place to be.Couple of things to note... Keep an eye out for knock offs. Especially North Face gear. That jacket you loved back home that cost $400 and is just $26 dollars here in Thamel is that price for a reason. Check the tags and make sure the materials match expectations. Second, I suggest staying off the big streets and shopping in the smaller allies. The probability of getting something cheaper is higher there. That and bargaining power. One must haggle and haggle a lot. I haggle more I nepal than I even do in India because all the shops carry mostly the same stuff... So if you don't like the price at the first place, simply move on to the next store. If you find it was cheaper at a previous store after all, 97% of the time they will still honor it.

Can't say enough. If you don't stay there, well at least visit.. Got a hotel here on recommendations off tripadvisor. Glad I did. This is a "backpackers" area, but I have had tons of fun just walking around and taking in the sights an sounds,....and sounds there are aplenty. Get a high room or a sound proof room. Noise from noon until about 2 in the morning. That being said, I would not trade my noisy room for the world. Or a different world which this place is. One has to work to get the reality of the place, so much fake despair hiding the real despair of which there is plenty. This is a very poor country and city and area and you will have to figure out how to navigate it with compassion . Figure out which of the persons need to be ignored and or "watched". If in Kathmandu this place is a must see.

Avitaar. Hotel write up for AvitaarAs first guests at the newly opened Avitaar we were more than pleasantly surprised on our arrival! After a long day of travel our airconditioned room felt wonderful. The room thoroughly sparkled. It was clean and polished with glittering chrome and shining marble surfaced counters. It was a joy to be part of the opening ribbon cutting ceremony. Located in the hustle and bustle of Thamel, this hotel is clean, quiet and sure to delight.
Chaotic!. Thamel was a very busy tourist shopping area. I'm not a big shopper plus I was trying hard to avoid being hit by cars.

Nice Things to buy. Thamel is a nice and less crazy than other parts of Kathmandu... Lovely stuff to buy but people will charge higher prices for tourists, so be aware! It's nicer at night as there is less traffic and the shops stay open late...

Shop until you drop. Great shopping area with a great variety of shops. Things range from antiques to original Mandelas and a large variety of tourist souvenirs. You can bargain with most of the shopkeepers.

Must see area!. You must go to Thamel when you come to Kathmandu. Large area in city that is full of mountaineering and clothing stores, books, bars, hotels, restaurants, etc. Built to cater to the crowd of tourists headed on treks. The area is very inexpensive. You can get nearly anything in this area of the city. Highly recommend!

Trekkers Shopping at its best. Buy all your trekking gear here, at a fraction of the price overseas, its top quality, and the range is huge. All the brands, probably fake, but still from the same factory, only the locals know how to source it without the middle man. Great variety of cafes, bars, shops, restaurants and accommodation all pitched to the trekker and the tourist. Everyone speaks polite competent English and you can even get great camera gear, designer brand clothes and the best maps and gear in just about every corner of every street. free wifi everywhere you eat and every culinary wish met from Asian, European, African and island. its all here in Thamel.

Drool you hikers. Thamel is the refuge for the trekkers and hikers who do not wish to get robbed by the big brands. One can get good equipment from a basic set of shoes to best ice ax. Though the biggies have set up shops here, few strolls around will make you aware of the treasure available there.Pros- Large variety of things on sale. Also good place for souvenirs & gifts to carry home. One can find good, knowledgeable photographers and book sellers.Cons- If you are not good at bargaining... then you miss all the fun.Good place to stay if you need to live the pulse of Kathmandu... during the day and nights ;)
Trekkers area.... Trekkers from all over the world gathers here. Here you can buy (copies of course) equipment, clothing etc for your trek. Just check the quality!!

Heart of Kathmandu. This is where all foreigners come to after landing in Kathmandu. This is a tourist's delight with various options of dining & shopping all available at the same place. There are many good hotels as well as budget hotels in Thamel.

Crazy but a must see. Here you shop, eat and people watch. Some travellers are as interesting as the locals. Just pause and look. Rickshaws can be a pest but you can take a ride or ignore them. This is the site of the best bookstore in the world: Pilgrims. The original burnt down to the ground last year but ther was another branch in existence before that happened. You can get great books here. An amazing variety, especially books about Tibet and the Himalayas. Modern fiction also available. I always buy heaps of books and CDs and DVDs here.

The tourist centre of Kathmandu. It's amazing that no one gets run over in the busy streets. Everyone is friendly and happy. Outdoor shops abound with every type of equipment from best quality to grade 10. Tiger balm and various plants are offered by the minute. Local artefacts and gems are on sale everywhere under the random umbrellas of 500 wire telegraph poles. The bustle is electric ,inspiring and enjoyable. Meals are available anywhere and are very cheap. A great place to buy all your Christmas presents for next to nothing.

Touristy but nice. Thamel is very touristy, but it is also very convenient. Filled with trekking shops, hotels, bars and restaurants it is the most convenient place for a tourist to stay in Kathmandu. It is within walking distance of all the sights, and if you venture a few streets away then you can escape the tourist atmosphere. Just don't expect it to reflect the real Kathmandu and you wont be dissapointed.

Super place to shop.... Brilliant place to do all your shopping for yourself or gifts - no other place we visited in Nepal had so much and at such prices. Browse around and try to buy the most in one place. You have much better bargaining power even if you do it for fun of it.
good place to stay. This place was nearby from airport to stay and move around to shop necessary things. I did bit shopping from here and the price was reasonable.

It's what you must see when in Kathmandu.. After 3 hours, you might have enough of it; but it is a wonderful 3 hours. Beware, a lot of the goods are probably cheap fakes, but you will experience backbapacking, climbing, treking Kathmandu and local vibe like nowhere else in town

Worth a visist if you are staying near by. This district is full of shops and restaurants, heavy on climbing stores, and Nepali souveners. Very crowded narrow streets. Very dark at night and dangerous due to cars and motor bikes and lack of side walks.
Walk like a local. I love it, but you need to be like a local otherwise locals will annoy you and follow you around asking for a taxi, bike, to buy stuffs...etc

Culture Place... Compare to 2 years ago when I first went to Nepal, they are more commercialize now. Maybe there are more and more tourist from all over the world visiting Nepal.. I can feel the pure humanity has slowly fade away... a little bit of disappointment during my second visit. But I still love this country as what I always do.

Get whatever you want in Thamel. Thamel is the place to get everything: good food, good drinks, decent lodging, clothes, accessories and so on. It's cramped, crowded and loud but it's great to visit and soak in. A must do in Kathmandu for westerners!

good for shopping only. the place has large number of shops which are priced correctly. you can get everything that you need to buy in Nepal. avoid the night clubs in the area. there are some nice restaurants and supermarket in this area. A must visit in Kathmandu.

Barter barter barter. This is a shoppers Mecca. Well for anything Nepali,India,China. Original are only in local fabrics like wools rocks. But there are great fakes! Never believe exactly what your told, a little knowledge goes a long way. Keep your sense of humour! Have a masala tea.

Great fun & bargains (I think) to be had. Many many shops, most of which sell the same things (cashmere, pashmina, tea, coffee, local style souvenirs ....). Lanes are a little crazy and you need to keep your wits about you as cars and motorbikes drive through. Everything is to be haggled for and from my experience you can achieve 20% of the initial asking price - the traders will really try it on at the start, but be prepared to walk away and prices soon come down and there are some great value purchase opportunities.I ate at two restaurants here (Thamel House and Eco restaurant) and had good meals at great prices.

The Essence of Kathmandu. Thamel is crazy and chaotic and wonderful. The people are hardworking and friendly and a simple "no, thank you" is sufficient to get rid of unwanted solicitors. It's hard not to love.

it is a awesome and a huge market place for travellers.. it is a awesome and a huge market place for travellers. their is too much costly thing. You can go to Bishal bazzar without going there. it s a good and nice place

Bustling touristy street. Its noisy, bustling with activity, tourist friendly and a must visit.The shops might sell the goods for a higher price but the street offers not just shops but also restaurants and cafes which are tucked in a corner offering beer and food.It is safe for women, and brilliant if one wants to shop for jewellery, artifacts, trekking gears and more.

It grows on you.... Thamel is the touristy neighbourhood which reflects Kathmandu's identity - chaotic, crowded, dusty and noisy. My first impression of Thamel, as a result, was that it was terrible. I wanted to rate it 1 out of 5.Over time though I began to embrace Thamel, BECAUSE I began to embrace Kathmandu and all its qualities that make it both challenging and amazing. And Thamel was no different than the rest of the city, it just has more tourists.Of course, as a traveler, I enjoyed some of the amenities in Thamel that tourists look for, such as Wifi, maps, bike rentals, English books, and hippie clothes. But I lodged outside of Thamel, and ate outside of it as well, where I found much cheaper, tastier and genuine eats. I would recommend you do the same.

So alive but be sure to stay alive there!. Such a vivid and active place day and night. But walking, driving or being at the streets of Thamel can be dangerous if you are not sed to the crowd. Cars and bikes drive too close to shops and people there so be careful. The road is not all paved so you will need a bandanna to cover your mouth and nose from the dust or car fumes. Nevertheless, it is such an active place with plenty of souvenir shops, restaurants and hotels.
Loved the Shops.... Great Restaurants and Shopping place, Bought lovely Pashmina shawls, singing bowls, Statues and the Thanka Paintings...But have to Bargain hard...

Nepal main street. It was extremely crowed, dangerous with the travif and narow streets, although the up side was there were some great cafes, book stores The Pilgrim and fabulous shopping, but one must look for good deal and barter. Worth the trip, but just be careful and don't hang out long!

The most touristy place of Kathmandu. Thamel is obviously a must see and many people stay here but it is truly crazy. The roads are filled with cars, the pollution is bad and also the tooting horns is out of control. Its good to stay here a few nights then venture out of the city. There are a heap of good restaurants and night spots but they all finish by 11pm.
Everything you need is here. It's a crazy busy street/place! But everything you might need is here--from souvenirs, restaurants/bars/cafes, tour/trekking service/info.
shops tourists. You canot avoid Thamel with all the tourists all the shops . you can buy everything and you have to make a good and charming barging. People are nice and have a sence of humour

Crazy Fun. Cheap thrills! Nice merchandise at a 'good' price if you can bargain. Everyone, and I mean EVERYONE, is out to get you so start at less than half of their first quoted price. The musical instrument vendors are annoying and will harass you, so don't talk to them unless you are up for this experience. It was dry when we went, so it was very dusty! I could not get enough! Have I mentioned that everyone wants to overcharge you?!......

Just a great big shopping district. Still worth a visit to try and absorb the organised chaos.. Shopping mainly. However, watching people weave in and out of traffic without hazard is truly fascinating. How these taxi drivers do this day after day is beyond me. Lots of lovely bright colours and interesting characters about.

Good marketplace. A good market place for travel needs. But must go around and bargain hard before settling to buy anything. Has an express laundry service at couple of places. Not very good quality but they deliver on time. 2-3 money changers also exchange currency at a very competitive rates.

Kathmandu's one-stop tourist hub. Thamel is everything you'd expect a city's backpackers' area to be, a one-stop tourist spot for shopping, dining, and nightlife. The streets are kind of tricky to navigate because they don't have street signs, Google maps don't work here, and vehicles just suddenly appear from all directions. There are lots of shops for trekkers and souvenir-hunters. Shops and restaurants close relatively early though at around 11pm.

Chaos!. Thamel is a typical touristy area existing in most cities that are well-known attractions. Here, you'll find all kinds of souvenirs you can imagine: from incense to 18th-century army knives. People will come up to you with any services possible, among which, I believe, trekking is the most popular. If you're here for traveling and having fun, this is the area to stay. If you're here for an internship, volunteering or anything down that road that lasts for months, staying here might be bit too much.
Kathmandu Guest House & it's surrounds. An oasis in the hustle & very interesting bustle of Thamel. GO for it!Durbar Square well worth a visit & only 20 minutes safe walk from KGH.
Best Shopping. It is quite the experience to travel around Thamel in a Rickshaw. Lots of great places to eat and shops to barter in.

A crazy, hectic but fun area. Thamel can be a bit much to take when you first arrive but you quickly fall into the pace. There are people everywhere trying to sell you all kinds of things you never thought you might need or want, tons of tourist offices, guesthouses, restaurants and shops along with street vendors and beggars and holy areas. I ended up enjoying the area so much that I stayed there all three times I was in Kathmandu.
Vibrant area. Great area to stay in & visit - never a dull moment! Full of interesting little shops, plus lots of interesting restaurants & local sights.

Busy place, noisy at night. We slept few nights in Thamel before and after the trek. The music at night was very loud that we could sleep properly. For travelers looking to sleep peacefully, a bit off from main town is recommended. Else good place, lots of restaurants and shops!

The Hustle Bustle of Thamel. This area in Kathmandu is the 'tourist' area, with shops, stall, cafes, restaurants and street hawkers galore. I absolutely loved it here but the pollution - oh my! Locals were hardly ever seen out and about without a mask to cover their noses and mouths, so bad was it, But if you can push that back to a far corner of your mind, you'll love it too! Some of the prices here are quite hefty compared with places off the beaten track. but if you are willing to take the time to negotiate, you can get a real bargain. I bought some Tibetan-style blankets for an absolute SONG! We also stayed in a hotel in the Thamel area - The Lhasa - cheap as chips with a friendly atmosphere created by the Buddhist owners. Marvelous experience Wouldn't have missed it for the world.

Tourist Ghetto. U will not have missed thamel, it has everything the traveller needs but is to overcrowded to enjoy. Yet u will find all your needs for eating, sleeping, recreation, adventure sports, tours, tickets n trekking gear here!I have a love hate relationship to thamel!can not recommend it but always find myself there....:-)welcoem to nepal! but remember to check out from thamel n see the real kathmandu and nepal!AVOID - Dance Bars!!!
Love the hustle and bustle of this place. Love the busy streets - roaming about the shops and great places to eat. Mandela Street is nice and with no traffic.

Fabulous, colorfull, user friendly!. We spent one week in Kathmandu in Thamel area with short trips here and there. It is full of shops, bars and restaurants so that everyone can find something nice. If you miss some sports gear you can sure buy one... The quality can be poor but the price may be good :). Looks with atmosphere similar to Khao San in Bangkok with friendly locals. One of must tries are small snack are momos dumplings in one of Thamel restaurants!

Energy, energy, energy. Thamel is a vibrant part of Kathmandu and is constantly busy. The place is bustling with shops, restaurants, bars and coffee shops. The best bit is that most of them have free wi-fi. Haggle hard and dont be shy to walk away - there will be another 20 shops offering the same thing. Don't believe the fixed price sign either - everything is negotiable.

Chaos. If you like crowded conditions and tons of people, then this is the place for you. But the traffic congestion and the dirty smog their vehicles pour out was overwhelming for me. Better to visit the souvenir shops on the main street: Durbar Marg.
big lunapark. you have it all under your thumb...every thing you drea just name it.do not missdo not stay too long

Such a lively place!. I just loved it! Its a place full of life! vibrant! Color was everywhere. I felt so alive and connected while I was in Thamel. There were people from different places, countries you can mingle with. If you love people definitely this is your kinda place!

Chaos, overpriced, dusty & excellent.... We stayed at a guest house on the outskirt of thamel and used to go to a walk in the heart every evening.. like to tahity, jp marg, jayatha, thamel marg etc... most of the shops sell the same thing.... good restaurants are there as well as hotels too.... but it's better to stay on the outskirts to have good nights sleep... going after 8pm must be discouraged as at that time the ugly part of the place comes out... like you will be asked if you'd like any drugs, girls, dancing clubs etc... but good thing they are not aggressive... will leave you once getting a negative answer. But hey that is the way a tourist district should be....

A Nice Launching Point for Nepal. I like to enjoy restaurants, bars and shops frequented by locals when I visit new places, but having a starting point that is a little more oriented to tourists can make it easier to get used to a country. Thamel was that easier introduction for my group. Because it offered a slightly sanitized version of Kathmandu, it was easier for us to split up in pairs or as individuals when we were in Thamel. There are shops down each and every street and people are constantly trying to sell to you. Between that and the noisy traffic, Thamel can get overwhelming. But there are restaurants serving local goof as well as catering to tourist' tastes so there are plenty of places to duck into for quiet.

Good but crowdy. This place is nice for the facilities but very crowd. You will not like this place much but if you go away you will try to come back to this place also because you can find there everything. You can get any information of nepal in there.

Intriguing. The "cheap stuff tourists trap" of Kathmandu. Shocking / revolting / intruiging / colorful / noisy / bizaar beauty / great variety of food - people - fragrants.
A "must" visit to better understand a different view / aspect of Nepal

Get to know the local restaurants. I lived here for two months and at first it is hectic. Yes there is lots of pollution and people selling you things non stop in the streets but if you find a nice quite place to stay and explore the local dhabas than you can easily fall in love with the area.

chaos. lots of shops and restaurants, hard to buy anything unless you have something specific in mind. all seems fake, too much pressure in shops. area very crowded and polluted, even locals wear masks. but we found a good restaurant.

Lively and with the vibe... As Thamel is the "touristy" part of Kathmandu, as tourists ,we decided to stay in a hotel in this area. The area is throbbing with activity as tourists walk around the narrow, crowded streets looking over the shops selling all the touristy thing. You find any number of shops, located in the confusing maze of streets, selling traditional handicrafts Trekking kit and clothes all at prices that are very "bargainable". Dozens and dozens of cafes, restaurants and bars serve a wide variety of food from all over the world. As the roads are narrow and crowded with people and vehicles, you have to be a bit careful while strolling around. he area seems quite safe though a bit later at night ganja and "masti" are on
Noisy but what an experience. Its definitely something you can't miss. Take it slow and enjoy the trip. Dont forget to haggle for a bargain.
Get havoc in Thamel. It is basically where trekkers got dumped, because its trekkers heaven! You could shop till you drop!
Oasis for tourists. A typical overcrowded tourist district with many expensive shops (do no expect do find any bargain prices there!) but a practical and good start point to visit Kathamandu.

Perfect shopping destination. The streets are busy, dirty, and crowded--that's the beauty of Kathmandu. There are shops upon shops of glorious handmade products from Cashmere shawls, yak yarn throws, organic products--amazing. Be sure to hackle the vendors, as they tend to jack up prices for tourists.

Bargain super hard. thamel is good place, but be careful about shopping. Every shop you go, bargain hard. Rs 100 item could cost you 3000rs. During night stay away from people who offer you services like massage, sex etc. They will tell you that girls would be available after midnight. By the time you wait for midnight you won't even notice that some girls sitting nearby you are drinking and having fun and you have to pay the bill. A juice could start from 700 to 1000. which means you will end up by hotel goons to pay. And last there will be no girl which you are fantasizing about.Its good place to eat, but keyword is Bargain.

KTM in a street. Undoubtedly the best place in KTM for anything - Food, pubs, shopping. You name it and Thamel has it. You just can't miss this one. Nightlife and live music at pubs in Chaksibari are must visit.

The tourist's Hub. Thamel is the main destination for tourists,restaurant ,hotel,travel company,night club,spa,shopping center,typical nepali product and no of holiday tour planner is the main attraction .location is prime 10 min walking distance from unisco heritage site kathmandu Darbar square .lets rock your holiday in thamel.

busy busy. A must visit in Kathmandu. Lots of activity. Lots of tourists. Be prepared to negotiate for everything. Make sure you can dodge/run/outwalk the bikes, cars, rickshaws. We had a wonderful time. Early morning it was peaceful when shop owners are just opening up, then it gets busy and remains that way. Spend time browsing the shops. Lots to find and buy.

Great For Shopping Hell For Walking..... The crime rates are much worse than known, a young woman said she was doped at a jewellery store in broad daylight, asked into a backroom...to see something, and I read also that men who go to the better female massager places may suffer police raids, as they want the richer clients to fine, makes sense, from an economic viewpoint...Still I would go shopping there, with a taxi nearby, and the food is quite nice too....pizzas with local cheeses, coffees, you hear a lot of Western music, I do not need when in Nepal....Tibetan music, book stores are great....more English books in one store than I saw in all of China....Fun but watch traffic and crime....not really Nepal...

Holidays in Nepal Aman Sheikh and Family. This is my second visit to Nepal in less then a month. This trip was purely family holiday trip and once again Mums Hotel was my first choice Mr Sudarshan did his the best to keep us comfortabe just like his home guest. He made sure everything was taken care if us from booking to travel arrangements he went out of the way to assist us in rebooking of our Qatar airways flight back home.All airport drops he gave us as complimentry they dropped my daughter back to airport in his own vechile as she had to leave early.each staff were very friendly i have booked again for my wife she will be in Nepal for short trip end of october.High standard as 5 star service.Hotel Mums home should be the first choice in KTM NEPALAman SheikhShahanaz Aman SheikhMustafa Aman SheikhZahra Aman SheikhDoha Qatar

Crowded but don't miss it! . If you aren't sleeping in Thamel, you should at least spend there a day to see the real Katmandu. Get lost in the narrow streets and watch the life of the local people. The are lots of souvenirs to buy- don't hesitate to bargain!Go to the Square and find a guide in order to understand better what you see.

Prices are on the upper scale as the place is famous for tourist. All the gifts to be purchased are readily available at this place and the choice are plenty. The price is on the higher scale compared to pokhara.

Real Kathmandu. Visited in October, 2014. A visit to Kathmandu is meaningless without a visit to Thamel which is the happening place. Has excellent night-life. Best for shopping as it is the central market area. A must visit place.

Hectic and relatively expensive: shop in Bhaktapur instead!. If it's shopping you want, combine it with seeing the historical sites in Bhaktapur and get cheaper prices too, with more space and less hassle!

Truly lively. When I was in Pokhara I was said Thamel is a lively place with a lot of shops, restaurants, hotels, and people. Indeed it was true. There were a lot of people. I visited it at night after I reached Kathmandu and found out it was crowded. I saw a film shooting too in the street. People were cheerful and saying 'hello hi namaste nihao' to every passer by. Noisy and crowded at most....but that was the reason I enjoyed roaming around. It was alive. Grab a bottle of water and wonder around. :D

dusty but interesting. a cloud of dust and exhaust gas awaits you, to what is called city-centre. Really noisy place with no sidewalks, streetlights, road signs whatsoever. Yet, give yourself a chance to explore it. You'll surprisingly find clean places to eat local food (search for restaurant "momos" or "momo" with a beautiful yard), enjoy a 650ml cold local beer or a cup of coffee at charming bars.

Chaotic fun colourful, Thamel. A great starting point for a trip to Nepal. Wandering the laneways of Thamel is safe and easy to negotiate. We stayed right in Thamel at the start and finish of our trip. Shopping is fun, laneways colourful, little restaurants were great.
