Shoppers Paradise. If you want to get all your shopping done in one day, or just enjoy shopping, this is the place for you. Just roll with the crowds and know that as a foreigner, the prices are automatically much higher for you - but still quite reasonable. Don't be afraid of some bargaining for sport.

Shopping haven for trekking gear. Thamel is a foreign tourist hub and as such, is quite crowded. This is the destination for avid trekkers who can lay their hands on good trekking gear. Other items for purchase include colourful masks, prayer wheels, silver jewellery and precious gems, woollens, etc. A variety of restaurants serving all kinds of international food are available. There are also several night clubs and dance bars.

A Must Visit Area. We stayed right in Thamel and what a fantastic experience. There is so much to see and do, that you could never be bored. An absolute delight to wander the streets and visit some of the shops. We certainly learned quickly that you can barter, or just say no thanks, no thanks, no thanks. Quite aggressive salespeople.
Usual tourist trap. Good place for shopping for second hand mountain gear (that will lst you a season at best). Otherwise, not much worth seeing

Shopping District: Heaven of Trekking Gears!. Tons of trekking gears you need to survive everywhere in the world. However, quality is upon the buyers' eye. Bargains are normal, if not a must. Price can be negotiated upto 70% based on personal shopping experiences of cashmere.Streets are so busy that you have to be on the look most of the time not to be hit by cars.From personal experiences, top worthy investments are walking sticks, rounded hat to cover buring sunlight and bag plastic cover.Home to many interesting restaurants serving diverse cuisines such as Tibetian and Italian. Worth a try!Enjoy shopping and eating!

You can find everything at Thamel !. Thamel is the place for tourists where you can find everything that you need. Hotels, Restaurants, bars, souvenir shops, travel offices, trekking information centers, trekking equipment stores and everything can be found for foreigners.
Festival time and so most shops shut. Close to Garden of Dreams and thus Kaiser cafe. Clearly several restaurants around there, diverse, ... Locally recommended, but I didn't try them myself.

Chaos rules Thamel. Oh my god Thamel! Honking, noise, screaming, people playing instruments, stores selling everything you can think of, dozens of trekking shops, cafes and restaurants, little alleys hiding interesting places to eat and shop, chaos in the streets. It had to be this interesting to be an attraction in itself.

Touristy Thamel. Crowded, hot, dusty, honking, bikes and cars. We likened getting around to the show bag pavillion at the Easter show in Sydney!There are wall to wall souvenir shops that look identical but as tourism is a major source of employment in Nepal this is of course acceptable. Apart from the souvenirs, there are some interesting little restaurants, lots of trekking gear stores and atmosphere plus plus. Take a bottle of water and just wander around.

vibrant and alive. Thamel was noisy, polluted, crowded, but also alive, colourful, vibrant and exciting. Yes you do get accosted by street sellers, but they are polite and friendly, just remember to haggle.

Kathmandu. Thames is the hustle and bustle city of Kathmandu.Watch out for traffic, wouldn't eat at road side stalls.Great shopping and bargaining.Purchase trekking gear here, walking poles and gortex very cheap prices.

A city of night life.. You can get anything from here. The city is turned in to a different look at night. At day time the city is full of shops for the tourist. Lots of road around the city, The place for best Kashmiri shawl and tea. You have to know how to bargain.

Don't miss out on the chaotic shopping! . It's to much, over crowded, cars in both direction and shops hanging on the side of the streets - it is really a chaotic place! Either you love or you don't - I do! The different bars, the lights and people, the beauty and ugliness - all in one place! This very touristy area is still a nice place to be, the vendors are not hazelling and it is actually possible to bargain good deals!! Smile, laugh and bargain hard - this is the way to do it! Live music is on every corner and you can find happy-hour everywhere! In some of the places the music is actually really good - we walked in on a rock-concert which was totally awesome!

Photogenic town. I love Thamel. Despite the chaos and noises, it's full of life and people are so nice. So easy to get good photos and as much as I'm glad to be in Pokhara 2 days after staying in Thamel, I started to miss Thamel and appreciate it more after I came back from trekking. Getting lost in Thamel is a must do in Nepal, definitely!!Some recommendations based on my experience, and all of these are on the same street with Kathmandu Guest House, the oldest guesthouse in Kathmandu:1. Spa: Tranquility Spa, try the Ayurvedic Massage. Trekkers massage just seems like something that is overpriced to fit the purpose.2. Book Shop: Pilgrims (near Tranquility Spa)3. Food: Northfield & Jesse James for dinner, they have local bands playing instrumental piece. Serves variety of food, mainly good for Mexican food. Opens for bfast till dinner.4. Yoga and stay: Hotel Himalaya Yoga. You pay for the room and get free yoga on the rooftop. Good deal! Walk in has to pay 500rps for yoga. Which is not bad either. Teacher is good.All in all, don't get tired of the place, stop for coffee or lassi whenever you can and enjoy the madness!
Chaotic but cool. It's a cool area that has everything you need. But very touristy - it rates up there with Kho San Road in Bangkok as the most touristy area I've ever been to in the world.

A dump, but an interesting one!. Kathmandu can be summed up in one word - a complete "dump"! It's polluted, very dirty and traffic is a nightmare.But Thamel is its touristy heart with lots of salesmen trying to get you on to their trek, shops devoted to trekkers' items and a few restaurants dotted around. It's great for street scene and people watching photography, but the Nepalese are generally so charming, which makes this an interesting place to visit.

Best Place. great nightlife, amazing place and great people and cultural diversity with very comfortable hotel in particlar hotel yambu located at heart of thamel. thamel is a great place for tourist in Nepal
Excellent Nightlife. Lots of Bars and discos operate till 12 mid night.. U can just stroll the streets or get into one of the bars.. Live music at Shisha was great..

Busy, Chaotic, and Fun. Thamel is the tourist location for a reason. There are so many shops and great restaurants, but because the locals know that there are tourists, they will try to sell you...illegal substances. Just say no thank you (in Nepali if you can) and keep walking! Haha, had some pretty funny experiences with those folk. If you're not staying in Thamel, definitely give it a visit as there are many comforts of home there.

what a place. night life, disco & live music...what not i nepal.....lovely....what a place for a taste liking people. Thamel have taste of atleast 50 countries.Believe me.Bakery,Pizza,Pasta,Thai,American,French,Israelian,Chinese,Indian and what not....Loved it.

Tourist District. Thamel is where most of the tourists stay while in Kathmandu city. The narrow streets and chaos of locals and foreigners roaming around give the district its personality. There are plenty of stores, restaurants, hostels, and hotels in the area.

Fun place. there is every thing you want in Thamel.. great food, great hotels, super market, dust, smoke, traffic, crowd, fun, shops, live bands, pubs.. Most of the tourist stay here. there are lots of shop from where you can buy souvenirs, trekking stuffs, pashmina... it is fun to explore Thamel..

Great place. A fairly central location and a good, safe place to stay in Kathmandu. We stayed in the Tayoma Hotel initially which was basic but cheap, £7 a night for a double room. After trekking we thought we deserved a it more luxury and so stayed in the Potala Guest house a few doors down. This was a bit more money but it was worth it for such a lush room.

Fun for a short time. Thamel is fun to explore for a few days. I wouldn't want to stay longer than that as the pollution started to give me a headache and the shops are all the same once you've spent time wandering. You can find anything you need in Thamel- great restaurants, supermarkets, souvenirs etc.
have to see Thamal!. Amazing shopping district geared toward tourists. Bargain, get your best deal, and have a ball! Very safe even for single females to walk around at reasonable time at night.

It's all the shopping of Asia in one place. It's hard not to like Thamel. I's noisy but not aggressive, its busy but friendly, it crowded but not hassled. Thamel is shoppers paradise but also shopper beware. You can find anything from serious mountain walking gear to the latest rip offs from yak blankets that aren't to high quality items. Thamel has it all - good food places, cool food places, good shops ( bad ones too) but its the feel that makes it work. Relaxed you can drift - see it as a friendly bermuda triangle

Hectic, noisy but good shopping and dining. Here you find all you need for the friends who stayed at home or to fill your hungry stomach with food from around the globe. It is noisy, dusty, but still worth to stroll around. The later you arrive, the better, as the traffic in those small lanes gets less then.
Shopping Area. It is a must visit place for shopper to buy cashmere & other souvenir with cheap price. Lots of small2 shop to choose for

Everything you need. Thamel is a very touristy place, this is the place where tourists usually lives, it has foreign exchange, a lot of hotels and a lot of food places with english menus. many cafes and restaurants offers free wifi for customers. There are also a lot of shops, which is worth shopping around since they sell mostly the same thing. we made some wonderful friends in thamel and bought some crafts at reasonable cost. overall we got to know the place pretty well towards the end of our trip
Touristy. One will be amazed by the variety of shops selling all types of souvenirs. I bought some tea, coffee and scarves. The restaurants in the area are great.

tattoo in thamel. I had a tattoo done at mohans tattoo inn by Vibek and it is wonderful. He was very friendly, great to talk to, gentle and I cannot fault his work at all. My friend also got a lip piercing done and again, the procedure was faultless. We are both very happy and would recommend this place to anyone.We did go to funky Buddha, but the room was dirty and stunk of smoke and the guy we spoke to looked and sounded wasted.Mohans was clean, very professional, has lots of jewellery options. The staff are helpful, speak very good English and are trained to a high standard.
All in one place. We found variety types foods and restaurants around them. It was great experience. Also lots small shops with variety items. The only problem is traffic jams, but they are few.
happening place. All the happening things in Kathmandu, shops, restaurants and good quality hotels. Closed on Saturday, so plan accordingly.

traffic is getting worse!. the shame of the Thamel area is that is is undoubtedly an amazing area with a plethora of interesting sites, smells and experiences to be had. Unfortunately it also what feels like a thousand cars, motorcycles and rickshaws all vying for space at all times of day and night- its really not safe to walk through the Thamel streets and the constant beep of car and motorcycle horns is head banging stuff - too much.

Always Bargain!. Amazing place to shop. Although it is a bit pricey, a bit of bargaining can get you some nice souvenirs for a good price. The tourist goods wholesale shop next to Silver home hotel has products with a better quality and fixed price which is surprisingly lesser than the products in the other shops in Thamel.

tourist district with friendly shop owners. Though deemed by many backpackers as a place too touristy. But I find the shop owners selling yak shawls and herbs quite willing to make small talks and sell u giving j discount by rounding up the numbers if u dont haggle too unreasonably

Tourist Thamel. So much to see and do here. It's the epicenter of tourist KTM. Dancing girls, discos, lounge, bars, karaoke, shopping, etc etc etc. Neverending really. If you're looking for the heart of Kathmandu, you've found it here in Thamel.
Main Tourist district. Lots of shops & restaurants. Be aware as you share the narrow streets with cars, motorcycles & bikes
Good for Shoping. You can find everything here; restaurant Chinese or authentic Nepali cuisine, bookshops, souvenirs, money exchanger and ATMs

a good place to take a hotel. Thamel is a very good place because you can:
- go walking to Durbar Square.
- There is a lot of restaurant (go Third Eye Restaurant)
- There is a lot of shops.

Perfect place for local and artistic materials. Thamel is considered as a place for night life in Nepal but I see it differently. It is a place where you will find local artistic materials if you think of taking some memorable things back home... You can find wide variety of things here...

Unforgettable. A place that is buzzing with life and, at the same time, serene! Especially, the experience of waking up to soothing flute notes being played out on the streets; and taking a stroll in the evening to sounds of Buddhist chants being played in various music shops - are some of the unforgettable memories.

Must place for night life when in Kathmandu. Rock bars, pubs, cafe's , Anything you name it is available in Thamel. Shopping of souvenirs or enjoying a roof top Italian food. This place is must visit.

Eventually you come here.. Lots of hotels, shops, bars, eateries and more. It is the central area for tourists. There are everything from quaint coffee shops to seedy massage places all at tourist prices. You can get lots of international cuisine here as well as many many souvenirs. Taxi drivers won't let you walk by them without letting you know they are available. Hash and sex is offered continually at night if you are a male walking the street. During the rain this places gets muddy and with the potholes make sure you are nowhere near the splash area. The are no sidewalks. Things here cost a bit more than other parts of the city.

Totally funky place. If you are doing any trekking in Katmandu you are certainly going to end up here. Lots of action and shopping, cheap places to stay and lots of good restaurants and bars. A great experience just loved it.

The hotels area in Kathmandu.. It's the place where most of the travelers stay. Plenty of lodges, restaurants and shops. Sometimes to much traffic even though are narrow streets with no separation for pedestrians. Most of the strees have no concrete.

Not a safe place. . It's a nightlife area in the capital city of Kathmandu and most famous place amongst all the visitors, you can find all the tourist attractions in Thamel starting from below average hotels; night clubs; gift shops and end up with all the prohibited stuff you can imagine; it's nice place to hang out for few hours only but definitely not a safe place to stay longer than that.
heart. this is heart of the city which is croweded.hear one should be carefull as it has crooks& cheaters. stay cool as it is a shopping area
backpacker area. with great bars and restaurants. really a nice spot to hunt for nice items from backpacks and hiking gear to everyday stuff.
Over rated. The area is very busy and chaotic.....crazy traffic......just go there if you want to live the shopping and the nightlife (rather limited).

Depressing !. Yikes ! Where does all the tourist Money go? Everything is dark and depressing..strange characters offer you Marijuana when you linger in front of a Bakery. LOL I checked out several hotels and no matter what price range, they were all depressing and dark and had old furniture. YUK !small shops overcharge for items like bottled water,et.It just seems so dangerous and dark....very bad vibe. The one good thing: All Bakeries offer 50% discount in the evening :)

Great for food and shopping. If you stay in Kathmandu, you'll probably stay in Thamel. It 's a good, albeit touristic and crowded, area and great base for all your Kathmandu adventures. Lots of souvenir shops (shop early, so you'll have the 'first customer' experience), very good restaurants and some cultural experiences as well: temples and durbur square nearby.

The place to stay. Noisy, chaotic, touristic, wonderful.I lived in the surroundings of Kathmandu for over 7 weeks and Thamel is my favorite spot.You find everything there, from knives to soy milk. The best restaurants are also there.My piece of advice is to avoid staying in the mais roads. Go to the hotels in the alleys, so you can have a little peace for your ears.
Good for shopping. Place good for shopping as you find a lot of different crafts within a 500 mt radius. Other than that, pretty noisy and not so clean area

Must visit when n Kathmandu. Stayed n Thamel for a few days with my friends. Place is nice good deals if u willing to bargain for it. Excellent sheehsa cafes and clubs as well. Njy ur stay b safe. Noticed lots f cops post 2300 n Thamel.

Exciting for first time travellors. Though thamel is a busy noisy place it has its own attractive personality that does not bore you...be sure to see alot of mountaineers sitting in the road side sipping there beverages , or smoking a cigar...I saw one reading Sanskrit book .... you will they are mountaineers either with their rugged looks , well built body or the will be carrying or shopping for mountaineering stuff.I found the city to be safe
Thamel!!!. I really love Thamel. I've been there 3 years ago but now it's much cleaner and that is big up for Nepalese people :)

Better as Pharganj in Delhi.. Thamel is area full of hotels all stars, restaurants, travel agencies, shops and bars. Even if you didn’t book your hotel before, in Thamel you will always find some accommodation. Go throught Thamel and watch local people in their daily activities. Thamel have also good acces to Ratna park, where are local buses to the almost all places near Kathmandu.
busy market. thammel is a busy area..you can shop everything from there...you can call a taxi and go anywhere from there

Amazing, ancient, chaotic place.. the touts, beggars, and traffic ruin it for me. Best way to travel is bicycle rickshaw, this removes you from much of the tout/begging. Cars and trucks should not be allowed on these narrow streets. Watch you back here! Most of the shops have no price tags. How can you haggle when you dont know how much the goods are worth. If a store has price tags, I shop, otherwise, I give it a miss. Worth a visit for certain. Two or three visits maybe...
I like it a lot. Busy place, everybody can enjoy just to seat on the corner and check other people in hurry !NO HUSTLERS ...IT is safe !

Busy area but great to do you shopping. Many streets with shops with all kinds of gifts, organic tea and coffee.Very nice to shop around and have a nice lunch or diner.Many restaurants available.I prefer to stay in hotel near ringroad which is in evening more quiteter

An unplanned city. The road are so narrow and dirty,that you can't walk or drive comfortably.the shop are unplanned ,hapazardly placed.Trafic is also not good. As a tourist hub, it should be upgrade ,otherwise tourist will directly go to pokhara from airport and then back to airport.

Best place to stay as its in the heart of the city.. Thamel area is great place to stay when visiting Kathmandu. There are lots of budget options to stay, lots of shops around for buying trekking stuff, woolens or handicrafts and too many restaurants to satisfy your hunger. There are two ATM lounges in the area so its very easy to draw money from whatever bank you use. Pilgrims bookstore, the best in the city is also a short walk away and so is Garden of Dreams.

Typical tourist area. This is where all the action happens. Plenty of cheap hotels, bars, and restaurants. There are many shops selling stuff. Just be warned to shop around and barter hard. We went in august so stuff was very cheap but still needed to barter. In high tourist months, prices will go up so be warned and shop around.

Shop around before you buy. We almost got taken by several vendors in Thamel. They know we are tourists and they will price gauge us in a bad way. We learned this the hard way, by not walking away. You can always get the real price if you haggle for a bit, and then leave. When you are leaving, the vendor will always tell you a legitimate price in order to try to get your business. That way, when you approach a second vendor, you know what the item should cost and you can start your haggling at that price. We also learned, over masala tea with a local Nepali pashmina vendor, that all of the colored pashminas that say 100% cashmere are not necessarily 100% cashmere. You also have to be careful when buying scarves because many of them are imported from India or China, so if you want to support the local economy, try to buy from a vendor selling actual Nepali goat wool scarves. Ask to see a "ring scarf"...engage in conversation with a local vendor about the story of this special, high quality scarf. You will be amazed at the skill that it takes to make one of these scarves, and their versatility with respect to travel!

Chaotic. Chaotic, busy, slightly smelly, bustling and full of street hawkers. Bars, veg momo signs and food joints litter the streets. Then theres the gem shops, scarf shops, trekking shops, camera shops, soap and incense shops etc. Young Nepalis come here to drink and socialise, travellers come to have fun, whatever your inclination, Thamel offers it. Little tip though, buy ear plugs if you want a sound nights sleep.

Busy and vibrant. Thamel is one of the most vibrant part of Kathmandu. With all the tourist coming and going, becoming the most liveliest part of the city. It's a great place to meet up, not particularly quiet to stay thought. But it's very strategic to all you can get in Kathmandu.

Backpacker's place in Kathmandu. Lived here for two months. Pretty touristic, but this is where you will find more options with regards food, accommodation, shops and english spoken people. It's full of restaurants, bars, trekking agencies and stores selling just about everything. Prices there are obviously higher than the rest of the city but still cheap compared to the rest of Asia.

A Classic Place to be. But very Expensive.. Thamel is the main shopping area of Kathmandu. Its quite a happening place in terms of restaurants, shopping, tourists etc but over all quite expensive. You can purchase the same items else where at less than half the cost.

A place where your wife wants to go at night and your husband at night ;). Thamel is undoubtedly the tourist heart of Kathmandu. It is almost always filled int with tourists from all over the world. Some good, traditional and highly reviewed restaurants around makes the place even more significant. There are plenty of street side shops from where you can buy things that you wanted to buy. There are adequate number of restaurants and eating places around. By the sun moves, the vibe changes from shopping to partying. Thamel could also be called as the party district of Kathmandu. There are a lot of Bars, Pubs, Dance Clubs and Cafe's along the road. The Nasha Club right at the entrance of Thamel is the only standard dance club that I would recon. A good and fun place to be.

There is Coffee and cheap DVDs!. Wish this neighbor hood had less bars, coverbands and noise at night. Its changed a lot over the last 10 years. Many coffee places...a spots to chill out in restaurants. Not as Holy as Boudha...and it has grown overpriced.

exhausting-good shopping!. Many beautiful handmade assortment of things, though you have to carve your way through the hectic streets and avoid all the unnecessary touts and bargain over the tiniest of things!

Love Hate Relationship. I have a love-hate relationship with Thamel. I love it because it is the best place in Kathmandu to find food, and it has beautiful and colorful shops, but I hate it because from the moment you arrive, you are pretty much assaulted by the numerous people who want to share you anything from flutes to hashish.
CRAZY STREET. i got lost 3 tims in thamel looks like similar street many where same but such beautifun everything you cxan fine in thamel a lots of bar,pub,club restaurant hotel everything there...

If the don´t have it I don't exist. Although i probably is a copy, you will find everything you ever need. Amazing place, do not fear the small shops, and the "special price fore you" go inside and they will let you shop

Touristy, but great fun. Bustling with noise and activity, Thamel is a haven for tourists visiting Kathmandu. Hotels, restaurants, cafes, bars, supermarkets, stalls, shopping and more shopping – it caters to all tourist and trekking needs. The location is great for exploring older parts of Kathmandu - it’s a good idea to do that and visit parts of Kathmandu which fewer foreigners frequent, because otherwise the impression would be that Kathmandu is just one big chaotic, crowded, noisy tourist trap, and it’s not at all.Great vibe (especially at night) and great character.

Tshirts, sleeping bags, shawls and sweaters , latest DVDs. Thamel has just about everything ...including some great places to eat... Gems, fancy sequinned long skirts for the ladies, cashmere sweaters ...used books, new books..you can spend hours just wandering around...lots to see !!

Kathmandu:Thamel/Pokhra/Nagarkot. If Ur visiting Kathmandu,U have to experience the energy of Thamel.The shops r so many,so close and so stocked with souvenirs.All the pubs and bars are also in the same area.U musnt miss the pop quiZ that happens every Thursday(m forgetting the name of the pub but thats public knowledge so no worries there)The world cup was happening when I went so there was a football quiZ instead.Even tho Im not into the sport,I enjoyed it thoroughly.Moreso cause its done by the volunteers to raise money for the poor children.The restaurants I was particularly impressed by are the Electric Pagoda and Places(vegetarian food only).Electric Pagoda is outdoor seating so clearly my fav.Silver jewellery is amaZing in Nepal but dont forget to bargain.Have the local beers Nepal Ice and Gorkha instead of ur regular Tuborg etc.I had the Jhooin Khatte(millet liquor)in Pokhra and I must say its cheap and I really enjoyed it but U wont get it in all the bars.Paragliding and River Rafting are a mustdo in Pokhra.Ive done Paragliding before in Panchgini,Maharashtra but the view of the lake in Pokhra was amaZing.The bat cave and Davis Falls are worth seeing.Nagarkot is known for the sunrise and sunset.I went in the rainy season so I didnt get to see much coZ of the clouds but still the village is so small n forlorn n adorable,my trip was still worth it.

Thamel is tops!. I've never travelled in Nepal, much less in KTM, so I rely upon Tripadvisor/other sources to clue me in as what to expect. Based upon available information, the Thamel district of KTM is the most attractive part, depending upon how you define "attractive". This is about as authentic and original an area as one can find anywhere. Many, many cities around the World, especially the capital, would have razed & rebuilt this vibrant, thriving beehive of commercial activity. I am a life-hostel member, NOT a 5-star traveller, because I thoroughly enjoy to closeness to the indigenous population, learning the lifestyle of the rest of us--those of us in the 99% class! Just carefully walking the rough potholed streets, weaving amongst pedestrians, cycles (motorized & not) motorized vehicles, through low doorways & passages, thrilled me no end. I loved it, and look forward to returning.
Great nightlife and shopping. I loved it! The rock music blasting out into the streets, the shops with all the cool little trinkets, the friendly people, the PRICES!

Loads of shopping opportunity and great evening walk venue. Hundreds of shops and thousands of people walking around in Thamel. Great place to spend evening walking around and absorbing the atmosphere. Indulge in street food and get great bargains on shopping. Best place to exchange currency. Lots of travel agents here to book all your travel needs in NEPAL.

organized chaos so beautiful!!. Thamel is loud, busy, beautiful, confusing, and fun. Most people will end up in Thamel as part of their trip. It is full of restaurants, souvenir shop, outdoor apparel, rickshaws, and photoshops. If you forgot to pack something for your Everest trip or forgot something for you camera you can get it here. The quality of the apparel is good at best and of it come from China. inspect the clothing at the seems and the zipper, but if you forgot something this is the place to get it and you will not find it on you trek I'll guaranty that. Be careful at night if you stay out late and don't carry large sums of cash. The Nepalis are great people, but don't be foolish. You can get the best deal on souvenir here and the best exchange rate. Have fun!!

It's Thamel. A 500% tourist trap, the majority of backpackers and tourists stay around Thamel. As such all the stores around Thamel are stocked specifically for tourists with poor quality Khukri's and other items.There are some nice places to eat the Chicken & falafel and Mexican restaurant opposite the Pumpernickel Bakery.Expect to be approached by multiple guys offering to find you hash, girls, massage.....

A good place to practice your bartering skills. Great place for souvenir shopping! Very cheap but be prepared to barter. Also be aware of 'tour guides' and tour company reps - you might want to use them - it's just a warning you will be approached every 20 seconds!

Don't miss it. If, like me, you like lots of shops selling local goods and souvenirs, then this is the place for you. Lots of interesting shops selling all sorts from clothes, to tea, to knives to ice cream. Don't forget to bargain too. At night time there are lots of good bars and restaurants.

Shopping place for tourists... What i found in Thamel is, not much of locals do shopping here..shops main customers are tourists, beautiful handicrafts, mitalii arts, masks of all sizes and materials,

Mixed bag. What can you say about Thamel? Crowded, dirty, smelly, shoppers paradise, backpacker haven, full of life, fun. Great place to walk around for a few hours if you can avoid getting run over. Not a great place to walk with kids. Always wanted to see it, not sure I need to see it again. LOTS of trekking supplies, some of them were even real (North Face store, Mountain Hardware store on Tridevi Marg).

Been 3 times and love it. Thamel is the tourist centre of Kathmandu. Full of cheap shops selling a range of goods from knock off trekking gear to trinkets and souvenirs. I've purchased trekking gear from here which has stood the test of some pretty hardcore trips. Good restaurants. Check out Trek Nepal International who have 2 offices in Thamel if you want a reasonably priced well organised and guided trekking experience

Shoppers and eaters paradise. The best way to explore the place is to start walking through the lane and peep in the shops around. The best place to buy curios but bargaining is a must thing to do before making any purchase. The eateries will take your heart away since the cuisine is global in appeal and have all the choices.

Hundreds of artisan shops. When I travel, I always buy presents for my sister, cousins and friends. And so knowing the best place to shop for local products. When you are Kathmandu, Thamel is the perfect place. There are hundreds of artisan shops in the area. What to buy? Nepal is known for their rugs, although most of the rugs we saw and in fact bought were made by Tibetan women. You can also find really good scarves made of Kashmir silk. I also discovered that they have very good fabric from India. If you are I to quilting, there are small shops around Thamel which would be a paradise for quilters. The downside walking around the place was that the streets were very narrow and there are no sidewalk, so you need to be careful with speeding cars and motor bikes.

Exciting and chaotic. So many lanes and alley ways to explore here. If you can't pick up a bargain in this area you need more shopping experience! We couldn't find any kind of street map and it appeared many of the roads/alleys and lanes don't have a proper name! Find a roof bar and people watch - it's a great pass time here.
shoppers delight. many shops selling goods of questionable origin. If you are planning a trek it would be a cheap way of outfitting. Some of the quality seems dodgy.
Poor mans Fashion paradise. You name it and you will get it in Thamel. Once used to be the shady side of the city, this place has transformed into a great shopping place now.

Mixed feelings about this very touristy area. The night live is cool, fascinating because it may be the only late night scene in the whole country. The trekking gear is cheap. There are some ok clothes, but they are not worn by locals, they are purely a fabrication of the tourist industry and the perception that Nepal is a laid back, groovy destination. It's important because a lot of Nepalese are benefiting financially from the tourism in the country. BUT: the streets are filthy, not unlike the surrounding non-tourist areas of this sprawling disorderly city; a lot of the interactions with local business people feel fake and tourist prices and straight up price hiking/cheating it prevalent. Taxis, rickshaws and street drug dealers will hassle you without fail + the insincere "namaste" from shop owners and "hello" from beggars can sometimes keep your attention on defensive behavior. Nonetheless, I think the tempo of these negative aspects stay calm enough to not become upsetting on a 2-3 day stay.
Backpackers Heaven. With a billion shops, eateries, coffee houses, and bars -- Thamel is a great place to experience the heart of backpacker culture. There's always something to do and see.

Crowed Tourist Hub. Its a nice place but very crowed place . We stayed in Thamel on the way to Limi Valley Trek with Eco Holiday Asia . Everything you can get in thamel, restaurants, bar , pub and shopping stuff . But Street Guid , Taxi and rekshow make you frusted in every step .

Thamel was once lovely. Back in around 1971--1979 Thamel was quite lovely. It was a hive of stalls and small shops with a quaint timelessness. Now it is ugly, squalid, noisy, and choked with the fumes of vehicles. If you want to shop and eat in a pleasant place try Bodha. There are some things that can only be obtained in Thamel - but make it a short trip. There is an excellent Gurkha Army shop where you can but a genuine Gurkha khukri - do not buy one anywhere else. There are some good book shops - but beyond that it's hell.

The Tourist Shopping Hub of Kathmandu. Well. If you like tourist shops and sheet vendors trying to sell cheap and/or imitation goods, then this is your place. If you like crowds of people all trying to cross roads and drive on roads designed for people and donkeys only, with no road rules, signage or order, this is the place for you. If you like the smell of effluent in the street, this is the place for you. It isn't the place for me.However, I had one real highlight and I would recommend it to anyone who has the opportunity. Take a Rickshaw ride around the narrow streets. Not only is it a very traditional way of getting around, but the driver I had was a very friendly man and he was keen to tell me about the significance of some the sights and sounds around me. Very cheap too.

hussle and bussle but great bargins. yes its kathamandu nepal, loud with horns blowing and cars and bikes from all directions but this district offers some traditional shopping at very good prices. Always room to haggle prices and pack some real goodies to take home

Shopping.. We stayed in the Thamel district and were constantly amazed at all the little alleyways and streets that although only very thin managed to not only have 2 way traffic but pedestrian shoppers as well. Shopping is cheap (bartering a must and expected) with a wonderful array of clothes, jewelery and souveniers.

Shopping Galore. Great opportunities for shopping, dining, meeting people. From Gurkha knives to pashmina scarves to trekking equipment...Thamel has a selection of it all.
Fun to haggle and good bargains await.
There is a "seedy" element in Thamel... the tourists bring dollars and the dollars can bring trouble. Lots of scams and shady activity. Be cautious.

Water problems. We all know Nepali politics is a corrupt money game. Egotistical corrupt fraudsters steeling all the benefits from grass roots Nepalis living on the poverty line. And mostly, we all turn a blind eye. But corrupt ineffective government has left Thamel drinking directly from the rancid sewer. Almost all the historic water wells that supply Thamel have been contaminated by sewerage. Thamel us sitting on an underground lake of sewage. From there it is pumped into hotel roof top tanks, buckets of bleach are thrown in to kill the give away stench of human waste and then the resultant brew flows down to kitchens , laundries and bathrooms. Stay in Thamel and you are bathing in sewage. So all those dirty bathroom reviews, are in fact missing the point. The bathrooms are sewage stained. Simple as that. Ever seen the waxy hair syndrome amongst Thamel travellers? Yep, it is the bleached sewage final rinse. Arsenic levels are more than 10 times the W.H.O. upper limit. Its utterly toxic. Personally I think its time for a massive Thamel boycott to ram home that while politicians steel national resources and avoid their duty, Nepal will be punished hard by enlightened travelers. Give Thamel a big miss because all that glitters is not gold. Stay at Boubhanath, but not in the inner circle because that has the same problem. Always ensure you have town water not supplemented by pumping from wells. Honestly, its a bloody disaster -:and its time. travellers knew the truth about a big dark secret the Government is ignoring.

Thamel is great for shopping - pashmina, music bowls, crystal jewellery, deity statues, trekking gear, cold weather wear. I found some fantastic businesses in Thamel and the prices are so good. You can negotiate for a good deal but please be fair given the poor economy over there.
A market place for inveigling guests. Be careful in this market. a product worth 1000 will be sold for 10000 or say 15000 in case you don't bargain. Indians are not welcome in this areas

Thamel or Pushkar/Chandni Chowk. Had read a lot about Thamel and the first thing me and wife did was to visit Thamel in the evening..but not a good place to be in after 8 PM...Lot's of restaurants/pubs but had an eeire feeling. Shops get closed by 8.30 PM. More suitable for young crowd who want to enjoy pubs/dance bars etc..Did not visit again during the trip..so review could be biased and based on 2 hours stay...

Just One night. I consider Thamel as a shopping area for backpacker to get ready an trek. It is a very dirty and ugly place, even the shops are the same and no matter who far you wolk you will keep seeing the same goods and shops.I would say that its better to exchange all of you money there due to the cheap rate they offer compering to other cites in Nepal.Further, you may find some historical sites nearby and add a flover on your stay, rather then spending your day rooming around the same shops in Thamels' shops. I don't recommend any body who looks to enjoy Nepal to stay longer than a day.

Tourist Hub. We stay on Trekkers Home for a couple of days in Thamel which is in the middle of thamel.Its close to the Road House (famous place for pizza in Thamel) and just joint with Helina's restaurant which makes us to test different foods. Thamel is very good place to by different stuff where there are lots of shops.We buyed one "Khukari" (weapons used by gurkali army in time of war) which is so nice for decor.Love it........................................................................
Thamel Camel. Great town. Very busy city streets. Cars everywhere. Intense traffic. No real danger though, they're all moving slowly. Good shopping and food everywhere too.

A True Experience. Lively, full of good energy, full of people from all over. This is a truly amazing part of town. Normally, tourist stay in Thamel when visiting Kathmandu so there are plenty bars, shops, restaurants, guest houses...It's always hectic and crazy. It's very safe, day and night. It's the Soho of Kathmandu.

Thamel, Kathmandu. Hotels, restaurants and shops, shops and more shops. Excellent place to bargain and buy hiking and some climbing gear. Safe to walk around day and night. Experience the sights, sounds and smells as it is a total experience and vendors entice you into their shops and street vendors try and sell to you. Be alert as you share the roads with bicycles, taxis, cars and lots of pedestrians.

Shopping/Business streets in Kathmandu. The shopping area is full of people. Bazaars are like India. Prices are higher than India , as I was told by locals, that most of the things are not of local origin. Only advantage is that you are not treated like foreigner and Indian Rupee upto Rs 100 note is acceptable everywhere without a wink.

fun and crazy!. if you're visiting KTM, then you'll end up in Thamel! its full of the same stores over and over again - but the nightlife and restaurants are great. watch your toes with the ever tight roads and be prepared for all kinds of approachers from sellers to street beggars. I love looking at the architecture and eclectic colours of the buildings - great textures for photos

A coin has two sides. It has enough of what you need especially if you plan to go hiking. Products come in various grades and prices so choose wisely. I met a very annoying merchant with attitude and that imprinted a bad impression about the place onto my memory. So, I guess one suggestion - just leave the shop if you begin to feel uncomfortable with the merchant.P.S. The date visited is actually October 2012.

Thamel Tourist Trap. Other reviewers have said it all so I would just like to add fuel to the already raging fire. It's all about "Namaste - gimme money", but they HAVE to make a living somehow, please be kind to the rickshaw drivers who come from impoverished villages and try to make a living here, it's so easy to bark at them (I have stopped myself). Thamel does have great eating places and if you are hungering for something other than Dahl Baht you will find it here from Felafel to Hot Dogs. Plying the streets are con artists galore be vigilant. Still, Thamel is vibrant, full of colour and beneath the patina of "Namaste - gimme money" are wonderful kind hearted and impoverished Nepali people who just want to better their lives and will bend over backwards to help you. Please DO NOT GIVE MONEY TO BEGGARS - even the Nepali government pamphlets request this of us.....especially to the children. Instead, we have purchased food and give that which also is greatly appreciated. I have given this an excellent review simply to help Nepali - oh and there are some grrrrrrrrrrreat coffee shops with real honest to goodness java that is NOT Nescafe!

It's crowded, dusty and traffic is hideous-you'll love it!. It's all abuzz with street stores selling knock-off outdoor gear (very cheap prices) and everything a hippie could want. Think hempy, herbal cheese cloth clothes. At first I loved the frantic activity, the narrow streets and general hustle n bustle of the place. But after day four, I think I was Kathman-done. So I recommend a hotel that is peaceful and somewhere where you can escape the noise, dust and erratic drivers! Also get a good map because the claustrophobic nature of the streets could mean you get lost very easily.
Picadilly Circus of Nepal. This is a great place to get your trip started for the rest of Nepal. It is also the place to get your gifts for your return home.

Lots of Touristy Stores. Did not care much for the "touristy" arts-and-crafts places. Couple of very good book stores and hiking equipment places. Just "window-shopped" -- did not purchase anything other than a few maps.

Rip off. The place was highly touted as a great shopping area. But we found the shops selling the same stuff everywhere at exorbitant prices. The place is big though. It's extremely dusty. Wear a mask.

Hippies and Vendors. This area is full of brohems - people named "brad" that drop off the map for a couple months and disregard anything that resembles clean water (i.e. a shower). They get decked out in local gear and talk about the latest trek and how they're vegetarian but then eat fishsticks.

Outdoor gear. Everest Outdoor Gears Pvt Ltd Bhagawati Bahal Thamel is a good shop to purchase basic travelling and trekking stuff.The prices quoted are totally reasonable and the owner is easy to deal with.This is a departure from most of my shop experiences in Thamel (where cheating the tourist is common) often the initial quoted price for an item is so high you would think you are in Paris or Milan.He does not have a huge range but for basic items it is the fairest costing that I have found.Highly recommended.

Good shopping. Keep your eyes open there are just too many drug dealers and pick pockets hanging around so if you are not careful you may get yourself into a big mess..try shopping from the supermarkets and if you shop from the small shops then start bargaining..the mark up is around 100 - 200% of the original price (MRP)

A MUST VISIT!. thamel is the place to go to buy any trekking equipment! :) There are tons of shop selling such items and the prices are really decent! There are many restaurants selling good food too!

yuk. Stay in Boudha. You won't be hassled by touts, drug dealers and those that prey on foreigners to make a living. Nasty in the rain. Nasty in the dry. Thangka paintings aren't as rare as you may assume.

Chaotic blust. The first thing you notice when coming to Thamel is... chaos! Everyone is honking, people are rushing. Seems like people here love to honk whenever they ride a car/bus/motobike/bike/riksha.... So noisy! But I loved Thamel because of food))) Nepali food....Mmmm.....I am ready to go to Nepal right now to eat it aain and again! Apart from that Thamel is dirty (well, like everywhere in Nepal), dusty, noisy, and crowded place, add to this narrow streets and you will get what u have))) Good experince though@
good shopping. u get everthig a trekker/traveller looks for, also lot of superstore,resturants,not expensive & within easy reach of hotels in town center

Made in China!!. A purse full of money is what i had when i ventured into Thamel, again with memories of the good times spent shopping a few years back and alas i came back with just some souvenirs and trinkets to gift and a purse almost as full..... Stuff was made in China and quality wasn't really great plus seems like the shopkeepers consider you as the last shopper on earth to visit them hence try and fleece you and make as much money as they can......After shopping in Vietnam, Cambodia, this wasn't an experience i would care to repeat again!!

"lifetime experience". We started are Nepal adventure here and ended it here. We stayed in De Veda Guesthouse.It's a shopping paradise.Lots of shops selling jackets, scarfs, souvenirs, with bargains, good local restaurants and bars, lots of fun just walking around.. Great place to get all your souvenirs or find some great food.

Stay here first. If you're new to Tibet you want to stay here. English is widely spoken, good restaurants that are clean and cater to the western taste, lots of hotel choices, lots of tourists, lots of good deals, so bargain, even though the price seems ridiculously low.Thamel has most everything a tourist needs.

The place to party. Thamel is the place to party in kathmandu. Was with friends in Kathmandu and visited Thamel almost every evening. There are no of Coffee shops , pubs , bars , restaurants and small shops for shopping. Negotiation skills required when shopping, Walking around is the best way as the streets are narrow and crowded.

Local shopping experience for Foreigners. Thamel Market is a typical foreigner market where local goods- typically handicrafts, trekking equipment, dresses are sold. This place also has quite a few eateries on the first floors with different cuisines - there are small shady places, but some are also known and famous. For foreigners, you need to very careful with the place where you eat as hygiene in these joints is not good.For shopping, our wives bought a few dresses and shawls/ stoles. You have to bargain really hard on the prices, as the prices they quote will be really high, especially to foreigners, who pay in dollars. Some of the shopkeepers themselves told us that they quote a price 5 times higher to foreigners compared to Indians and also close the deal at 2-3 times higher prices.There is some good mountaineering stuff also available here, especially at the North Face store near Sanjay Ghose chowk, but it is quite expensive.Overall a good place to shop around and enjoy the market. This market stays open till quite late -almost 12-1 in the night and best time to visit is after 6 pm.

An Amazing and vibrant area.. A great, vibrant collection of streets and alleys, chaotic and wonderful for shopping of all sorts. Souvenirs and trekking gear a plenty. Heavy tourist area so lots of bargaining needed.Plentiful hotel, guest house, B&B and hostel options, at reasonable prices. A good hub to navigate the rest of Kathmandu from.

trekking gear mecca. If you are trekking then buy everything but boots and sock at home the rest is a fraction of the price at home and the quality is fine, souvenirs are plentiful its an easy place to navigate and bring your negotiating price skills!

Feedback provided. It is the place for travellers. Cheap places to stay, accessibility of food and getting to places are all made convenient here. They do have Halal eateries here for the Muslim travellers and need to be asked around.

Extreme touristy. Our hotel was a 15 min walk ro Thamel and since it was so popular we decided to visit the area one evening. Crowded with shops, pubs, restaurants and travel agents, Thamel is typically a touristy area with extremely high priced souvenirs and scarves. If u do intend to buy any make sure you bargain a lot. You will naturally see a lot of tourists than locals in this area.

Central spot with something for all travellers. We came and went from Katmandu for trekking and I was glad we stayed in Thamel. It really felt central to both bus stations/airport and great dining/sights and had a plethora of little shops for souvenirs/gifts and items for trekking. We picked up hiking poles and clothing and were glad for the abundance/availability in Thamel. Further, our tour operator was based in Thamel which was super in terms of being able to visit the office, make arrangements and etc. In terms of souvenirs/shops I appreciated the variety of shops with a social conscience where they clearly supported communities either through fair trade or by giving back percentages of funds raised. When it came to the clothing shops, we shopped for both trekking and casual wear and were very pleased with what we found. Some have said "come with nothing but the clothes you stand up in, and go from there" (in terms of very affordable clothes, and the variety to choose from). I don't know if I'd go that far, but I would say if you're "on the fence" which what to wear/bring: bring a handful of basics and welcome the opportunity to pick-up missing pieces once there. Truly they have everything from fleece jackets, hiking boots and tents to swim suits, dresses and casual wear. In terms of snacks/toiletries there are many little corner shops that will perhaps not have brands you're familiar with, but that do the job (very affordably) AND possibly the best investment was a two-prong adapter which cost about 1$ Canadian (there) but I could only locate in specialty shops prior to leaving for 20$ dollars in Canada (and it worked perfectly with converter/adapters that I brought).Hope this helps! Safe and happy travels!

you can easily get crazy!. You cannot avoid Thamel but try to fix everything quickly (visas, tour, bus tickets, whatever) and run away to Pokhara or other pacefull places of this incredible country that is Nepal.Thamel has excellents restaurants but it is really TOO Noisy.

Can skip this place !. I visited Kathmandu with my family in first week of june. Having browsed about Kathmandu, Thamel seemed to be the happening place. So on very first day of arrival we went to Thamel in the evening. On reaching there; we wondered what to see there and nothing seemed extraordinary as it was written. It might bea paradise for non-Asians as it quite resembled="Paharganj (New Delhi). But for us it was a ordinary place. We decided to eat something but could not get anything worth. We tried some snacks but they were of sub-standard quality. Roaming Thamel gave me a uncanning feeling and we left it as soon as we could.

The world at sagar asthma. Thamel is full yet without the trappings. The vibrant neighbourhood that is the centre of all Trekkers and backpackers, carries the charm of an ancient city with international charm of freedom, cafes, colours and a whole range of eateries. It carries the message of minimum baggage maximum experience. I guess that is he motto of Nepal anyways. One has to go there with nothing. thamel is a neighbourhood, that is a must on Kathmandus to do list. It is a world in itself.
Good For Muslims. Here you will find Al Madina Hotel near Thamel Chowk and Dolphin Guest House. Try its Daal Channa it is so tasty.
Energy Energy Energy. Thamel was a great place to watch people from all over the world. The energy was always high. Watch out for the motorcycles that zip through the narrow streets.

Great Neighborhood. This is probably the most scenic and cleanest neighborhood in Kathmandu that offers the best restaurant options. However, make sure that you walk close to the buildings because you might get run over if you don't.

Staying in Thamel. We stayed in a hotel in Thamel (Vaishali). So shopping was just walkout and get it. Bargaining is very essential. And we got most of what we wanted at decent prices. Goods are from Nepal, India, China and certain food items from Europe etc.

good area for a couple of days. Really the only game in town for backpackers and independent travellers of all ages. Lots of guest houses, bars shops and restaurants. Busy street life with people from all over the world. Full of travel agencies and tourist shops but not overpowering and there are quite a few gems in there.most people seem to be here for a couple of days before or after trekking but it is also good for a city break if you are in the region (we're in Dubai so 4 hrs away).Loved it and will come back hopefully on our way to the countryside next time.

Busy, colourful and safe. For me, Thamel has much of an Indian city about it without the pressing crowds, noisy and terrifying traffic. Lined with every variety of tourist and local store selling everything from genuine to cheap knock-off goods. People are invariably polite (including the street vendors) with a cheerful “Namaste!” to greet you. Easy to get around and no issues after dark.

Lots of book shops!. My first visit to Nepal and stayed in a hotel in Thamel. Narrow dusty roads but still manageable! Lots of shops in and around Thamel with many good restaurants. What surprised me most was, there were quite a number of good book shops especially on the way to Newroad. Loved browsing in these shops. If you love reading and have the time do look for these shops around Thamel.
Thamel. Nice place to stay for couple of days. A lot shops, restaurants and hotels. It is compare to Khao san road or Kuta Legian Beach!
Thamel. Down town of Kathmandu and its amazing to stay here there are a lot of hotels in thamel and shopping centers
Only for souvenirs. This place is over crowded Nd full of noise, especially in the evening when the bars start blasting their music sets all at the same time!

shopping shopping shopping!. You can find whatever you want here. Negotiate prices! Loved the hustle and bustle. Everything from cheapy to handmade. A one-stop shopping spot! After shopping, there are TONS of restaurants for every taste!
city tour. Over the bridge from the main city is this fascinating old City of Thamel. You will see the Rotary logo on the bridge and the emblem in the shrine

Full of life. So interesting wandering around the narrow streets and discovering all sorts of little alleyways leading to courtyards with little shops, cafes/restaurants tucked away, but don't expect late nights as everything closes down early in Nepal.. Full of interesting sights and sounds. great shopping. lots of bargains to be had, you'll be tempted by all the knick knacks. Dont expect

value for money. Its a nice place to shop kukris and clothes..go to a shop called trance trip for ladies outfits...kukris sold on roads are duplicate...however shops have the orginal one....if a kukri is priced at 700 np rs..then he will sell it to you at 400 np rs...it is sensible to buy antiques from shops rather than road side....pashmina shawls also can be purchased as low as 600 to 800 nepale rs..
Shopping paradise!!. We started are Nepal adventure here and ended it here. We stayed in De Veda Guesthouse.It's a shopping paradise.. Great place to get all your souvenirs or find some great food.

Lots of Gifts. So many shops to choose from especially the Felt shops with felt slippers, bags and hats for all the family. We also loved the hemp bag shop with so many bags to choose from and so well made.

Multiple warrens of minor insanity. Good news, you can find most anything if you forgot if for your trip, bad news it's hard to tell if it's authentic until it falls apart at altitude, but the riot of color, noise, movement, shops, extreme activity and all else make this really kinda fun. I had to look hard and long and pay a lot for fresh fruit but I didn't care. Once I figured out how to get back to my hotel around all the twists and turns I had a ball looking at all the pretties, and settling on what had to come home after the hike, it was great fun. One head's up- if you're looking for boot warmers, don't go to Holy Land camping equipment. His are $16 apiece and old. You can find them for a third that nearly anywhere else.

You'll gonna love it eventually. Thamel is a very eccentric place, you have to walk there once to see for yourself, but it is an essential place for a full Nepali experience. I had a cultural shock the first time i went there, but since my hotel was in Thamel (everything is in Thamel basically), not only i got used to it but i started to love it. The people are really nice in general and the prices are good. A true traveler heaven

Time to shop and eat. It is hectic and good luck crossing the street but Thamel is our place - the western visitor. Excellent places to eat, just avoid the raw fruit &veges. When you need to do your souvenier shopping for those T-shirts, hats, tea, prayer flags, etc this is the place. Don't forget to haggle - it is cheaper than you think.Don't miss the Sherpa store for some higher quality clothing/sporting items.

Cosmopolitian Corner of the Country. A vibrant tourist area within central Kathmandu, Thamel is home to numerous hotels, bars, restaurants, shops, night clubs, bookstores, travel agencies and coffee shops lining up its narrow streets. Decades ago, hippie movement brought artists and explorers from world over to Thamel, characterizing this locality into what it is today - a confluence of cultural, entertainment and touristic activities. View pictorial blog at http://purecamp.com/localities/thamel to get a glimpse of Thamel!

characterful chaos. Thamel is a great place for a wander. There are loads of little shops to explore which sell everything from trekking gear to musical instruments and it's great fun trying to bargain with the stall holders for pashminas and silver jewellery. There are lots of little restaurants to stop at when you get tired and lots of alleyways to explore. You never know what you are going to find next.
Great shopping & bar hopping. I found a yarn shop selling yak wool and recycled silk sari yarn.Loved all the textile and jewellery shops and everything was so cheap

Very Touristy, But You'd Expect That. Wild, crazy Thamel is the most touristy spot in Kathmandu, but there are good shops and restaurants. It's just fun to wander around and people watch, but look out for the cars and bikes!

Exciting Thamel. I have visited Thamel 4 times now and it is a great place. There is loads of good restaurants and shops to eat and browse in. You can buy anything you wish from cashmere to holiday gifts. People are friendly and helpful.
Cool, Hip town. the vibe is great in this town.although many tourists comes with many scams.you can buy almost anything for an up coming trek
Western fun. Lots of shops selling jackets, scarfs, souvenirs, with bargains, good local restaurants and bars, lots of fun just walking around.

Chill out place !!. As as heart of Kathmandu and one of the main tourist attraction, Thamel is basically about shopping, lodging and eating. For music lovers, there are plenty of restaurants with live music and club bars. The place needs to be kept clean, reconstruct roads and heavy traffic free otherwise personally would rate this place as one of the central and safest tourist destination.
Thamel has had some improvements. I guess if your on a budget this place has everything. It has had some improvements, but for others a short visit or a meal would do the trick.
Hustle Bustle. Must visit place for tourists to experience the night life and a wide range of food from all over the world!

Chill out . I really missed the vibration and craziness whenever I was out of thamel to other parts of NEPAL. Though it might not be the best place for all. This is the most active town in the country where you can get everything you need. Wonderful environment...

The Heart of Kathmandu. as busy and noise as it is.. you gotta love THAMEL.. i have been in Nepal 3 times now, and i always make couple of days to be around the craziness of this place.. Tourists, shops, bars, restaurants, you name it.. All in one spot! <3

Shopping, eating and tourist central. If you can compress all of the bargain shopping and good eating of any tourist city into a square block, you get Thamel. Its a busy, dusty, active and vibrant part of Kathmandu where you can shop about frankly anything, eat just about anything or just walk around and not do anything. Walking here ins't the easiest since the roads are narrow and the traffic is pretty much non - stop. But if you keep your wits about yourself, you'll never realise how time flew past.

Buy anything at all. Given the touristic nature of the place, I expected a much more, well... touristic place. The truth is that there are streets and streets and some are as authentic as it gets. Some are full of tourist stuff, but you can still buy anything else as well. I enjoyed walking around, although I have to admit that flip flops are not the best footwear.
Overrated.... Seeing Thamel and moving about The place seemed to be quite overrated to me. The market not great, the roads greatly narrow and nothing really special in it.
Best for shopping. thame is best for shoping where you get everything. Many restaurants , shops for handicraft bar etc. You can buy evrything in single visit.
Funky, hectic yet fun. Lots of restaurants, bars, trekking shops. Make sure you check out Mandalla Street, which is an oasis of silence and calm in comparison to the rest of Thamel.

Necessary stay. Thamel is actually quite fun if the air wasn't so utterly unbreathable. We stayed to get all our permits, did some shopping for our trek, had a look at Durbar Square, Swayambhunath, and left. You may get away with two days in this stink without getting sick, and that was all we dared to give to Kathmandu.

discover **. unexpected things will discover along the narrow street & some fantastic's sigh might surprise you :)the bargain paradise here !"BUT beware the roadside fruit hawkers :( ... the banana can cost USD 5+++ LOL

Thamel Street. What a vibrating area, very active with tourists and merchants. I enjoyed the easy access and the variety of shopping opportunities, although you will see repetition of all the stores. Bargain the prices down, never pay the asking price.

Over rated. It had been 20 years since last in Thamel. Found it very much the same, crowded, pushy vendors/shop keepers. It was not as nice nor as clean as it had been, more motorbikes and cars making it difficult to walk around and much more hassling the tourists. A few good shops for specialty items but can take or leave it.

Prostitutes, drug dealers racist taxi drivers. If your idea of a good time is being hit up by drug dealers, seeing stippers on every corner and hookers all of the place this is the place for you! Beware if you're not white, my friend was actually refused a taxi because he was Indian...the taxi driver said they only take white ppl. The taxis are wayyyy over priced! The goods are fake (knock off -fake The North Face items come to mind) and wayyy overpriced! What you pay in Nepal you can get 1/2 price in India! Stay OUT of this area and don't bring your family here...but if you're a guy (or girl) looking for a good time...this is the place for you. Def bring some sort of protection tho as these girls work every day... and be careful of the drugs, the Nepalese police like to bust drug buyers and send them to jail as the USA has forced Nepal to make drugs (like hash) illegal.
Crazy. Besides hotels and restaurants, everything that you imagine find for trekking, hiking and climbing, you'll find here, in this noisy, crazy and crowded place called Thamel.

Trekking Epicentre. The area of Thamel is huge, but its main focus is trekking equipment and tourist needs. This is definitely the place to visit to stock up on supplies, or to get last minute items for your mountain treks. The amount of shops will astound you, so do exercise a bit of your bargaining-muscle and get a good deal to tell your friends back home about. Also available in Thamel are watering holes such as pubs, bars, several hotels, bookshops, a post office, bakeries, massage centres and restaurants,
Back in time. Many tourists here you can get a good deal if you patient enough shops are closed after 9 in every shop is pretty much the same with different prices

Fun, crazy and great people!. The Thamel is just plain awesome to hang out in. Great shops, good restaurants, wonderful Nepali people, tourists from all over the world, everything you could need to purchase just a store front away...what else needs to be said? I loved every minute of my time there and the wonderful energy of the area.

Thamel - take your time and look both ways before crossing the street!. We've made it a point to go to Thamel whenever we're in Kathmandu. There are so many shops and you can really get good deals if you aren't afraid to haggle. Street vendors can be very persistent, so unless you really want to get something they are selling, say no thank you and look away - otherwise you will be followed doggedly through the alleyways. Besides shopping, there is a fantastic - as in your Italian grandma's cooking from New York fantastic - Italian restaurant in Thamel across from a grocery store. It is upstairs and is called "Dolce Vida". Amazing food! There is also an incredible farmers market within a block of the Thamel shopping district which is the hangout for those old Woodstock hippies that disappeared. Fun place for delicious baked goods, amazing espresso and delectable French cheeses and meats.

Different feeling. When you roam around in Thamel you feel like being in a blend of beach and hill city. Several shops to haggle around, numerous restaurants serving great food and dance bars to end your day with pomp. On suggestion I went to other shopping places too but found Thamel to be best, even though cost here was little on the higher side.Must visit place.

Evening walk. Thamel is such a great part of Kathmandu. The streets are narrow enough to be not mown down by traffic because few vehicles attempt to drive down here. Lines with shops and cafés blasting out music, it is all rather touristy but great fun to people watch. You will probably be asked if you want some hash. It starts to quieten down by around 11pm. New Orleans Bar on Thamel is one of the best if you are looking for a place to eat with live music.

great place to shop. Thamel is as busy as it can be, but I narrow little streets lined with shops and restaurants have a certain fascination. Walk into the little side alleys – there is a lot to be discovered. And even this is a touristy place there are some good local restaurants around (we asked a bookshop owner and he recommended a great restaurant in side alley that we would have never found without his help and had a great lunch).-

Shopper's paradise. Well, I am confident everybody who travelled to KTM knows about Thamel - and those who visit KTM for the first time will learn about and experience Thamel fast. Shopping for gems and jewelery, pashminas or anything woollen, carpets, thankas, singing bowls, incense, teas ... Don't forget to relax at the Himalayan Java coffee shops when your shopping bags tire your arms - excellent Nepalese coffee there.

Courtyard Hotel. We love staying in this grand hotel. The hotel is in the Thamel area and is sits off a busy street so that the hustle and bustle is left behind. It is very roomy and hospitable. Our room was large and clean. Bedding and towels fit our needs. The breakfast is spartan but very good. The pancakes were delicious and filling. The owners (Michelle and Pujan) were welcoming and accommodating. They seem to be continuously improving the property. We have stayed at the Hotel Courtyard on multiple occasions and will return in the future.Thank you Michelle, Pujan and your loyal staff.GJS

Filled with tourists, in the best and worst of ways. If you're an "off the beaten path" type of tourist, you'll be sick of Thamel in about 30 seconds. You should also consider staying in another part of Kathmandu.However, after staying in another part of Kathmandu (where I was one of the 3 tourists in the only guest house), I was ready to go stay in Thamel. The shopping was great, the bars/restaurants were plentiful, the nightlife was awesome, and it was easy to coordinate other trips from Thamel.It's worth walking through for anybody, but consider what you're looking for when you decide where to stay. You'll have fun, but it won't be a very authentic experience. Also, remember to bargain at the shops. A lot of the prices were at least double of what they should have been. I don't mind paying an extra 100 rps for something, but I do mind paying 2000 rps when the item should be 300-400.Ask at lots of shops before you buy... and, shopping on a rainy day is good.Don't be as aggressive about bargaining as you may be in India, though. Ask around for prices first, and tell them how much you got other things for.
Mixing of populations. We walked three full days in the streets of Thamel without tiring. Music Om Mani Padme Hum and the scent of incense burning constantly kept us in a very special atmosphere.

yeah do it !. Breathe in the smell of incense as you wander the streets. A shoppers paradise for extremely cool stuff. Plenty of funky restaurants to chill out in. It feels a very safe city to be. Enjoy !
Madness and mo mo. A melting pot of humanity. A crazy jumble of hotels, shops, eateries, massage parlors, meditation centres. Every alleyway is full of surprises
Best for Shoping. buying for trekking gear, sleeping bags and handicrafts the Thamel is best for shoping. Sourrounding by many restaurants you can enjoy meal of your choice.

Touristville in Kathmandu. Loved the hustle and bustle of Thamel, you can buy pretty much anything you could possibly need for your trek. Some great restaurants and coffee shops. But make sure you get out and see other places in Kathmandu

Still worth spending a week here. It may have lost the romance of the '60's but it's still a great place. Just slow down, chill out, and take the time to sit and watch the world go by and you will soon come under the spell of this place. Shops start closing at 8pm where once they would have been open past midnight, but the crowds are gone and everything is now so much more sedate. Maybe it will come back again, but I don't think so. Times have changed but this is still one of the great places to come to. Enjoy before it's too late.

Good place for start of your Nepali adventures . You can find good accommodation here for the 1st day of your stay in Nepal. We bought map of our trekking route and arranged the necessary permits. Bargain about taxi fare from the airport to Thamel - there are dozens of taxis.

Busy and dusty. Thamel is a great place to visit as it has a real buzz - it has a great supermarket which has all the small quantities for things you might need on a trek.Good shops for trekking equipment/clothes, lots of good places to eat and drink, and lots of 3 star hotels.Very noisy and dusty - I would prefer somewhere quieter to sleep at night because the noise goes all night.

A real buzz everywhere you look!. We all love the hype surrounding Thamel. it is a real tourist magnet but the local vendors respect your wishes. Sure they are in the game of selling but it is done with good grace and spirit. They dive from one stall to another , in and out of shops then if you show an interest they often ask you to follow them down through a back lane and up the stairs into another small room that contains a variety of all kinds of gems! We always stayed in small groups but felt perfectly safe. It was a fun way to share a little camaraderie and money around. Nothing seemed too much but the haggling was all part of the deal!
A good place for souvenier shopping. You will need your bartering head on!. Loved the bartering and the variety, though if you are looking for high quality try New Road instead.

Safe Place to base yourself. Thamel is a safe place to base yourself and has some great spots to each and get your does of tourist shopping however that is all there is tourist shop after tourist shops so need to get out of this area to really experience the real Kathmandu

Don't Miss It. Thamel is dirty, busy, crazy and puts most folks on sensory overload but it is just this chaos that makes it worth a visit every time we go to Nepal. The streets, alleyways and hidden-away courtyards are like a warren filled with tourists, hucksters and vendors. What's not to like?There are lots of good restaurants and plenty of places to buy gear (real and fake), souvenirs and gifts. It is also good to note that there are plenty of places to change money. It's best to bring cash to Thamel as most vendors only accept cash. Also, do not be afraid to bargain! Never accept the first price offered. Also, when we were there, there were police on every block. They were very helpful with directions. Go with an open mind and have fun.

Heaven for backpackers/trekkers. The area is full of bargain shops selling everything you can need for trekking and climbing and much more. Do remember to bargain as the shop owners tend to ask for prices 3-4 times more than what you would expect to pay. The streets are full of energy and people are usually friendly.

Kathmandu Tourist city central. Thamel might be where all the tourists go but it is also full of locals and embassy staff. Lots of good bars and restaurants to choose from and if you like shopping...... Personally, I don't.

Interesting but very dirty!. The main problem with Thamel - and indeed Kathmandu overall - is the dirt and the dust. Much like Beijing’s infamous smog, Kathmandu has a haze of dust which blows up in your face every time a car or bike drives past you. It becomes essential for a prolonged stay here to invest in a surgical face mask that the Japanese have made famous in their own country. But believe me, Japanese cities are nowhere near as dangerously polluted as here in Thamel.If you can withstand the pollution, you can marvel at the shops and restaurants on display, and these shops in Thamel sell everything from Tibetan bowls, to Gurkha swords, to hooka, to charming little amulets.Another thing you must be wary of in Thamel is the narrow streets. The narrowness is what gives the area its charm, admittedly, although you must heed the honking of the horns, as taxi drivers and guys on mopeds are not known as the most careful or patient drivers in the world.I stayed at a hotel in the middle of Thamel called Gaju Suite, and from there I could easily walk eastwards to the Garden of Dreams, which is a nice respite from the smog at the far end of Thamel.

Shop till you drop. Shop what you want to bring home as gifts, shop what you need for trecking. Shop till you drop .... I found it exhausting but still ... it's a bit like the small sister of Khao San in Bangkok

Like any touristy street anywhere.... Lots of shops selling all kinds of souvenirs, handicrafts, trekking gear... many restaurants for Nepali or other food.Busy, noisy, narrow and crowded, but also exciting, energetic and action-packed! Try a ride on the rickshaw :)Haggle like crazy. Even with money exchange shops with 'fixed rates'. At night, this street becomes quite shady and sleazy. I was asked by guys 'what are you looking for... drugs, girls?' even though I didn't look like a tourist at all.

Yeah...go, but don't stay long. Thamel is the tourist center- souvenirs, trekking shops, knock off Northface, and Thanka art. I enjoyed the time there, i had about three days all up, i went to restaurants and bought my souvenirs, and enjoyed it. Very busy!! Thamel was the only place in Nepal that i felt a bit off being out at night alone, cat calls and whatnot - nothing threatening, just different. A few expats i met suggested not to be out alone after about 8pm, something i would now second. But during the day i wandered everywhere with no issues whatsoever!

Crowdy, noisy, not interesting. Thamel is the turist area of KTM, but the bad tourista area. It is crowdy, lots of traffic and noisy. You can buy trecking shoes, jackets and other staff like sleeping bags. 99% of what you find is fake, however sometimes of good quality if you don't climb... and just want to have North face shoes or Mammuth shoes to bring home. It is enough to spend there 2 hours not more. There are a few bars and cofee shops that are not too bad alfhough expensive. Thamel is not Kathmandou and is not Nepal.Avoid it if you can.

Dirty, noisy, crazy traffic - Thamel has it all. You can't visit Kathmandu without going to Thamel (but wear old shoes). This is where you find the bargains and the great, cheap restaurants. Watch where you're walking!

Thamel a Must!. So Thamel is an experience that you must endure during a visit in Kathmandu.
