The busy streets are overwhelming at first but the more time you spend there the more you get use to the beeping horns, bicycling and tuk tuks passing by. I often found myself still jumping when hearing a horn at times. It is quite an experience and gives you a little taste of the city. I wouldn’t spend too much time here but it’s hard to escape unless you visit Pokhara. The shops all seem to have similar items. If you find something you like walk up and down the streets it can be negotiated. Overall, an experience you must have while in Kathmandu.
Tourist trap. Well if you like to meet other tourists and eat in overpriced tourist restaurants and buy useless trinkets from one of the many souvenir shops, then this the place for you!

Not just about the shopping .... Hey guys! Surely it's not just about the shopping? What about the wonderful architecture? The sanctity of the many temples tucked into small side streets? The frightening spider's web of electrical cables sagging overhead? The fragrance of incense and spices? The sound of bells and chanting? Watching the local Nepalis doing their business with one another? And time-honoured industry all around you like matress-making, pottery, brasswork, threading flowers for garland offerings? If you have time after absorbing all this, by all means shop. Personally, I didn't as I was too busy immersing myself in to the local culture. After all, that's why I came to Kathmandu!
Crowded, narrow streets. Everything you need before and after the trek. Although some writers say "this is not the real Nepal" I find it charming and very well worth a visit.

The shopping experience must have. The shopping here is great and women would love the shopping . Even I am not a shopper wanted to shop here . The narrow alleys and the ancient houses and temples amazing place.

You need, they have. If you lost your luggage, do not worry, you can find whatever you need here! If you are programming a trekking and need to buy some accessories, by here. The price are very good, and they have all you think might need. The original ones and the fake ones as well.All the grate labels are here for the adventurous, so if you got here and get bite for the trek mosquito you will have no excuse.First make a tour to get familiar with the prices and the bargain method, then, choose your preferred shops and go for it!!!Restaurants, cafés, bakeries, meat shops...... They are all together. Go with the flow and enjoy the hustle bustle.
Tourist area. A lovely place to buy souvenir items for family and friends. You can also find restaurants or cafes to have a meal or just relax and have tea.

Best place for shopping. Thamel Square best place, best prices. Good for all kind of purchase. Purses, backbags, trekking stuff, pashminas, souvenirs, and don't miss Himalayan Java (coffee store) at the entrance of the place.
Best shopping in Kathmandu. Authentic goods, amazing shops that seem to go on forever. We had a terrific time gathering handmade Nepalese goods and tremendous prices.

everything is here. its a place that every tourist must come and stays here. street are crowded with tourist, lots of restauran, cafe, supermarket are in the walking distance ( i mean it just seconds of walk only).

Hussle bussle. We had dinner at the Rum Doodle where world renowned climbers have left their mark. Thamel is a thriving section of Kathmandu - lots to see - lots of shops - people of all nations visit here.
Thamel. I loved the restaurants and shops around thamel. watch out for the busy street though! the town is good for a couple of days then you should go out to Pokhara etc..

Nice Area to Hang Out. This is the melting point for all tourists. Nice look and nice environment. We enjoyed walking around the streets, restaurant hopping. Maaaaany shops selling mostly fakes..........must bargain very hard..........but don't expect anything original. We bought a few pashminas for $30 each. Turned out to be fakes. Besides this we bought a few souvenirs. Overall nice.

Busy but crowded with tourists. This is a place for trekkers to go and buy their last minute camping gear. The place is flooded and crowded with tourists. I would rather stay in Boudnath Stupa just before I fly out. There are many cheap monastery hotels with nice food. We ate at the Shenzen monastery for vegetarian lunch. We stayed in Happiness guest house.

Heart of the city. Dont miss it! Noisy, colorful, full of smells, interesting people and food. Bargain shopping at its best, less than Thailand prices. Bought North Face hiking boots and 5 good quality North Face jackets. Go for a rickshaw ride! Wear good shoes, streets are cobbled and uneven. vendors friendly and hassle you less than other Asian markets!

Wild and Crazy, and full of bargains. Thamel has so many shops you can't begin to count them. You can find everything in Thamel, and always bargain for the best price. If your looking for Singing Bowls, the best place is Freedom Exports. Don't be afraid to take a rikshall ride through the matkets.

Shopping in thamel. Thamel is full of shops where you can buy clothes for trekking or some spiritual buddhist items.
Thamel area is very interesting
Great hustle bustle. I love being around here to shop, look at ppl and drink some good coffee. U will also find some nice restaurants in this area.

many small shops from cheap souvenirs to luxury goods. Plenty restaurants etc... Thamel is colour full, crowded. It has a nice athmosphere.
You can (have to) bargain when buyng something.
Kasmire wool clothes/accesoires are attractive.

Thamel Have Henna or Mehndi done - recommended artist. In Thamel, my friend ran into a young man that is very skilled at henna drawings. She had one done and I later called him so he could do one for me as well. He copied an elaborate decoration from the catalog that he showed me. He is working on saving money so that he study to be translator and already speaks 11 languages. We were happy to help his business as well as offer to help spread the word about his artistic talent. We highly recommend Amit. Give him a call if you are in Thamel and he will come and meet you 981-355-8969.
Busy Kat. This is the spot for anyone in Kat looking for a shopping deal on anything imaginable, to hangout with expats, get a great bite to eat, or hit the town for a night out drinking!

The antithesis of trekking.. Great place for action and souvenir shopping. Yes you will get hassled by sellers and yes it is busy. But it is also vibrant colourful and great fun and is full of good restaurants and bars. Don't forget to haggle hard its expected.

Interesting market, but dusty. If you go to Kathmandu, you must come to this place, where you can buy a lot of things with bargaining price. But, in some places especially just outside the market area, is very dusty. You may need to bring a masker. The hotel I stayed, Kathmandu Guest House hotel, in Thamel area, where you can find also some cafes, groceries/supermarket.
tourist place. My hotel was located here, easy to get anywhere, tourist place soo many bars , restaurants everything was there.

A busy city. Vibrant, Full of lovely Nepalese People who are so friend and helpful. Shop owners obviously want to make a sale BUT if you smile and say no thank you they are very pleasant don't pester you. You feel free to browse and are able to walk away if you want to.

Heart of kathmandu!. This is the first place i stayed in Nepal. This is a place bustling with lot of color and energy and seems to be close to every other tourist attraction in Kathmandu valley and boasts of some very good places to eat. And yes.. do bargain for anything that you would buy here!

World of pure contradictions. Tourist focused - in both meanings. Great restaurants, tailors and shops. At least some of them. Scam, overpriced and dope-merchants on the other hand. Always been vexed by taxi owners, rikshaws, and tourist guides. Overcrowded when tourist season (mid March-April, mid-September-October), especially by white mens, motorbikes and taxis. Be careful. On the other hand no thievery.

Crazy Place. I guess its a must see but you need to keep in mind this is a bustling, crazy place. It's noisy, dusty, dirty and full of life. Avoid like the plague if you don't like crowds or don't like haggling. There are some great cafes and restaurants too.

A bustling place filled with culture. This was my first experience of nepal and I loved it. It is unlike anywhere else I have ever been and would recommend it to anyone who is thinking of going,There are many temples and stupas in almost every direction, great shopping to be done in marketplaces and lots if great local food to be tried. The people are friendly and the atmosphere is good. Although the roads are underdeveloped so you may be in for a bumpy ride in a taxi and you need to watch your step when walking around.

A must see in Kathmandu. Thamel is wild, chaotic, smelly, loud, dusty, and thoroughly delightful! If all you see is the dust and noise, you're missing a lot. Look closely: how many of the Nepali you see are smiling despite the crush and the crowds? Virtually all of them. If you find crowds difficult to handle, Thamel may make you a bit crazy, but never fear, you can always duck into a hotel garden or a garden-like restaurant courtyard and find yourself in an oasis of calm in the blink of an eye. Don't forget to bargain! And don't expect all those "North Face" bags to be authentic (there is a North Face shop for that): locals refer to them as the "North Fake"!
Haggle like never before. If you like to haggle then you must really up your game. These traders are amongst the best I have seen. A bargain can be made if you take your time with each transaction

Shopping heaven. There is nothing quite like shopping in Thamel but it has several 'faces' so to begin to get the feel of it (and find the best bargains) it really pays to walk around slowly and go as far away from the areas that are aimed solely at foreign visitors. In fact the best way to find bargains is to ask a local person, for example, we were told that Thahiti Chowk was the best area for cotton goods - and it certainly was. It is inevitable that at some stage, if you walk deep enough in Thamel, you will get lost but then you will see things and perhaps have conversations that you won't if you stay in 'upper' Thamel. Thamel is more than simply a place, it's an experience.
Polluted. Yes lots of shops and restaurants but also lots of noise and pollution. Also fairly close to bus stations for getting around Kathmandu or away from it.

Bargain market in city center. This area has hundreds of small shops packed in about two km distance.Apart from merchandise you have hotels and restaurant in the area.Go around, bargain what you want to buy and make most of it.A must visit if you are in Kathmandu.

The tourist district, best wandering/shopping.. Yes all of us tourists are here but its winding narrow streets chock full of shops, cafes, guesthouses are compelling and actually a respite from the noise and bustle of the rest of Kat. The shops tend to be repetitive and quality varies, some cafes are excellent.

Thamel town. We stayed in this area and the shops were very competitive, the streets were clean, the people very friendly and we enjoyed walking around the area, very safe, did not feel threatened at all.

Nepal Outdoor Mall. Quite a nice place to get lost in, not a great place if you're trying to find a restaurant when you're hungry. A lot of the same shops. By the way, there is no such thing as 100% Cashmere/Pashima/Yak. They're all fakes, the fake Yak wools are worth picking up those, they're worth the bang for the buck.

Crowded!. Tiny streets & alleys crowded with shops that sell you anything and everything you need on trekking gear, artefacts and cheap souvenirs. Perfect place to base yourself if only for a day or two as you are centrally located. Tons of cheap accommodation too so it’s the ideal place for backpackers.

Shop till you drop. O Thamel...it's a shopper's paradise...what can't you find there!!!?? I had no intention of shopping on this particular holiday in Nepal but once I visited Thamel I couldn't stop myself.....pashminas, yak wool shawls, scarves, gems, custom-made soaps, carpets,topis, muflers, bed sheets and what not! Also
great. its a tourist hub, walking aroung in thamel and stopping by for some great food with music and little souvenir shopping...

A unique atmosphere!. Having traveled all around the word there is nothing to really compare the unique atmosphere of Kathmandu and especially the are of Thamel. Magical scenery, people and experiences, it is like stepping into a different era!
The Place For Tourist. Everything is happening in Thamel except for the tourist sights. If you can find what you're looking for there then they don't have it.

Great location in KTM to base yourself. We found Thamel to be the best part of Kathmandu to base yourself. Within easy reach of all the shopping, eating and trekking companies you are likely to need. Yes it's dirty and dusty, yes it's a little chaotic, but what a place for an adventure or two. Enjoy the local foods and souvenir bargaining, and if all get's too much, The Garden of Dreams is nearby to relax in.
tourist area. Nice area, I see tourists everywhere, live bands, restaurants, book shops,hotels, everything we needed!!! very enjoyable area..

Cheap things to buy. Good place if you are looking for cheap souvenirs. I was able to find a very nice pashmina. Probably little cheaper then Europe. I feel like quality is good for some of them. One can easily spend 2-3 hours

Everything you need in one place. Rock up with nothing, leave with everything. Dont worry about booking because there are thousands of retaurants and hostels to suit all at your finger tips. This is the tourist central though so barter hard. Ask people of directions or help and they are more than happy to help. It takes time, but once you get used to Thamel you fall in love.

Very cheap place to shop and stay. This is a tourist hub, frequented by bag-packers due to availability of very low cost hotels out here. WiFi is free and common, even on street shops. Electricity is less so for heater you have to pay a lot extra... Good for shopping for souvenirs.

noisy. Thamel is one big noisy area in Kathmandu. You can eat cheap, get some clothing and souvenirs. In the three months we where here, we often went to Thamel in the weekends, and every first day we where so tired off all the honking cars. But when you get use to that it is a nice place, for a few days!

Shopping shopping shopping. If you like messy small streets and shopping, this is the place for you! Shops allover, with everything you could possibly want... and everything you never thought you'd need but suddenly can't live without. Some really nice charity shops too, supporting women equality... Worth a visit!

Love the hippie vibe. Don't miss the rush and hush if this square! Lots of places to go shopping (And bargain! Always start at 1/3 of the seller price ) and get a nepali Masala Tea at one of the nice cafes there are along the main road.Soak the vibe and don't miss to buy some music, cause you won't find it in You tube (Trust me.... I've been trying... and I regret not doing so!)
Shopping and Dining.. Ate at Big Belly, The Heritage and Da Hua Chinese restaurant. Shopped for baby goat cashmere (the finest quality), cashmere poncho, winter jackets and top quality gems
Great vibe ! Must visit or stay. Loved thamel - it's a must for shopping for trekking gear but also just to walk through. Safe day and night - lots of places to eat as well !

Hustle and Bustle of Thamel. I loved the atmosphere of Thamel. I was given a lesson in salesmanship many times while walking the streets. If you maintain an awareness of the ability of some store holders to get your business you will be amazed at their well honed skills. For the unwary traveller don't be surprised to end up with a suitcase full of nicknacks that you thought were a good idea to buy at the time. But enjoy the atmosphere there and open your eyes to the culture of the people and their kindness and strength amidst such extreme poverty. I talked to the people a lot and was treated to some great experiences like a private concert with the Gandharba musicians who have a club house set up in a private building behind the scenes. I loved it there.

Dusty, dirty, noisy but great fun!!!. Really fun to look round the shops. Backpacker central. An easy walk from here to Durbar Square, so don't bother paying for a taxi unless you have problems walking.

Backpacker central.. Thamel is insane. A confusing maze of narrow streets packed with cars, motorcycles, people, rickshaws, and dogs. Thousands of souvenir shops, restaurants, and hotels. A mix of tourists and locals. Plenty of hawkers around every corner. Westerners are approached to buy stuff every few feet.Despite all of the above, I still stayed there for three days and somehow enjoyed myself. I got used to the madness and managed to find it somewhat charming in a weird way. Most of the hawkers are actually somewhat friendly and will give up quickly if you politely tell them you are not interested in whatever they are selling. I found prices in the stores to be generally inflated even with bargaining. Prices seemed to be better on the outskirts of Thamel rather than near the center.When the hectic streets get overwhelming, seek out the peaceful nooks and crannies that are often found in the small side alleys.

No more fun :(. Kathmandu is only good for casinos now.. Earlier it was a lot more fun. If any one of you is looking for good night life, never visit Kathmandu.. Even the most happening area of thamel is dead by 9 in the evening. Moreover dance bars and night clubs (they also shut latest by 10) will not leave any chance to rip you off through their bar girls and cops won't help if you get ripped off. They do not want to loose the commission. And never ever believe a tout if he is promising you night adventure for some money. He is most probably putting you in a trap where a planned police raid will put you in trouble and you will end up loosing money because they only understand bribe and everyone will get a cut. Be aware of golden looking eggs!!! No professionals only money hungry people. Really disappointed by looking at the path these guys are following.
Crazy. Thamel is awesome to shopping. You can find anything there. You can pay $10 for something that they asked $100 before, it is up to you if you have the patience to bargain prices. I loved it!

Fun place to stay. We stayed in Thamel at Hotel Friends the two weeks we were in Nepal. It is a good central location for walking, Taxi's, or taking those fun Bicycle rickshaws. We felt safe there, but got a little uneasy when we tried to walk deep into the city where the streets all come together in wheels. Since there are no signs we had no idea where we were.It has got great shopping, lots of outdoor store, good restaurants, and easy access to other locations.

Street shopping. Tooo crowded... area is lit up in the night. Lots of street shopping and cafes.
Did not like the crowds and the constant bargaining. The place has very narrow streets and lots of people around. Not my kind of place.

Tourist trap. We were in and out of there in an hour. The noise the traffic of cars and motor bikes breathing down our necks beeping constantly as we tried to navigate the tiny roads drove us out. Not to mention the beggars who wouldn't leave our sides and the hawkers trying to sell stuff at every turn. We had a brief respite in a restaurant before heading straight back out never to return. Much nice places to see in Kathmandu. Only go there to find a restaurant or if you must, haggle for souvenirs.
Good atmosthere.. But polluted air. Very( One of the best area in the World for gurmans as well as gurme) Try to ger views of the mountains from roof tops)
Too crowded. It's definitely somewhere everyone goes. Therefore, it's too crowded, filled with tourists and everywhere is overpriced because of that.

Go for shopping!!!. Everything you need for your trek is there, come and get what you want at an excellent price and quality. Gifts, handicrafts, restaurants, bars and spas. Good atmosphere here. You won't be disappointed to spend a few days in Thamel.

Touristy, colourful. Although very touristy and crowded, Thamel has a good vibe and many colourful shops. You can buy almost anything here, and there is a huge selection of hotels and restaurants. A good place to stay when you first get to Nepal or if you want to do some shopping.

What a Place. I have spent a few days there, I know is touristic but I just loved getting lost around the street of Thamel looking for deals, you can find pretty good things and end up meeting some of the locals too. My favorite,the spice and food market

Vibrant area good for shopping. If Kathmandu is your first stop before your trek, do drop by Thamel to get some of the essential trekking stuff before proceeding further, especially if the places that you are going does not have a good shopping area. I would recommend getting your trekking poles, pants, jackets, outerwear here though you would need to bargain. Also, a point to note that the stuff are not real but are just as good enough for you to use for trekking, especially if you are not a serious trekker and do not wish to spend too much money on getting all the right trekking stuff.

The sold-out section of Kathmandu. If you're tired of Nepal and Nepalese things, go to Thamel. Here everything is geared towards the Westerner/tourist. Prices are higher, vendors more aggressive and foods flavors are changed. You'll see as many tourists as locals, and the few locals you do see will be trying to skin you in one way or another. You can find good food & things here, but be prepared to pay.Need drugs...here's your place. In the couple hours I was walking around, no less than 7 "dealers" approached me with whispered offers of "Smoke,hashish?" At least they weren't the aggressive ones.
Total tourism place. Busy & crowded, for shopping & gifts, really delicious food. We went there many times, the first thing you need to know is that you must bargain before you buy things.

Nepal people and culture experience. Thamel is a special part of the city of kathmandu. the people, hostels, shops, restaurants, souvenir shops, and all other places. the contact with the nepal people is there total, and special experience, really nice.

Very touristy but lots of fun restaurants and bars. If I go back to Kathamandu I may try to stay outside of the Thamel district. If you like to shop this is a good place but be wary of counterfeit goods (many are labeled Northface and others claim to be Pashmina).If you like to eat out there are a lot of fun restaurants that offer a variety of cuisines including Western food as well as many other types of Asian food. There are also clubs (I didn't go in but heard the blasting music).

Busy shopping streets and restaurants to spend free time. Thamel is a busy place with lots of restaurants and shops. Shops of travel, trek equipments, souvenirs, money exchangers etc. Most of Restaurants include Indian, Chinese, Nepalese dishes and some serve continental too. I felt its best place to buy souvenirs and gifts to our friend and family members and also so many good restaurants to eat.

Thamel is good for first timers to Nepal. Thamel is a good introduction to Kathmandu for first timers. But there are better places to shop if that is your intention. I like wandering from Thamel through to New Road where the locals tend to shop. Also the prices are more realistic there. Thamel prices tend to be very much inflated for tourists. Also Lazimpat Road has some really good Handicraft shops on both sides heading from Thamel towards the Shangri-la hotel.

Love it. The Thamel area is a vibrant, busy, yet organised area. There are many, many mountaineering shops selling everything that you could possibly need for any type of trekking that you were about to undertake. Wonderful stores selling North Face clothing, of very good quality. Huge variety of Restaurants and Cafes, with good quality food and fabulous Tea and Coffee. Thamel is such an interesting area to walk around. Also the book stores are great.

Tourist area. I came Nepal with my family. One of our family friend took us here in thamel saying its a tourists place. I am staying in the hotel near Thamel, this place is so cool. I can see soo many restaurants, I can hear musics at night, they say restaurants have live music at night, I havent visited one, but sounds great!! I am loving the stay here..

Colorful and cheap. Don't miss. Just let you feet take you around this colorful market. The people are very friendly and you can bargain on everything. Stop for very good Falafel and if you are Jewish don't miss "Beit Chabad".

Unique City with a lot of History. Kathmandu is a must on your Nepal trip. Since the international airport is here, you can spend your last two days here.You can do all your shopping before you leave. The prices are cheap, but make sure you bargin for the best prices. Plenty of great restaurants and bars to hop around in the evening.Our hotel was in the heart of Thamel so we did not have to worry about taxi, although we did take a rickshaw. In the day time this area is crowded with cars, people, and whatever else can fit. Best to visit this area in the evening when you can walk around.

Vibrant area. Thamel is a colourful area, full of stalls, shops and souvenirs to buy. The restaurants are all pretty good and you will never go hungry or be stuck for choice if you are around here. However the bad points are that it is so busy and full of pollution. There is a lot of begging from children which made us feel uneasy and uncomfortable. The traffic is crazy which makes is hard to cross the road as there is no right of way. However, still worth a visit!

Busy, thriving, lots of fun. Thamel is a lively, hectic, noisy, fun tourist enclave in the heart of Kathmandu. It has everything - shops, restaurants, cafes, bookshops, accommodation. You can find everything from German bakeries to southern US meals - and of course, traditional Nepalese food and souvenirs. This is the place to come for new or second hand trekking gear and maps as well as guides and porters if you need them (though cheaper and more reliable to do this in advance). Most trekking companies have outlets in Thamel. You can also do your money exchange and banking here. I recommend going into the supermarket here to pick up very cheap soaps, shampoos, food items, snacks for your pack and a face mask if you want one (good idea on dusty trails and around town). Lots of fun! Go with energy!

Worth at least two days. Colourful-Noisy-Chotic-Dirty!
This just about sums up Thamel.
Some great places to eat.
Dont walk around in a white shirt-It will be black by the time you get back o your hotel

plenty to buy and eat. Great spot to do your shopping, definetly the cheapest area to shop and eat in kathmandu. We particulary liked the pilgrams rest and feed restaurant, good clean food, toilets and free wifi

the place for us. this is tourist area, so it's very nice to be here, easy for me to find souvenir, to find the foreign restaurant and the road was very uniqe, narrow but very bright , a lot of small shop.. it's antique area.. really nice place, tourist have to come to thamel...

A place to go in Kathmandu. Thamel is the place where you have to spend time when you are at Kathmandu. Thamel represents all the culture of Nepal in just one place. You can get all the cultural items to buy. The hotels are also great it ranges from cheap to really expensive.

Epicenter for tourists and trekkers. Stayed 3 nights total in the Thamel area. It's loud and busy with activity. Tons of restaurants and shops. Trekking companies and gear shops are at every corner. There are lots of cars and motorbikes that pass through the area, so just be extra careful to walk on the side of the road and when crossing the street.

Great Location!. A great location in Kathmandu for tourists. Heaps of shops, taxis and restaurants. Most things I have wanted to go to visit are within a 200R taxi ride if not a short walk (less then 10km).
Highly recommended for tourists.

Be prepared.... Thamel is the touristic place in Kathmandu by definition. You can experience Kathmandu in its raw form. Cars, motorbikes and people struggling for the same space on narrow streets, endless stores with all sort of things and chaos. You got to go! But prepare your spirit for not being stressed with the noise and the many almost hit you will get from motorcycles and cars.

Tourist paradise. This is the hotel, shops, pubs, eateries and what not area. It has options for everyone on every account. Truly the most happening and colorful place in kathmnandu. If you in KTM then donot miss being here and best way to explore is via foot.

don't spend all your money at once!. I loved Thamel but I am a shopaholic! The shops are colorful, people are soooooo friendly (that you can't say no to an offer!) I went to a tea shop and they "made me" drink their tea... I checked other tea shops and prices and I went back to the first one because of the prices and because of the treatment I received...I ended up drinking 3 cups of tea!!! (they kept refilling it!) and this is after I made my purchase! Check prices before you buy anything, they are tourist prices, sometimes you can bring it down as much as 50%, some other times is impossible! Great restaurants, vegetarian options and just a place full of life!!! Walking the streets in the morning is fascinating! people are opening shops, watering the streets (they are so dusty!) and the scent of incense burning as they open shop most places burn incense as an offering to there gods...I am in love with Thamel even tho this isn't the real Kathmandu...but it's a walk away from it...you can't miss it!
love it. thamel is back to basics area... noise dirt hawkers business 5men students... absolutely amazing! Loved everything Bout it, but in the dryer months it can be very dusty

Shops and restaurants. This is touted as the tourist centre of Kathmandu. Most of the hotels and restaurants are situated here. However, there's no beauty to the place, its just endless rows of shops and bars and restaurants. If you love shopping, you will love the place, but remember that the prices here are a little steep. If you want to buy handicrafts, artifacts etc, its better to do it from Bhaktapur or Patan.

Shopping and shopping. Essential stop before any Himalayas trekking. So many items needed for the trek including socks, jackets, boots, trekking poles, thermo flask etc etc can be had here for very reasonable prices. It is said that you can come empty handed to Thamel and gear up totally within 24 hours for Himalayas trekking. Now, I believe this totally. As the saying goes, "shop till you drop".Many restaurants around which serve all sorts of food and drinks you can want, Nepalese , Tibetan, Western, Chinese etc. My favorites are the Nepalese Curry Chicken Rice, Naan, Tandoori chicken to name a few.

Bit of a rip off. Very touristy and a lot more hassle than other places in Kathmandhu. Quality of merchandise isn't great, but there are things to be found it you look hard enough or have a recommendation from someone who knows the area.

Great place to hang out. But really shady crowd at night.. Thamel is one of the most happening place in Kathmandu. Lots of bars, cafes and food joints here. We reached there at around 7 to have drinks and food. It was Christmas eve. The streets were bustling with activity. Lots of people. Now comes the thing which we did not like about Thamel at all. The crowd. Most of the crowd during the later part of the night was shady guys (localites) who were eyeing our female friends. We really wanted to party at one of the discs but then abstained because of the crowd.All an all, a good place to hang out, but afternoon or evening. Not a night party place if you have female friends with you.

It is what it is. Touristy, noisy, chaotic, but there are some great restaurants and cafes. Make sure you bargain hard for your items, shops automatically put on twice the value expecting to be knocked down to half the price.

what a mess. Thamel used to have a few interesting shops but these days its overcrowded with cars and motorcycles and pedestrians all trying to not hit each other. The shops are pretty much all the same. There are rug shops, outdoor camping gear shops, travel agents, video stores, restaurants and money changers. Not much quality stuff but you can get some deals. A few years ago I bought a "north face " (it wasn't really) jacket at one of the shops. Within three months it was falling apart. Inspect carefully anything you buy. There are a few nice places to eat. I like Pumpernickel Bakery for breakfast and Fire and Ice for lunch or dinner

FACE MASK is a must!!. I don't like this place. Dirty messy dusty with crazy traffic. Motor cycles, 4-wheel cars, pedestrians are competing on a narrow street with no pavement. I heard horns from the cars ALL THE TIME. I am so lucky that all my 10 toes are kept intact after walking here. Wearing face mask is a must, or you will breathe in tons of dust. I found black inside my nose everyday and saw so many tourists including myself coughing.No need to do shopping here as products are of the same pattern everywhere. Better shop at Pokhara.Since it's a super crowded area, beware of your belongings. From time to time, there are locals trying to sell things to me who is solo female traveller. I didn't feel so disturbed, as I could just give no response.Spending 2-3 hours in this Thamel area (for visiting Durbar Square mainly) will be very enough for me.
Nice town. Tamel is the main neighbourhood in kathamndu. There you can find a lot of restaurants, hotels ,B&B, etc... if you want to buy cool clothes, you can find there!!!!!!!!

Amazing but so full on!. Thamel is the main tourist area in Kathmandu and consists of a maze of unnamed streets hosting a mass of restaurants and stores aimed at tourists. Its quite unnerving that people will just routinely walk up to you and offer you drugs or some trinket they have in their hand but they are always friendly and NEVER hassle you if you are polite and say No thank you in a friendly manner.Just keep a smile on your face and you'll be absolutely fine. Lose the uptight Westerner vibe and just go with it.The serious downside to Thamel is the traffic.The streets are narrow and have limited or no pavements and cars, scooters and bikes thunder along the streets weaving in between pedestrians. The best thing the Nepali government could do would be to ban traffic from Thamel as it is a serious risk. I was shocked I didn't see more serious accidents while we were there. I love it, but the traffic....

Great place for food and shopping. Its probably the best place for tourists in Kathmandu. Plenty of Hotels to stay, Restaurants, Travel agencies and Shopping. There is frequent power cut in Nepal, except few main streets, its quite dark in the evenings.

must see. Being honest. I loved the thamel. Solo traveler and deaf. I never felt threatened or uncomfortable in the thamel. All the shop keppers I delt with were understanding and patient with me. The coffee shops I found were cheap and cheerful. A fresh coffee and chocolate doughnut came to about 75p.my advice would be to wander about.take the side streets and marvel at the architecture. .

More for Trekkers. This place would be good if you are looking for trekking equipment or specifically jackets. Otherwise, I felt that the stall holders here are slightly more obnoxious as compared to the other parts of Kathmandu. (People here are absolute gems!) I'm guessing this is due to the touristy nature of the area. If you are looking for handicrafts and such, other places would probably offer you much better bargains.
Shopping. Love this area because of shopping. Shopping was great here. I bought all gifts from this area and have good restaurant to eat as well.
Cool place to explore. Pretty decent if you're out for a stroll and looking for a place to eat or for souvenirs. Other than that, it's mostly shops selling the same stuff!

Most popular tourist area. Thamel has long been a main tourist shopping area and although prices are not necessarily the best it is colourful and fun and the shopkeepers generally friendly. With few exceptions bargaining is expected and during off-season prices very reasonable

Pefet hot spot, night spot.. flooded with bars and live rock music. the best place is purple haze..awsome live band..great covers - Genre- Metal/thrash metal/alternative. too good...spent my NYE there...couldnt have asked for anything better...the locals so welcoming and got mixed up with a group...just loved it...will be back soon,, just to listen to the awsome band...

It's nice, but really for the tourists. Every city has a Thamel. It's a place designed for the tourists and for many people coming from first world countries, you almost need the Thamel as a nice way to settle in. It's touristy and sells all the usual stuff. Has the clean restaurants etc. I couldn't help feel that it's not the genuine Nepal and that's why you have to get out a bit as well.
Colors of Kathmandu. A colorful and lively corner of Kathmandu. Take some time to walk through it and stock up on presents to people back home.Absolutely worth a few hours of your day.

Good foreigner-friendly area with all the services. Thamel is in interesting area that is centred on foreigners and provides many of that services that travellers will want, e.g. lots of money exchange places, western food for when you need something other than dal bhat, cafes, restaurants, lots of shops... If you are craving some live music, there are a few places that have live western music as well. Overall, Thamel is a great place to visit and stay in, but just remember that it is not necessarily the "real" Nepal.
thamel visit. nothing great about the shops as all the items are expensive as all have to be imported from out side except RUDRAKHA BEADS

Must visit in Kathmandu. This is only place peaceful enough to walk and contain streets where vehicle not allowed so many coffee and bakery shop .
Must for shopping needs.
Most of the people you see will be tourist .
You can call it the heart of Kathmandu tourism.
Tourists Dream. Everything you need / want can be found in Thamel. Great for shopping .... heaven on a stick !! Be prepared to bargain - you can usually get it for half the original price quoted.
Nasty but nice. You just have to love this maze of streets, shops alleyways,small shrines trekking companies restaurants etc etc etc

Tangled Tourist Turf. The Thamel area is designed for tourists. The streets may seem unbelievably chaotic the first day you are there, but you should be navigating them relatively well by the second day. You can even tell when you've reached the Thamel area with your eyes closed--simply smell the incense and listen for the familiar musical strains that beckon tourists in the various shops. And you will need to use all your senses to avoid the continuous flow of rickshaws, taxis and cycles through its crowded streets.Whatever you are looking for can be found in Thamel: hotels, restaurants, Internet cafes, religious objects, books, souvenirs, books, maps, trekking equipment, trekking and tour guides, groceries, electronic equipment. The prices are reasonable by western standards, but there IS a reason that locals do NOT shop here; you can find much better prices if you're willing to venture past the tourist zone.Most tourists stay just a few days, but if you are here for a longer duration (I spent 3 weeks) you will find that many of the merchants will recognize you, the regular flute hawkers will no longer bother you, and you will become friends with some of the workers in your regular hangouts.

Don't leave yourself too much time here.. Dirty, polluted, busy, packed with cars and motorbikes. Local guides and tour companies hassling you for your business. Lots of trekking shops although the majority are selling fake gear. Lots of restaurants to choose from although most are built for tourists. Spend perhaps a day here to stock up on trekking gear, but that is all.

Happening place. Full of shops with all that you may look for in Kathmandu, Kurkis, the resonating bowls, shawls, etc are the common this available here, there are lot of resturants hotels, bars, night clubs here.You can bargain in the shops here.

Bit like Japan subway. Bit like traveling on Japan subway without any map ... Lots of things to see and buy ... It seems they says the price they offer is fixed ... Food come in very small portion ... More like kids portion

Colour, Noise, and Crazy Traffic Fun!. After spending time in Thamel, most western cities will seem very quiet and less colourful. Thamel is a riot of pashminas, religious objects, restaurants, and money changers. Enjoy your foray into the streets as you learn to casually make your way through the glut of pedestrians, motorcyclists, rickshaws, taxis, tuktuks, and buses that defy all laws of traffic to get where they're going. You'll get used to the honking and relate to it as good-naturedly as the folks who are pressing their horns. It's all in good fun. You'll quickly learn which street vendors to smile and wave away as you KEEP MOVING, and which ones you can say no to but still carry on a conversation with over tea. Many will be delighted to share cultural stories, and welcome you back for more!People are kind, and Thamel is a fun place to be. Enjoy your stay.
Tourist trap. Thamel has changed drastically since my first visit in 1975. Now full of shops all selling the same inferior products to tourists.

Too full, too expensive. Prices were way higher than anywhere else in Kathmandu. We went there for all our shopping, having heard it was the place to buy all the presents and souvenirs, but we came back empty handed as we had seen other prices at all the other tourist attractions. It is full of western people who there with the same in mind (shopping). Their starting price was about 4 times as high as the starting price at other places. Ridiculous!

Mmmm we wouldn't go back. I mean, Thamel was alright, it had a lot of tourists and the second busiest nightlife we came across in Nepal (first being Pokhara), but it's just so hectic and we didn't get the best vibes from the people there. Store owners would charge 1100Rs for a pair of pants identical to ones that cost 200Rs everywhere else, and I caught one man peeking at me while I was in his change room trying clothes on. We planned to spend four or five nights here but returned to Bodnath after two because we were just not happy. Instead of Thamel, stay at the Happiness Guesthouse in Bodnath and take the 400Rs taxis into town.
Nothing scary but Pokhara way better. Honestly if you do not need to visit Kathmandu go straight to Pokhara. Cleaner air, quieter shopping, better views, overall a much nicer place to visit!

Overwhelming. Almost every other shop is a copy selling Yak hats, purses, pashima scarves, rice paper, tea..it goes on forever.At first it is fun bargaining but after a time it becomes wear some. At the time of my visit $10.00 had a value of 10,000 Rubees, during negotiations often you realized you were bargaining over a $1.00...The streets are very narrow so take caution walking, cabs, motor cycles pass by with inches to spare.Sort of fun for several hours but then tiresome, the pollution from those cars/cycles can almost be overwhelming.
Market. Narrow streets, marketplace to buy souvenirs. You will get approached a lot by people trying to sell you stuff. Becareful.

Disappointed. OK for locally produced souvenirs , restaurants but NOT / NOT / NOT for the buying of trekking gear . Most makes are nothing more than inferior copies of the original and the quality is poor .It certainly is an area for learning how to bargain.The street are a nightmare as you fight against cars and motor bikes ...................I'd ban em !!!! Other than that , the local people are simply fantastic !!!!

Touristic. You will end up your day here for sure. This is a totally touristic area. Hundreds of shops, restaurants, cafes, music shops,...Due to high competition the prices are ok, but bargain with the sellers anyway.

Tourist Capital. Thamel has everything for tourists. Many souvenir shops, restaurants and guest houses (a bit noisy). Tourists should negotiate the price before buying, you can also buy trekking stuffs here too. Most of people is very friendly and helpful. Staying in Thamel is convenient for you to go to many attractive places, only few minutes by car to Swayambhunath (Monkey Temple).

Excellenrt place for tourists to visit!!!!. Thamel is the heart of Nepal's tourism. It is the place where tourist get everything they want. It is a colourful and beautiful mixture of craft shops, boutique cafes, trekking gear, and rainbow prayer flags. Ason Bazaar, Durbar Square, Samakushi and Swayambhunath are a mere 10 to 30 minutes walk from Thamel.Thamel has clean narrow streets full of mushrooming lodges, hotels for budget travellers. There are about hundred hotels located in Thamel. Restaurants, bars, travel& trekking agency and other tourist oriented shops can be seen bustling with activities. Arround 99%of tourists must have come to see thamel for shopping and to do other activities.

Good for trinkets. Good place to hunt for trinkets. Watch out for petty crime and make sure to negotiate prices! Assume anything you are buying with a name brand label is actually counterfit. 100% cashmere is more likely yak hair. Also, the children beggers are hard to ignore, but if you give them anything make sure it is food and that they eat it in front of you else they will hand it over to their adult minders.

Thamel. Great personality & vibe in the old area. Sellers can be a bit pushy, so be prepared to walk away & be a little rude at times. Remember they are trying to feed their families & everything is so cheap, bartering really is a waste of time for what you save
Busy buzzy Thamel. It is a quite a small district but exciting and welcoming place for new arrivals with a wide variety of hotels restaurants and shops.

busy, pumping, local!. A big area within the city, with very much narrow roads for which kathmandu is famous for. the best way to get around by foot, where you can find shops where you can get everything you want from food to trekking stuffs!

busy, exciting, friendly. an exciting and welcoming place for new arrivals with a wide variety of hotels restaurants and shops in quite a small district. Lots of night life for the younger one's so be careful which hotel you chose as some have night clubs with open tops next door.Cost is very varied, mostly low cost, I think it's worth paying a little more for a slightly quieter place as you may need a retreat from the activity outside on the street.A little sad to be offered so much in the way of drugs on the street but it's casual, no aggressive sales.Love the Tanka art shops, an extensive collection of buddhist artwork. Lots of beautifl temples around the area.Don't be afraid to explore wider afield, it's lovely to stroll through the streets of Kathmandu for the first time not know where you're going, miss that feeling.

Tamel... Old city living city.. A very small area with lost of shops for souvenirs. But more than that, old buildings and narrow streets reflecting historic texture of the town. Buildings are collapsing as there are No funds for restoring them. So do come and see nefere it is lost

Exhilarating!. Beware of the motorbikes!!! You really do take your life in your own hands as there are no rules and you have to be alert at all times - but it is such a colourful wonderful vibrant atmosphere - if a bit smelly at times!!! So many bargains to be had, be prepared to bargain hard - bought a wonderful pashmina not to be missed - wished I'd bought more!!

Great place for everything. Though it is understandable that some tourist may not appreciate the "chaos" of this place, it is a perfect place to shop for souvenirs or trekking equipment. Just give yourself some time to acclimatize to the constant honking and you'll start to see more and more of Thamel's charm. Not to mention that I felt safe walking around despite the crazy amount of people walking about.

Not much besides shops. This touristic area does not have much besides handicrafts shops and restaurant. At night can be really noisy due to the many bars some of which are definitely seedy places that look like cover for other business! I would definitely change location if I come back.

Chaos or adventure?. It was my first time in a developing country, and I was solo. I stayed in Thamel and found it a very safe place to move around. The traffic was chaos to try to navigate but I soon got used to it. Bartering was a skill I had to learn, but learned quickly. The shopkeepers seem to think westerners have bags of endless money and so they try to get the highest price...opportunists or rip offs??? U decide. I was suprised to find prices as high as they were. Even accepting there is a double standard for local vs foreigners, I think much of it is inflated.If you stand in one place too long you will be approached by taxi drivers, rickshaw drivers, trinket gypsies, tatoo artists, dope peddlers and tour guides all trying to drum up business. Its all part of the Thamel culture, and is quite an experience.

shoppers' zone. Really enjoyed the place throughout the journey because of its unique nature. it is always full of energy and life. the whole area is full of shops of various products and services. the good thing about this place is that you just walk along the road and shop whatever you need. this is actually the tourists' zone of kathmandu city.

Typical Tourist Place. Directly went to Thamel from KTM airport, took almost 20 min to reach. Thamel is a typical tourist place. A lot of places to stay and eat. It has a huge Tibetan market to shop for artisans, trekking items and local gifts. All range of hotels are available to stay. You can look out in the various lanes of Thamel for accommodation. Casino Royale is 10 min walking diatance form here. A lot of other tourist attractions are also not far. Hiring a taxi in Nepal is pretty costly, so I would suggest to hire a bike for the whole day and roam around the city. Overall good experience.

Great Energy...ALways felt safe. This is where our hotel was located..and so glad we stayed here. This place has a ton of great restaurants, shops, characters from all walks of life ( i mean that in a good way). Best of all, you had a good mix of locals too. Walking distance to other important tourist sites, embassy row, etc.
Stayed right in the mist of Thamel. Stayed with a friend our hotel was up a lane way close to everything. Some great restaurants and shopping galore. I would recommend stay in Thamel.

Great trek supply shopping!. Awesome place to shop! Especially if you are going trekking, this is the place to buy what you need. There are shop after shop with inexpensive knock-offs. Careful tho, we bought "Waterproof" Northface rucksacks that ended up leaking. You get what you pay for!

A kaleidoscope. It is a centrally located market in Kathmandu. It is rightfully a kaleidoscope of people, colors, shops and life all mixed together. The restaurants serve an eclectic mix of food and drink, dishes you have not tried before. The shops hold a wide range of cheap goods that you can buy and take home as a souvenir. The locals are great to watch and chat. Basically this is a place full of life and you are a part of it.

tourist place to shop in Kathmandu. Busy tourist shops with a lot of them selling similar goods. Still it has a nice atmosphere and friendly bartering. Good for colourful scarves, shawls, pashminas etc Plenty of places there to eat and drink too. It can get a bit hectic so personally I would only want to visit for a couple of hours at a time. Found delicious home made lemonade in glass bottles with glass toppers made with fresh lemon which was refreshing.

Small respite in crazy Kathmandu!. Initially having traveled only from the airport to Thamel, I thought that it was quite crazy wandering the streets there. That is until I left Thamel to travel around the Kathmandu Valley. I realized Thamel was the calm in the other wise chaotic experience of Nepal's capital. If you are setting out on a trek, you can find anything you forgot to bring with on the streets of Thamel. The people are very friendly and purchasing anything is a good experience. Streets are swept clean everyday, all day. Lots of restaurant choices, lots of hotel choices. A very pleasant experience.

Shop Shop Shop. Bring your American dollars. This is nothing more than an outdoor shopping mall. Busy and most of the items are cheap, as in cheaply made. There are many other places to get authentic items from Nepal without all the people. This place defiantly attracts the tourist.
Heaven for trekkers. Get all the trekking gears here! May not be authentic but they are cheap and serve its purpose. Walk around and mingle with other fellow trekkers!

Tourist area: hotels, entertainment, food, shopping, everything!. Though as my Nepali friend always puts it: "This is not the real Nepal," Thamel is a great way to start off your journey as a tourist because of it's relative convenience and no lack of anything. Hotels, hostels, restaurants both local and international, shows, bars, cafes, streets lined with endless shopping stalls, it's the perfect (aka easy) way to show up and get comfortable, before venturing into the much quieter, less intense, and rural life of the "real Nepal."If you're planning to shop, Thamel is the place but try to do it on your way out or you'll be lugging a lot of extra weight with you while you travel. Thamel has beautiful Nepali treasures and trekking gear. You can also buy many other necessities (toiletries, feminine products, etc.) that you won't find off the beaten path, or off the tourist circuit. You can also book your many excursions in the many travel agencies and trekking companies there. Thamel is loud, busy, colourful, a lot of fun, and is a great start and finish to any trip to Nepal.
shopping and shopping. this is the best place in all Nepal where do business!!! here you can find all! restaurants, hotels, agencies but specially shops where negotiate!

Good. Thamel, what can you say? Well it's the definition of tourist, everything is aimed at the tourists. Don't come here expecting anything authentic, but come here anyway. There are an array of great restaurants and decent hotels, plenty of shops to occupy your time and your money and lets be honest, if you are coming to Nepal you will go to Thamel.

Shopping paradise. Great place to go shopping for souvenirs, tiny streets with lots of history and excellent restaurants. A must is the yin yang restaurant for Thai Food. Excellent menu, high quality food and service. Slightly over priced but worth every penny.

can't avoid it!. Thamel area is said to be hellish for the traffic and the noise,but:where else you can stroll and see people from all over the world,buy simply anything which is made in Nepal and even in India,try any kind of cousine at any price,meet the strangest people,find rare books,organize trekkings ,tours,have massages or more,or just seat and do nothing but observe the world going around?

Heart of the city. Kathmandu will catch your heart at the very first sight when you enter its wooden airport. You will be lost in the tile color streets of Bhaktapur as if you are travelling in the pages of history. And you will feel at home when you see all the time smiling Nepalese people. Thamel is the heart of the city, all the time alive and if you are a outdoor gear fan like me, it is a heaven! You can find the high quality fakes of very well known outdoor brands for very cheap prices. When talking about food, you will be full with delicious momos.If you are an open hearted traveller, Kathmandu will make you happier than ever..

Tourist district marred only by endless honking traffic. Practically every 2 metres in Thamel there is a tourist shop hawking something from woollen clothing & fake outdoor gear ( North Fake is very common) to statues, jewellery and fabrics. It's the area for restaurants, clubs and bars too....if only these tiny medieval streets were traffic free! As it is, one browses to the constant background honk of grinding traffic. The same is available in Pokhara where it is more relaxed and where Phewa lake helps maintain the calm!

Thamel is endlessly fascinating.. Thamel is endlessly fascinating. Each time I think of returning to Katmandu I picture myself walking the streets of Thamel, seeing temple and shrines everywhere, getting lost and finding a site I remember from an earlier visit. That's exactly what I did this trip. I had no idea where I was most of the time, no idea if I had ever been on that route, and then i would see a sanctuary or a corner or a chowk or a water spout that I had photographed 10 or 15 or 45 years ago.Yes, it's noisy and crowded and polluted, and the traffic is dangerous, and it was hot and muggy in late September and October, but it was like I had come home. Maybe not home - more like a dream world that never stops revealing itself.

A tourist attraction. We were staying in a hotel that was in Thamel itself so that’s how we got to explore Thamel. It is a kaleidoscope of various restaurants and shops along with the local crowd. The hustle and bustle of the place sucks you in. We shopped till we dropped as the stuff is very cheap and tried out a few eateries. We visited it thrice and even revisited some eateries here.
about thamel. Thamel is a popular place inside kathmandu valley for tourist and familyThamel is a popular place inside kathmandu valley for tourist and family

Good choice of hotels and eateries. Thamel is the place to be if you want a good choice in hotels and eateries. It is also a fantastic area for shopping--catering to everything you want and desire. However, the place is super busy with taxis, cars and motorbikes (incessant horning all the time) not to mention pedestrians. The roads are also badly damaged with potholes everywhere and not all areas are well lit at night, so be careful where you walk. My husband almost sprained his ankle when he inadvertently stepped into a hole one night.

Busiest area in Kathmandu!. I think it's the busiest area in Kathmandu, so many tourist- including me, so many cars- horn all the time, so many shops- good for shopping, so many money exchange store and so many restaurant- good for tourist. I stayed in this area because it's quite convenient for shopping and eating although the food price was higher than other areas. But you can find some cheap restaurant in this area as well. ^^Although there's lot of pollution here but that's Thamel, I think it's something exciting like a new experience. Lol But you can get away from this crowded and full of dust street by going to the Garden of dream which is just a few steps away.
Great place to stay. We stayed there and the atmosphere and colorful streets were great. It was busy and we had to be careful of the motor bikes. There were so many great places to eat near by.

A tourist mecca. Whilst there is a lot of accommodation options in the Thamel area, we chose a hotel closer to the airport which was away from the "hustle & bustle, the chaos, the noise, and the excitement" that is Thamel. If you prefer like us, not being pushed & prodded, and being almost run-over by the cars & motor bikes, then may we suggest you visit Thamel in the late afternoon / early evening. It has a different feel and a seemingly more relaxed environment. Being a "tourist area", prices seem to be higher as compared to other areas but you are able to bargain down ... it can be fun.

Good Location for Staying and Shopping. A great location for staying and shopping in Kathmandu. Though the roads and communication system are not that good but still a good place for cheap hotels and restaurants.

bit silly really. do not see the appeal of this place. After a quick visit to aroma Garden for great incense and some soap, short lunch we headed straight back to the Durbar area. Next time we skip thamel, unless someone reeeeeealy needs a knitted hat from thamel, and spend more time in Patan.

Place of many face... The place might look like a busy market street .. but one stop stops for Shopping , Partying,, Clubbing.. chilling out , Having a drink.. Trying different cuisines .. over all i would say if you like music and good cafe's This is the place to be in Nepal.. The place offer Free wifi service which is availble throughout Thamel market ..
Thamel. Loud, Congested! Great place to poke around for souveniers and trekking gear. Prices are a bit high, and people always asking you into their shops for the hard sell.
i live here. A place for traveller , for a trekkers, for party people, in one word you can get any thing you want. A little bit noisy but i love where i live.

The streets of Thamel.. Yes the streets Thamel are crazy. But they are also full of lovely little nooks and crannies and full of bright and wonderful goods, lots are hand made here in Khatmandu. Yes the prices are higher than other areas of Khatmandu but it is no different to any city centre any where in the world. I have no doubt the price of shops and stalls is higher too because of the location. So yes you can bargain and maybe knock a few rupees of an item but then that cuts into the tiny profits there is to be made.

Cakes - Pastries - Beers - Bikes and - Much more. I had been visiting Thamel since the last 10 years and the flavour of the place is unchanged. Now, Thamel has been a tourist destination in Kathmandu since the hippie movement and you can actually feel the hippie pulse once in Thamel! Even though Thamel has been referred to as the "ghetto" by some, most low-budget travelers consider it a tourist heaven. Thamel is distinguished by its narrow streets crowded with various shops and vendors. Commonly sold goods include food, pastries, walking gear, music, DVDs, handicrafts, and clothes. Travel agencies, and budget hotels, restaurants also line the streets. Of the many hotels the most famous are Kathmandu Guest house, Hotel Norbulinka are famous. There are many bakeries in Thamel and one must try them if in Thamel. Some bakeries are, The Bakery Cafe, The Pumpernickel Bakery, The Weizenl Bakery and many more. Thamel has a great night life and once the sun sets Thamel wakes up. The Irish Pub was one of my favourite hot spots. Other pubs around Thamel are the Northfield Cafe, Paddy Foleys Pub, Road House Cafe etc. There are a few steak houses in Thamel and all of them serve good steaks. My personal favourite is a rare done Chateaubriand steak at the Everest Steak House. Thamel also acts as the pre-base camp for mountaineers. It boasts a wide range of mountaineering gear shops, foreign money exchange booths, pubs, clubs, and nightlife along with the numerous travel agents and guest houses. All in all, Thamel is home to a wide range of audience of the Nepalese population for entertainment and employment purposes. On Wednesday, 28 September 2011, Thamel was declared a full Wi-fi zone in Nepal.A word of caution here - The gift shops in Thamel are very much over priced and it is always better to avoid them. Also do not buy CD's / DVD's / Blu-Ray's from Thamel as they are all pirated and a lot of them would not be supported by the players at home as most of them are not region coded!

Crazy. The streets of Thamel are crazy, cars, bikes and trucks swerve around you as you try to walk along the edges of broken road. Horns honk and vehicles stop amazingly quickly and i never saw anyone hit.

tourist shopping destination. Thamel is the place were every tourist would go. there are narrow roads and number of shops, restaurants and hotels were there. there is nothing to sea instead of shopping and eating. if you want to see more natural beauty then go to Pokhara.

Shoppers paradise. Great place for shopping. Thamel has quite a few shops selling quality products but prices may be slightly on the higher side. One may try bargaining skills but most of the times they don't work. Traditional stuff, handmade paper products, garments etc can all be found.

Center of it all... Busy, entertaining, good food, special vendors...
Life is here.. so is everything else. This is the most happening place in Kathmandu. Great shops featuring Nepal products, music venues, cafes, and more... Namaste

chaotic but all tourists go. The place for shopping, walking, eating and hanging out is Thamel. It's chaotic, noisy, crowded and an overload on the senses but everyone goes there and many choose to sleep there as well as it is so very centrally located. Be aware that some items you can buy are either fake or simply of very poor quality.

Good Area. Great place to walk around and find the things you need for your trek. Catered to tourists, there is plenty of western breakfasts and food around. It felt safe walking around this area, even though you can get lost because of the winding streets.
Sopping place. Nice place to shop around for gift items and antics. The road has lots of happenings. I liked the crowd.
great shopping. the area is beautiful, yet traffic comes both ways and can be dangerous at times but still the best food and shopping there....

The hustle and bustle of a busy place. It is busy, it is dirty, it is crowded, but it is exciting at the same time. Horns are honking, traders are constantly stopping you to ask you to go inside their shop, others just want to practice their English, it is constant, but there are some great shops, pashminas are made in Nepal and are to be found for sale everywhere. If you love crystals and crystal jewellery there are so great bargains to be had. The roads are full of pot holes, it is very dusty, so a mask is advisable even when just walking round the streets.

Shops..Food....Supermarket. Lots of shops with very inexpensive souvenirs. Great restaurants catering for western tourists with lots of choices. A great supermarket in the middle of Thamel. Plenty of bakeries and pharmacies and laundries.

Typical developing world market place. Beggars, pushy salesmen, high pressure bargaining. Can't walk the street without being approached for some kind of art or gadget for sale. I much prefer the free trade stores with fixed prices that outlet artist goods and benefit the artists. Everything is so inexpensive anyway, it didn't make much difference. I hate bartering with people who don't even have running water.
Perfect ambience for foreigner. I love the ambience here in Thamel. Perfect ambience for foreigner. Everything is in place, just name it. A shopping heaven for us.

If you can't buy it here you don't need it. Great variety of shops ,cafes , hotels & more hustle & bustke than you can imagine.Whether shopping for gifts , souvenirs , or necessities for trekking it's all here.Taxis are easy to find & the quickest way to get around & back to where you're staying.Some of the buildings & shrines are beautiful as you walk around.Just be careful of the traffic as scooters ,bicycles , cars come from nowhere.Retail therapy at it's best & vendors love to haggle , but will soon tell you that they have to make a profit.

A little bit of everything in Thamel. Most vistors to Kathmandu would spend some time in Thamel; it's convenient, a good place to get some gifts to take home, and also to get some last minute trekking gear. Have been there many times, and always feel safe providing I keep an eye on the scooters!!

Busy and crowded. Thamel is a shopping area good for knick-knack shopping, hiking gear, fabrics and also souvenir shopping. It has many criss-cross lanes with number of small shops. Many restaurants are also there. Do negotiate/bargain about price.

It's a kaleidoscope. Best place for tourists with international cuisines and shoppers and hoppers stop by if you are looking for good cafeterias and kaleidoscopic experience pls do visit this area rather opt to stay here as the accommodations are indeed affordable and clean with mountain view if you opt to climb on roof top also eat good pan cakes and steaks and Nepali Thalis

An illusion. Thamel is designed to cater for the needs of those of us who prefer the creature comforts of the west. I will admit I am one of them. Despite this there was no guarantee of electricity 24 hrs a day even in Thamel! The best thing about Thamel is the food! We could have eaten at a different place every night and the food was cheap and delicious.
Visited here looking for bargains. Do not go at night very difficult to walk since no street lights and road is not suitable for walking

Kathmandu. You have to experience this, there is nothing to like or dislike, it is an impressive experience: busy street life, high pollution, extremely friendly people,( not pushy, even if you don't buy) poverty......
very crowded. small small shops for trekking experience (as per our guide - half of them are not registered) and the Dance bars..

typical fake shopping area. this district is the typical sale area of Kathmandu with ever-alluring sellers to visit their store where you can buy at low prices but definitely fake products. It's a quality-price issue so you have to compare what is not so simple.

City Center. Its good to be at thamel. It is the city center where 99% tourist visit, where all the facility is provided depending upon the places - prices are flexible. You have to be a hard negotiator.

Enjoy the hustle and bustle of Kathmandu.. Thamel is the tourist mecca of Kathmandu. The streets are lined with fabric/scarf shops, mountaineering clothes and gear, souvenirs and restaurants. Although the shopkeepers encourage you to enter their stores, they do not hound you or berate you if you do not want to buy their goods. The outdoor shops were honest when asked if the clothes that they were selling were the 'real thing'. Although not the genuine label, the quality is very good.

an amazing place to visit. You can find almost anything you want there. There are whole bunch of shops, restaurants, bars. For trekkers, it is a great place to find shoes, trekking poles, sleeping bags etc... with very very reason prices but bargaining is a must as people here usually offer very high prices

Go and see it .... but .... I suppose its a 'must see' but in reality this place is a nightmare, appallingly clogged and polluted streets with touts, motorbikes, cars, vans, people all pushing down the alleys and passageways. Heaps of gift shops, bars, restaurants, etc .... all of varying quality, This place was a backpackers mecca its now pretty overblown... and not that cheap anymore... make sure you visit, but maybe don't make this area focus of your time in Kathmandu.

An must go to place in Kathmandu. The Thamel is basically many small allies in which there are small stores were you can buy Nepali things like: jewelry, tea, climbing gear, cloth, hats, bags - all Nepali style. It can be intense, the sellers are all over you and its sometimes too much. Take into consideration that the prices are negotiable, normally you can drop them to 50%-60% of the first named price. If you are in Nepal its worth going there for sure.
Tourist nightmare. The only place I could say I was embarrassed by how Westerners looked/dressed. Alot of junk for sale, and the only place street vendors approached to sell pot.
Busy place to be.... Very busy and can easily get lost...Lots of things to see and find. Resto, cafes, hotels. More tourists than locals

Chaotic but charming!. Thamel is very chaotic but at the same time charming once you have spent some time there. It is a great place to shop and bargain. It is not a place for peace and quite but take at least one day and get your shopping done. Talk to the people working in the shops and negotiate a good price. Sit at one of the restaurants or cafes and enjoy watching the people, animals, cars and other vehicles go by. There are great places to eat and great shops with fair prices.

Interesting, noisy place, you have to visit. I think the most tourist place in Nepal. Except the tourist shops, you can find everythind a tourist want, like minimarkets, street food, pharmacy, massage, trekking gear etc. nice cheap (also expensive for Nepal standards) restaurants and very interesting pubs. Pretty noisy street but i'm sure you can find a nice, quiet room even close to Thamel. There are a lot of them.
A must place for tourists. Shopping, food and nightlife. U can get all three in Thamel. Definitely a place for the tourists. But don't buy anything without bargaining.

The place for fun unlimited. Thamel has a history since the days of the flower children. Today it has almost 100 restaurants, bars and hang out places with cuisine from all over the world. Just walk down the street with your ears open and let the sound of music be your guide for the evening.

Awesome place for tourists. I loved this place of the city. It is were most if not all tourists lodge themselves.You can find a wide range of shops. From basic shops where you can find the unexpected, up to specifix trekking shops with "The north face" clothing.Bargaining is an martial art here. If your don't bargain, they might be charging you a 1000% more.A wide selection of restaurants are set up in thamel nd very nice roof topa were to smoke a shisha and just chill with some friends.

Thamel is a nice place to chill. Thamel is the nicest area of Nepal, it's got tons of foreign food resteraunts, like Korean food places, Western food places, and so on. It's got a nice relaxed atmosphere, and is overall a very pleasant place to relax.I highly recommend it.

Bustling with Life & Energy!. Choose a hotel/hostel & stay there if you are in Kathmandu! From early morning, before the shops are fully open, street vendors paddling local pancake like breakfast, seeing how the empty streets becoming busy as the sun rises.Plenty of restaurants, cafes & stores everywhere for your every mood! When the night comes, bars & pubs light up the place, although it might be quieter than big cities downtown, but it sure has it own beauty in it's way!
Good for food but not for shopping. You can try foods in this area but for shopping its very expensive. I would not recommend to shop here. but this place is best for hotel

Very Touristy. Thamel is a must see in Nepal, but don't expect an authentic experience. It is a lot like landing in a cruise port, where all of the stores have the same stuff (knock off North Face, hand made gloves and hats, swords....) It can be a bit scary crossing the street and the pollution is horrible, but it was a neat experience.

Rip offs. Overpriced and incredibly crowded. Easy to get lost because none of the streets or alleys are marked so bring a map to find your way out. Bargaining a must, if you aren't in the mood to haggle go elsewhere. We prefer shopping in Pokhara ten fold!

Tourist Shopping District. If you want Nepal t-shirts, fake North Face, wood carvings or woven socks hit up Thamel. Streets are packed with tourist, taxis and backpackers. Fun to try to not get run over. Interesting shops. Some have unique items but most sell the same products. Good rooftop restaurants.

Crazy fun!. Thamel is a bit difficult to get used to, but once you get over the shock at how close the cars and motorcycles get to you (it's ok- they don't move very fast and won't run you over!), you'll be fine. The stores are great and you can bargain at most of them except for the few high end shops. One hundred US dollars can last you a week's worth of shopping- and you can do a LOT of shopping with that money, I promise. Just bargain. Bargain. Bargain.
My hotel. I was in Thamel area. It's a shopping destination of Katmandu. The Resturants, hotels are all nearby.

Food & hangout. Lots of nice restaurants, bars and shopping places. Good for tourists as well as locals. Downsides - hustle bustle, overcrowded, places with overpriced stuffs. But once you get to know the place well, its a delight. Don't hangout much there lately as we used to do several years back, but still like the place.

Ladies & Gentlemen, welcome to Thamel!. Colourful, tourist oriented, crowded, a maze of narrow streets and alleys offering everything you could ever want, a tourist attraction in itself, a wide range of hotels, a shopping haven for budget travellers, annoying hawkers, bakeries, both an old area and the tourist section of the city, bronze figurines, Buddhist Thanka paintings (paintings on silk with embroidery, usually depicting a Buddhist deity, scene, or mandala of some sort) & khukuris (a Nepalese knife with an inwardly curved edge, used as both a tool and as a weapon), cakes, carpets, chunky necklaces, colourful handicrafts, fresh Himalayan coffee, fridge magnets, Indian foods, intricate, jewelry, knitted wear, maps, massage centres, Mexican dishes, mountain climbing gears at cheaper rates (if you know how to haggle), nice woollens, overpriced Nepalese souvenirs, pashmina stuff, pizza, postcards, semi-precious stones, some very exclusive things (like traditional musical instruments), statues, stone carvings, sushi, tea leaves, Thai food, Tibetan eateries, tour agencies, wooden carvings, yak bone key chains & lockets. Just NAME it and you get it! Anything!!! You want, you get it here! Ladies & Gentlemen, welcome to Thamel!I have visited many places reliant on tourism. Thamel is one of them, undoubtedly! As it is the touristy/souvenir area of the city the pushy sellers are ready to take large profits off of clueless tourists. Not all stores try to rip you off though, but don't be shy when it comes to haggling and bargaining. After all, they aren’t shy at the time of overpricing their stuff! Hawkers are a constant pestering and that can be annoying (almost impossible to look and shop without being bugged to buy something). However, good news: If the price of what you want to buy seems high to you (some items are REALLY expensive/overpriced, at least for a South American traveller like me), all you have to do is mention the price at which you would like to buy it and they will be happy to give it the price that you quoted (not always, of course!).Thamel can be exciting or down right annoying, depending on who visits it. It is always active, always crowded. Noisy, crammed. Full of polite people who seem to be the descendants of the hippies of the 70's. Drugs fairly openly offered on the streets. You will never feel lonely in this city! Thamel has a bit of everything. It boasts of excellent eateries with many different cuisine, a place to hang out for the locals, a lively fun place, sometimes a bit dirty, always very busy. Should you want to be harassed, the place to go! Oddly, despite all its drawbacks, Thamel has become, the major tourist attraction in Kathmandu, mainly for young people. The atmosphere is that of Carnaby Street , London by the end of the 70s they say. Yes, Thamel has something for everyone!But before heading to Thamel, ask yourself if it a place for you. Not everybody’s cup of tea!If you are a brave traveller, it can be fun!
