Its narrow sidewalks, its pot-holed streets jammed with honking cars (crazy traffic though you soon learn how to walk with it - literrally), motorbikes, bicycle carts and tourists offer a much more interesting atmosphere than the wider and more elegant boulevard areas. Enjoy it! Love it! Or leave it soon! U choose!
we love this place. thamel lots of things are there,center city, good food & many lots of diffrent place to dring & hang arround, nice hotels are there, night life excllent,
Great shopping Spot. Its really nice shopping spot to buy anything for souvenir and many hotels, restaurants but traffic in small road.

The Tourist Trap. I stayed here because there were great reviews on a hotel in the area. Even though I loved my hotel stay, I can't say the same about Thamel itself. Thamel is made for tourists - it's essentially the modification of a neighbourhood into a shopping/bar/restaurant area with inflated prices. Some tourists don't mind this, in fact, some love it. Even some locals who can afford spending their nights at the countless bars and music venues love coming here. I would recommend ignoring all the people who try to sell you something while you walk down the street, as they are only interested in turning in a large profit off of clueless tourists. Not all stores try to rip you off though, but don't be shy when it comes to haggling and bargaining. It would be good to have an idea of what the price of an item should be, and you can even ask at your reception desk before going out hunting.However, if you are the sort that would rather stay somewhere with a more local feel, I would recommend you stay away from Thamel. Or, at least, not to spend a significant amount of time in Thamel if you are staying at a hotel there. As I come from a country reliant on tourism, I have seen similar areas in my own country, and recognized it straight away. I didn't let it affect my stay though, and spent most of my days away from Thamel, even though I was staying in a hotel there (which was a great hotel to be honest).
best shooping area!. we shop lost! a bit expensive for tourists but we enjoyed shooping. Shop under Trekkers Home were we have bough carper were really worth it!

Best area to hangout and get food. Very vibrant neighborhood in Kathmandu filled with stores, markets, and restaurants. I spent every night walking through the streets here and absorbing all this area offered. A fascinating country and this neighborhood gives you a great lenses into their culture and people.

Great shopping district. Very busy with chaotic traffic as with all of Kathmandu. Amazing how they manage to avoid constant accidents. Lots of bargains to be had in souvenirs, mandalas, pashminas and many local products. Lovely singing bowl shop. Noisy at night if you're staying in the area, but I think that probably applies to most of the city. Some good places to eat, including the air-conditioned Penguin hotel.

Tourist's place. I like the crowd and color of Thamel. I used to walk for more than two hours every evening when I worked in Kathmandu. It's full of people from many countries. The shops have elegant colors and smells. Lots of restaurants, souvenir shops, low and medium budget hotels. But one need to be careful about the price which is much higher than other places of Kathmandu. And it's not wise to buy antics from Thamel, which are most cases made in Patan area. The massage places are not also authentic in most cases.

Something for Everyone!. Thamel is the official section of Kathmandu that is tourist oriented. It is a maze of narrow streets and alleys offering everything you could ever want. It is becoming a tourist attraction in itself. The shops, tour agencies, massage centers, and restaurants are truly colorful and overwhelming. Compared to the rest of this noisy and crazy city, Thamel is clean and attractive. But all the signs in Thamel obviously give it a cluttered look. Fortunately they're not all in neon, but that would be impossible given the power blackouts. Yes, everyone pestering you for this or that can get annoying. But I guess you have to not let it get to you, and let it go. I loved Thamel. For me, it was the restaurants and the bars. By the way, there are plenty of choices of lodging outside Thamel, you don't HAVE TO stay there. Thamel is an escape. You're on vacation in Nepal, so enjoy yourself. And you can always leave Thamel. Thamel has something for everyone.

Noisy but nice. You'll find lots and lots of shops and places to eat here.Don't be taken in by ''The North Face'' shops selling,yes you guest it, ''Not! North Face'' clothing.Hot Breads is a must try and it's nice to sit in the rooftop bars drinking a cold beer and watching the streets below.Bet you can't walk down the street without being offered Tiger Balm.

Only for souvenirs. This is the heap tourism heaven, full of small hotels and brimming with loudly pubs, pot sellers and seedy guys. It is good to look for souvenirs, but for restaurants and hotels, I surely reccomend another place, like for example Boudha, much more relaxing and calm.

worst experience. I had visited thamel in the month of june 2013, stayed in a hotel that comes under budget hotel. The receptionist charged 2000INRs extra saying that service tax and room service. Frankly speaking do not stay in any hotel. Stay in only registered hotel

Shopping for souvenirs. This is the so called shopping haven for budget travelers. Indeed souvenirs & mountain climbing gears are found here at cheaper rates if you know how to haggle. There are souvenir shops selling local made products such as tea leaves, knitted wear, carpets, bronze figurines, wooden carvings, semi-precious stones / jewellery, Buddhist Thanka Art paintings & khukuris. Many guest houses & motels available plus plenty western & a few Chinese restaurants around. Not far walking distance from Durbar square.

Mixed Experience. This is both an old area and the tourist section of the city. As such it contains a range of hotels many of which are very good as well as excellent restaurants and bars. It is also the souvenir area of the city and the one drawback is the constant pestering by hawkers. It is almost impossible to look and shop without being bugged to buy somethng and it is likely that more tourists are driven off by the relentless selling thus actually causing them to lose business.

The best place after your visits. Full of quality shops , cafes, trekking equipment, travel agents and bakeries with quiche Loraine and ..croissants. Where else you can have all of them in one place?. Good book shops and "beautiful " people . (the descendants of the hippies of the 70's) . Its fun . Enjoy it.

Always active , Always crowed. Thamel, Kathmandu is a active place shops at roads ,sellers shouting to sell their products ,huge number of buyers.i say a 1 hour stay at thamel make our mind very energetic as you find people rushing and shouting . The crowd at Thamel really makes you move fast .

Its just a market with crazy traffic!. Don't expect too much! Its a maze of roads full of shops. And traffic swarming all around.There are some extremely shady looking 'Nachghars' or Dance Bars all around. Avoid hanging around too late. Haggle like crazy, and visit lots of shops before you finalize on something. We picked up something for NPR1500, which the first shop quoted NPR7000.Its a great place to pick up souvenirs, postcards, fridge magnets, pashmina stuff as well as mountaineering gear.

Crowded but interesting old area of Kathmandu. Our hotel was conveniently located in the Thamel area, an old section of Kathmandu full of shops and restaurants catering to tourists but also locals. The sidewalks were very narrow and the pot-holed streets were jammed with honking cars, motorbikes, bicycle carts and tourists but the atmosphere was more interesting than the wider boulevard areas.

Best Shopping in the World!!. Exporters from elsewhere in Nepal come to Thamel to shop, and so should every visitor to Kathmandu. Be sure to haggle a little over the prices - expect to pay about 2/3 (or less) of the original asking price.

Touristy!. Title says all - its very touristy area. You'll find everything from equipment shops to restaurants, good food, but also annoying hawkers. A perfect place if you want to be entertained and need lively environment but stay away if you want peaceful stay. I don't think any hotel in Thamel could be far away from loud noise (at least one bar is at next doors).

Just another asian typical town.. Thamel is colorful and simply a town that we expect in other part of Asia. Colorful handicrafts, tourist oriented seller etc. But the foods are nice. Named Dalbhat is rice, lentil soup and curry in varieties is a local food but i think they are better in other food. So amazing that they have a lot of mexican food rather than western. Foods are notably i loved.

Hustle Bustle. This is one of the busiest cities that I have ever seen in my life. It is so crowded with people AND vehicles that you cannot practically walk without bumping in to people and things! There are so many different types of shops and restaurants. You will never feel lonely in this city! The only problem is that the rickshaws and the taxis would want to know whether you need a ride. Please make sure to check out the little alleys as you walk in the main road because you may find some of the nicest boutiques and restaurants in the little side roads than on the main road. This is the place to do your shopping. If the price seems high, all you have to do is mention the price at which you would like to buy it and they will be happy to give it the price that you quoted. You have such a wide variety of goods in this place that you can buy Nepali Pashmina shawls to European books!
Nepalese Arts and Crafts. Shopping for Nepalese crafts and arts is awesome in Tamel. Prices are really cheap. People are soooo friendly.

Maybe it was great but not for me. So crowded, and everything is so expensive there, no peace except inside the expensive hotels, but yeah Hotels are great so for Travellers that place is the first choice cuz there are no good hotels in Kathmandu like in Thamel

Mishmash. Thamel has a bit of everything, shops rentals hotels restaurants markets...and lots of tourists. Its a must visit on every tourist's list. Infact many stay in thamel coz its relatively cheap and boasts of excellent eateries with many different cuisine. Most of all foreigners meet each other.For the locals, thamel is a place to hang out, to let ur hair down... Thamel is lively, throbbing a fun place but it can be noisy and a bit dirty and foreigners need to be careful not to be cheated.

A Bustling Market. Thamel can be exciting or down right annoying, depending on who visits it. If someone loves noisy, crammed and crowded space with tons of cheap souvenir shopping options, then Thamel is the place to be. On the other hand, if someone prefers peace and quiet and a clean space that is not touristy, then Thamel is not the right place. But what Thamel offers to everyone is many good restaurants, bars and night clubs, even though some pricey than others. Thamel has become, oddly, despite all its drawbacks, the major tourist attraction in Kathmandu. If one does not visit Thamel in Kathmandu, it would be like not visiting Ginza in Tokyo or the Time Square in NYC.

hectic but convenient. Thamel has just about anything you want to buy. If you forgot something for your trek you can buy or rent it here. You want pizza, cake, sushi, Thai, Mexican, Tibetan, Indian, etc, food, you get it here. Handicrafts, jewelry, pashmina, carpets, fresh coffee, internet, maps, thangkas, ANYTHING ..... you will get it in Thamel. It may not be the most authentic and you may not get the best price but it is super convenient. Oh, and you can sleep in Thamel too! Kathmandu Guest House is one of the long-standing guest houses with a range of room types and prices.
Carneby Street 1969 in Kathmandu. Thamel is the touristarea off Kathmandu. The athmosphere is like being in London in 1969 in the hippy time. Every time feels like coming home.

Market place of Nepal. This is the common walk-around, busy, noisy, all-in-one but relatively peaceful place in Kathmandu a foreigner should visit. The best way is hire a cab (pay +500 NRs) drive around o have the "feel" of the place. Then you can choose to walk around. The place is safe. If you want to buy any thing, ask the lowest offer price at least at three different places before deciding to buy at the desired shop.Thamel is an example of how Nepalese traditional city life, buildings, urban landscape and trading practices are done. It is also alike The Old Delhi of India.

U have to see it. Overprised restaurants with poor service. Nice for tea and Kutumba cd. ( great nepali music) but better to buy in indra chowk. Deffinally get your pasmina shawls there. The best shawls are inside the shop , not hanging outside. . For wood art and thanka s go to the shops in patan. Best place to buy and bargin. Dont overweight yourself at the airport. They are very strict and u have to pay. Put heavy stuff in handlugage. For dutch, dont do gargo to the harbours in holland. To pick u things up u have to pay there aswell around 200 euro!!!. Try DHL door to door. Thats a fixed deal. Check how much the weight is allowed. It was 10 kilo but dont forget they had to pack it also. ATM Standerd Chartered bank in Lazimpat. Only place your card will work to get out cash money.

A nice market,but not my cup of tea. I've spent about a week around Thamel waiting for my flight. There are a lot of restaurants, some of them are actually good, and almost all hotels and restaurants offer internet connection.As for the shopping and street atmosphere- they just don't know when to let go. nepali people are very pushy and made me quite uncomfortable to walk around their shops.Another thing is the overpricing on nepali products, I wish I would have bought the souvenirs back in Pokhara when I was there.
Tourist sub. Good restaurants, guest houses, great place for shopping. When you want to go on trekking you find all the gear you need for a very reasonable price

Overpriced. Thamel is the hub of mainly young tourists who visit Nepal. There are many shops, all selling the same stock of trekking goods and clothing and overpriced souvenirs. There are many restaurants and bars, all pretty much of a muchness. However, despite living here we visit every now and again just for the hustle and bustle. You will get better deals for souvenirs away from Thamel but bartering is a must and there are some deals to be had, which are better out of season.

Great Shopping and more. Thamel is a great place for shopping, dining and entertainment, hotels for tourists, and more. I would recommend this area if you wish to find a cheap hotel. A number of internet phone offices allow you to make real cheap calls back home. Must see.
Nice Touristy place. Many restaurants, many bars and pubs, many touristy shops selling souviners, nice buzz, some shady places tough. should go in the evening for a good atmoshphere.

Its a must. Though you are likely to find as many tourists as you are Nepalese, this is an absolute must see. If you have been to Kathmandu, then you have been to Thamel. This is what allows you to chat with fellow travelers and share the "common" experiences.

Good Shopping, Rough Area. Thamel is a huge tourist attraction, but if you have many Nepali friends, they will tell you that many Nepali's avoid that area because of the trafficking atmosphere. There are often raids of local businesses as prostitution and drug use is illegal there as it is in many other areas around the world. We went to Thamel only once to meet friends at a trendy restaurant and we had a good experience. I was expecting it to be seedy after what friends had warned us of, but to us, it was like any other big city tourist area.

Ew. Filthy. Should you want to be harassed, the place to go. Have you heard that there's a festival on today - the day of your arrival? You are so, so lucky. Just give the unofficial guide an unjustifiably large sum of money to find out just how lucky.

great shopping!. Great place to shop for Kashmir throws, shawls, woollen hats, gloves, long socks etc. Great food. Try out OR2K for an awesome meal. The whole of Thamel has a cool vibe - beware, lots of hippies!
A very touristic. A place where the most of tourist visit but very unorganized, Lots of hotel, bar and restaurant, All night running.
Spread your wealth. This is what we do to Nepal, spread your wealth a buy a scarf. Classic tourist centre of every Asian country is everywhere the same. The usual touts, cheap beds and average food.

Shopping. Great shopping although many of the shops have the same goods. Bargaining is the name of the game although I did feel awkward when you know the owners don't earn much money. Watch out for the traffic as the cars and bikes seem to appear from nowhere

Backpackers haven!. Thamel is a great place for tourists. It has good hotels, cafes, shops, restaurants serving all kinds of good food, bakeries, money changers, internet cafes, telephone booths and whatever else tourists need. I have stayed in Thamel 3 or 4 times and I felt its completely safe to walk around the streets late in the evenings. There's no problem. Its a peaceful neighborhood, they dont cheat or trouble the tourists. Its a great place to buy hiking gear and many useful things you may need for your trek. I was here before my treks to Mt. Kailash, Mukthinath, Annapurna and Everest Base camp and found everything I needed. Outdoor gear shops like North Face, Mountain Hardware and Sherpa have some very good choice of gear. I also rented sub-zero sleeping bag and down jacket with the help of my Guide. The variety of outdoor stuff you can get in Thamel is much much better than what you can find in some of the stores in US or Jack Wolfskin in Germany. Thamel - Good stuff and best place to prepare for your trek and also come back from you trek and chill out!

Nightlife. It has one of the best shopping destination for trekking stuff.But slightly expensive stuff need to bargain on it.One should do go for the night life in Thamel. House few good restaurants where u can get authentic Thakali food.

Great little neighborhood in Kathmandu. We stayed in a wonderful B&B (hotel) in this neighborhood for 8 days. We could not get enough of the shops, restaurants, streets and people. We walked everywhere, so we were through each street and passed by each shop every day; thus, we experienced the neighborhood at all times. Given it is tourist central, and given it is a huge hiking destination, there are many shops catering to hiking tourists! Enjoy the people, winding streets, shops and unique interface between the locals and visitors.
many tourists. This is the main tourist area in kathamndu.I was surprised with so many guest house,restaurant & bar here.so many trekking massage centre.Too many people too much crowd!
touristic city Nepal. meeting many travelers, specially from western world. Nice shopping , souvenir shop. even more crowded, it is nice for the look around and meeting new friend.

"Tourist World in Colors". Thamel is fascinating one-stop tourist spot gathering every and each features of a tourist center with wide variations and standards of hotels, restaurants, clubs, Antique Shops, souvenir shops, clothing shops, etc. The Kathmandu International Airport is just 30 minutes away from here (11km). Important places of Kathmandu valley: Swayambunath, Boudhanath, Kathmandu Darbar Square, Bakthapur, Lalithapur, Pasupatinath etc, are scattered around Thamel.It is a place where all types of people, races, business get together...!There is no festival of Nepal, that void the keen watch of tourist eyes...! THAMEL IS ALL COLORFUL...!!! (I've been visiting and staying in Thamel for the last 4 years...)

Fun. Thamel is a fun and interesting place. A huge variety of shops and the people are nice. Got really tired of the beggars and the street sellers who walk right up into your face trying to get you to buy something.

Fun area!. Really fun area! Great for an evening - especially if the weather is good - lots of casual fun places to hang out at - open air - with decent food and a nice selection of beer. All open air places allow smoking too if that's something you want to watch out for. Dolce Vita was great!
Shopping great. Lots of little shops with good prices after bargaining. We were there in off season, so prices probably better-too much to see, too little time.
Crazy Fun Place. It's a thrill to walk through this tourist area, crazy drivers, street vendors trying to sell stringed instruments and khukuri knives. You have to experience it.

Touristy, but fun!. Everything from Kuhkri knives to fine Yak scarfs. Singing bowls and Himalaya Honey, which comes complete with warnings for use. Visit, have fun and don't be afraid to spend a little money on the locals. How long will it be until you return?

Shopping!. Don't get shocked by the noise and traffic in the little town, this is a place you either love or hate it. We are one of those that love this touristy place, very resourceful place for trekking gear shopping, they are cheap but definitely can last you a few trekking trip. Before putting down your purchase, bargain! Give it try yourself to see if you like them.

Hectic. Thamel is the main place for western visitors to visit. It's barmy and it's easy to get lost in, but it's safe (or appears to be) but would suggest getting a taxi if in doubt. I would suggest checking out as many of the streets and shops as you can before buying anything as prices vary hugely. One trick is to go into a shop and discover the lowest price they'll go to and then go to a street seller and start negotiating down from there. You'll usually find that you'll get it for paractically nothing compared with the original price. For instance - starting at 3,500 rupees with a street seller, often ends up at 70 rupees. . . just do it with a smile.

souvenir heaven. A district full of tourists, traffic and pollution. This is a place where you can buy anything and everything. You should know that most of the products here are most likely mass produced and fake. However there are still some nice and worthwhile souvenirs you can bring home. Just make sure to shop around and bargain so you don’t get rip off too badly. Although after walking around for a couple of hours, all the shops and products were starting to look the same. Be very careful when you are walking around as motorcycles and cars will zoom by you with centimeters to spare. There are also tons of restaurant and trekking companies in this area.

Thamel traffic. Loved Thamel, the traffic is crazy when you first get here but you soon learn how to walk with it. There is pollution but you need to expect that. People do beg but only because they have to so give up some money to those who really need it, we have more than we will ever need.

Best Place to Spend Time in Kathmandu. Thamel is always bustling with activities. Good Hotels, guest Houses, restaurants, Shopkeepers smiling but you have to negotiate prices with them.Nice food at not so good price though.quite a experience to walk through lanes of Thamel.

Busy & Bustling. Thamel is a busy shopping area with a lot of shops selling everything that you would need. Bargaining at these shops is the normal way to purchase in this market & can be quite stressful. In case you are interested in Jewels then you should definitely visit a shop called "Monte Carlo" they have the best selection.
Tourist bargains. Bazaar atmosphere. Reeked of 'being touristy'. Good bargains though. Purchased pashmina. Had supper in a lovely bar.

Must-go place. A must-go place. You should bargain when you do shopping. There are variety kinds of souvenir. You can enjoy different food or bars here. Also, there are many hostel here, living in here is a remarkable experience.

crazy. A good place to get more traditional Nepali goods as souvenirs. Be aware though that since it is geared towards tourists, they will try to rip you off (my host family here told me a good rule of thumb for bargaining is to go for half of what they initially offer. But that doesn't always apply; it depends on the store you go to. There is a money exchange place here as well.

Tight Quarters. Thamel was a very interesting district of Kathmandu. The streets were narrow and completely lined with shops and vendors. Traffic is tight and frenzied, so be careful as you walk the streets. Vendors are ready to make a deal!

Shoppers paradise. Perfect place for shopping, getting lost and bargaining. Better you take cash in Rupees with you, they add 5% service fee when you use a card. Don't pay the first price they offer you, offer half of that then work your way up, but be friendly.

manic. Tourist hub push bikes motor bikes cars and constant horns narrow streets people trying to sell you any thing. Lots of bargains souvenirs bars restaurants. incense burning Funky Buddha worth a visit for loud entertainment Pilgrims for peace and quiet. Amazing telegraph poles lots of wires worth a photo.

Stayed in thamel. Good place for foreigners. As lots of market selling traditional things. Lots of food options. You need to bargain here before you buy clothes. For Indians there are few options for traditional indian cuisines like ramas kitchen.

too congested with traffic. the traffic ruins the experience. thamel is full of shopping, cafes etc. but as the motorbikes rip by beeping endlessly it really detracts from the expereince. i would suggest to the nepali authorities to make parts of thamel pedestrian ONLY for a few hours each afternoon to encourage shopping and a relaxed atmosphere for tourists.
Shoppers' Paradise. Thamel is the place to get anything and everything but the only problem is you are expected to bargain, bargain, bargain!!!!

Trekking gear heaven!. If you are going trekking or even just want to stock up on waterproofs, this is the place. Really good bargains and it's definitely not worth traipsing it all from home. Thamel has lots of cafes and rooftop places just to watch from. It is traveller central, but that can be amusing...

For the shopper. Purely for the shopper who demands coffee, pizza and hot water on demand.
Not really Nepal.
So many shops selling the same items.
Busy crowded streets with many obstacles

good hotel. Awesome budget hotel in KathmanduIf you need a really great hotel with a modest price, this one is for you. The rooms are clean and the beds are very comfortable! The prices are very reasonable and huge portions! The service is fantastic. They take care of anything you might need or want and even anticipate things you might not think of. The best thing is the location. We first thought upon our arrival that it seemed odd to drive down a back alley to the hotel, but we quickly discovered that it was perfect as it provides much needed privacy and quiet away from the main roads. The hotel is located few blocks from the main Thamel road. I highly recommend this hotel for those wanting comfort and a great location but travel on a budget.

Fun!. I thought Thamel was great fun. Sure there are hagglers and sellers, within seconds of stepping onto the street, but they are good natured and accept no (eventually) happily. There is a wonderful blend of hippy, traveller and newbie, which adds to the intoxicating mix of everything. I recommend a visit to this area of Kathmandu- it may not be authentic, but it's a lot of fun!
Ideal Shopping destination. Thamel was a classic point to see nepal mix with the rest of the world. Wonderful shopping points around this location.

Not my cup of tea. If you are in to the full blown tourist bit meaning lots of shpos, people, noise and of course the traffic then Thamel is probably the place to go. personally I couldn't wait to get out pf the plcae. Mind you there are some reasonably good eateries there and stacks of hotels for you to choose from. Otherwise a one day only visit.
Crowded. So noisy and crowded in the evening.But I guess that's the reason people go to Thamel.If you want to buy things there, plz learn some cut-price tricks which will save you a bunch of money.
Medieval Streets. tiny streets full of shops full of nepali who like to bargain. watch out for the traffic.take lots of small rupees.
Great shopping. walk down the busy streets avoiding the cars and the bikes and enjoy the shopping. A good haggle about prices is always fun. So much to see and do and in a very friendly and safe way.

ok, lots of shopping. souveneirs and knock offs of all kinds, lots of stalls and good deals. Make sure you bargain shopkeepers down. They will give you ridiculous first prices on stuff. Some nice cafes and restaurants, many with wifi.beware shady characters... lots of close talkers, follow-behinders, and drug offers

Way Too Touristy. I no longer stay in Thamel when in the KTM Valley. I much prefer Boudhanath. Icompare Thamel to Bangkok's Khao San Road, except in Bangkok the scene at least includes Thais among those crusing around, buying overpriced beers and dopey t-shirts. In Thamel, the only Nepalis around are catering to the tourists, not being part of the scene.

Never ending shops. The shopping lanes go on & on. Really nice to see a variety of things on sale from the yak bone key chains & lockets to intricate Thanka paintings. Some very exclusive things like traditional musical instruments, khukhris, stone carvings, chunky necklaces, nice woollens, statues..... It was a pleasure to just see some of the things though we were not going to buy them. But beware lots of bargaining.....start from one third the price & usually got it for half the price originally quoted. :)
THE shopping site. Great shopping site but vendors won't let you haggle or bargain. Found more reasonable shops near my hotel.

This is where the hippies went, long time passing.. Gear toward the young and the hippies, fun, fast busy dirty. Knock offs and great gear sold side by side,great place to buy any last minister items before a trek or a climb. Cheap hotels and expense ones all lose power regularly. Lots of good restaurants, I recommend OR2K on Mandala street.

Touristy but we liked it. Narrow street, cramped shops and lots of people - but hey, they all are charm of Thamel. In fact, the very characteristics of the place. Good restaurants and book shops are at every step. Got bothered by street vendors though but we expected it to happen.

Home of Tourism in KTM. Thamel has everything that a tourist in Kathmandu can want (except a quiet night's sleep). There are hundreds of souvenir shops where you can buy affordable knick-knacks. Restaurants of all styles and quality. Budget and upper-class hotels. Nichtclubs and quirky cocktails for when you feel like getting your drink on. Tour and trekking outlets for all your transportation and hiking needs. Pharmacies to fix your belly problems. Shops to exchange your foreign currency. ATMs galore. Finally and most importanly, plenty of pharmaceutical dealers to keep you buzzed for your whole trip in Nepal. Thamel has narrow streets and cars that zip by you. Vendors constantly spruiking their nebulous merchandise. Shady characters trying to make shady deals. Street children begging you for rupees. It is a crazy, hectic place. However, if you want to escape the madness, you can just go chill out in the Garden of Dream, which is also inside Thamel.Thamel is a wonderful place to visit. It is the exact opposite of what you experience in a Western country, which is one of the main reasons why we travel to countries like Nepal in the first place. Check out one of the local dohori bars and you'll see what I mean. It is a noisy, insane mess of alleyways and shopkeepers, but it is your mess. Thamel is brilliant. Just don't expect a quiet night's sleep.

Nice shopping area. Lots of shops with different stuff. If you negociate well you can buy nice things there for little money. The whealing and dealing is nice to watch. And if the salesmen get angry your price is to low.
what an interesting place. It is a must see in Kathmandu...you can easily interact with people and find many souvenirs...I liked it!

Da Place. A handy spot to book a trek, eat lots of kinds of western food, and be surrounded by tourists from around the world. A good place to visit but don't stay too long-get out and visit the many sights and sounds of the greater Kathmandu valley.
shopping. Crazy shopping, crazy deal, without going to thamel, you haven't been to kathmandu. Highly recommendate!
Absolutely buzzing. It's loud, busy and buzzing. Some good shopping to be had but it's not the very best that Kathmandu has to offer.

Chaotic, crowded & mad!. Thamel is the tourist centre of Kathmandu and all life is here in its narrow, crowded chaos. If you don't mind crowds, motor scooters coming at you from all angles coupled with the constant gentle badgering from shop owners there are plenty of shops, bars and restaurants packed into the area. Be prepared to haggle - or to be ripped off. Never accept the first price. But the atmosphere, even after dark, is non threatening.
Totally Tourist Residential Area.. There is a lot of budget Hotel for F.I.T. Tourist.many many handicraft good's are available on the street no pro blame for x-change Money every where ATM machines.
chilling spot. shopping, great food, music... u name it they have it... also a large number of money changers are available here so you can check and get the best rate.... :)

Thamel- tourist hub of Kathmandu. Thamel was our anchor point during a month of trekking in Nepal, April 2013. To say that it is busy and interesting is to understate it. Its narrow streets are a hive of activity with pedestrians, cars, small trucks and motor bikes all sharing the roadways. It's full of shops for hiking gear, t-shirts (printed) and embroidered; the latter will embroider whatever you want on a t-shirt for less than a printed t-shirt in most other tourist locations. You have to bargain for most things, and the shop keepers are generally good humoured about it. There are restaurants serving every kind of food you can imagine, ranging from local Nepali & Newari to Mexican and Japanese. Often one restaurant will serve multiple kinds of food, for example chow mein and pizza. Generally speaking the food is very good to excellent.Changing money was easy because there are exchange shops everywhere with their rates outside. They do not charge an extra commission, so you get the same rate whether you change $100 or $10.We felt safe walking in Thamel in daylight as well as in the evening. I didn't hear of any tourist that had their pockets picked or backpacks entered during the several days that we stayed there.

A busy street full of stories.. The junction of tourists, thamel is known for its presence of the fusion of the tourists and the locals. The place that is always happening. This place is focused on tourists and there are different things like crafts, arts, foods, culture and events available there.

All the fun of the fair!. Great place to wander around in! You have to haggle a bit or the traders try their luck though. Mind you people are not well off, so don't overdo the haggling.Everything Nepal has to offer in souvenirs is here and I noticed that a lot of the travellers were ditching their western attire for the easy care and easy wear clothing available. Wise move in that heat.If you can, spend some time just wandering before choosing your presents. I think that this is also a good last stop before getting to the airport. That way , you don't have to carry souvenirs far.

Full of Life all day and late night. It's a place where you will see travelers from all over the world. You will find exotic food of all varieties. You have to bargain a lot if you want to buy some souvenirs. YOu can find some good massage places also now in Thamel, done by trained people.

Interesting to see. So different, a real cultural experience, fun to see for a short amount of time, crazy & chaotic, lots of shops & restaurants, bring earplugs for walking in the streets since horns are blowing constantly right beside you & your ears go numb, much more enjoyable with earplugs

The HUB of Kathmandu. This place is the central hub of Kathmandu and heaving with tourists, shops, markets, massage places, restaurants, bars, supermarkets, money changers, internet cafes, food stores chemists, bookstores, jewellery and most of all trekking gear stores....everything a tourist could want. Just love the atmosphere.....just got to go wandering and wandering, ducking in and out of alley ways and stores. Remember...gotta bargain, it is expected.

Great place to watch people. The sights alone are worth the visit to the heart of Kathmandu's tourist center. Retro Hippy, free attitudes. Just be careful of the jewelry stores as what they offer isn't always what it really is. Only in the jewelry stores have I had bad experiences. The rest of Thamel is great. Check out the roof top gardens.

Bargain is a must!. This is a place where you may get all the trekking accessories, cashmere shawl and handcrafted decorated home items but bargain is a must!! The road seems like endless under construction with all the dust covering your face and cloths. Remember to wear a mask and bring torch light if you walk till late at night. There are a bars, pubs and music which for those who like to hangout before, during and after hours.

If you enjoy to bargain..... If you enjoy the bargain, here is the good place to get your trekking accessories and cashmere, dress & etc...you surely get a good price, pls reduce the price from 50% onwards....:)

From a backpacker heaven to endless souvenir & knock off outdoor gear stores. Gone are the days when Thamel was party central for backpackers & returning treckers - today it shuts down at 10 pm & is wall to wall souvenir shops and dozens of outdoor gear shops selling essentially the same Chinese made North Face, Mamut & Arcteryx low quality knock offs.And pollution levels are way high because of all the cars & taxis that clog the narrow streets & endanger both pedestrians & the poor cycle rickshaw drivers.Change is probably inevitable & it isn't all bad because today there are better restaurants & hotels - but seeing exactly the same souvenirs, fake antiques & badly made gear in dozens & dozens of stores really reminds you this isn't the Thamel of old..
Desapointing. Too much shops, presently vey polluted with ongoing renovation works, lots of dust, avoid, some nice places include restaurants with gardens
Great laugh. Not everyone's cup of tea but very lively, noisy and full of shops selling outdoor gear that may or may not prove to be a bargain - still waiting to see how long all the clothing lasts!
A home away from home. Good shops / good restaurants / good cafes / good departmental stores / good bars / a lovely atmosphere ... what not ...

Shopping. Love the shopping,the markets.Be prepared to haggle. Check your prices but to be honest even if you find it cheaper you probably have still got a bargain. Enjoy the novelty of the products. Great range and variety of cafes and restaurants. We enjoyed the roof top approach with views of the streets.Fun,busy and a bit hectic but all part of the atmostphere

The tourist Mecca. Thamel is where all the tourists gather. The narrow and dusty streets can get a bit much after a few days however for shopping and places to eat it is the place to be. Every second shop is a knockoff gear and equipment store. Some great souvenirs can be found. At night it gets a little interesting.

Funky, busy area right in the middle of Kathmandu. The touristy district of Kathmandu, you will find Thamel full of hotels, hostels, guesthouses, restaurants and shops.If you are looking for a comfortable place to stay in when you come into Kathmandu, I recommend this place. There are some incredible restaurants I went to. Unfortunately I do not remember the names; one seating us barefeet on the cushioned ground amongst intricate murals with an amazing vegetarian menu, the other one with live Nepalese music and the best damn momos I ever tasted ;)Plenty of shops to pick up cheap hiking gear, odd trinkets, as well as a variety of places to stay. Easy to get a taxi to the nearby located attractions i.e the three Durbar Squares, Pashupatinath, Swayambhunath and more.

Kathmandu - Thamel - Loved it here. For anyone who likes to get involved in a city then Thamel and its bustling streets are a must. There's all sorts of shops, bars, restaurants and cafes to keep everyone interested. Street after street of activity with good food, relatively cheap beer and bartering opportunities a plenty. My wife's favourite place on our recent trip. We were staying in the heart of Thamel so experienced both day and night and it was great. The only issue I had was the vehicles pushing through the narrow streets. For such a compact area you would have thought they'd make it pedestrian only, but who am I to say. Just watch out for some crazy car drivers and in particular the motor bikes as they speed through areas which are crowded. I didn't see anyone run over so maybe it just needs getting used to. I enjoyed this so much just walking around looking at the place that I didn't even mind my wife shopping. That's how good and interesting this place is.

chtf. Thamel is a mecca for trekkers and tourists. Good food can be had at the many restaurants however what spoils the place is the constant sounding of car and bike horns as you walk along the narrow streets. Maybe they could make it rickshaws only within the centre of Thamel.

Great for shopping and local nightlife. Thamel is the place to be for shopping in Khatmandu. The place has a variety of tourists shops selling local items. One can also find a lot of cafe's and restaurant's to relax in.

Very good shopping area. It takes some time to get used to area but when done you can find a lot of good things for a good price, both originals as well as fakes, as usual. Clothes, cashmere wool things, a lot of trekking equipment, etc. Be prepared to negotiate; up to 30-40% reduction can be possible, sometimes even more. Have fun.

Crazy. I'd fortunately had some experience of the type of traffic problems I experienced in this area. Horns appear to replace road rules, indicators and at times brakes. Having said that, surprisingly, there was a noticeable lack of any evidence of road rage. A lovely, vibrant place to browse all the lovely shops, if a tad dusty and polluted. The streets appear safe both during the day and in the evening. I felt Durbar Square was possibly a little overpriced and possibly preferred the one in Patan.

Crazy, noisy, busy Thamel.... Thamel is the main tourist area of Kathmandu and as such it is full of shops, restaurants, trekking agencies, hotels and guesthouses along the extremely busy narrow streets but a really interesting place even though the air is very smokey there like in the whole town...

A place not for the faint hearted. Thamel is great for souvenirs and dining in Kathmandu but if you wan't the real bargains you'll have to walk a bit further and escape the large tourist crowds.You need to keep your wits about you, as it's both easy to be ripped off while buying things and hit by oncoming motorbikes.The air is very smokey like the rest of Kathmandu but you quickly get used to it.A must for any tourist visiting Kathmandu.

Busy and dusty, but fun.. As you drive into Thamel you will wonder if roads ate really roads or merely gaps of bumpy dirt between buildings. You will also wish you owned the face mask distribution business since many people are sporting them as commonly as a fashion accessory. Thamel is busy, crowded, full of vendors looking for your business, and it is a great place to wander aimlessly, coming across different market areas and small temples. You will get dirty and dusty, andyour ears will be ringing from the sounds, but it is addictive as our current third time visit will prove!

Thamel is deteriorating. You kind of have to stay in Thamel if you want the convenience of cheap shopping, good cafes and the company of funky travelers. But over the years, the traffic and pollution has become nightmarish and you risk life and limb every time you walk the narrow streets, with cars and bikes brushing against you. Noise levels have also increased and because of the jam-packed nature of the place, the incredibly loud reggae band playing 10 nightclubs away may as well be in the room with you. Met a few people who stay elsewhere these days.

Shop till you drop. Bring more money, there are so many things you can buy, and they are cheap. The only thing we do not like is to bargain the price. Once the local business peoples see the tourist, they will give you the price sky high, try knock down the price less then 60% or more, but you will have to spent a little bit of time just to play the game. sometime it's tiring. Foods is good, must try their "Mo Mo".

Best shopping market of kathmandu. I visited twice this place in my 2 day stay in kathmandu..its true that this market is really very addictive..everyone can find the things of their taste..very noisy, traffic and congestion all the time..surrounded by hotels, B&B, restaurants.. Very interesting and must visit.
polluted and busy but fun. nice for a stroll, a banter and a bargain. we ate at Fire and ice which was good. Watch your kids if you have them as no where safe for them to walk really.
best place to stay. This is a touristic neighborhood with all amenities you need. It is also easy to get around. There are good shops, restaurants and accommodation.
Fanstatic shopping. It is nice and quiet during off peak season, and you can get better bargain! Plenty of restaurant and bars as well.

Chaos chaos wonderful chaos. Narrow streets cramped with trekking gear, tourist shops, travel agents, restaurants, fast cars and motorcycles, dishevelled tourists, vendors selling tiger balm...the mixture and chaos is extreme that it becomes very interesting. Seeing begging lepers make it quite sad though.

Somewhat pricey. You can get a pretty cheap place to stay if you're not fussy and it's convenient to be close to all the shops and other tourists/party scene but I wouldn't eat here. The food is extremely overpriced - far better to wander out of Thamel for cheap eats.Still it's an area to be experienced. Be prepared to barter for souvenirs!

Don't miss the music!. There are many music stores around Thamel, apart from the numerous silk scarf, pashmina shawl, carpet and antique stores.
I picked up some good Tibetan and Nepalese music from there.
They also have movies (and full seasons of various serials) from around the world, but make sure you buy the original stuff.
I love the food. I love dining in Thamel as it houses the best places to dine and Fire and Ice is here and a lot of bars and pubs are at hits place!

Disgusting part of the city. It's worth seeing as a tourist attraction, but this is a genuinely yucky part of Kathmandu. There are massage parlours (brothels) on the main avenues, and in the "red light district," hotels cost USD$6-10 and the shops are overpriced and often haggled down to 1/10 the sticker price of just about anything from wool hats and rugs to hashish. Fire and Ice is a decent place to eat a pizza by candlelight (power goes on and off unpredictably throughout the day), but other than this landmark restaurant, Thamel is not worth visiting.
An experience. This IS Kathmandu. Shopping and more shopping. Great place to sharpen one's bargaining skills. Beware the jewelry presented as genuine stones when many are glass beads.
very busy and colorful. if you want to get good bargain on shopping, this is the spot. very crowded and good place to eat out also.
for budget tourists. Budget area but be careful about snatchers. Won't suggest taking night walk in the area. Plenty of curios shops may get a good purchase if you bargain hard.

Part of the city for tourists. Fun, busy with lots of very good restaurants. Trekking shops galore some good but lots of rip off gear that is poor quality when you get to test it. Do not buy essential gear like ruck sacks, boots etc. they will probably fail when put to any test.

Nothing great if u are an Indian. Most of the things are extremely overpriced. The market does not offer any thing unique. Most of the thing are imported from India only and nothing unique. The market is messy, polluted and noisy

Tourist Area. Thamel is a nice area to stay. There are some nice restaurants around there. Note that most hotels in Nepal are over rated. A four star hotel is equivalent to a two star. In general you don't get value for money on hotels but the people are very helpful.
Great bargains. Don't buy you hiking/hiking gear anywhere else. Excellent prices in Thamel. Just remember to bargain and check out the quality of the products.
Smog, hassle and noise. Really bad place to go, worst Asian town iv been to as its more like a messy warzone that causes a migraine

Touristy place and expensive. I wouldn't recommend buying from here as things are really expensive. You get a lot of souvenirs of local culture here but be careful to check out a few stores at other places to decide whether its worth buying. You can hire bikes here.

Shops and Nightlife. This is basically the part of town with an abundance of cheap tourist shops, a mix of good and terrible restaurants, and ok night life. The best use of Thamel is getting gear before you go trekking and getting a few other gifts. There is also a nice local market worth going to. If you are in Kathmandu, likely an area you should spend at least an hour in to have seen (even if just to eat).

A self contained haven. Thamel is self contained. It has hotels, cafes, travel agencies, minimarts, shops that sell trekking stuff, tea, t-shirts...etc.Prices from what I gathered is also cheaper than in Pokhara.

Good if you need last minute gear. This area has a lot of shops for trekking gear and souvenirs, and a lot of tour companies. I hate haggling, but be prepared to do it if you are going to be in Thamel. Definitely get a map of the neighborhood, especially if you are looking for a specific company or hotel. Our guide also told us there are different qualities of gear, so even if you are buying a brand you know, it may not be the same quality as you'd get a home.

Touristic but really ice. When you arrive to thamel you feel you are a tourist and you love everything you see at the shops, and the places to eat, good choice for staying you can visit durbar square and swayambunath waklking

worth about fifteen minutes, but you have to go. Thamel is a seemingly endless labyrinth of commerce offering cheap hostels, abundant alcohol, illegal drugs, 'human services,' and of course, souvenirs ranging from the cheap and crappy (95%) to the unique and interesting. If it's for sale in Nepal, it can be found in Thamel - probably for less. It's where most trekkers and backpackers stay, and as such has become an institution unto itself, offering food, entertainment, even clothing uniquely suited to this infamously miserly crowd and not on offer anywhere else in Nepal (except in Pokhara, where the cheap trekkers and backpackers like to hang out to get away from Thamel). After a year in Nepal we managed to locate some truly unique shops where we could get a custom-made gong stand, for instance, or antique wood printing blocks. We also found that most t-shirt shops will custom make something for you at a very reasonable price. We even located a really fun rock-climbing wall suitable for children and adults and totally safe (it's next to the Belgian consulate). But mostly Thamel is shops selling the same stuff. After fifteen minutes you've seen about all you're going to see - like the backgrounds in Hanna-Barbera cartoons, it's just the same thing over and over and over. Don't waste your time in Thamel continuing to look for the elusive "perfect" souvenir. If you haven't seen it in the first fifteen minutes, you're not going to see it. A better option would be to go to Pulchowk and check out Mahaguthi, Dukuthi, and the other fair trade shops. Their stuff is much higher quality, truly unique, and, most importantly, it meets fair trade standards. While you will find a stunning array of foreigners in all manner of strange dress seeking pseudo-enlightenment (or cheap hash and beer) and cheap souvenirs, most people in Thamel are simply there, drawn by the spectacle of the foreigners in all manner of strange dress seeking pseudo-enlightenment and cheap souvenirs. It is a maddening, entertaining, pulsating place to be sure.
Trekking shopping. For all of your trekking gear (although fakes they will get you through your trek). LOts of souveneirs to bring back and some good eating places.
A place like nowhere else. This is the low price shopping centre of Kathmandu.Can get almost anything there although some (all?) may not be legit.Best tip ... Haggle with a smile, it's good fun

OK for a quick stop-over. Thamel is the main tourist area of Kathmandu, and as such it is full of souvenir shops, travel agents, bars, hotels and restaurants. There is plenty of good food of all types to be had, plus really good coffee, however, be wary of some of the bars especially the 'Dance' bars where you could be slugged a huge amount for drinks, especially if you buy the resident ladies a drink or too. The cost of souvenirs and clothing is also at least twice the price that you will pay outside of the tourist areas, so be ready to bargain hard (start at least 60% below the first asking price). Every time I go to Nepal I can't wait to get out of Kathmandu and up into the mountains, which is what Nepal is really all about. The mountain people are also much friendlier and easy going than the city dwellers.

Great atmposphere. You cannot visit Kathmandu without visiting the bustling bazaars of Thamel. There is lots of good accommodation and lots of places to eat and drink, including a number of Irish pubs
Best for tourist. Thamel is one of the best destination for tourist sport such a good place for food, drink and nigh life...

Shoppers heaven!. Loved Thamel streets and all its neat souvenirs and crafts. Lots to see and if you've had enough of touts trying to sell you tours etc, wander a little further out into the local area an see the way the locals live..A must see place for tourists who like a bit of quirky-ness!

Laberinth of temples between the crowd. Great city, with lots to see and do. Plenty of temples to discover in this labyrinth city. There is lovely restrants and clubs. If you need to do some shopping, there is lots, make sure you bargain, other cities have cheaper things depending on what are you looking for (metal decorations were cheaper in Pokhara). Most of the outdoors items are fake but not for that reason are all bad. For those who care about animal protection, if you need warm cloth, don't buy down jackets as the plucking of feathers is done in the most cruel fashion. To rent perhaps is a better idea, then to buy them. In my opinion Thamel is a place to see but not to stay for long as is noisy and crazy, so i am incline to any other place in Nepal to be closer to the beauty and quietness of nature.

Bloody hell :). Crowded, dusty, noicy.....hectical place I would better avoid. As Kathmandu as such, in fact. But acceptable for the few days one has to spend there before/after trekking in mountains.

For everyone. Thamel, is a busy, noisy crowded place, difficult to get around, shopping can be a headache, a lot of shops were the same, so bargain hard, quality very poor with something's, shopping cheaper in Pokhara and Patan.
Restaurants were good, lots of choices, overall great

Must see. Dirty, plenty of pickpockets and extremely busy BUT a really interesting place. This is the place to go for tourists and tourist shopping, the place to buy your rucsack badge for Nepal trekking.

place for tourist. hamel s the best place to stay,every thing is available there,hotel are good.food is good,night life so well,but...but...but.early in the morning news paper sealer baking so loudly..there is 2 man..little..one with bicycle..& one little man..crazy they are.they dot knew about people sleeping...?they are like crying...big voice...people cant sleep well co of them, if thamel want more tourist...thamel they should control them,if not coz of two man thamel ganna be crazy.

The pulse of Kathmandu. Somewhere it is always active. Every morning begins with the Om Mani Padme Hume chant coming out of many stores. Yet you can stop and talk to anyone, whether you buy something or not. Namaste, I see the divine in you, begins each conversation. From there it may lead to talking about the goods they sell, their family, a great excursion. Even a man selling necklaces on the street checked in with us every day to make sure our trip was going well, and we had all the information we needed.
Bargain. Trekking gear shopping here is simply amazing, lots varieties, it's cheap and it last! I bought my knapsack from there and it is still in one piece after my trekking trip.

Crazy chaotic Thamel. What a culture shock. No road rules, no roads, death defying taxi rides...and yet no one gets hurt. Restaurants galore to suit all tastes and budgets, lots of shopping, just watch the holes in the road and on the 'footpath' that will see you disappear completely. Worth a visit.

good place for shopping. The thamel is crowed, the streets are small and all the cars and rikshaws are there, many people come around to ask to buy some things every time. many shops for the trekking, gears and gifts for the family and friends...

Very hectic yet interesting. Nice to walk around for buying some souvenirs, and also lots of nice restaurants around. Many tourists. As minus - the place is very noisy, you are followed by some people who want to sell something to you. Even if you walk with a boyfriend. It's hard to find a good taxi, tey are small and dirty, so we had to rent a car from hotels we stayed in, both times.

Hustling And Bustling Shopping Streets. Thamel has multiple lanes with scores of stores, hotels and restaurants. Visit a couple of stores and bargain before buying anything to get a fair deal. Nepali rupees, Indian rupees, Euros and RMD are generally accepted by all stores. You can also get the local currency from the local Money changers. Visit this place in groups and carry a flash light in the night. Neglect any distraction caused by passerby. It is a common thing to see some nosey/pushy guys forcing tourists to visit their stores.Please avoid this place after 9:30 PM as these streets turn into an adult entertainment location with location for Pole dancing/Bar dancing all sorts of illegal activities. Generally a lot of youngsters lure tourists to visit these places and fleece them/mug, them with their valuables and cause physical injury. This street is prone to frequent power outages.

Worth a day, but not much more. I stayed in Thamel for 4 nights during a work trip and was pretty underwhelmed. In fact, if you're in Kathmandu (especially on business) I'd recommend you stay elsewhere, because getting in and out of Thamel is an annoyance, as is the air pollution, noise pollutio, pushy touts and hippy foreigners wearing clothes and hair and attitudes they'll seriously regret within a year or two. For travellers who have stayed in touristy places before (think Pai or Chiang Mai, Thailand; Dali, China; and plenty of others), there's little here of interest. And the men selling girls and gunja are a bit more creapy than in most places (at least in Dali it's the cute old bai women doing the selling, and they're completely harmless). I say - buy your pashminas, have a beer, then get out of Thamel and Kathmandu altogether and head for the hills.

Dark and a little scary at night time.. We were there in the evening, and there was a power cut. It felt very dark and a little scary at times. Didn't like the attitudes of some "pushy" guys trying to get us to their stalls, or trying to strike conversation.

The tourist mecca of Kathmandu. If you want to shop and hang out with trekkers and hippies, Thamel is the place. In recent years it has lost a lot of its charm, and is overrun with shops, coffee shops, restaurants and bars. A happening place though, if you're young. Usually quite crowded, but so is most of Kathmandu.
It's a makeshift town. Created to cater to tourists, this part of Kathmandu is a must see. Full of local craft retailers, restaurants, bars and night clubs, it really is an experience.
Crowded, not so clean. The title says it all. We decided to take a hotel out of Thamel and I was happy we did that. Shopping can be fun there but otherwise not much to offer.
Nice Place to hangout at Night. All the good restaurants are located here, KFC, Pizza Hut and the ice cream parlour. You will love this location.
Very Hungry people. People come chasing you just to buy their materials. Too much tough to walk through the road without being tortured.

Nice place to roam around. This place is known as the shopping place for tourists where you get to find lots of different souvenirs and also other stuffs. Remember to bargain a lot while buying stuffs from Thamel.

Crowded and not so clean. The heading says it all, I was glad I had chosen to stay in the vicinity of Bodhanath instead. In Thamel the enviroment is quite polluted by noise and garbage. Some good bookshop and restaurant there, that is all.

A trip back in time. This aprt of Old Kathmandu is positively medieval - a cacophony of sounds and smells. It's all very good natured though and the Nepali people are some of the most chilled out and friendly people anywhere.The feeling is slightly run down and definitely crowded, the surprising thing to find are the dozens of outdoor adventure stores, catering to the enormous trekking market. Don't bother to bring anything from home as it is far cheaper and just as good quality in Kathmandu.Durbar Square is further down and a great place to people watch. Thamel is probably the best neighbourhood to be based as a tourist.

This is Kathmandu. This is a shopping district. Lots of shops, restaurants, etc. Even if you're not doing any shopping, you should come here. See the people, the busy traffic, the dusty roads, the loud and busy streets. This place is chaotic! But amongst all that, if you look hard enough, you'll find one or two very nice shops that sell very high quality 'hand made in Nepal' pashminas. Or perhaps a very fine restaurant with wonderful local cuisine. Or if you fancy, T-shirts to bring back as souvenirs. But bargain you must to get good price. That's where the fun is.

Potboiler of Nepal - Action Place Undefined !!. Visit to Thamel is the Most Imp Part of yr Itinerary to Nepal - all Treks - Mountain Climbs - Everest Base Camp or Everest itself starts at Thamel - Food - Artifacts - Gifts - Camping Equipment - u name it its available here - Old Music
Heart of the city. An amazing place where you can just keep walking. You get cuisines from all around the world and also a lot to shop. Once again don't forget to bargain.

You have to see this. It is dusty, crowded, and you have to share the streets with cars; but this is the real Kathmandu as far as I am concerned. Find the Pilgrim Bookstore. It is one of the best places to shop for anything (not just books).

Loud, noisy, fast moving and wonderful!. Over the last 6 years Thamel has got a lot busier with motorbikes, rickshaws and cars going through far too fast. There are the usual constant honks of horns to get you out of the way and after a while you just want to escape from the thoroughfare of shops into one of the many cafes. It is an amazing place that shouldn't be missed but do be aware of your own tolerance level for the bustle. It is also much dustier now and I came ack with a full blown cold that grew out of a sore throat from the dust. Lots of people are wearing masks and I wish I had.Prices in the shops and stalls are very good but unless it is a fixed price place see if you can negotiate around 1/3 off the price. Great reversible fleeces for NRs 900 and singing bowls from NRs 500 for the smallest ones.
The best area to stay in Kathmandu. This is the right neighbourhood to stay at while in Kathmandu. Full of shops, tour agencies, pubs and the main attractions in the city.

The real Nepal. Thamel - it's the real Nepal ... for tourists, of course:) If you want to feel the real Nepal, you must stay only in Thamel. Some people choose Lazimpat, because you can find 5* hotels there, but Lazimpat - it's just normal district of Kathmandu without any nepal culture and nepal spirit.In Thamel you can find many different restaurants (impossible to mention good ones because there are many of them), shops, travel agencies, hotels. Of course, mostly there are cheap hotels for backpackers, but not only, and you can find some good 4-5* hotels there (Norbu Linka, Vaishali ) and even really boutique hotel (Royal Penguin Boutique Hotel). So if you want to stay with comfort in the heart of Nepal spirit, you can do it.

Very unpleasant place.. If you walk in Thamel by yourself, expect to be bothered by touts all the time. Literally all the time, there will be somebody jumping out of every second shop to invite you in. Prices in Thamel are sky-high, because only tourists go there. Locals visit Thamel to take a look at tourists, it's like a zoo for locals. Bottom line - everything is pricey, and you will be bugged all the time.

Get ready for chaotic fun energy. This is the touristy area of Kathmandu and it will assault your five senses, but in a good way. There are many good shops and restaurants along the winding narrow streets, so be ready to bargain on prices and enjoy a variety of tasty foods.
overhyped. Usual market area. same flavour to allure visitors. Lot of bargaining and still no surity about buying right product at right price.

Average place to start your journey. We spend 3 days in Thamel. This is the place you can start your journey to Nepal.You can shop there buy your stuff for adventure sports and travel. Prices are quite decent and you can bargain anywhere including your Hotel room rates.We did mountain biking there with Himilyan Single track. You can contact Santosh there he is very experienced cyclist. The ride was very tiring and difficult but we enjoyed that.You can also visit Pashupati Nath temple and some other temples nearby.Yes there is a night life in Thamel upto 12 midnight.

Great place to stay, stroll and shop in Kathmandu. Thamel is a famous place for tourists from all over the world, located in the center of Kathmandu, about 15km from the airport. I stayed 3 nights in Shree Tibet Family Guest House located in center of Thamel in Feb 2013 . I likes Thamel most compared to other areas in Kathmandu city because this area more clean, more safe, more comfortable, full of decent shops, hotels, restaurants, money changers, tour agencies, easy to get transports, near to tourist attractions, and walking distance to tourist bus station. So many shops in Thamel, the most prominent shops are shops selling mountain climbing and trekking attaires, tools and equipments, then shops selling locals/natives handicraft such as clothes, shawls, scarfs, caps, gloves, and socks made from wool, yak or silk. Here also many bookshops selling books/magazines mostly about Nepal, Mountain, Trekking, Mountain Climbing, White Water Rafting, Mountain biking, Yoga, Meditation. Supermarket and Bakery shop are easy to find in Thamel. Everythings are within our reach. The most important thing in Thamel electricity supplied longer hours (6-8 hrs per day) compare to other areas in Kathmandu, and most of the hotels and shops in this area has their own power generator.

Wish I had more time. It was very busy but I wish I had had more time to browse and buy from the small shops. If you want good quality outdoor clothing or equipment for a fraction of the cost at home, buy it here! It's not genuine, but if you spend the time to find out what makes a good quality knock-off different from a poor quality one, you will have made great purchases!

Timeless, tight, teeming traveller crossroads. Thamel is a place that you will either love or hate. If you come to Nepal looking for Buddhist peace, or Nepalese temples, or ancient mountain kingdoms, or 5 star quality and hygeine, you aren't going to find it in Thamel. Its more like a cold weather verson of Kuta in Bali or Khaosan Road in Bangkok. Its just as dirty, seedy, noisy, colourful and vibrant and caters predominantly to foreign, young-at-heart trekkers and travellers.The place is a virtual ghetto. It is a labyrinth of narrow lanes and alleys in the old centre of Kathmandu, not far from Durbar Square. Potholed and cobblestoned roads in Thamel were designed eons ago for foot traffic, so struggle with vehicles. Motorbikes still wind through though, along with bicycle rickshaws, and tiny taxis squeezing to get past each other. The narrow lanes are jam packed with shops selling Nepali souvenirs, embroidery, cashmere/pashmina, pirated music and DVDs, cheap accommodation, and a huge variety of restaurants and bars. There are multitudes of travel agencies arranging Himalayan treks and tours, and shops selling outdoor trekking, climbing and cold weather equipment - some genuine, but the vast majority well made counterfeits imported from China and sold at ridiculously low prices. Shop touts are determined hustlers and you are expected to bargain hard. During the day, the area is a hive of shopping activity. At night it takes on a gaudy and seedy, multi-coloured quality, particularly in the heart of Thamel as the upstairs nightclubs and basement dives crank up the volume. Personally, I enjoy the place and the vibe that goes with it. The I love to travel, and am lucky enough to travel to Kathmandu on a semi regular basis. Although I now stay in better quality hotels than the majority of those in Thamel, I still love to return here to wander, shop, eat, drink, and chill out. It is a crossroads of travellers, tourists and trekkers, from every nationality and walk of life.The first time I ever visited was to trek the Annapurna Circuit, almost 25 years ago. At that time I stayed in the Kathmandu Guest House, right in the centre of Thamel. The more things change - the more they stay the same and I swear that the Thamel doesn't seem to have changed since I was here decades ago. Sure, the everything is more modern, but the place has a deja vu quality about it that is quite timeless.
Great area!. Good shopping area or just to stroll around, lots of tourists in the area. Full of restaurants, cafe's and bakery's, gifts shops. Life of Kathmandu.
For shopping and drinking. That's about it. Drinking, partying till 11pm and shopping. It's the place to stroll around the narrow streets. Don't get lost. Bargain!

A great place to wander through and look. All sorts of interesting things for sale in little tiny cave-like shops. Wonderful incense smalls permeate the air. Lots of hustle and bustle - you have to keep a close eye on the traffic with all the scooter, bicycle rickshaws, and motor bikes - a lively area of the city.

Steel yourself. Thamel - manic, busy, colourful. Rows of shops all selling similar gear. We stayed on the doorstep and dipped in on a couple of occaisions so we were lucky we didn't have to do it all at once. A good street map is essential. Beware and ignore drug dealers they6 can be pretty persistent even when you are in your mid fifties!

Great place to shop and eat. Thamel is touristy, yes. And yes, at night it can be a bit sketchy (but not unsafe). However, for a wide selection of shopping and dining, it's a must. There are also plenty of hotels in the surrounding area.
Nice shops. In Thamel you find shops, shops and shops - beautiful pashmina, local craft and lots of (unoriginal) trekking equipment. We liked it.

You may as well just go to an outdoor mall in the States.. This place is terrible. It's essentially a cesspool of aggressive vendors preying on tourists. I honestly don't understand why so many people/books recommended it - You may as well be at an outdoor mall in the states, as the only things to do there are shop and eat. Expensively. With the lowest quality of product in Kathmandu. Ugh. Ask for New Road if you want to shop, it's the same thing without the corruption - you know, where the locals go.
Good shopping. Heavily congested and noisy, but in the heart of Kathmandu. A good place to shop or enjoy a meal. Lots to see and experience.

Another happening place in Kathmandu. Thamel is interesting to visit with lots of shops and restaurants. Although crowded now it still is one of the popular places for night life. If you are looking for a place to enjoy some night life, this is the place. It used to be a popular place for hippies once upon a time. You will not see them any more but their stories are still very fresh in this area. You must check the Cashmere shawls and other cashemere products available in this area. It holds pubs, restaurants, money changing booths, hotels, shops of various nepali products, mountaineering products etc. It is a must visit place in Kathmandu

Everything's there - take the smooth with the rough.. Thamel has had bad press about it's rip-the-tourist-off shennannigans but we found friendliness. Sure the pushy salespeople are there but they take "No thanks" for an answer and still smile.

Touristy place, but still cool. Shop, after shop, after shop, of the same common tourist items you would expect, bags, hiking gear, jewelry, pashmina shalls, etc. The prices are more expensive in Thamel, but the restaurants are good, and you can find some unique things. The streets are narrow like everywhere else in Kathmandu, but the road conditions are slightly better.

Definately THE place for tourist atmosphere.. There is SO much going on in Thamel, take a walk and see where you end up. My 9 year old twins and I went on a rickshaw for half an hour but an hour would have been better. Think we paid 100 rupees??? make sure you window shop first. We went looking for jackets for the kids. Check the quality but prices ranged from 3500 to 1200 NR for pretty much the same thing. Loads of great cafes. Watch out for the street boys, they can become quite violent after sniffing glue. It's a fun place. Laundromats advertise per kg but double check as most say that price only includes socks and jocks. You WILL get 50 R per mixed kg and it's lovely to have clean clothes after trekking.

the best. i would ever stay in this place for all its great places for great food;the bars the dances the massage homes; the friendly people and the places of stay. great walking in the cobbled streets and the proximity to all the places . the internet center the Mahaboudda area to purchase anything under the sun at a very reasonable price and the cycle rickshaw ride for a reasonable price. loads of eateries and meat and fish stalls . a wonderful place to walk clicking pictures and getting observed and fill your bags with great memory stuff

VERY busy. A VERY busy part of the world, noisy, smelly, and poor roads, but all part of the experience. Not what I ever expected to find in Kathmandu but still, the sites and sounds were still worth the effort to be there.

If you are in Kathmandu, you should visit this place. One can find everything here, almost everything. Budget stays, expensive stays, good restaurants, cafes, money changers, bars, live music, cyber cafes, tourists guides, travel arrangements, shopping, people. It seems like the whole world converge at this place in Nepal. Fun place to be for couple of days.

Thamel. Very busy and touristic zone; the best to buy rugs, wooden works, souvenirs, silk and 'PASHINA" scarves, better use more expensive stores, less junk there. "Thamel" restaurant is the best, very good food and service

Great shopping. This is the place to go to, to shop for tourist souveneirs - trinkets as well as trekking gear. You'll be surprised by the variety and prices - be prepared to bargain to get the best deal. The Thamel also hosts some great restaurants and bookshops. Just go for a wander.
A Happening Spot. Many shops and restaurants.They cater to tourists. Bargain hard or buy things you fancy somewhere else.

Thamel is Thamel. Everyone who comes to Kathmandu, will no doubt end up in Thamel at some point, if they aren't staying there.It is the most confusing, maze of winding streets, that you will most likely ever stay in, and full of hawkers and people trying to sell you something.That said, it is also very interesting, and there are many very good quality restaurants and bars in the area, which anyone who has spent a reasonably amount of time in India/ Nepal, will enjoy. Shopping is also very good and cheap, but obviously, you have to be prepared to haggle everyone, from guest house, to taxi drivers etc... as everyone will try to rip you off as much as they can.Well worth wondering around and also walking from thamel to some of the other attractions such as Durbar Square, as you will see interesting street scenes along the way.
tourist area of Katmandu. This is the best place to spend some days in Kathmandu, you get all you need shops, restaurant, bars and the travel agencies, but little noise but is ok in Kathmandu,

OK. We went to the market for the first time at night. We were not impressed and mostly found Nike shoes and Northface clothing.Went back the next day as part of a tour and it seems we didn't go deep enough into the market to find more variety.All in all, it was ok but we have been to many other markets that were more interesting. That being said I did buy silk scarves and shawls and was pleased.

good place. Many shop selling the local handy craft,Nepal pashmina,casmere,trekking equipment..anythings u look for can find at Thamel.the traffic is crazy,must be carefull always keep left when you walk on a roadside..because all the car and motorcycle is very fast.Remember to bargain evrythings and anything u want to buy at thamel at least 80% from the starting price...they will asking 5000NPR but in the end sell 1500NPR for you.

Love it or hate it. The first time I went to Thamel I disliked it and said I wasnt going back... well, the second time I went back I gave it a shot, and actually enjoyed it. We found some cool shops and restaurants, and became expert negotiators. I wouldnt spend too much time here, but for the price, its great for souvenir shopping.
Dirty and dusty. This place was ok to see about except foor the people begging and lying on the streets ,very dirty and dusty,as loads of road works going on,
Very dangerous .night life is not safe. Night dancing club is very dangerous the rough people they will hit you and grab your money be very carefully

Heavenly shopping. As it is the popular place for shopping, you can find some shop that offer you the very reasonable price. You can but the holy praying wheels, bhudda eye necklace, brass handicrafts, back, down jacket. I can't believe that some items here are cheaper that what I bought in Pokhara and Bhaktapur. If you visit the shop when it it almost the closed time you might not have to bargain for the price as they would offer you the unbelieveable cheap price :)

madness. we landed just before xmas, Thamel so busy, stayed for 4 nights, loved the people here, great shops to barter in, only down side was our credit card got coppied here and used when we got back, watch out on dodgy merchants.
