Cool!. I had my guide take me through the back alleys of the Thamel district. To give me a change to capture some photos of people.
Cheap. Excellent for buying souvenirs from Nepal, and also for warm trekking clothes and boots before trekking. Be prepared to bargain always all things..........

Great place. We stayed in Thamel for most of our visit to Kathmandu. It is a fantastic place to base yourself for day trips. The is great shopping and an easy walk to many places. There are great restaurants and plenty of places to eat or just stop and have a drink. Lots of rooftop cafes that give a great view of Kathmandu and surrounds.

a happening place in Kathmandu... This is a very happening place in Kathmandu with lots of budget hotels/guesthouses, restaurants, bookstores.There is also many shops selling souvenirs, clothing (traditional/winter/etc).If you are into outdoor activities, well this is a place for you to shop till drop.Lots of outdoor shops and huge amount of gears selection, but be careful of some fake goods/clothing.This is a great place to stay if you are in Kathmandu but please ignore the annoying honking of taxi and motorcyclist.

Cheap and cheerful. If you don't spend a lot of time outdoors and just want some equipment to last a trip or two in Nepal, this is the place to get outfitted. Don't waste your money on some western "brand name" that will never be used again. Buy key equipment at home, but anything else when you arrive in KTM at a fraction of the price
Shopping heaven. Excellent for buying souvenirs from Nepal, and also for warm trekking clothes and boots before trekking. Be prepared to bargain with a sense of humour.

Touristy and overpriced beware!!. The place to be if you are Nepali and want to make money from the tourists! Thriving place full of outdoor clothing and equipment shops, hippie clothes shops and gift shops, has some interesting characters to behold, the home of the three wheeled tut tuts and taxi drivers shouting to tourist's taxi!

Music, Drugs, Coffee, and Pedalers. Thamel, many people rave about this semi historic place. I however was disgusted its the most westernized part of Nepal it mimic's most tourist centers around the US and Europe cheap low quality good made specifically for touristic. Its not the good's that Nepali people are buying/wearing you see goofy white folks in cotton parachute pants and hippy-esk attire when I have yet to see native's wear much besides kurta's and teeshirt/jean combos. As for the food its rice and lentil's (at super inflated prices compared to anywhere else in KTM) are available but most restaurants make strong attempts at failed western cuisine (to there credit its not there fault the proper ingredients just are not imported into the country to make it correctly). It is however on of afew areas that brewed coffee (non-Nescafe) are possible. Hot water showers are at most hotels some time during the day. During the day any tourist is subject to aggressive peddlers of Tiger balm, cab rides, squeaky instruments, and more. At night the same peddlers are present but they have switched to selling illicit drugs and "full body massage" making it almost not worth the hassle of being on the streets at night. One thing to note is that at no point did my safety seem compromised, personal spacial boundaries yes people get right up on you without thinking twice. The music scene seem rather active, bands played at may venues every night generally covering radio classic's with surprising accuracy, there was however a prominent punk/hardcore circuit that played atleast once a week I think they may have been the bands in different lineups they all sounded a touch like the NYC band "Leftover Crack" I'll leave it at that. From the Nepali side I know many Nepali native that love Thamel for the happening nightlife but this is only because this is as good as it gets in this county its about as happening as small college town in offseason and most establishments are done and shut down but 12. I hate to be the cynic but I also love to hate on the "tourist scene" if your in KTM by all means go people will ask you about every time you mention you have been to Nepal but like so many other places in the world its does not live up the hype its given.

A Happy Colourful place. I really like Thamel it is so busy with things happening all the time. The colour and the people are just wonderful. Children walking along chatting with each other dressed up all clean and lovely going to school. Shp owners wanting you to buy the goods and love bartering but they are always polite. Rickshaws, scooters cars etc all competing for the road. The only downside is the dust and that is the governments fault. They should be doing something about it....

Great Shopping!. I had left shopping to the last minute on my 3 week trip and had half an hour to shop! And Thamel was perfect, I managed to do all my shopping in half an hour, I got some good deals and traditional things such as prayer wheels, gurkha knifes, prayer flags and 'magic purses'. They have plenty of traditional gifts and souvenirs. I recommend eating at Rumdoodle.

Get all you need. No worries if you can't get your trekking gear before you travel to Nepal, here you can get affordable/reasonable hotel rate and get the gears at the shops along the streets and souvenirs too (remember to bargain) :)
Shopping ++++. Busy narrow streets Hawkers, shops noisy & frenetic Great tourist area. We bought yak blankets Shop then dine @ Rum Doodle

Take time to feel life on the street in Thamel. We enjoyed exploring Thamel. There were so many little lanes and alleys that opened into magical courtyards. So temples and shrines were tucked way in interesting corners.

Ok for 1 visit.... More toursitic really with not much of variety.. pretty much all outlets selling the same thing !.Prices are over rated and you could easily get the same for half the price in another area.Nice to look around but nothing spectacular!. this area is more hyped than anything else.Make sure you arrive in good time. Most shops close by 7.30-8 pm.
crazy shopping area. Was a great place to get the souvenirs to take home. Also only a few steps from some tourist heritage spots. Great eating places that serve local as well as western cuisine.
DUSTY. Very busy tourist area, heavy traffic.Plenty of very good restaurants.A lot of bars with loud music

It's a tourist trap but......... There are some great shops and it was great to support the local economy. There were some pretty unique shops and if you're a westerner I think you HAVE to check it out.

Thamel is a popular tourist destination in Kathmandu, Nepal.. Thamel is a popular tourist destination in Kathmandu, Nepal. Thamel has been the center of the tourist industry in Kathmandu for over four decades starting from the hippie movement when many artists came to Nepal and spent weeks in Thamel.Its concentration of narrow streets are lined with small shops selling everything from food and provisions to clothes, walking gear, cakes, pastries, music, DVDs, handicrafts, travel agents and budget hotels.The area has some very good restaurants. Although prices tend to be significantly higher than non-tourist areas, food hygiene is generally a lot better too. Thamel also acts as the pre-base camp for mountaineers. It boasts a wide range of mountaineering gear shops, foreign money exchange booths, pubs, clubs and nightlife along with the numerous travel agents and guest houses. All in all, Thamel is home to a wide range of audience of the Nepalese population for entertainment and employment purposes. On Wednesday, 28 September 2011, Thamel was declared a full Wi-fi zone in Kathmandu.

If you want a fun night out this is the place.... The place is nisy/over-priced and clean. Theft is minimal and the people are friendly. There are several nightclubs/dinner/live music venues to enjoy. It is the tourist center of Nepal.

shopping and history. Narrow streets with shops and courtyards... great place to be based. Organic restaurant, Tibet Guest House, Prezel bakery... a place to barter for things to take home, enjoy a meal and chat with the shop owners. The internet has left the Nepalese keen to charge European prices forgetting that we are expecting to be rewarded for travelling thousands of miles before purchasing their wares! Street children high on glue beg for money outside the supermarket. A good base for the visitor.

A Shopper's delight!. There are a number of shops in this area! Be it filled with curios or food! It is a nice place to be at during the night! just to take long walks and just relax! You could buy your gifts, for back home from here! The shops do close a tad bit early as compared to the shops in India! So remember to start shopping early here!

Disappointing Thamel. I was really disappointed with the shopkeepers in Thamel. they are very rude and have lost the essence of Nepali kindness. They don't even bother to acknowledge you when you enter their shops. I prefer shopping in small cities like Chitwan, Bhaktapur and Pohkara where the shopkeepers smile and welcome you whether you purchase or not.

Nice place... perfect destination for the tourist.. It is one of the places where there are different hotels. Its like the amsterdam of germany. hahaha.. for the information.. but its not legally approved. there are many coffee shops here. You should stay here for hotels. You can buy nepalese hand made clothes here.
Tourist district. Typical tourist shops can be found all around himalya's. The Gorkha military shops are rather unique ( if you like long blades ).

Kids in the street. I just came back from living in Kathmandu for a month. I spent a lot of time in Thamel and the one thing you will see is kids roaming the streets asking for money. I admit when I first got to Thamel I thought these kids actually needed the money and I gave them money. But one day I was eating in a restaurant looking out and watching these kids. What they do is they act homeless and hungry so you the tourist will give them the money and as soon as they get the money the go to a loca Drug dealer and buy glue. These kids are using the money so they can get high sniffing glue. So again I must erge you not to give these kids any money. Outside Thamel you will not see this, so feel free to help kids outside Thamel.
dec 2012. very busy, take a face mask for the dust. excellent shops and good for bartering, interesting buildings

Thamel District, Kathmandu. If you like crowds and shopping, this is for you. Great place to pick up all your souvenirs and must-haves. Very crowded at night, loads of places to drink, dance and shop.
shopping galore. Like: shopping spree. Culinery restaurants that would suite everyones taste. Herbal & Ayurvedic +Tibetan healing centres.Dislike: nil

Not heading in right direction. Travellers familiar with Kathmandu have always enjoyed the throb of Thamel. Today we see motor bikes and cars where we once saw only pedestrians. You will still want to see the shops etc but it is not so enjoyable now.

Nepal ,Kathmandu Tourist Hub. Thamel is the located in center of the Kathmandu Nepal. Thamel is the narrow streets and lined with small shops. In Thamel you will get clothes, trekking gear, climbing gear, handicrafts. In Thamel has good restaurants and food are hygiene. For night life there are many pubs with live music.

Perfect place to shop Adventure gear. There are hundreds of Adventure shops in this area. Remember one thing, BARGAIN to purchase any item, unless "FIXED PRICE" board is displayed.
Kalapathar shop gives for reasonable prices for quality goods. Renting is also available.

Shopping in Thamal. Great shopping opportunities for Nepali items for good prices! I especially liked the fair trade stores. The streets are narrow and you have to be careful dodging vehicles. It is quite an experience!

Interesting place but watch your money. This is a great place to buy things you forgot to pack but be careful with your money here, it's easy to spend it all and some of the people I interacted with were less than honest and tried to short change me. Just remember to double check your change!

Bustling place. This is where all the tourists of KTM come together... to bargain, to shop for trekking gear, to eat at the hundreds of restaurants etc.
It's a thriving marketplace for pretty much everything from gear for trekking to tea! Must visit, just for the atmosphere!

Absolute chaos - but everything to buy!. Completely chaotic, frenetic and gave the appearance of danger with the driving. Could purchase virtually anything there, but needed to 'haggle' unless you wanted to pay way too much.

Good place for souvenirs. Very good for woollen gloves, hats, socks, yak wool jackets and blankets and |both money changers and ATMS galore. Any souvenirs you wish to buy will be here and you can obviously bargain. Varied selection with many many stalls.
Dislike having to dodge cars and motorcycles but that's par for the course in Kathmandu!

vibrant and fun. great place to meet fellow trekkers either coming or going. great shopping and cheap easy way to get set up for a trek. tons of restaurants to checkout.the noise and pollution is a bit of an annoyance but most likely you wont be here long enough for it to bother you too much.overall a must visit for some fun!
Crazy. Thamel is a great base and you could spend hours wondering the streets. I got a little fed up of the street sellers but was well practiced at turning them down by the end of the trip.

Get out quick!. I found Thamel dirty, crowded, loud, and claustrophobic. Every time we went out we were hassled to buy things. While in Kathmandu, we escaped to the courtyard of our hotel (Kantipur Temple), the oasis-like Garden of Dreams, and had a massage at Seeing Hands (which employs blind masseuses), all of which were wonderful antidotes to the city. After that we escaped the city entirely to spend the rest of our trip in Patan and Bhaktapur which are nicer by orders of magnitude.

Nice place for a free afternoon. This is a nice place to spend a free afternoon. It gets more happening from the late afternoon onwards. While there are lots of shops for shopping, after a while, you realised that the merchandise are about the same. Bargaining here is a must.
A fun touristy section of Kathmandu.. It is like Canal Street, New York City on steroids! It is a place to buy souveniers and things for a trek. Prices are good. It is a fun place to walk around.

Great marketplace. This is where most people stay, shop, eat etc. The food is great, you can find cheap or expensive places (all relative because everything is still pretty cheap). Very fun place to just walk around...you can lose time just people watching or walking around shopping. Get good at haggling before you start buying.

Fun for a day or two. Busy, dusty, hectic, with an amazing number of trekking shops, knockoff stores (It seems like 80% of the locals are wearing "North Face" clothes and jackets), and tourist-oriented craft shops. While everything seems like chaos, I did notice that there is really very little litter on the streets - the shopkeepers are constantly sweeping the mostly dirt streets. It would be a SO much nicer experience if they kept out the speeding motorcyles that are constantly buzzing everywhere, but I don't see that happening - maybe it adds to the general atmosphere. Overly persistent street vendors, but everyone's trying to eek out a living.
Great town in Kathmandu. Thamel is the most busy town blend with Good food, attraction + shopping heaven....mean this place is specially for tourist;)

Backpackers, cheap(ish) hotels, lots of souvenir shopping. If you're looking for souvenir shopping, cheap eats, and cheap (dirty) hotels, this is the place. As a single male traveler, I was constantly asked if I wanted to buy drugs, get a massage, or go to a dance bar. Got followed for a bit - you have to be firm and tell them your not interested or ignore them. Fairly well lit and seemingly safe at night, but a single female probably wouldn't want to walk around too late night. Similar to Khao San in Bangkok.

Enjoyable Chaos. We stayed in this area for 5 days. You need a quiet hotel to relax in as walking around this noisy, busy area can be quite exhausting. Shopping is great if you are after a limited range of goods and there is a great variety of restaurants in the area.

The best place for bargaining souvenirs. Some vendors however are a bit harassing. Dont go there if you have a headache,its very noisy.Besides that, this is where you can have fun bargaining your souvenirs.

busy and touristy but fun. I enjoyed the Thamel. It is colorful, loud, and touristy, but lots of places to step in and buy a knick knack, or step off the main drag to an alley to have a momo or a beer. I would definitely go back if I were passing through Kathmandu again.

Colors, Smells, Shopping. Bargain... bargain... bargain... If they tell you a 1000, chances you can get it for 600. If you're looking for an authentic Nepali experience, this is it! But mind you, the majority of things to find here are not authentic. Thamel is the place to go for shopping in the whole of Nepal. Whether you are looking for knock off sport/hiking and trekking gear, traditional souvenirs, or interesting ethnic looking cloths and accessories.
crazy busy. tons of people, great shopping opportunities to negotiate, it's fun but a full day of it is PLENTY. make sure to get off of the main roads and duck into a java shop.
Noisy touristy and frenetic. I was happy when I got out of there.. but there are gems to be found for sure.. and some good food.. and as always the delightful Nepalese smiles.
Fun but you may not want to stay too long. You will want a few days here but more than that it becomes overwhelming with people trying to get you into their stores and to buy things.

Noisy - motorbikes should not be allowed there. motorbikes
rickshaw owners - pest you all the time
southeast Thamel - where the locals go - not many tourists, and no selling pressures in your face

A busy tourist market, but still some nice things to find.. As one reviewer already said, it is what it is, a tourist market.That said, if you fancy a nosey round some shops and pick up some gifts for those back home, then it's worth an hour or so. Whilst some of the shopkeepers can be a touch pushy, it's nothing compared to some places in the world I've been. The wonderful Nepalese people don't have it in them to be aggressive or rude. We picked up some super bargains by having a good look around and got gifts for all the folks back home to enjoy.It's also the home of Funny Nepal Trekking company, who are THE best for your travel and trek needs. So head to Thamel and enjoy it for what it is.

It is what it is. A market for tourist. Although it is nice to walk there, Thamel area is for tourists. A lot to buy but as any market, buyer beware. We did not get hassled at all which was great. There's plenty of restaurants there too. Place to go for souvenirs
Great atmosphere. Walk into Thamel & although very busy it had a great atmosphere. good shopping and great eateries. We did get a little hassled but on the whole felt very safe walking around .
Shoping haveh. Everything...cloths, bags, jewerly, tea, inesense, ceramics, bronze,thanka, and sometimes low fixed prises, not as in Indian markets.

Busy shopping area. I did enjoy this area. It was buzzing with interesting little shops and things to see. the prices are moderate so you can follow your shopping mania or whims. There is also quite good trekking shops so you can top up it needed.We ate on the local tibetan restaurang, really nice. It was clean and the food was nice, recommed.

Wondering in Thamel. Wow , I lost in thamel in search of my hotel , but I wanted to be lost again and again as it's the only way while you see the hidden Thamel.A tourist Bazar , full of attractions around in terms of temples , monasteries Restaurants, Spa , Bars, Live Music , Clubs , Make shift stalls containing Worthy stone , bones ornaments, yak wool caps , shawls and los more I can't explain really.Day thamel and night thamel two different tastes you would find

noisy and busy citycentre. For the shoppers an eldorado.
First look around in this streets and you will find nice restaurants too
Do not forget to visit Amrita Craft shop telnr 4240757

So for the Tourist. But hey, you are one, so you might as well enjoy it! Once you get past the constant hassle of the sellers on the street, you learn to love the place. The hassle and bustle of the place make it what it is - fun. Learn to haggle and enjoy it! And remember there is no need to be an a-hole, these people are just to feed their families.
overrated. worth a visit to set up a trek, or gear up with missing items, but i much recommend you rather you stay in the Bodhanath area, it's cheaper and much more quiet.
Set up for tourists. Pintoresque place set up to get cheap souvenirs, just average and you find better alternatives in the shops certified by the government.

Shopping Meca. Its the Bangkok Khao Sahn Road of Kathmandu. Its been very hip and cool for decades, It has a bit of a hussle for sales but after 30 years of tourist its still not totally burnt out.  Good shopping and eating, Great place to get lost and wander,

great bargaining and shopping. it s so much fun to hone your negotiating skills in a culture where bargaining is a game and expected. you might end up paying more than you think you should be but rest assured, you are still getting your items much cheaper and will be taking home some really authentic souvenirs
heart of kathmandu for foreigners. good place to pick up bargains (if you know how to haggle) good restaurants, good selection of places to book trips around nepal, and good hotels.
Great vibe. Can get a little boring with the same shops, but I love the vibe and the food is amazing!! Designed for the tourists but sometimes a bit of a relief to go back there.

A beehive of inexpensive baubles. Kathmandu is many things but its industrious character is brought forward by everything that goes on in Thamel. Although the shops tend to be a little repetitive, there is so many shops and so many things being offered that you need time to appreciate it well. Take your time and be firm to negotiate; the first price is sure to be at least double the selling price. You have to be able to walk away to get the right price. It is easy enough to get rid of the occasional drug pusher. The sellets are not that annoying that their hawking becomes a bother; they tend to be polite and not too insistent. If you start asking for a price for something, be ready for a long process because they will only let you go if your price is way too low. A fun experience. I did not experience or get wind of any theft of dishonesty in my 4 visits to Thamel. There is a fair amount of police on hand.
Anything you want. It might be dirty and noisy, but I loved the small streets & conveniences of everything. Not many places like this on earth.

A "must see" for shopping fans. You can find any trekking or mountaineering equipment, gear + souvenirs, shawls, books, music etc. in Thamel.. Cozy atmosphere, nice restaurants even though it seems chaotic and noisy. Pilgrims Book House and Kathmandu Guest House offer delicious food.

Beautiful Chaos. Colorful displays lining the streets - trekking gear, clothing, Thangka Paintings, postcards, and souvenirs are the commonly found merchandise here, and every one of the store owners trying to get your attention, hoping to close a sale.If visiting during the main tourist season be prepared for the narrow, and often battered streets to be crowded, masses of people flowing each direction and among them motorcyclists trying to squeeze their way forward.Yet in between this chaos a calming tune of Om Mani Padme Hum will often sound, and incense burn creating pleasant homely scents, and in the end you'll feel that being part of this beautiful chaos is indeed a worthwhile experience.
Go there for street shopping. Go there for street shopping, average street food, nice beer. You would nice winter wear, trekking gear, souvenirs, paper works etc.

Chaotic,dirty but fascinating. I really enjoyed walking through the chaos here , at times it gets so busy that any independant motion is impossible and you just go with the flow of people.Beware, watch for pick pockets.The highlight for me was a visit to the Himalayan tea corner where the enthusiastic owner lets you taste some of the finest teas I have ever tasted
Shoppers Paradise?. Only if you get away from the touristy bit and find the area where the Nepali's shop. In that area you find the real bargains at Nepali prices.

trekking in nepal. Traveling as a single woman you have to be a little more careful of who you trust and who you choose to guide you through the beautiful Mountains. After meeting Puru and talking to him for 5 minutes i felt at ease. It helps that his English is really good it makes communication easy and that is important when you are in the Mountains. He is always full of life and energy. He is very flexiable and easy going as well. He has a wealth of information when it comes to any questions you may have concerning the mountains and Nepali culture. I would use him again in a heart beat Thank you Puru Shannon

A Bustling Ancient Suburb of Kathmandu. Great place for trekkers and visitors to stay away from the filthy parts of Kathmandu but close to all the glorious ancient sights and not too far away from the airport
Great for shopping. Great for last minute items for a trek and Nepalese gifts. I liked the headbands and scarfs the best. Remember to bargain but not too much.

Fun but touristy. I had a good time here, but reminded me a lot more of India than it did Nepal. There is a lot of cheap souvenirs that lack quality. For true genuine jewelry and singing bowls I had to search high and low to find good quality and know I wasn't getting ripped off. Go to Patan for the singing bowls.

Tourist shopping. If you weant tourist shopping then this is the place. Every 100m or less you cycle round the same sorts of outlets with a few exceptions. The pilgrim's bookstore had all the information I needed and nearly I picked up some decent paintiings at low prices.
Need Time. You need to spend time in this area, it is all made for the typical tourist! The restaurants, bars, shops, people, excitement are all so enjoyable.

Everything is there and too much. Easy place to every tourist, especially young one. Excellent shops, but not too agressive salesmen. Variety of restaurants for every taste, sometimes too noisy. Mostly small hotels, but apartment homes too, like Arcadia.

Dont go out of your way to visit, but if you have time.... This is basically the backpackers haven. Although the shops are interesting to look at handicrafts etc and are definitely cheaper than around the key sites, they are very repetitive and not that special. If you are travelling with a young child (and therefore being a little more discerning about where you eat) there wasn't anywhere that jumped out for us.

Busybusy. Well, there has to be anything you ever wanted somewhere in the warren of tiny alleys and slightly larger streets. Also ancient temples, charming cafés, kooky sights and good hotels. Another must.

Tourist Area. If you are a shopaholic you could spend days looking at all the things for sale. This area is very touristy and you have to be careful what you buy. Many things are not top quality and the prices are very high. So, bargain hard! There are lots of restaurants in the area, so it is fun to walk around, shop and have a meal. Be very careful of the traffic. The streets are not well marked and are very narrow. Cars and motorbikes come zooming through with little regard to pedestrian traffic. We had a great experience, but our guide told us to be very careful because the area has many pickpockets and motorbike snatch and grab of handbags/cameras/backpacks/etc,

Thamel Health Centres. Thamel is very busy, especially as I was there during a festival. The pollution is terrible, so you may want to wear a mask. I suggest only a day or two in Thamel. Women: be careful getting a massage, I was massaged by a man and it was obvious he had no massage training or skills and he tried to massage parts of my body that i have never had anyone try to massage before....and then he asked me for sex!! I think although it stated massage, it was a brothel. Beware!!
Backpacker haven. there is allot to do and see, mostly shops and restaurants.. all kinds of things can be found in Thamel.. it's one of those places you MUST not miss seeing when your in Kathmandu
Great Place to Explore. Thamel is the main attraction for the Tourist, can chill out because there are a lot of Bar, Discos, Restaurant...
Amazing city with beautiful people.... I felt like I went back in time upon arrival to Kathmandu...what a fascination city "Themal" with beautiful people...I will never forget Nepal!

Good place for food, beer & souvenirs. A chaotic mismash of streets festooned with shops, bars & resataurants. Frenzied but retianed a sense of charm. Note..things tend to close up at around 10-11pm in the evening and take a torch with you!

The centre of tourist shopping!. If you want to see thousands of tourist shops crammed in a tiny area, selling anything and everything, then get along here. It's the best place for all those souvenirs. Enjoy the haggling over price: it's fun and shows you care about the product. There's also a good selection of restaurants of you've had too much curry.

Dirty. The place is dirty, people spitting everywhere the locals.
Shopping paradise but not cheap and shop owners are not bothered to entertain bargains.
But the best place to book any tours, treks etc, many choices.
Budget place to stay but not sure of the quality and safety of the place.
There are some restaurants but the kitchens dont look clean.

Don't miss this place, day or night it's wild!. A wild vibrant district of Kathmandu - not to be missed. Just chill out and watch the bustling crowd from a roof top snack bar or join in and have fun bargaining for anything and everything. Food fun noise and smells.

Get a rickshaw and cruise around. We loved walking around the Thamel region in the evening. It feels safe and the people watching is incredible. Taking a bike rickshaw is always worth it. Lots of great shops, restaurants, people, cows, random temples...just get lost and explore.

A nice market place but pricy. Thamel is a tourist market, and because of that the prices are inflated. Bargaining will take you a long way, but not as low as other places. There's also the fact that the place really smells bad and is very dusty.

Good fun. This area of the city is a bit over touristed with a few too many shops selling all the same things but it has a fun, friendly vibe and a busy atmosphere, you can get pretty much anything foodwise and its all pretty good quality, prices are not bad and the people watching can be interesting!
fun place. fantastic shopping for trekking clothes and for winter wool jackets etc for the cold of europe. endless restaurents chose with care .

Touring Kathmandu. I recently returned from a trek to Ama Dablam basecamp in the Khumbu Valley of Nepal and had a few days after the trek to see Kathmandu. I was looking forward to the visit since it is supposedly a UNESCO World Heritage Site and I have visited many other World Heritage Sites around the globe with great pleasure. I confess, however, to complete disappointment in the sad reality of Kathmandu, which is a capital in a state of serious deterioration. The city is polluted, crowded, filthy and almost totally without aesthetic merit. The city's Durbar Square, though crammed with ancient structures, is tragic to see. The once beautiful monuments are falling into pieces and offer only shadows of past beauty. Foreigners pay to enter the Square (supposedly the money is devoted to restoration efforts), but I saw little evidence of restoration in process. Interesting shopping can certainly be done in the little shops in Thamel, but be prepared for filthy conditions along the road (wear a dust mask for sure) and dangerous street crossings. There are no street lights and streets are packed with motorbikes, cars, buses and bicycles that follow a logic of their own. Beyond Kathmandu, it is worth seeing Swayambhunath (the Monkey Temple, northwest of the city), Bodhnath (the large Buddhist stupa east of the city), and the Durbar Square of Patan, an ancient sister city south of Kathmandu which is in a better state of repair than Kathmandu. In general, however, I would advise travelers coming to Nepal for a trek to minimize their stay in Kathmandu. There is very little here worth seeing, sad to say. Remember to drink NO TAP WATER at all and to completely avoid uncooked vegetables and unpeeled fruits. Sanitation is poor here. I have only admiration for the local people I encountered in Kathmandu, however, who were uniformly helpful and polite. These people clearly deserve better from their government!
Great shopping. Fun barter shopping in Kathmandu. Many of the shops have similar items but you cannot find any of it in the USA for the low prices in Thamel.

Busy and small streets. Thamel is a very busy place with narrow streets and lots of shops. There are certain parts of Thamel that are very nice but also parts that are horrible. You should walk in Thamel because even the small taxis can hardly fit in the small streets. I would also recommend not going in the rainy season because then the streets are very muddy and you can easlily get splashed by mud when a bicycle cycles past. You should also keep an eye on your belongings because there are pickpockets around.

In the thick of it. Noisy narrow crowded streets packed with dusty shops and peaceful garden restaurants. Go rooftop for views as all Kathmandu is pretty low rise. Pubs are cushions and low tables with live music but dodgy food and lots of 'working girls' hanging round the bar. Do not give money to child beggars - glue sniffing is a shockingly open past time of these kids.

Thamel, the easiest base in Kathmandu.. ahh good old Thamel. Where to start,, well it is a travelers Ghetto if there ever was one but that does mean you can get whatever you need on just about any street. There is plenty of great food, lots of nice guesthouses and plenty of shopping. Thamel does get old after too many days but it is a great place for stocking up / getting ready for a trek or other travels. And makes a nice base for exploring Kathmandu.

Grew on me. Extremely busy, crowded, noisy and worse of all polluted. However, as the tourist season developed, the ground pollution was cleaned up, and as you grew accustomed to the noise it developed a life and atmosphere that was quite fun. This was probably assisted by finding "safe spots" and having made some friends. It grew on me. Once you got the decisive "no" in the vocab it became quite enjoyable
Shop and eat. No charm in this tourist hub, however one can find a great deal of souvenir shops. Some of the best eateries in town are also located there
Great place. Great shopping, people, food and value. Stayed here for a week and loved every minute of it, easy to get around clean and a general nice feel.

Shops. All the tourist and trekking shops you will ever need plus hotels and eating places.There is still a lot of traffic in the area - they should consider making a few a of streets pedestrian friendly.

The heart of Katmandu. Browsing the narrow streets of Katmandu's Tamel is a must. The shopping is great. Look for trading gear, arts and crafts and Nepalese souvenirs. Bargaining is mandatory!! You can reduce prices by 50-60%. Restaurants in the Tamel are the best in the city. Look for Indian and Italian restaurants, or coffee shops. If you are late nighters, the Tamel's late night scene is amazing. In short – you can spend several days in the Tamel without having to leave. Enjoy!!
Centrl place for tourist. It is central area , very good handicraft and pasmina shopes, If you love night life walk around very good places gives relaxing music

Touristy Chaos. I normally avoid touristy areas like the plague; but Thamel has its own charm. Absolutely buzzes at night, and packed full of good restaurants. Not sure why you would stay here more than a night or two. Hotels in Bhaktapur are much more pleasant and devoid of all tourists at night.

perfect trekkers town. We stayed at Samsara resort in Thamel and were able to roam the streets. Safe at night and great place to haggle for gifts and such. Also delicious momo's and massages and food off carts everywhere. Perfect place to enjoy Kathmandu with chaos and still a little pace.
If you are in shopping time, this is the place. You will find almost any kind of handicraft which is produce in Nepal and Tibet. barging is a must . Offer half of the price and do not quit.

Very interesting city Thamel. First day was in Thamel,This city is very much interesting and very exotic type.I like Thamel at the night most.In day Thamel look very busy but in the Night it look like paradise.Very fun and very cool night ,everywhere only fun ,songs ,disco, Pubs, Shops ,like it,But please don't believe any one there if you don't know ,you can have chat with them at day.If somebody ask you ,like Treks ,shop ,etc.Then if you need you can go but beware don't go very inside with them ,because we are new there and any thing can be happen there. If you chat with agent then you will know how to live there so chat with agent ,talk with them ,visit more office but donot do very inside places with them...But in aggregateThamel is very beautiful and very interesting place.....
Fun place to wander and explore. Great place to have plenty of food choices and lots of shopping. Glad we didn't sleep here, just stayed 15 min walk away, but loved people watching and eating here.

Intense Vibe. This is not the place if you do not like noise. However, if insane traffic, pulsing music, rooftop dining a million horns and good food, all sound appealing, than this is the place! we divided our trip between Patan (very nice,) Thamel ( wonderfully insane ), and the mountains. I do not think I would have liked it as much, had we spent our entireholiday here.

TOURIST MECCA. busy busy busy SHOPPING GALORE prices ok but be prepared to barter get chased by the Tiger balm men selling their wares and all the others good food venues if you want some western style

Hectic, frantic day and night. Thamel area has everything a tourist can love or hate about an area-- It's busy, there are lots of shops providing evry possible service-- from internet to restaurants to nightclubs to cheap and not so cheap craft shops. It is also always busy-- 8:00 AM or late at night, so for me it continues to be an enjoyable experience.
overcrowded. For those who want to SHOP this is the place but it is oh so crowded we just left as quickly as possible . Also bieng full of tourists also a bit high priced !

Kathmandu, not for the fainthearted!. I was expecting Kathmandu to be rough, it is a developing nation after all but not as rough as it was. Seriously I have been to some incredibly poor nations, not the least Haiti, and this place is pretty dreadful. Now this may be due to the fact that it rained solidly for the four days we were there and that does put a dampener on things (pun intended) but maybe not, the one saving grace of the place is the people! The Nepalese are fantastic, friendly, polite and willing to help, even the hawkers can be discouraged with a simple "no thanks" and a smile and that is great. So to sum up, if visiting Nepal then take a day in the capital and get out to experience the rest of this remarkable country!
good market,. get everything. good market, good market place lots of eating joints, small shops, pub .. SPA everything. every body should vist this

Tourist heart of Kathmandu. This is one of the few overtly touristy places that feels authentic. The narrow streets and bustle of people are great to walk around in and haggle for great bargains, not to mention the restaurants of course. Thamel has something for almost everyone.

Once is enough. I've been to Thamel 4 times. On the plus side, just about anything you'd ever want to buy can be purchased there at prices lower than in the US or Europe. You have to bargain, which can be fun, but is a double edged sword. If you really drive a hard bargain, your concience may bother you, because you know this is not a culture of wealth. If you don't drive a hard bargain you walk away feeling duped. I always by a tin of Tiger Balm from the first tout that approaches me. Then, for the next 47 touts, I can pull my little tin out of my pocket and show them that I already have it. The one Nepali phrase you should learn to shop in Thamel is "Chi Di nah" (I don't want it). The touts can be relentless if you show any interest in their product at all.The resturants are risky. There is no guarantee of quality or safe food preparation, so it's easy to get sick. All in all, I would say Thamel should be seen once just because it is an interesting experience. Guard your wallet and stay away from the food and you will be ok.

The place for tourists to start. Ok there are good and bad every where but if you're traveling, you need to start somewhere and it should have access to travel agencies, banks, restaurants, pubs and bars (to unwind) and more importantly, HOTELS. Thamel has it all. It's the tourist center of KTM.

Touristy Neighborhood.. This place is not all that nice. there are so many more places in Kathmandu to visit and to shop. I like cities and I like going out at night to do photography. You can't walk down the street without someone coming up to you trying to sell you hash or girls or something. Stay somewhere else if you can.

Good, but explore. Thamel is great. There are tons of restaurants, shops, and things to see. But Thamel is not the true Nepal. You have to get out of the city, especially out of this tourist district, and see what has made Nepal famous... its landscapes.
Good shopping.. I liked the jewelry and it was pretty cheap. The vendors were not annoying, instead they were polite but remember to bargain!

Tough to get there from our Hotel but well worth it. So many restaurants and bars and so many nice atmospheric shops to buy anything you might want, practically. We went to several bars in area and had some excellent snacks and then some good drinks, ending up at Fire Club for some great music and dancing. Went home around 2:00am, good time!

Thamel is very insecure.. One of friend has taken two beer and had to pay 400 USD, they captured someone and beated in to 'kitchen bar with dance' peach moon bar with dance. Never go to any unknown / non -crowd bar.

Thamel ? Tourist Trap! Get out, this is not Nepal!. I have been living in Nepal for a few years and I really try to keep out of Thamel as much as possible. The "Tourist Area" is - for me - the most annoying place in Nepal. I only go there if there is no other choice for something I need. At every corner one is hunted by touts and prices are only there to rip you off. The quality of the garments offered here is usually very low. Walk a few minutes outside and you get the same stuff for one tenth of the price. If you have any interest in the culture and the people of Nepal, stay somewhere else, for example around Patan Durbar Square, where a few very nice guest houses have opened recently!

great place to buy souvenirs. bargain your head off...what you think is not a fair bargain my advice is go below it shamelessly...trust me it helps.. for example if they say 400NPrs...you say 175NPrs then i guess you settles for 200NPrs...and you are happy you got a good deal...he he he trust me they are also happy that it was a good deal :-)...so just shoot off a price less than what you are willing to pay...you never know. Thamel is a very narrow street with two way traffic in some places you will get lost in it's multi streets keep some landmarks and imagine bird's eye view to have a direction of where you are going...the royal palace is just 600 meters away from thamel so if you going to book it for a taxi don't it's just walking distance...rest is upto you on how much you want to shop...you see something nice don't buy it immdtly..just walk forward and you will see that same thing at a lesser price...all the best and wear comforatble shoes. they have many supermarkets out there so you can buy your beer and other stuff here which are sold at a premium in other shops and your hotels...for example bottle of water is actually 15 NPrs...in the supermarket..but at other places you will pay 25-30 NPrs...same for any other thing you want to buy. indian and dollar currency are accepted

Extremely touristy but convenient. If you are just passing by Kathmandu for a day, Thamel would be a great place to stay and explore. You can shop, dine and entertain yourself easily and quickly without having to move far from there. Lots of shops to choose from and great live bands to see at night. If you need to take a bus to some region the very next morning, the bus bay is just at walking distance. Stay only for a day, trust me you'll get bored the next.

Good place for dinning options and trekking equipment. Thamel has become crazy with all of the motorcycles plying the streets. They will have to eventually make this area pedestrian only, or it will drive all of the tourists out. There are many good restaurants and huge amount of trekking shops, so this is the place to go for this.

Visit to Thamel. Thamel is the tourist hub in Kathmandu and is a great place to walk about exploring. I wouldn't like to stay in this locality as its too crowded. If you're looking to grab some stuff for a trek, its a must visit and they sure have lots of stuff

Amidst the hustle-bustle. Thamel is the area of Kathmandu that most foreign visitors choose for hotels and restaurants. It is not the real Nepal but a place to get what you need on your way to a real Nepali experience.You will find supermarkets with most kinds if western foods usually at western prices. You also have your choice of restaurants from just about every type of cuisine. It is a hectic but friendly place. You should settle a price from the get-go with the rickshaw drivers. Taxi drivers were much more honorable . Be prepared to haggle for decent prices on souvenirs. Lots of places to choose from if you feel the price us too high.
A Place to have fun and Shopping. Stay in Thamel and enjoy the festivities and simply unwind yourself in the evenings, with good beer in pubs.

Tourism Area of Kathmandu. Thamel is centrally located in the heart of Kathmandu. Most of the famous hotels and international levels restaurants are located here and Full of wifi zone. Thamel area is specially design intense to provide facility for tourist.

Great place to start your trip in Nepal at. A great place to start the tripThere are a lot of agencies where you can hire porters and buy the permits you needAlso, except of good hiking shoes and bag , do not buy anything at home, you can buy there anything, from clothes, rain coat, hats walking stiks etc. very very chip
Best place to shop and bargain. Lots of shops in very narrow streets with moving vehicle which is quite dangerous. But its the best place to shop and bargain.

Touristy but flabbergasting!. It is full of tiny shops, and the tiny shops are packed with souvenirs, handmade goods and artifacts. Just like in every well frequented town all over the world. But it is only in Asia - and the Arab world - where the still surviving traditional craftsmanship and its products can be found in such mesmerizing abundance. And the small shops of Thamel are real gold-mines for that!

Thamel, Kathmandu. Thamel" it is center for Kathmandu tourism for western tourist, every western tourist wish to visit this part of town. Clean narrow streets with lot of small boutique shops full of antiques, pashminas, fabric etc...There ere so many small restaurants and mid range and budgeted guest houses situated in this area. Just avoid dance bar restaurants for any fraud.

good place to buy local handicrafts. there is an awesome collection of handicrafts that can be purchased here. lots of bargaining is required. this place comes alive after sunset.. there are all sorts of pubs and bars available which is the highlight..there are some good english pubs which is favorite watering holes for europeans and westerners for the quality of music they play. you have great dining options also here. the best part for Indians is that Indian currency is accepted here though be careful not to carry Indian currency notes of 500 & 1000 denominations as they are illegal anywhere across Nepal.

Place to stay in Kathmandu. I would definitely recommend staying in Thamel, as it is the centre of Kathmandu, as from what I've noticed. A backpackers' area, it is so common to see so many backpackers in the streets. It is also very small, so it's easy to get from one place to another -- from mountain gear stores to souvenir shops to hostels to travel agencies to restaurant of different cuisines. It is a poor country, so the roads and transportation is not great, but it's interesting to explore the character of urban Nepal.

poor. Napal is one of the poorst counter in the world. you have to be ther to see it I staded in the thamel as you know by know it is all so 1 of the dirtyest townes i have bean to and thay are not to good to the tourest .thay just want your money So if you dont have to dont go

the tourist hub. you can find a lot of guest houses and hotels here its in the center and all the streets is about tourist and what ever you need you will find there, its more expensive than other places so try to get your gifts from durbar square or other cities like chitwan if you are going there

Not roads but lanes. I got a shock to find that Thamel doesn't really have roads but a network of lanes filled with rickshaws, taxis, hotel minbuses, bikes, motorbikes and begger children. The noise can be quite draining and irritating. If you forgot to buy your trekking gear at home you will find tons of trekking gear shops here along with coffee shops and mostly clean restaurants.
the tourist place. even if it's full of tourists we felt so good in this area!!Lots of nice and cheap restaurants, many hotels and shops to buy souvenirs and trek stuff.

Older part of Kathmundu, shopper's heaven. The streets are littered with shops of woolen stuff, silver and semi precious stones, kashmiri items etc. What I liked most about this area are the people- the shopkeepers are very amiable and nice- not pushy like the other street shops I have been to.
Shopping paradise. This is the place where you can shop, shop, shop. Plus they have all the bars with some good local bands, enjoy the ride

A Shopping Heaven in Kathmandu. Thamel Market is one of the most livliest places in Kathmanduwith Pubs, Clubs, Restaurants and Shops you can do so much thereFood from all around the world is found here Shoes, trek gear, Shawls, Tshirt, Souviniers, Khukri and many more items to shop from the trick is to know bargaining as evething is local and u are sure to get a good dealHave fun Shopping there !!

Bargain, bargain!. This is the best place to bargain and get the best deals on pashminas and other trinkets that you want to buy. Be sure to ask for atleast 30-40% discount on the quoted price. In case of pashminas, lot of them are imported from Jaipur (India) and sold at higher prices. So if you know your stuff, you can get a great deal.Thamel also has lot of restaurants with live music etc. It also has cybercafe's for those who want to access the net.

A busy, thriving town... Thamel, whilst very 'Nepal' is also very much geared to the tourist. Busy, thriving shopping centre where everything you can possible need can be found. Some amazing textiles to be haggled over where a real bargain can be obtained. On the down side there are MANY shops geared for the tourist who will not consider haggling and are actually quite expensive.Just be aware of the two sides to the coin here and you will have an exciting shopping experience. The bars and restaurants mainly cater for tourists.
Any Food. Any Food i,ll try myself. it depends on my mood and the imvironment. i'll find restaurant myself. normally during my travel i like fast food or continental food.
Old world Charm. Loved this places. Lots of shops to buy Thanka, Khukhri, Nepali Pashmina etc. Do remember to bargain a lot. Some very good cafes with music.
Tourist hub. Just the place for tourists to spend their evenings...many restaurants, souvenir shops and pubs to choose from. Be careful of cons though.
Everything you could want. Prices are probably cheaper on all souvenirs outside this tourist area but i enjoyed it anyway. Salespeopletend to be overly friendly...bakery, book shops, clothing.

Buzzing!. Kathmandu can be a difficult place to locate a bar or restaurant you feel comfortable going into, but Thamel is the area where you will be spoilt for choice, Irish pubs, Italian restaurants and comforts of home you will miss if staying in Nepal for a long period can all be found here, one personal experience was walking into a nightclub in Thamel at 3 o'clock in the day and it was buzzing with life, odd but fun!

Very touristy. Thamel really has become a bit of a tourist trap in the last few years. The atmosphere is very tourist market and bargains are hard to come by. You get what you pay for whether it's rip off Chinese/Indian or other. Having said this there are still a few gems. Found a nice little hand made instrument shop on this last trip.

Know what you need...... We would recommend going to Thamel if there is something specific that you want to buy.  That almost certainly means bypassing most of the trinket sellers and focusing more practically on all of the outdoor gear in offer.  But again: know what you want before you enter any of the shops or you could end up with a million and one accessories you have no real need for.  The trickiest thing is to get a sense of what a fair price is because there is no simple way to calculate this.  Take North Face gear for example: there's a bona fide branded shop, some places that sell genuine seconds, others that sell good quality imitations and plenty that sell cheap knock-offs.  So examine your purchases carefully, offer no more than 50 percent of what you're originally quoted, be prepared to negotiate upwards a bit (but only a bit) and you should be fine!(NB: if you are trekking throughout SE Asia you will, in our opinion, get some better bargains in Vietnam, particularly of the North Face gear that it made there.)
nice shopping and restaurant. A lot of people, a lot of shops and a lot of restaurant. Very nice place to spent your time, relaxing yourself.

Cool place!. Great bars, fun atmosphere, shopping, eating, travel booking, tattoos, walking around, etc... Mind you, the souvenirs here are more expensive than perhaps near Kathmandu's Durbar Square just a few blocks south. But this seems to be a fun place for night life and hostels. Enjoy!

Tourist hole. Nice place to eat in Kathmandu, but terribly overpriced and incredibly touristy. It's bustling atmosphere is energising, but don't stay long or you'll be broke. Its also worth not getting trapped here and make sure you leave Thamel to experience the real Kathmandu

Breath. Walk, stop, shop and haggle...immerse yourself and become lost in the lanes of Thamel. The charm of the area, people and crafts/skills of the inhabitants will keep you wanting to see more...small cars and smaller lanes.

Tourist and hawkers galore. OK - so it is the most visited tourist site - but here is a tip. Whatever the shopkeep tells you the price is, offer 1/2, and when they balk tell them you live in the area - Maharajgunj is a good answer - and ask them what their best price is. Then negotiate to 1/2 of the new rate and your starting 1/2 price... Keep in mind that shopping in Thamel is not the only place - Boudhanath, Kupondole, and Indra Chowk/Asan Tole are often where you can find better prices for some things. But if you are on a quick trip - bargain hard and you will be happy.
another magical place )). my love interest and I kept running into each other as if brought by a magnet .... i really feel destiny has been so loyal to us..

Good place to buy your trekking equipment if you need any. This place is always crowded with people when I was there. A lot of cars passing through the roads as well. However, it is not dangerous at all, just have to walk and watch out with care as per any roads. There are alot of shops selling trekking gears and apparels at inexpensive prices (however note that they may not be authentic). But still a good place to buy stuff such as fleece jacket and linen which may be helpful if you are trekking during the winter season and needed some extras. I remembered buying the fleece linen at around 10-15USD. Ornament souvenirs and cashmere/pashima scarfs are also sold there but only buy if you are sure of the quality. Overall, it is a nice busy place to be in, whether in the day or night. Just soak yourself in the atmosphere!!

Great Fun For Shopping and Character. Thamel was originally the centre for 60s and 70s hippies who drifted to Kathmandu and still has a rather anarchistic flavour. Today it is touristy restaurants (many of which are surprisingly good), antique shops, spas and some touristy dives. However, it is great fun and no one pressurised you

What an "olden" mini city would be like (w/o cars). Unfortunately, the roads are pot holed badly, and cabbies drive at full speed in these narrow lanes. But as a "walking city" from early centuries it could easily be a model for future cities without polluting cars. Very stimulating part of Kathmandu.
Tourist hub of Nepal. it is Tourist hub of Nepal,where normally use to stay here,where tourists have get Hotel,Resturant,Shoping center & others more................

Loud, Louder Thamel. If you want to be in the middle of everything...and you don't mind noises and bad dusty air...than Thamel is your place! At least everything happens there and the most restaurants -budget and no budget- are here!Its nice to see this area but don't stay to long...you get a dusty lung!
History in History itself........... Should walk around this area to feel and watch the old history of Nepal at least for two days and take a look in each and every lane.

Tourist's Paradise - Eat, Drink and Shop till you drop. Its a great place. Always packed with tourists. Nice pubs, live music places, sheesha bars, tons of cafes and eateries. Good to see free wi-fi at almost every place. The saying "Shop till you drop" always holds good here.
The real heart of Kathmandu. Just love this place - daytime or at night. Really tantalises the senses. Be careful not to get run-over by people or vehicles as you wind your way around the streets!

Tourist central. This area is front and center for the foreign visitor. You can find anything you want here from dinner to travel agencies to help you plan the rest of your time in Nepal. The people are helpful, friendly, and informative. The best place to start and end your trip to Nepal.
Walking around and shopping.... Thamel is busy and noisy but it's great for shopping (books and movies, clothes) and to have a beer or cappucino on a terrace...

An experience. With so many shops around and as one of the review said " you can shop till you drop" along with music, so many cafe and eateries all around you the aura is just mesmerizing. A must visit to have loads of fun and remember kathmandu

Shop till you drop. The best place to shop for all the kind of stuff! Remember you have to bargain: prices are approx half of those you are told at the beginning... We bought some nice semi precious stones, kashmir pashmina, Ganesha statues and paintings. Restaurants are nice and cosy and not that expensive.

perfect place to stay, shop and eat!. Thamel is the downtown in Kathmandu known as tourist town, its the best place to stay, as very convenient to get everything you want and lots of restaurant and the shops, and easy to go to any sightseeing place, but stay on the corner of Thamel so you will not be bothered from noise, we stay in Hotel Moonlight it was quite and peace a minute walk to center!

always nice but more and... More and more noisy... The numbers of cars and motobikes increase again and again.. and the horn is the pleasure toy of the drivers. But the place is colorful and the shops attract peoples... even if sometime you get fed by the numbers of invitation to "Come in my shop" Come......come...

Everything you need and more but to busy for me. Tamel is one of the most pack backpacker areas I have visited. You can buy more copied trekking clothes here than anywhere on the planet. It has some hidden gems but for the most part I like to see other parts of Kathmandu ..
busy place. the people were very friendly. Everytime i go there i enjoy the electric atmosphere.
Shopping. I had a quick visit here and it has loads of interesting shops and restaurants

Busy. We spent a lot of time in Thamel, as seemed to be where the decent restaurants were. Its nice to browse but you do tend to get hassled and approached a lot to buy, which can become tiring. Most of the shops are very similar, trekking gear, T shirts, jewellery, knitwear/ pashminas or the painting shops! You need to barter for everything as often they ask the price up on the spot. Quite a few supermarkets, ATMs and restaurants. High;y recommend the Roadhouse Cafe.

Touristy. I'm a tourist so loved staying in this area packed with terrific little shops and restaurants. It was easy to hire a cycle rickshaw when I got tired of walking. The only negative was one who became quite angry when the tip didn't suit him. I didn't figure that out, but oh well. One day I was out when the school children filled the street as school ended. Loved seeing their joy and freedom. Good places for a cup of coffee and wifi.
Thamel....a blessing to tourists. I liked the nice tourist streets. Clean and full of friendly people. Also i loved Samsara resort
Its fun to get lost in Thamel. Have a great day among all the vendors and crazy little shops. They can get redundant but you might just find a really great deal if you keep looking!

The tourist hotspot in Kathmandu. Thamel is the place to be, if you want to go on a trekking etc, because of the many travel agency's there. A lot of different restaurants which provide a meal for everyone's interest. In one of the many souvenirshops you will definitely find something for yourself or a gift for somebody back home.There are numerous hotels and guesthouses.definitely a place where you have to go, just to wander around.
Thamel shopping, shopping etc.. Very nice part of town, people want to sell you something but do not force you or touch you. Of course don't pay what's being asked.
its like broadway of manhattan, nyc. lots of stores, with handicrafts, great bargain of goods, good restaurants, coffee shops, and nice place to tour by walking
Crowded. Crowded, very dirty and tiresome lots of shops good for shopping

Thamel is great for long-term travellers in search of civilization. After a few months on the road, Thamel was a welcome sight! It's neither cultural nor charming, but it's an awful lot of fun. Thamel has everything you need. Hundreds of clothing and gear shops (though good luck with boots), multiple trekking agencies (stick with Himalayan Glacier), restaurants, bars, music shops, grocery stores, and camera shops. Nothing is 100% legitimate (except from the North Face and Black Diamond shops), but the quality is quite good here. Most trekkers will not even leave Thamel, which is understandable if you've been on the trails or in SE Asia for several months. This is the perfect place to base yourself pre and post-trek.

A quick visit. Thamel is crowded, rough and not very clean. The alleyways of souvenier shops are worth a visit thoug, especially the hand embrodiered Kashmiri rugs, but remember to bargain hard and as a rule don't pay more than 50% of the asking price.The seedy rain shower night clubs are best avoided.
great place. it's the center of everything to know in kathmandu
Major Tourist Area!!. It was just kind of painful how everything (hotels, restaurants, and souvenir shops) was sooo geared to tourists. It is generally safe and easy to navigate.

Indiana Jones must be here. The streets are narrow. Rickshaws, motorcyles, bicycles, and pedestrians all share same narrow road. No sidewalks. Lots of open stalls where goods are sold at low prices. Many jewelry stores but I was not certain of the authenticiy of gems and value of jewelry. Know your merchandise before buying. I felt more comfortable buying trekking gear which was perhaps a third of cost back home, if not better. Negotiating is an art. Merchants expect customers to negotiate. Even currency exchange will negotiate.

Hustle & Bustle. Compared to the sometimes overwhelming atmosphere in Indian bazaars--Thamel is a treat. You're mainly left to your own devices and you can find souvenirs relatively cheap! Great food and live music

Interesting buildings but shopping average. The buildings are fascinating with what seems buildings being built upon buildings.The people are nice and, it's a miracle, the traffic actually stops for you!If I was back in my hippie days it would be paradise but it seemed there are several themed shops and then they replicate in their hundreds, all selling the same thing - not dissimilar to what I see throughout a lot of Asia. For me, not that interesting but I am sure others will like it.Regardless of my aversion to the shops, it's still a nice place to spend a few hours before retiring for lunch or cocktails.

My favoutite place in the world!. Thamel is a place like no other in the world. The atmosphere here is unforgetable. It is very busy, loud and chaotic. If your in Nepal for trecking then this is the place to buy all your trecking gear for very cheap. There are restaurants and cafes everywhere open until late. Dont walk in the middle of the road like most tourits do, you will see what i mean when your there. Everything from taxi's, shopping, food and hotel prices are negeotable. Internet cafes everywhere. If you visit Nepal then Thamel is a must visit place, tip generousally as the people here are very friendly and helpful but very poor. I have been to Nepal several times and love it more every time.

A maze of shops, guest houses, bars and places to eat. Thamel is the busy, dare I say, touristy area of Kathmandu. Cluttered within it's tiny maze of streets are a host of shops selling all kinds of items, several guest houses, and many bars and eateries with a variety of cuisines and prices - though all mainly cheap / inexpensive.A must see side of Kathmandu, along with experiencing the many food outlets (including many rooftop places), bars (inclusive of shishas), and the general vibe of Thamel. I got my neck tattoo done in Thamel at Mohans Tattoo Inn (very good and hygienic).

The centre of excitement. A cacophony of people, cars, vendors and motorcycles all vieing for attention. Can not, must not be missed. Get into the heart of Kathmandu by spending entire days in Thamel. Beware the easy shopper, this place is like Mexico on crack.
Always noisy!!. An interesting tourist area. Colourful, noisy with some very good restaurants.

Great place to visit. Thamel concentrates a lot of good things in Kathmandu. You can find good places to eat, that is almost impossible in the rest of the city. Although, you can find bars and other places. The best souvenir shops in town are in Thamel, you'll need to negotiate the price for everything you buy from pashminas to little budha statues.
Manhattan of Nepal. Loved the hawkers, the bargaining, the friendly chats with the storekeepers, the great coffee, variety of foods and the wonderful knits and blankets available in all the shops.

Shoppers Paradise!. Thamel is a place not to be missed if you are shopaholic... Right from gorgeous artifacts to funky handbags and shoes to great finger food... its all there! True spirit of Nepal can be captured right here
great shopping. A bit crowded and lots of traffic but bargains galore! Great for souvenirs. Try K2 restaurant for a surprisingly good steak and Himalayan Rest. for some local Chang.

Hustle and Bustle!. Very cool "backpacker" haven in the middle of Kathmandu! You can pretty much find ANYTHING that you would need in the area especially if you've forgotten something OR came there with the expectation of traveling light! Beware of beggers (touts), women with babies and children... Don't give money or anything to them as it just makes the problem worse. You can pretty much "bargain and haggle" with everyone to get a better price than whats listed and if someone won't budge - there will be 10 other places that sell the same things! I visited in January which is not the busiest travel time for the area, but I've heard that the "tourist" months can definitely be more hectic on the small streets! Be ready for beeping horns, bicycles, motorcycles and scooters, rickshaws and people everywhere - as well as cows and tons of dogs!

Busy Busy. You'll find lots and lots of shops and places to eat here.Pilgrims books is a lovely shop with a nice eating place at the back of the book shop.Their Masala Dosha's are the best in Thamel and they also do a fantastic rice pudding.

Chaos of Kathmandu to be experienced. We stayed in Thamel and even though it was always crowded and noisy, we think it's the best place for tourists to spend time. Many souvenir shops, bookshops and restaurants are in Thamel. Walking on the street is a bit crazy and never relaxing because you're constantly forced to move by cars, bikes, motorcycles, people etc. Also it's annoying that you're constantly asked if you smoke marijuana or if you want tiger balm.

Good Rickshaw visit. The rickshaw was waiting outside our hotel. I negotiated a price for a trip to get the atmosphere of Katmandu on my first night in Nepal and wasnt dissapointed. He seemed to know just what I wanted and it was a memorable experience

Not for Everyone. Thamel is for mostly tourists. If you enjoy bartering than you will have a ball here as most shops are open to offers. Want a rug a wool hat or a shawl well they have thousands of them. It is crowded, dirty noisy and just plain crazy. The rest of Kathmandu is just as busy but spread out a little more. If you are in Kathmandu you have to stop here just for fun. Severeral good places to eat and some deals to be had if you are a little adventurous.Don't judge a book by its cover thamel has some gems.

Interesting place. I would recommend going to New Orleans cafe for a nice chill out time in Central Thamel. The whole place generally feels like a never ending bazaar which my friend and I lapped up. We managed to get some souvenirs such as music instruments, tea, handicraft and postcards at reasonable prices.Being bookworms, the wealth of bookshops did help us appreciate the place better. Please remember to bring a mask along though, the streets can be pretty dusty and do bargain along the way.. (:
Crazy - Hectic but fun.. Easy place to walk around as long as you don't mind getting pestered a bit by the kids. Good restaurants and fun bars all over this area.

A very easy place to visit. Thamel is a must visit place in Kathmandu. We spent four days here and enjoyed every minute. Shopping is good, we bought adventure gear plus had eye tests and three pair of glasses made overnight. Good quality and good prices. Lots of restaurants and not too many touts. Just find a land mark because there are lots of roads and a little confusion

GIT OUT OF THERE!!!. The best part of thamel was leaving. I am horrible at haggling. If you are good at it, this might be your place. The faster you can get out of Thamel the better in my opinion. The people I met that stayed in the outskirts or near the buddha stupa said it was nicer than thamel. My next visit will bypass ktm and fly straight into Pokhara.

Not worth it. Went there one night with my girlfriend and was unimpressed. A bunch of dirty bars, and kids trying to con you into giving them money. During the day, there were some cool shops, but I would rather spend time in my hotel room relaxing after being out all day rather than the nightlife here.

If you want to shop this is one place in KTM. I enjoy visiting Thamel when in KTM but this mostly for the food as in Thamel there are a few restaurants that I really like. There are lots of shops all appearing to sell the same things. There are no fixed prices which is difficult for westerners as it is difficult to know the true cost of things. Like everywhere else in the world it is buyer beware and one should take care of yourself and your belongings. In about 10 visits there I have never had a really bad experience. Been overcharged for a non genuine garment or such like -- but that can happen anywhere. Enjoy your visit

bargainers delight. Plenty of inexpensive camping gear and tourist trinket shops. Shop around before you buy and get a rickshaw too, especially if you know what you are looking for... they will take you to the shops quickly and yes, they will take a commission on the back side but hey, it's worth the price of the rickshaw. Caveat! Set your price BEFORE going anywhere.
Busy touristic area. A good area for restaurants, souvenirs, travel agencies and stuff. But that's about all. So go and see the valley and spend you're night at this place.

Shopping Galore. This is the place to shop. From souvenirs to trekking gear to painting etc. However always remember to bargain/negotiate. Look to knock off atleast 40-50% of the prices in this area. Happy shopping!

Thamel is not KTM and it is not representative of Nepal. Thamel is a business district of KTM where all the tourists are.If you need a quiet district, don't go there, choose a small guest house close to Bodnath (for example)

It doesn't get much better than freak street. It's a great place to people watch, shop, eat, etc., Great central location, lovely locals willing to help, and some nice, inexpensive hotels. It's a must-visit when in Kathmandu.
heart of Kathmandu. enjoying walking at the street so much, it expresses the style of Nepal

Busy, Noisy, People Everywhere. I love It.. The old city center of Kathmandu remains the way it was, probably going back to a hundread year or so. Add more beatup taxi, tricyles, motorcyles and a few thousands of trekkers. You watch where you go, as pot-hole and uneven pavement can trip you. Trekking supply shops are one-after-another lining both sides of the street. Price is less than half you pay in Western countries. Food is very international. Went there twice, still think this is an amazing place.

Backpackers & nightlife centre. A very bustling area with many shops, guesthouses, and restaurants in narrow & crowded streets. If you want to meet other backpackers and spending the night going out, then this is the place to be.
must go,but better prices elsewhere. buzz of a market,prices not favorable even with bargaining

CRAZY. There is no place like it, every square inch is a shop or type of business. One can find everything there. Watch you step since cars and motorbikes travel the small streets. There's good food and pubs as well. Bargin in shops since they all carry pretty much the same goods.

New tourist to Kathmandu? - definitely stay here. Definitely the most "blinged" out suburb in Kathmandu - still plenty of the chaos and anarchy one expects to find in Kathmandu but generally much cleaner, well lit and better food (as in, you are less likely to spend the rest of your holiday doubled over talking to porcelain). I loved it!

world class location in Nepal. The place thamel is one of the world class location in Nepal where you can found each & every thing ln food ,cloths,hotels bars,resturents handicrafts etc.i can say what is not there peoples or turist are stayin from whole world.big depatmetal stores open at midight from early in morning.easy convence.

Great place to stay for a couple of days. Busy yes, but such a nice place to hang out. We where only there two days, but enjoyed walking around, shopping for pashmina scarfs and eating at nice restaurants.
love it. Thamel is special, you love it or hate it, so go and try yourself!

Good vibes. Thamel is overpriced. But compared to other tourist-ghettos over the globe, I think it's one of my favourites. I'll take you few days to fing the right bars, restaurants and hotels for your taste/budget. Relax, have a beer and feel Thamel:)

beautiful chaos. its not everyones cup of tea..and a little tacky..but give in and you'll be roaming around thamel..admiring all the things you cant buy (if youre a budget traveler) and eating places that blow your budget.. still..its worth it. the variety of people is amazing! ... dont give to street boys!!
Great, what an experience. Loved the bizarres. The small, winding streets are like a maze and the crafts on offer are great.Lots of bargains to be had and plenty of souveniers of Nepal on offer.

good shopping. Many little stores around selling handicrafts of all sorts. Do walk around and compare prices, especially for expensive pashminas (or those made of shahtoosh), tanks, and other expensive items.

Bustling tourist centre. Thamel is the tourist hotel centre and so the streets are full of hotels and tourist shops. Even so, it is a friendly place with not too much hassle from street sellers and plenty to see. Most of the shopkeepers appreciate a chat even if you don't buy anything from them. It's easy to get cash (ATMs or official money changers) and there are supermarkets around if you want to buy your own food or drinks.

Shopping and eating in Thamel. Thamel is tourist heaven as it's stuffed full of shops selling pashminas and yak wool blankets of every conceivable colour and design as well as Tibetan carpets and antiques of dubious origin. One thing I would say is harden your heart before you go as you will be approached by children begging you to buy them biscuits from local shops who will harass you until you relent unless you say a very, very firm 'no'. It might seem like a good idea but once you say yes to one you will be targeted by them all. Even the Nepali phrase Paysa Chayna (I have no money) has little effect you have to keep saying 'no' and keep walking until you get a good distance away from the nearest shop.
to busy. to much schops and the money changer is not to honnestgiving many time low rates,otherwise lot of restaurants andbars to enjoy the evenights there.

Very nice streets with many shops. Amazing all this narrow streets with shops.. Very old and nive scenary.People are very helpfull and friendly.Also old market is nice and has many sights and can go to old city and palace.

Thamel NO NO. Can't move Can't breath the area is being choked by car's, truck's.bike's rickshaws, hawkers, beggers. Narrow street's but two lane traffic. Crazy!! At night everything comes out of the woodwork not a nice place anymore.

Golden week special in Jyatha Thamel.. There is Holiday in Japan from May 3 to 7th, It will be very good time to see many flower like rose in this time . you have short time but use on wright way. Please go to Patan . Baoudha , Pasupati nath saymbhu nath, Bhaktapur and Nagarkot.
